What do I do when life gets. challenging? Something I do when life gets challenging is go sit next to my dog and just hold him. Being with my dog will make me fill a little better and can help me relax is something is stressing me out that being from homework or something coming up. Something else that I do is watch some show that interests me or a movie. Watching a show or movie can help me forget about things that are happening around me to be able to get back to what is challenging and have a clear mind to find a solution. Another thing is to take a walk it can be very good to get fresh sir and see what is around and see if i can se something that can be helpful and the walk can be a distraction to also have a clear mind.

When life's get challenging the first thing I try to do is reflect back on the last couple of weeks or months and think about what are the things that are affecting me the most, for me, its often school, and balancing work with assignments, as well as taking care of my mental health. When I am able to point out what is it that's specifically challenging, depends on how much its affecting me, I might take some time for myself, and ill try to take my mind off of it, but if it gets too overwhelming then I usually tend to reach out to those in my life that are there to support me, first to those that are physically close to me, like my sister and my friend, depends on the issue I know that I can rely on them to either just vent, or especially with my sister I know that because she has gone through a lot of the things that I am now going through that I might find challenging, then she probably going to be able to give me useful advice on the situation.

Throughout the past couple years, I've always had periods where everything gets more challenging for me mentally. I think it might be some kind of seasonal depression, but I'm not diagnosed so I don't really know. Everything just seems harder, it's harder to think, to articulate my thoughts, to be motivated to do anything, wether its things I normally like doing or things I don't particularly like doing but would usually be easy enough regardless. It always passes eventually, but I honestly still haven't figured out what to do to help it. Every time it happens I feel like I always forget what to do to get out of it, so I always feel pretty stuck. All I can do is take things one day at a time, try to keep doing things I usually like doing, like drawing, even if I'm not super motivated. Spending time with my friends usually helps too, even if just to keep from isolating myself.

I self reflect. I really like to journal important things or stuff that I find interesting and it helps make life less challenging at least in my opinion. Taking time to hang out with friends or all around down time is going to help. For me I love to sleep. Doesnt hurt to also love yourself in the process. Focusing on self improvement and value little things in life and the relationships you have. All this combined helps me out. I think people should take care of themselves just a little bit more.

When things get challenging, sometimes I go into a shell if its social, sometimes i'm on top of the world and push through it confidently using whatever life momentum I had going, or was crazy motivated last minute and avatar stated my problem away. However, I tend to run from "challenges' or "issues" which have a real affect on my life more often then not, and just procrasnate the issue or avoid it all together. I've done it since I was a kid, and I do it to this day, problem is I also suck at running, running in circles for hours till i'm no longer running for hours, because I got tired and I've walking for a week. In higher spirits though I always catch myself when it matters. I like to think I have a personal safety net, most likely not a divine beings protection but I get a weird self preservation push, where I unlock the useful part of my brain the other half of my brain insists I don't need. Often times I find whatever was challenging me, was never too hard after all. I trust myself for when things get challenging, maybe its not too much pressure.

My family has valued education tremendously throughout my childhood. Education was the first priority as far as my parents were concerned. They always taught my siblings and I that an education was the key to finding a successful career. My parents instilled in their children to find careers and jobs. There is a big difference between the two. A job is something where a person might not necessarily be happy when going to work. A job does not require the education it takes to find a career. A career is something that a person loves to wake up and do everyday. I am 33 years old and I took a few breaks from school and all the jobs Ive had, has led me back to school. I finally realize how important it is to have a degree when searching for successful careers. My parents still ask me about college daily.

In my community or my family at least we have a strong value of doing something to work toward the future and not stay in the same place. This helps me navigate college as to stay on track for something that leads to my success in the future. It helps me realize that I will never quit until I graduate even if I have some tough obstacles in the way. My family helps me navigate and solve these problems I have to be successful in my studies. I have a strong value of balancing every need necessary and putting my all into it like work, school, and any other activities to fulfill my life. My community believes to never be average and to do anything in my life to the most and to make me feel happy. And what makes me happy is to be unstressed so navigating through my college experience takes a lot of work to make it be easy.

Growing up, my parents always placed such a big value on education. Not really the grades themselves, but just the process. In high school, they could care less if I got As or Ds; they only cared about the work I was putting in. They told me that hard work and dedication has value in itself, regardless of the outcome. Back in high school, I didn't really understand their way of thinking. I thought that my worth was directly tied to the grades I had. But this view changed in college. My freshman year was very humbling--and I finally realized that I was not going to be good at everything, and that's okay. My mom told me that I need to stop focusing on the end result and pay more attention to the process. This has helped me so much in my second year. I've been learning to feel more pride in the fact that I put in the work, rather than just the outcome. This mindset has helped me not only feel better about myself but also do better in school. I feel so much less pressure to be perfect that I am able to focus on just trying my best.

Growing up, I always knew I was going to go to college. It was never an idea my parents pushed on me, I think the reason for that being that they wanted me to make decisions like that on my own. My parents didn't go to college, in fact, a lot of people in my family didn't. Besides my sister, brother (who is also currently in college) and maybe 2 cousins on my mom's side of the family, no one pursued an education beyond high school. While the reason for not going to college has not been shared, my parents have expressed the desire to go back in time and take on that opportunity. I like to use their desire to do what I am doing as motivation to do my best during my time here. The change is difficult at times, and I get very close to letting it get the best of me, but then I think of how proud my parents are of all I have accomplished and where I am in life and I push to give it my all.

Growing up, my family always had a saying, "suck it up sanders." Me and my brothers were always met with this in response to any hardship, it wasn't intended to diminish our feelings, but to motivate us because my parents knew we were strong. I find myself repeating this saying to myself when times get particularly hard in school because it's a reminder that I can make it, that nothing is as hard as it seems, and that I can always get through my problems if I just suck it up.

The values instilled by my family have been instrumental in my college journey. Education has always been a priority in my householdmy uncle, a math teacher, and my mother, who earned degrees in nursing and business, emphasized the importance of hard work and perseverance. Their commitment to learning has shaped my mindset, encouraging me to stay determined despite academic challenges. Additionally, my family's emphasis on resourcefulness has helped me adapt to college life. My grandma, who pursued a nursing degree, demonstrated resilience, showing me that dedication and effort lead to success. This has motivated me to seek out opportunities, ask for help when needed, and approach difficulties with confidence. Beyond academics, my family has instilled in me a strong sense of discipline and self-sufficiency. Whether its managing my time effectively or applying my baking skills as a creative outlet and stress reliever, these values have supported my well-being. Ultimately, my family's foundation has given me the tools to navigate college with determination, adaptability, and a growth mindset. 4o

Throughout my childhood my parents always brought me early to every single thing I went to whether it was school or sports or someones birthday party I was always there a few minutes early not even just on time. I genuinely dont think ive ever been late to a single class in my life im either there on time or im just absent for being sick or some other reason. I also have just always had good grades expected of me by my parents and to do more than im expected. Its not that if I didnt get an A that I was a failure but it was more of if I tried my absolute hardest the grade I got is fine and that just tended to be As. I think that 90% of doing well in a class is just effort and that most people even that probably think they arent smart enough to get an A easily could in a lot of classes just if they really put all their effort into it. I also think that Ive always just had the support of my parents to go to whatever school I wanted no matter how close or far and study whatever I wanted which I am very grateful for because im sure there are other people who wish they could do something different than their parents are making them do.

My mother, her mother, and my aunt are all teachers, so education was always emphasized as being something incredibly important that I should always work towards. My family has always emphasized hard work so centering my life around that value has helped me stay focused and on task in college. While adjusting to college has not been the easiest thing, knowing that I'm here to get an education does help me on the day to day basis by giving me structure and routine. I am very grateful for the opportunity to be here and to get an education which motivates me everyday to go to class and do my assignments. It is a goal of mine to potentially get education beyond an undergraduate degree and to do so, I know I will have to keep being motivated and keep working hard. All in all, my family has greatly impacted my view on education, inspiring me to work hard to obtain a college degree and maybe even more than that.

The person who really helped me and or navigated me through college was mostly my sister. During my high-school years I been lost and sometimes confused when it comes to applying for college and what I need to prepare and what major I should take while I was taking tests and stuff so it was a stressful year and I was the type of person if I needed help I wouldnt ask and try to figure it out by myself but that didnt end up working out so my next step is to ask my sister who previously attended college and graduated from Sf state asked her to help me with it application or getting started and which college I should go to at first I was thinking going to some community college near me but my sister said its a waste and it will take longer to graduate like could take 6 years just to get a AS degree so she encouraged me to go to sf state helped me with my application and for the major I ended up choosing what Im passionate about which is designing so I took the visual communication design and the start so far is fun which is a bunch of like digital marketing type of stuff photoshop editing removing blurring and Im excited for the future.

For the most part, a'lot of what the people in my life have taught me has helped me out a lot. I come from a low income background, so i've been exposed to a'lot of hardworking people doing their best to make a better life for themselves and their families, so the perseverance that I see in them is definitely something that I try to carry when i'm at school. I've found that a weight is lifted when you find other people who are going through the same things you are, so building communities and talking to people is another thing that's helped a ton. Whether its joining a club, or listening to the people in your class, having the support of other people really makes you grow as a person too. Asking questions is another thing that i've been taught my whole life, and something that i'm still trying to get better at each day.

My values were never too much. It's not like I had high expectations or high values on myself, for my family or my community. The only thing I ever ask for in my community is for everyone to get along, no fights or anything and always finding solutions to any problems we might have had. I never had any other values in my community but in my family, we always had one value which was to follow and support the traditions we share and love such as Christmas gift sharing, thanksgiving, lunar new years, etc. We also had another which had a lot of complications coming along with it which was having good children. What they would mean by that was to have kids who learn well, get good grades and become professionals in our career goals. I felt more like I was pressured into college, and throughout college so far, I haven't been too sure if I would say it's the values of my family that got me here but more of the pressure and expectations they held for me.

The values of my family have helped me navigate through college because they've taught me everything I know. Without the support and guidance from my family I know without a doubt I wouldn't be where I'm at or the young lady I am. Being a first generation college student in my family I do feel like I have something to prove but I think that just me because my family has never made feel like that. They've always taught me to just try my best and don't give up and if I fail just learn from my mistakes. I'm bias I will forever say I have the most supportive loving family ever. No matter what happens I know I can always count on them to give me the best advice and just be there for me no matter the distance between me here in SF and them in LA. The one thing they really wanted for me while being in college is obviously learn to be independent but also study, work hard and just live life to the fullest and that s exactly what I'm doing.

Some of the values of my family that have helped me navigate college has been the value of courage. Courage has helped me by being able to go to college that is in another city from where I live. It has helped to have courage in being able to commute to and from college. Another way that courage has helped me to navigate through college is by being able to try different classes and to do my best when learning new things. Another value can be independence, it can be very helpful navigating a new environment where there is new things to be learned and I believe that it has helped me in the sence of being able to get my classes and deciding what is best for what I am doing and independence can also help to better make my work in a timely manner or to study for an up coming exam or quiz.

My family has been one of the biggest reasons I have been able to navigate college. While my parents don't know much about a lot about how college in the U.S works, so they haven't been able to help me "navigate" college, they have been so supportive with my decisions on everything, from my major, to letting me choose the place I wanted rent, as well as financially. The person that has been the biggest help since I started college applications, has been my sister. Since she also attends SFSU and has been studying here for almost 4 years, when I first got here, she was able to support me when I didn't know where anything was, all of the important documents I needed to turn in, like FAFSA, and she's basically the reason I was able to find a job quickly, which I needed to do in order to pay my rent.

I feel like my parents have pretty simple values, honestly the main thing my dad has passed on to me that's stuck with me isn't even a specific value, but just him telling me that I should always stick to my own values. He especially has always been adamant about raising me and my brother to be our own people, so while there are values I think I've picked up from him and my mom, I've also always been free to and encouraged to create my own values. I think that's helped me navigate college in that I'm just trying to do what feels best for me, not pick classes or a major or anything based on what other people are doing or want me to do. I haven't actually picked a major yet, but I know I want to do something art related, and my parents have always been very supportive of that, which I'm very thankful for.

SPRING BREAK! Im happy I get this time to sit down relax and be happy doing what makes me that way, playing games and enjoying company of others. Unfortunately, I still have a lot of work to do, and i dont have the want or motivation to do it. Only reason i'm doing this one at all right now is that I have to turn it in tonight and i got a lil motivation. Anyway, sprouted a few little sunflower seed and is it weird to say its a weirdly emotional thing? I got really happy to see I can grow something that i wanted to grow, yeah its simple enough but if i'm able to cultivate it myself and do something that gives chance to life is amazing to me. Somehow its a little less lonely to know you and occasional fly or bug that sneaks its way inside aren't the only ones there. Why am I in SFState? I am at San Francisco State University in hopes of getting a degree. A degree is now a prerequisite to most well-paying jobs. I want to get a job that can sustain me in the future. Why am I in this class? That's because it fulfills one of my requirements for graduation. While I may be taking this class only because I need to, I'm actually somewhat interested in the topic of astronomy. It mainly stems from the astrology and stories of constellations being involved in greek mythology. I'm unsure about if it will help me in my future pursuits in a well paying career, but I'm sure it would be nice to be a bit more informed on a subject that has many made up stories and theories. Especially now when the claims of aliens being real are popping up more and more. I am here in San Francisco now because Ive been living here my whole life, but I do hope someday that changes just to gain a new perspective of the world that I have such a small viewpoint in.

It truly would be hard to gauge why I'm here, what my purpose is. Maybe it's completely subjective on whose view it is. My mom may see a different purpose in me than my partner does. Regardless, it's safe to say that without knowing what my purpose is, I live each day creating and forming what I want my purpose to be. Like most people I'd hope, I'd want to leave a positive impact on people, have positive memories, and ultimately live each day knowing I'm doing my absolute best at living. With that being said, leaving a foundation for my future family to be able to do the exact same thing would be my purpose, so that they eventually could do the same thing as my family did for me. Like an ancestral domino effect, we can build upon each generation giving each person their own purpose, their own reason for simply living.

This university offers the major I want (biology with an emphasis in conservation), so everything worked out for me. Plus, SFSU offers so many classes on a wide variety of topics, so I get to explore many ideas outside of what I already know, like this astronomy class.

I am taking this class because I needed to fulfill my science require, but also because I have always been really interested in astronomy and want to learn more about it. Last semester, I took 20 credits, and then I took a winter class, and am now taking 23 credits this semester, so essentially I have taken 46 credits in one school year in order to finish my degree. I am excited to continue learning about astronomy in this lab and ASTR 115.

I guess, to be honest, I dont have a concrete answer, and thats okay. Some days, I feel like Im here just trying to figure it all out like everyone else. Maybe Im here to learn something new, to make a difference, even if its just in small moments with people I cross paths with. I think about the people who make me feel seen, and I wonder if Im supposed to do that for others too. Maybe Im just here to experience, to explore what feels right, what feels real. Some days, it feels like theres a bigger reason, something Im meant to discover, but other times its just about getting through the day and trying to stay grounded. I think maybe Im here to grow, even when things feel messy or uncertain. The big picture isnt always clear, but I dont think it has to be. Maybe being here is just about trying to be true to who I am and showing up, even when I dont have all the answers.

When life gets challenging I like to take a break from everything. Whether it is time for myself or relaxing with friends, it's always important to take a break. Drawing, reading, listening to music, and doing other hobbies help me relax. I don't necessarily have to be doing something either, sometimes just taking a nap or catching up on sleep time is good enough. It's also important to realize when you might need help. Sometimes you just need to hear advice or feedback on things or perhaps suggestions from another point of view. Just stepping back a bit to calm down and think about what needs to be done will be enough. Other times you might break from the pressure and sometimes that is needed too. Emotions sometimes build up too much and a good cry or some sort of emotional release will help you more than you would have ever thought.

I'll try to organize a bit, whether that be a to Do, a Calendar, or even cleaning the house. I've noticed that I'm usually stressed when things are cluttered or out of order in my life, either physically or mentally. Immediately as I begin to clean, I feel a sense of relief, it's easier on my eyes, making it easier on me. Next I make time for myself, no matter how busy, saying "I don't have time" does me no good, it only creates more urgency and anxiety. That time could be something as simple as a nice hot shower, cooking, hugging my dog or even scrolling on TikTok for 10 minutes. Even better, creating time to do something physically challenging, like the gym or a nice hot sauna. Allowing myself to be vulnerable and recognize the challenges I'm going through, and to acknowledge them. Work with them and not run from it, because the longer I choose not to acknowledge, the longer the pile is for me to work on.

When life gets challenging, I allow myself to feel the burden of the challenges I face and the grief of the passing of times in my life where everything was seemingly much easier. Allowing myself to feel these things might not be pleasant, but it is the first step in accepting and overcoming challenging times in life. We are lost without reflection and acceptance of where we are and how we got to where we are. Once I have done that, I plan on what to do next. It is usually a simple plan, but an outline on how to move forward is better than blindly going forward. This method has helped me get to where I am today, and while there are probably better methods for powering through challenging times (which I am willing to explore and learn from), I will continue this method until it no longer serves me well.

When life gets challenging, I take a long break to recoup my brain and body. Then, I will be calm for whatever challenge I must face next time. How I do this is simple: Sometimes, I go and work out, or sometimes, I just sit down in silence and read. Usually, at the end of this, my whole mind and body are recouped and reset. I call them the complete rest of myself. one last thing, I do is maybe just go out and enjoy my time in my life, since theres not much time in one lifetime if you think about it, since time is always moving, but you can alwasy use time to relax and not waste it.

I have a long history of turning to the wrong things when life gets challenging. I have a lot of learning disabilities and I'm autistic so I have had a really hard time learning to adapt to my environment socially. honestly idk what i'm trying to say beacuse I think to understand why i cope the way I do you have to know a lot of details about me that i do not wanna get into at all. the real thing I'm tryinng to get at is that I used to be really bad at coping and handling life but since I left home and went to collage I have put a big effort into learning to handle things in a healthy manor. Some things I like to do when life gets hard: work on music, listen to music, exercise, talk with friends, self care, clean, scream, put my body through extremes in a way that doesn't harm me forreal (moshing, fighting, arm wrestle), cry (I feel like I have gotten a lot better at actually processing my emotions since I started being in touch with them and more open)

When life gets challenging I have some words of advice, "don't stress out or worry about the things that are out of your control". Last week when I was on the phone with one of my sisters, she was very stressed about every aspect of her life. She was close to crying and couldn't enjoy spending time with any of her friends. And almost everything she was stressed out about and felt guilt for was out of her control. Fast forward to the most recent phone call I had with her this week, I asked her how she was feeling and she said "even though I usually tell myself what you said, hearing you say it helped me a lot and I feel way less stressed now". Another thing that I have been doing recently that has helped improve my mood, is working out more consistently. This week I have ran on my treadmill 3 times so far.

That is something that I always try to avoid. When something gets hard, I always move away from it or face the consequences. I simply stop what I'm doing that's making life challenging because I'm too scared to face challenges or I think I won't be able to face them the right way. This step in my life has always been this way but I have stopped to face another direction when life gets challenging. Even though I am still working on it, it does help me. Now, when life gets challenging, I don't stop and face another way. Instead, I continue because I need to learn to take risks in life because that can help me change. It will make me into a better person, more mature. Therefore, when life gets challenging, I decide to keep going to see where this obstacles will take me. If I make a mistake, I'll know next time to not do it.

When life gets challenging, I generally go for a car ride or a walk where I listen to songs. Or else, I got to play pool or cricket on the campus and spend time with friends so that my mood lightens. I often go on the terrace to just get some fresh air, watch the ocean and also the sky along with some songs. I do not generally reflect on my day or my problems when I feel that life is getting challenging, I just believe in going with the flow rather than remembering old things and thinking about correcting them. This helps me with maintaining my confidence in the decisions that I make and remain calm rather than bustling my mind more by thinking about the past or the future.

When life gets challenging the first setp I take is a deep breath and remind myself that difficulties are temporary but our mental health peace is crucial. I often talk to my best friend if it gets more tough. I mostly sleep to avoid problems because I believe that sleeping solves all the problems. I believe to priotrize what I can control and let go of what I can't. Also self care should be first priority. Every setback is an opportunity to grow stronger and wiser. One should stay patient and calm to tackle any challanges. Back in my home country I had my comfort go to place. Here, my comfort place is ocean beach and golden gate overlook I mostly prefer to go there at night because these places are often very quite and peaceful at night where you can sit peacefully.

What I do when life gets challenging is that I try to calm myself down when I feel frustrated because of a situation. I would also talk to my mom about what I feel and ask for advice on how to handle the things that are challenging since she has been in challenging situations before. I would also listen to calming music. If that doesnt help me feel better then I would play puzzle games on my phone that would take my mind away from whats challenging.

When life gets challenging I tend to stall. Whatever I'm struggling with always tends to bleed into other aspects of my life and making everything even harder. But I know that when I'm struggling with things I can always lean on my friends and family. My parents are always there to help me work through my issues and find the best solutions, no matter what challenge I'm up against. I definitely need to work on not letting challenges knock me down and working through them without letting the rest of my life negatively, and I've been steadily making strides towards that. Sometimes taking a step back and reevaluating a situation can help you see what's really causing problems, and it'll be much easier to work through.

When life gets challenging, I often find myself avoiding everything and trying my hardest to avoid confrontation with the same challenge that I previously faced. If I were to be honest with myself, I should label myself as a procrastinator, and due to that same problem of putting things off until the last minute, I find myself facing challenges of all kinds of workloads piling up. In the moment when I first discover my challenges, I am unsure of what I need to do, but as I take the time to sit down and fully take a moment to see the exact challenges I make myself think of all the different kinds of solutions that could be made to my problems. Often, when I think of how I approach my problems, I find myself getting disappointed, because there could have been so many things avoided to not put myself in the position that is full of challenges.

When life gets challenging I love to play soccer with my friends or cousin or even by myself. I enjoy playing soccer alone sometimes while I listen to music and practice shooting at the goal or dribbling between cones. When life gets challenging I like to play guitar it's one of many hobbies I have as well. I enjoy playing Mexican music or playing guitar with my cousin as well. When I have a lot of stress from school I relax and just practice one of my favorite hobbies and after I'm all done, I'll go back to work. Another one of my hobbies and personally one of my favorites is going out clay shooting in San Jose with my dad. We usually go every Sunday Morning and I feel like it really helps me with my stress because when I hit the clay it drives my dopamine and therefore relaxes me ready for another week of school.

I dont know just deal with it. Or just like not. Usually when I have a lot of work I typically just do it. Or sometimes I just dont. Kind of have to prioritize whats more important and what I could probably be ok not doing. But I dont really really struggle in working. If anything I just get a bit behind but it never is devastating I just get it done. Its not really fun always but I just do it and then its all good.

"What do I do when life gets challenging?" I feel like I would answer this question differently every-time depending on what is challenging me at that moment. It could be school, personal life, or anything in general. But I think the most consistent response I could give is to meditate, not pressure or make myself feel bad about the challenge I am facing. Unfortunately, as humans we will always face challenges and most of the time we will cause harm to ourselves for that problem, that is not really our fault, but part of life. I think it is also important for me to talk to someone and not drown myself in all my problems and then eventually burst. One of my top priorities is to not to blame myself or others for any challenges I am facing, rather grow and learn something from the challenge. Along with me meditating, I feel like people think meditating is only sitting down in a butterfly position with your hands together, but it can be many things. For me especially, I enjoy coloring, going on walks to get fresh, but of course I also enjoy what most people think it as of.

Whenever life gets challenging, I like to clear my head for a bit. I am someone who loves to be outside, and I think best when I am moving around instead of sitting or laying in bed. I go for very long walks and sometimes won't even think about anything for the entire walk, but it's a good way to center myself and remove any negativity in my life for a bit. I've faced a lot of challenges, and I find that enjoying little wins is a good way to keep going. Right now, midterms are starting up, so I am taking everything one step at a time and trying to get work done when I am motivated or awake, otherwise I will relax and allow myself to reset until I am ready. Being outside helps me think a lot, and I can listen to music or talk on the phone while I walk through the city or on the beach. I am someone who strongly values my time to decompress. I am an introvert, so I get tired when I am constantly around other people and like to reset by myself. Life gets challenging, but it is more important to put yourself first sometimes to allow yourself to regenerate so that you can be 100% when the challenges hit.

Now that I think of it, I don't really think I have or ever had a step-by-step set of instructions of what to do when life gets challenging? Nothing actively productive for the situation, at least. I just get sad for a while and do nothing. Whenever that happens I'll take a break, either go to sleep, watch some TV or play a game to clear my mind. After that, then I'll try tackling the problem. I think more frequently than not I try to deal with the issue on my own without any help. I think it's cause back in kindergarten, a teacher told my mom I was too clingy with needing help and that stuck with me since then. I don't have anything else to say on this prompt.

When gets challenging I normally I would just take a walk to clear my mind and try to figure it out later. Taking a break is one of the most important things for me when life gets out of control and I can't really do much about it so I would go for a walk to figure something out. If going on a walk doesn't really help me I would go for a do something I know that I can achieve so I don't need to rush things with the parts I don't know how to do. Lastly, If everything I try doesn't really help I would normally reach out to someone I trust and ask for there advice, most of the time there advice would make it a litte better, something that my friends are good at is making jokes and making me think about others stuff then worry about whats giving me a hard time which is a good thing because it gives me time to relax and have fun and come back more open minded to the challenge.

The thing I do when life gets challenging is usually shut down. It takes me a while to really assess the seriousness of a situation, and I kind of feel the need to spiral first. Having that space to freak out isn't really the best thing to do, but's it what I do first. I don't usually ask for help, as I feel that I've navigated worse times for myself in the past and can do it again to a higher capability the next time around, so I usually just try to see what steps I can take next to resolve whatever problem I have. This is usually when I work my hardest, if I'm being honest. I'll resort to anything I need to to fix whatever I'm going through, and that's how I've resolved most of my conflicts. It's not necessarily the healthiest as I have to get 10x worse before I get better, but having that time to panic and cry clears out that negativity enough for me to also clear my head and get to work on whatever's plaguing me fastest. I did this a lot in high school. I had an F in a class my senior year that I was sure I wouldn't be able to recover from near the end of the quarter, but I pulled out all the stops after crying a little bit and I managed to get a B by the end of it. It's honestly helped me prepare for worse scenarios I've faced and I'm decent at last minute scrambling and improvements.

When life gets challenging, I don't want to sit there and take it. I want to get up and actually work my way around the problem and continue on. In the past, I haven't really been the best at dealing with difficult tasks or challenges. When I hit a road block, I end up crashing and breaking down. I feel as the weight of the entire world is on me and I can't bare myself to even complete the task, as I think its too challenging or down right impossible to get over and continue on in life. But as I grew up, I learned that way of dealing with things isn't healthy and it can be destroying to me and possibly the people I care around me. As of now, when I do hit a road block, I take a step back and give myself some time and a break. This can help me gather my thoughts and plans to reapproach that challenge again and move forward.

When life gets challenging, I tend to either sink or swim. Depending on the situation, and the point in my life I've been in, the outcome has varied. I will either take it as a sign to proverbially "lock in", where I'll analyze the situation completely logically and try my hardest to take immediate action to remedy or help the situation, or I'll completely shut down. By that I mean I revert back to unhealthy habits that provide comfort instead of putting in the work and effort to make it through the issue facing my life. While it's nice because I never only put in half the effort, that means that I either fix or do everything that I can to fix a situation or do nothing, the volatility results in some prolonged periods of low days to be especially tough.

When I read this question, I really tried to think about what my process is. However, what it really made me think of is how life is challenging all of the time. This isn't to say that I am struggle financially, physically, or mentally but its just to say that life happens, bills are reoccurring and getting more expensive, every day we have to go to work and go to school even though lot of days we are either tired or really just want to enjoy ourselves. The way I get through this is really just having a wish list, I found that having something I want makes doing my daily tasks more enjoyable. I know I am working towards a goal and I get exited knowing that I am closer to getting what I want. For example, right now I really want a Tesla. This is definitely a big goal but it really helps me get my homework done, go to work, and frankly just wake up. I hope maybe this can help someone else do the same.

How have the values of my community or my family (of origin or of choice) helped me navigate through college? In many Chinese families, academic success is highly valued. Not only that, but my parents moved here from China in hopes of the American dream. So there's these expectations put upon me and my brother to succeed in life in hopes of fulfilling that American dream. In a way, those expectations are a part of what is driving me to finish college. Additionaly, I live in an area where there is many homeless people on the streets. This has made me more determined to finish college with a degree that will help me achieve a career that would prevent that from happening to me hopefully. I do understand that some of the homeless aren't on the streets because of lack of jobs but it does sometime make me worry that I might end up there. Both of these factors are part of what drive me to succeed in finishing college so that I can hopefully get through life with a career that can support me.

Unorganized, chaotic, and ungrateful are words that would never come up when describing my experience entering and navigating college. I've been blessed to have had a constant support system around me. My two older sisters, one of whom graduated from SFSU, and of course, my parents who did their absolute best to prepare me for college, and for that, I'm forever grateful. My community of black and brown folk who set the stage for what I can achieve if I work hard. My elders who always preach their knowledge. They're who I learn from along as I open my ears and listen "god gave us two ears and one mouth because we're supposed to listen more than we talk." forever learning, moving forward, and paying it back to the community. So, I can confidently say that being Organized, happy, and grateful are values in which I'll leave college with the same way I came in.

My family, for many generations, has valued the pursuit of knowledge. Going to college is almost the natural state of progression in anyone's life for my family because of this history. And, coincidentally enough, the past pursuits of many of my family members have been in the scientific field. At the end of high school, when it was time for me to plan out a rough plan for my future, college was the only path I thought of, and my family wholeheartedly supported me and helped me navigate this new journey. They gave me anecdotes from their time in college, tips and tricks, and most importantly, their shoulders to lean on when college inevitably felt heavy and impossible at times. All of this has helped me so much. This family value has also helped me now, as I am halfway through college. Whenever I don't know what I am doing with my life or feel inspired but directionless, I think about my ancestors, and how they have probably endured similar paths. It motivates me to keep going, not only for their sake but for mine as well. I love learning and expanding my knowledge, it just sometimes takes a reminder of the past to keep pushing into the future.

How the values of my community or my family helped me navigate through college is simple: my brothers all already went through it, so when they came back after being gone, they taught me the simple stuff, but they all said the same thing. "Enjoy it 'cause it is not forever." I took that seriously, and I still do, and now, with how social I've become, it's gotten a whole lot easier to get through college.

Values that have brought me far: The golden rule, It can't hurt to ask, never give up, have some grit, let people have fun & just participate/be open to new experiences. I feel like my values have influenced the way I interact with my peers, how I make friends and navigate my social life & conflicts. Academically, I have always had confidence in my ability to get something done if I put my mind to it. In highschool I thought this but had very little actual confidence in my ability, I am still working on it but this attitude has pushed me to take risks and do what I think is right for me. I feel very blessed to have been raised with this mindset but I do think sometimes it can take a toll on me bc I have learning disabilities so sometimes when I know I can do something but am struggling with it It will make me sad or feel like I'm not enough. At the end of the day I try to go with a flow and adapt to my situation.

My family, especially one of my older sisters has always preached the importance of education since I was little. No one else in my family has graduated college except for the middle sister. Because of this even through my resistance in senior year i pursed high education. I find comfort in knowing that high education and better opportunities are possible in my family and I look up to her as a role model. It also helps to navigate college because she studied at the same college Im currently studying in right now. She made an effort to check my grades during my first year as a college and pushed me to do better.

As a first generation in my family, going to college is very important in my household. My aunt is the only one who attended and graduated college with a degree. This achievement has helped me navigate through college b because I see my aunt as someone I look up to. Usually, younger siblings always look up to the older siblings. Older siblings don't have someone to look up to because they are seen as an example for your siblings. But, in my case, I look up to my aunt because she showed persistent through her college journey and did it all alone. She values her family, education, and herself. That is someone I notice and want to grow as a person. She has helped me apply to programs, helped me in my first year of college, took a tour with me to campus and I am very grateful for that. She continues to surprise me with her generosity and values.

The values of my family have helped me a lot at different stages of life. Similarly, they have also helped me to navigate through college and get along with the different paths of life and challenges here in college. As an international student I faced a lot of difficulties at first, as I was a newcomer and was going to life far from home for such a long duration for the first time in my entire life. It was like I had started a whole new life and all I had was myself, at first I had to make new friends and the things that my family had taught me about being open and friendly with everyone helped me in making new friends and also meet new people. Another thing that I learned and came handy was to adjust to any situation and not step back in any difficulties whatsoever the situation maybe, this helped me to stay mentally strong in the initial days when I was not feeling very good about this new place and this aided me in adjusting to the new environment.

The values of my family helped me a lot in shaping my personality. I'm international student from a business background family also pursuing major in economics at SF State has never been easy. I faced a lot of difficulties at first, this was the first time I was satying away from my home and my parents, can only visit them in winter or sumer breaks. To get out through this phase my mother always thought me to stay strong in believe in god. She always tought me to stay mentally strong and face all the difficulties and challanges without fear. She always tought me that if you do good then god will always do good for you, just focus on your goals your study enjoy your life and let god handle the rest.

The values of my family helped me navigate through college by taking things easy and not procrastinating on doing assignments which I kind of did in the past. It guides me to the right path to make good decisions for myself. It also reminds me to treat people with respect all the time so that I would be treated fairly. The values of my family reminds me to be aware of what the consequences might be if I chose the wrong path in college. Doing what I can helps me navigate through college by knowing the limits of what I can do and that I shouldnt overdo things.

The values that my family, community, and I hold have helped me navigate college with the simple phrase, "Treat others how you wish to be treated." The phrase alone is what I think of before I approach other people, and it is what I think of while I am speaking to a person. If I were to describe a place in which this phrase that I follow could be used in a classroom setting, with the example of me listening to a person giving a speech. The phrase "treat others how you wish to be treated," is used by me being silent when the person is speaking, because if I were giving a speech I'd certainly appreciate not being talked over. But that is just one of many other values that I've brought with me. Another example is responsibility being important as it motivates me to do my work and not slack off much.

My major in college is Business Finance. I decides to take on this as my major because most of my family have something related to business. For example my grandfather is a CEO for a transportation company in Mexico and my dad is a manager of a company. In the future I want to work in maybe a high up company as an investment banker. My motivation also came from a show called suits. This is a show about lawyers but the competition among other people drives me to be the better person. Most of my family members have never gone to college so I am a first-gen. This has been a downside since I sometimes struggle to decide what classes I should take and have more of a good path in college, but with the help of other students and mentors I will get through college to achieve my goals.

I think the values of just hard work or something like that have helped me navigate college. But I guess thats it. For some reason for me college work isnt very difficult. I just go to the classes and I dont really put a whole lot more effort than that. But in the end I do fine if not good. Sometimes I dont do very well though but not really anymore. The main challenge is just trying to figure out how to pay for college and the commute. Because the commute per day takes up about 4 hours and because of that I dont really have a lot of time to study. But I guess I dont really need it. But maybe thats just because my classes arent very hard.

In my family college is important, to attend, to do good, and to try your best. My parents specifically believe that college is a entry to better success, to have better opportunities for your future. They believe this because they never received quality education as they had to work. All of these beliefs they clearly stated constantly made me push myself harder in my education. Even at times when I felt discouraged, they were always there to support me in any way. I think that is why it wasn't to hard for me to navigate through my first year of college because I had the support to achieve anything. I also had other family members who are currently in college also guide me. At times I have doubted my self, if i'm choosing the right path for my future, my family always encourages me. Their values of never giving up, of never doubting yourself, and to keep going forward have pushed me to be the better version of myself.

The values of my family/community have helped me navigate through college by showing me how to be a confident, positive person. Without the people in my community to encourage me to keep going and telling me they are proud of me even when I am not proud of myself, I would not have made it to my last semester of college. Wanting to make my family proud is a huge motivation for me because they have always been there for me. From them, I have learned the importance of honestly and integrity, and I strive to make good choices and follow a moral compass. There have been many times where I wanted to give up, but their encouragement has kept me going. I also look to my friends for guidance whenever I need it. Having people around me, even if they're far away, keeps me sane and focused. It is easy to slack off or not care about what I am doing, but I have a strong work ethic and want to get the job done as best I can. I have also always been taught that it is okay not to be the best as long as I am being my best, which is more important. When I was little, I always wanted to be first, and I was super competitive, but now, I am only competing with myself to do my best each time I set my mind to something.

I'm still trying to figure out how to navigate college, this is only my second semester. I suppose aiming for high grades is what initially fueled my motivation for doing well in classes; however with that goal quickly came a burn-out that kind of caused me to be a bit dead in class- participation and motivation wise. The stress of performing well in assignments, projects, and tests only drove headfirst into procrastination; which was got reinforced by the fear of not meeting up to my teachers' expectations. So that wasn't a great value to utilize for school. One of my teachers later told me that it didn't really matter what grade I got from a class as long as I learnt something from it and that was a pretty significant eye opener for me. So now I am trying to follow this value instead and do my best in class with a "whatever happens, happens" sort of mindset.

During my time in college I was able to navigate my way though school with family members because they all went to the same college when they were younger. Even though it was my only first year in college I was alittle nervous and didnt know how to approach it. But my cousins and brother was able to show me around and help me with stuff I didnt know how to do which made it a lot easier for me. They were able to help me pick my classes and help me get a better time management so I can do the best I can. During mid term and finals weeks they would check on me since its so fast pace telling me there are a couple of ways to get help. I wasnt able to really make new friends during college because I didnt think it was going benefit me a lot which was completely wrong and it was glad they informed me on that.

My family's always been really big on working hard and doing your best, so I've been doing that most of my life and it hasn't changed since I've started college. I do try very hard in all my classes, and though it is hard to be motivated or push myself beyond my comfort zone, usually I'm able to accomplish a task pretty easily if I just hype myself up enough. It's helped me navigate as being a college student is pretty challenging, especially now, and it's honestly in my best interest to try as hard as possible in anything I do on or off campus. If I get too comfortable, things start slipping past me like deadlines and I'll fall behind. I'm motivated by my fear of failure, yes, but also the idea that I want more for myself if I can have it. I don't exactly feel like pushing myself all the time but I can't think of another way in which I'd succeed the way I want to, so I do.

Im still unsure. Navigating throughout college is difficult because Im doing it on my own. Sure I have my parents there to support me but they havent really taken the time to ask how Im doing in college as theyre also busy with their own things. On occasion they will ask about college but nothing of the importance of them actually being interested in my college life or courses in general. And different communities at college? I really havent had the time to explore or meet new people. Sure Ive made friends and acquaintances with my classmates but outside of class and or school, I havent found anyone yet. The only person who is really offering support is my older brother who is also in college and is in his final year. Hes the one giving me advice and giving me that push to keep going and I appreciate that hes still looking after me and making sure I can navigate college with at least some knowledge.

I think the values of my family have influenced me and navigated me on a path that I didn't necessarily choose. I think the path I'm on is good and will be good if it pays off, but I always knew that I could do it and that kept me from thinking about why I'm doing it, and if i don't want to then I honestly just wont be able to. That being said, my family/ origin is all a bunch of very anxious people, so having as few things to worry about as possible by just trying to complete everything as soon as possible has helped me stay on top of my work and navigate through classes.

My parents and my husbands parents have not finished college some even high school. It's important to both of us that we get a degree. I also really have motivation to push through college with good grades because neither me or my husband really tried hard in high school, just wasn't a priority. I would like to put in the effort that I lacked back then to be able to prove to myself that I can accomplish a lot. Life gets tough but you have to be willing to put more in then you get out, that is what I live by.

I am here to do many things including learning physics, i think that i am here so that i can lean about all kinds of diffrent things that will help me help other people and make the world a better place for everyone to live. i think i am here because to do good things but i also think i am here because i am just another peace of a very large organism that is our earth, in the grand view of live i am a very insignificant being but that being said i think i can still influence the environment by trying to make it better everyone currently and in the future and i think that taking this physics class will help me understand how things in this world works on a more scientific level. that information is something i can use in everyday environment and in the medical field.

I'm in this class (Physics 102) to fulfill my science requirement for my Kinesiology pathway. Physics 101/102 or 111/112 is required in the Kinesiology degree. Honestly, I chose to do Physics 101/102 because I wanted an easier class. I'm not very good or confident in my physics knowledge so I went with the most basic and easier to learn course out of the two options. So far, this class has been going very smoothly. Although we are in our third week, the material that has been being posted has been straight forward and not difficult to follow. I'd say that the pace of this class is going at a steadily pace. I'm starting to learn that most of our assignments will be group based and will have the lab write-up, an analysis of our findings, and lastly a reflection and conclusion of the things that we have learned from the lab. So far, I feel confident that I will be able to learn, absorb, and use what I learn after this course.

I am in this class to mainly gain a pre requisite I need and learn more about physics and science in general. I have had a very unconventional journey as Ive gone through college and unfortunately physics was not one of my classes I had to take for my previous major so I needed to take this class along with quite a few others. Science classes have not exactly been my strong suit which is why I have not taken a single physics class since high school. I hope to be able to learn a lot in the lab and gain a good understanding of physics. Kind of going along with that, I would also obviously like to pass the class with an A and get the credit I will need to take upper division courses and apply for programs I need to reach my future goals and other achievements as well.

The question, "Why am I here?" seems like a very vague question to ask. Where exactly is "here"? In this Physics class? This university? Or in college in the first place? That's what I'm assuming this is asking. I came to San Fransisco State University during fall of 2022 straight after high school. Honestly, I was unsure of what my future consisted of, but my parents wanted me to go to college, so to college I went. My college planning happened very last minute and although my grades were more than good enough to be accepted into a UC, I missed the deadline to write an acceptance paper for any of them. The colleges I applied to were a grand total of two: San Fransisco State University and some other one in Long Beach. If I applied to any more, I had to pay, which I didn't want to waste money applying for the potentiality of my future. Some months later, I got accepted into both. I've always liked San Fransisco and wanted to live in the city, so naturally I committed to going here. However, it didn't change the fact that I still knew nothing of what I wanted my career to be, but I thought going to university and doing something with my life could be fun. About two years in, I'm still finishing up my general education requirements and I am considering transferring to another school. My best friend has planned getting a place for us two and others in San Jose, where I will continue my studies.

Why am I here? Its a question that not many know the true answer to. Sure, you may say that Im here to pursue higher education and others may agree. For me though, Im not too sure. Its not a simple question asking about why youre in the place you are, but a broader question of how did you get there. How was I created? How did the Earth weve come to know develop, and why? I believe we have scientists and extremely intelligent people in all types of field researching this exact reason. This is how this physics class comes into play. We learn about the world we inhabit through a very specific lens. We focus on why things happen the way they do. For example, why are we stuck on the ground? The answer as many of us know is gravity. Something less of us know though is how it works. Why does gravity exist and can we measure it? I think we as a species are here for this reason. To discover the truth behind our existence.
