My main goal right now is getting into PT school, and I know I need physics to get there. PT isnt just about knowing muscles and exercises- its about understanding how forces, motion, and mechanics affect the body. Whether its figuring out how much force a joint can handle, how to reduce strain on an injury, or why certain movements help with rehab, physics is behind all of it. I cant just go through the motions and memorize stuff for this class. I actually need to understand it because its going to come back in PT school. If I dont get the basics now, Ill struggle later when I have to apply them to real patients. Plus, physics is everywhere in movement. Things like torque, leverage, and center of mass actually matter when rehabbing someone or preventing injuries. This class is part of the bigger picture for me. I need to put in the work now so I have the knowledge and problem-solving skills to be a solid physical therapist.

Some strategies that I can put in place to keep me focused is doing the homework ahead of time, putting my phone on DND, and putting time limits on certain apps. Doing HW ahead of time would prevent me from having last-minute stress and possibly getting a low grade since making mistakes is high. Using my phone is the most important one since a lot of us get distracted, minutes become hours and than we realized that we won't have enough time to do anything.

Now, more than ever, it feels hard to remain focused on physics. The thrill and enthusiasm I had in the start are lost, whereas the end always feels far away. Something that I believe would assist me most is if the homework could be broken down into small bits and pieces and simplified. When I look at all of the things that I still need to accomplish, especially hard subjects like electromagnetism or thermodynamics, it just seems too much, but if I just work on it one small step at a time, then maybe it won't. I also have to develop a study schedule that works for me. I know I get distracted easily, so maybe I should try using strict time limitslike studying for 25 minutes and then taking a 5-minute break, which I have started to try out, and I've heard that it really helps with concentration. Putting my phone in a different room might be a useful tactic since I tend to check it far too often. Another strategy is attempting to make learning more fun. I could study with a friend so we can keep each other accountable or try to explain physics concepts out loud as if I'm teaching someone else. Visual presentations or simulations might also be useful in nailing tough stuff. The key is reminding myself of why I started and how awesome it will feel to finish strong. I just need to make it through these last few weeks!

Truthfully, I don't really know what I need to do to focus because the senioritis is starting to kick in, which makes no sense bc I'm a third-year. In addition to going to tasc i also went to my teachers office hours to ask questions about the material. This is what i plan on employing in this class. At the mid-point of the semester it could be hard to find motivation, or even if you have its hard to find the energy because most of us are tired or just need a little rest. Strategies that will keep me focused through the end of semester is making productive study techniques or systems that will enhance my productivity. One method that has work for me is the setting of where I study. This technique came from a book I read a while ago which I vividly remember that when you associate a place with a behavior, this will become a habit. For example for me, when I study I tend to study in my table, cafe or even the library as this will make me fully focused and study better. Another method is creating calendar for deadlines such as HW, exams, and many more. This method will enhance my ability to remember paper due date especially when you are bound with a lot of classes. For example, Im taking 24 units this semester and keeping a calendar with my due date will organize my day-to-day schedule. This will allow me to be ahead and be on-time with my deadlines.

The way that I try to keep myself motivated is to focus on the process and not the end destination. There are very few moments in life where you are actually accomplishing your final goals compared to how much time you spend working towards your goals. Each day is a competition against yourself to do the best you can and accomplish the most you can. Maximizing and not wasting any days is what I try to do every day. I never want to feel like Im wasting time and I know that not everyone feels like that but doing something productive every day is important. I also think excersize and coffee and great ways to help give more energy and keep you going. If you plan out your weeks ahead of time it makes it much easier to accomplish your goals and get everything done rather than doing something when you feel like doing it.

Some strategies I implement into my routine to help keep me focused through the end of the semester include putting my phone away or giving it to someone I trust to keep it away from me. My phone can become a big distraction at times, and I'll sit for hours scrolling/binging when I intend to do work. Motivation for me is always reminding myself of my goals and how they will be affected based on the decisions I make in the present.

At this point in the semester, staying focused mostly comes down to keeping a routine. Making a basic list of tasks and checking them off helps me to stay organized. I like to break assignments into smaller parts so that they feel more manageable. It also helps me to set timers or use a schedule to keep track of time. I take breaks between tasks, where i like to read, scroll instagram, or walk away from the desk for a few minutes. I try to reduce distractions where i work, so i put my phone far away from where i am working. I find that it makes it easier to concentrate. The main goal is just to finish the semester without falling too far behind. Even if motivation is low, doing a little bit every day can keep things on track. overall I think that I am doing fine and have enough motivation.

For the remainder of the semester I aim to spread out my studying and try to review my lecture nots as soon as class is over. I feel like doing this will help lessen the weight that I can sometimes feel when studying and make the information I am trying to learn much more manageable. I also feel like taking necessary breaks can also be useful since I don't want to "overdo" my studying and leave room for my mental health, something which I feel like I do less often that I probably should. other strategies might include further reviewing my assignment schedule to properly spread the assignments apart so that I am able to not only complete the assignments on time but also in a way that doesn't stress me out as much or might instigate a sense of wanting to procrastinate or push the assignment past the deadline due to lack of time.

It's easy to loose focus as the semester goes on, especially now that we are halfway throughout this semester. Preparing to end the semester well is stressful. However, in order to finish this well this semester what I like to do is set aside as much time as I can to study and finish assignments. Even better when I get the chance to get a head start on assignments, that way I don't fall behind on any classes. As well have enough time to study for exams, so that I get the chance to really understand the different concepts that may be on the exams. Just knowing that leaving everything last minute will only make it the semester worse, my motivation to doing assignments is the thought that if I get them done instead of leaving them, that will grant the time I need in order to do hobbies that I like.

Well, first of all, one thing I could do is sleep early for once. A lack of sleep is definitely preventing me from fully paying attention in my classes. Another strategy I could do is to try to take extra notes whenever there is a lecture. I also need to be less distracted by my devices.

To stay focused through the end of the semester, Im going to try to rely on a few strategies. I am going to make checklists for everything I need to do. Breaking my tasks down into smaller ones is going to help me stay organized and on top of things. I am also going to plan out my days of the week, assigning specific tasks to each day, so I dont get overwhelmed. My goal is to finish all my assignments by Friday, so I can enjoy the weekend without worrying about school. That way, I can actually relax and recharge, making it easier to focus during the week. I am going to keep distractions to a minimum by setting designated study times and creating a quiet space to work. Keeping up with this routine is going to be really helpful for me, and it is going to help me stay productive.

As the semester goes on, it gets harder to stay focused. One way to make things easier is to focus on one goal at a time instead of stressing over everything at once. If I break my work into smaller tasks, like finishing one assignment or learning one concept before moving on I wont feel as overwhelmed. It also helps to set small goals each day so I can see my progress. I also need to find better ways to study. Instead of just reading my notes, I can try practice problems, explain concepts out loud, or make summaries to help me understand the material better. Having a set study schedule with specific times for different subjects could also keep me more organized and help me avoid last-minute cramming. By keeping my focus on one goal at a time and finding better study habits, I can stay on track and finish the semester strong.

Some strategies I have in order to stay focused throughout the end of the semester focuses on 3 main concepts that fall under self care, discipline and organization. I plan on making a study schedule so I can best succeed in the last few exams that are going to take place that really focuses on the deadlines and also has a designated time for breaks so that I dont burn myself out since I noticed that I tend to burn out really quickly. By breaking the larger assignments and tasks into smaller and more manageable parts can also contribute to success as breaking down large assignments into smaller ones has worked before in the past for me. I also want to employ and lean on my friends to help me keep myself accountable since if they nag at me then I am more likely to stay on task and get work done.

Frankly half way through the semester, burning out is far too easy to do. The newness has all worn off and deadlines loom horrifically and the end still seems near and yet so far away. But staying on course is all about momentum in small incremental steps that continue to propel me along. As far as I'm aware, dividing it up makes it manageable. Instead of thinking about, I have to get through this entire paper, I tell myself to just write one paragraph. Even booting up my computer and being ready to go is a leap forward. Another way in which I manage to stay on course is recalling why I'm doing it to begin with. If its going to be about my future, or about my family, or even about the love of knowledge, reminding myself keeps me going through the tough days. Its also important to take breaks from time to time. Burning out wont benefit anyone so going outside, getting a snack and even just stretching makes me wonder if I should reboot again and get going once more. And accountability too whether thats with a study group, a friend checking in or even just writing down what Im hoping to get done in the week and when the end of the semester comes I simply have to get through step by step.

When I started the semester, I tried being on track by attending all the classes and submitting all the assignments on time. But reaching mid-semester, I have realised that I am exhausted from the work. The credits are not much, but amount of efforts it takes to stay on track is difficult. So, mid semester, the practices I apply to stay on track is to attend most of my classes (the attendance requirement keeps me going), visit office hours when Im confused regarding an assignment and lastly, I take adequate amount of rest. I realised that over exhaustion is not good, so rather than procrastinating, I simply take a nap or watch a movie. Sometimes, I even try going to the library so that the working environment over there encourages me to work through my studies. These are my ways to stay on track mid semester onwards.

At this point in the semester, motivation is running on fumes. Its not that I dont care, I do, but the grind is starting to feel endless. Between classes, track, and everything else, its easy to fall into the just get through it mentality instead of actually staying engaged. So, what can I do to keep myself focused and not just go through the motions? First, I need to get real about managing my time. I keep telling myself Ill find time to study, but unless I actually block out time for it, everything else (practice, random distractions, exhaustion) will take over. Setting specific work periods, especially for biomechanics and any other class where I tend to procrastinate, would help. Maybe using practice as a hard cut-off, like, if I have an hour between classes and practice, that hour has to be for work, not mindless scrolling. Second, I need to keep my goals in sight. I didnt put in all this effort just to coast now. The whole point of these classes is to build toward PT school, and slacking now isnt going to help me later. Even for classes that feel less directly relevant, I need to remember that finishing strong matters. Maybe making a quick list of why this class matters could help on days when I just dont feel like caring. Also, accountability. Im way more likely to stay on track when I know someone else is expecting me to. Study groups arent really my thing, but even just telling a friend what I plan to get done each week could help. Or maybe setting up small rewards, like no Netflix until I finish a study goal. Lastly, I just need to remember that this phase is temporary. The end of the semester always feels far away until suddenly its here. Pushing through now means less stress later. So, time to lock in, get things done, and make sure I dont look back wishing I had tried harder.

It's the middle of the semester, and honestly, I feel like I'm just pushing myself from one deadline to the next. Motivation feels like a battery that Im constantly trying to recharge because it keeps dying. I think what helps me stay focused is remembering why Im doing all of this in the first place, to graduate and hopefully go to grad school. But even with that big picture in mind, it's hard to stay motivated every single day too. Breaking things down into smaller tasks helps though. Like, instead of telling myself I need to ace an exam, I focus on just getting through todays study session. Ive also started making to-do lists where I can physically cross things off, its small, but it feels good. And Im trying to cut myself some slack. The pressure of doing well can feel overwhelming, but letting myself take breaks and enjoy little things like coffee runs or gym time helps keep me grounded. Talking to friends who are also struggling makes me feel less alone, too. Its a reminder that this feeling of burnout is normal and temporary, it'll go away. I guess the key is not expecting to be perfectly motivated all the time but learning to keep going even when Im not.

I am already a very focused person when it comes to school so I will continue to do the strategies that have gotten me this far. The first strategy I use is a calendar with all the tasks I need to complete each week for school assignments. As I complete the assignments I like to check them off because that gives me a little seratonin boost along the way. I also try to do my assignments earlier than they are due. I find that if I wait until the last minute to do a task I get anxiety and then I am not doing my best work. Another strategy is to study a little bit each day on topics that I know will be on the next exam. That way I am not cramming all of the information the day before the exam and instead have practiced the concepts more than once so I am not nervous the day of the exam.

Some strategies I can keep in place to keep me focused through the end of the semester are remembering why Im in school and why its important to do well in school. I think its important to have a reason why you want to do well so that you can focus on school and be motivated. Having motivation allows us to keep on task. Something that keeps me motivated to finish the semester strong is to remember that once I finish summer is around the corner. think about the things in your plans and how you will be able to relax and that the hard work you put in now will be worth it. I also tell myself that what I learn now is important for my future and my career. Especially the kinesiology classes since I am a kinesiology major. Its even easier if I find the topic interesting. Another point of motivation is to look back at the work I put in through the first half of the semester and not let the work go to waste because I decided to slack off. Having motivation allows me to push myself even when I am feeling lazy and do not want to do anything.

Honestly, I too have been struggling to keep up and stay motivated. I think it's more like laziness because we've gotten to a point where things just feel like the same all the time. It's hard to stay motivated when we've gone so complacent to every day school life. It's like an endless cycle. I think because of that, we need to find something to look forward to whether that's summer or graduating, there should be an end goal or something important or exciting ahead to keep the motivation there. Some of my tips include keeping a calendar with not only school dates, but fun ones too; for example, I'm going to a rodeo with my significant other and their family this upcoming weekend so that encourages me to finish all my work for the week. Keeping a to-do list also helps so we aren't so overwhelmed with work at the end of the week because it keeps piling up. Taking things one day at a time I think is so crucial because for me, the main reason I lose motivation is because I feel this impossible mountain of work or things I need to do so I get discouraged and lose the will to do those things, even if they are due next week! Hopefully we all get a little boost of motivation again soon.

The strategies that I have used this semester and plan to continue using in other to help keep me focused are using a planner, using my google calendar, checking my email constantly, and continuously checking my canvas calendar to ensure I'm not missing any due dates. I have been keeping a physical planner since high school and it has helped me out a lot. I have also started using google calendar and it has helped me keep track of everything and the fact that I can add times and reminders helps even more. It's nice to be able to receive reminders of what I need to do and what I need to finish by when. I truly don't think I'd be able to survive without keeping my calendar organized. I have terrible memory but checking my calendar constantly knowing that I have already written down what I need to remember is such a weight lifted off my shoulders.

I am here in the physics 2 lab because this class is a requirement for my degree in biochemistry. However, beyond just checking off a requirement, I know that physics, even if its not my primary focus, plays an important role in understanding the natural world. Electricity, magnetism, circuits, and waves; all of these concepts influence biological systems in ways that arent always obvious. Even though I dont see myself using equations for electric fields daily, I know that physics is embedded in biochemistry, from how neurons transmit signals to how spectrophotometers analyze samples. I might not always feel a deep connection to the material, but I can appreciate its significance. Perhaps this class will surprise me. Maybe Ill find unexpected connections between physics and the microscopic world Im passionate about. For now, Im here to learn, to push through challenges, and to remind myself that even subjects outside my main focus in biochemistry will come in handy.

I want to work as a psychiatrist, thus I'll need a solid background in biology, psychology, and medicine. Although it may not initially appear that physics and psychiatry are closely related, physics is crucial to the medical industry. For instance, medical imaging methods like MRI and CT scans, which psychiatrists utilize to examine brain anatomy and identify anomalies, require a solid understanding of physics. EEG equipment record brain activity, which is helpful for identifying illnesses like epilepsy or sleep disorders. This is explained by concepts like electromagnetism. Even the most fundamental concepts of motion and force can be used to understand biomechanics and the effects of physical trauma on the brain. Studying physics also improves analytical thinking and problem-solving abilities, which are critical in psychiatry for patient diagnosis and treatment. I can see how this class can advance my general knowledge of the sciences and medical area, even though it's not my primary concentration.

My overall goal is to live in a place that I like. I personally believe that environment is everything when it comes to building who you are and that is exactly why I'm here. To complete this goal, I will also have to chase a different goal that I've always had which is becoming a doctor. I want to specialize in anaesthesiology specifically because it will give me exactly the freedom I am chasing in choosing exactly where I want to practice. I also however have my eyes on becoming a family medicine doctor for a less selfish goal of wanting to be able to experience something that I think is completely unique to that profession. The idea of being able to watch a family grow and be there with them as their primary care throughout that time is so powerful. Either way, this class is not only a requirement for reaching those goals, but also something that will genuinely come in handy as I work through future hurdles towards that end.

My goal is to get a deeper understanding in physics, and see how it connects to biology and chemistry. I am a biochemistry major and even though most of my classes are centered around chemistry and biology, I still have to do a couple physics classes. I find it interesting to see the connections made between chemistry, biology, and physics. Most of the time, people find it hard to connect the three together because physics is associated with engineering more but the principles of physics are deeply embedded in both chemistry and biology. For example, understanding the behavior of atoms and molecules in chemistry often requires knowledge of quantum mechanics and thermodynamics, which are core areas of physics. Similarly, biological processes such as muscle contraction, nerve signal transmission, and even the structure of DNA rely on physical principles like electromagnetism and mechanics. By studying physics, you gain insights into the fundamental forces and laws that govern all matter, which can enhance your understanding of biochemical reactions and biological systems. This interdisciplinary approach not only enriches your knowledge but also equips you with a versatile skill set that is valuable in research and various scientific careers. Embracing the connections between these fields can lead to a more holistic and integrated understanding of the natural world.

At the moment my goal is just to pass this class. I honestly I have no idea how this class will play into my future at all. This lab frustrates me so much. My goals for this lab are to learn to the best of my ability and apply it to what I learn in lecture. It is one thing to listen to a professor talk about physics. However, to see concepts applied to real life examples aids in my understanding of how physics actually plays out in reality. In addition, our lab seems to be going at a quicker pace than our lecture so another goal of mine is to use lab as a good preview of whats to come in lecture. My greater goal is to attend health professional school to be a healthcare provider. Therefore, this class will help me not only fulfill a prerequisite but also prepare myself to become a health professional. I can apply what I learn in lab to other real life examples in the future. Overall, this lab not only stands as a required class for graduate school but also as an opportunity to further understand what I am learning in lecture. My goal is to make the most of my time in the three hours of lab each week.

My goals professionally are to become a physician and to help promote health equity. This course is a prerequisite for medical school, which I will be starting this summer. Thus, this course will help me reach one of the milestones toward my goals! Since I self-taught physics for the MCAT, taking this course has been really rewarding in bolstering my knowledge and understanding of the topics in a much more detailed way (beyond equations and variable relationships). I am also excited because after taking physics I, it has been easier to think about how physics applies to my everyday life. I used to not love this subject and avoided it in undergrad and graduate school, which is why I am taking it through Open University now. However, I have come to appreciate it and better understand the topics and how they relate to the human body, which will be especially helpful for the career field I am going into.

I am taking this class to fulfill a prerequisite for medical school since my long-term goal is to become a physician. Although one may think that physics is not directly related to preceding medicines and curing diseases, I am glad that I have the opportunity to enhance my knowledge of basic sciences and gain a stronger understanding of how physics can be applied to a variety of other scientific disciplines. For example, by understanding Ohms Law, I will able to apply this concept to cardiovascular medicine and understanding how blockages in arteries can affect blood flow. I also appreciate that physics allows me to see concepts come to life in real-time whereas sometimes in other disciplines of science, it can be harder to actually see the application of certain concepts. I have a strong interest in neurology but I sometimes find it confusing to understand how action potentials and neurotransmitters work, so I appreciate that having a stronger understanding of certain concepts in physics allows me to visualize these phenomena in different ways. I look forward to continuing to see how physics laboratory will help me in my pursuit of my long-term goal.

As the end of the semester approaches, students often feel the pressure of upcoming exams, projects, and deadlines. Staying focused during this demanding period can be challenging, but with the right strategies in place, it's possible to maintain productivity and finish strong. Here are some practical approaches to help sustain focus through the end of the semester. Staying focused through the end of the semester requires intentional planning, effective time management, and a commitment to self-care. By setting clear goals, creating a distraction-free study environment, using time management techniques, and seeking support, students can maintain their concentration and perform at their best during this demanding time.

Firstly its crazy to believe that we are almost at the end of the semester, time did fly by. It just reminds me how close I am to graduating soon. During this time in the semester, it does take me a bit more effort to get my things done especially after spring break. One strategy I have to keep myself focused through the end of the semester is taking breaks in between studying. I like to focus and complete my work for one hour then give myself 15 minutes to clear my mind a bit before I get back to working. Another strategy that helps me to keep my motivation is to repeat positive affirmations related to school and myself. I believe repeating affirmations can create a positive mindset moving forward that can motivate you to keep pushing. One last strategy would be creating study groups with close friends so they can be your motivation to finish strong.

Some strategies I can put into to place to keep me focused through the end of the semester are to keep an organized planner where I can see all my assignments and when theyre due so I can have everything turned in on time. Another strategy is to also block off time in my schedule and dedicate it to studying especially as we get closer to finals so I am prepared for exams and have reviewed and refreshed my memory on topics weve learned at the beginning of the semester. I also plan on attending office hours to get a better understanding of the lectures and ask any questions I may have on topics that are still unclear to me or am having difficulty grasping. And one final strategy I have to end the semester strong is to also remember to allow time for myself so that I dont feel burnt out or overwhelmed in the end, and help keep a well balanced life.

I'm order to stay focused for the rest of the semester, I would have to attend class consistently, pay attention and take notes, and study hard to retain the information. I could also work with others and ask questions to resolve any confusions or conflicting information. These steps will help me continue to do well in class and score high on the exams I need to pass.

What strategies can I put in place to keep me focused through the end of the semester? At the mid-point of the semester I can't be the only one struggling with motivation. How can we keep ourselves on task? Something that helps me maintain focus throughout the semester is trying to make sure I have a friend in every class I am in. It helps me motivate myself to get up because I know someone will be at class that depends on me or vice versa. Another thing I do is write down what is planned for each class and what material is being covered so I am less overwhelmed and more ready for each class session. I do still struggle with motivation though and theres not a fix-all solution. I think what works best is multiple small strategies when trying to maintain motivation, rather than one big strategy that you put all your effort into.

Honestly, its getting really hard to stay focused right now. I feel like the beginning of the semester had some momentum and I was trying to stay on top of things, and I actually felt motivated. Now I can feel some motivation being stripped away. Im tired and burnt out and everything feels like a lot. Especially in physics. Some days I still ask why this matters even though I know why it matters and I know Ill regret it later if I give up now. So my strategy is to take it one small step at a time. Instead of stressing already about the final, Ill keep focus on one assignment or one concept at a time. I also think talking to classmates will help. Knowing that Im not the only one going through it makes it feel more doable. I keep reminding myself to finish strong and then finally rest. Summer is coming so its something to look forward to.

The question posed in the reflection piece is one of the things I have struggled most with in my academic career. Learning the discipline required to be successful as a student is much more difficult than learning the expected course material. I think from today my goal is to hold myself to strict standards in terms of sleep cycle and activity expenditure. I want to return to an 8 hour sleep cycle that gives me enough time in the mornings to get ready for any and all of the class sessions that I am enrolled in. I also want to restrict myself from activities that will distract me specifically before my first class period for the day so that I cannot rationalize missing the class for any reason. Lastly, I want to make commitments to classmates that will require me to actively participate in classes to uphold the commitment I make, whether it be study groups or other such agreements.

I think that staying focused through the rest of the semester in general physics 2 lab requires a balance between a variety of strategies and motivation. One thing I would focus on is setting small, and achievable goals for each study session. At times physics concepts can feel a little abstract compared to other molecular interactions that I am used to in biochemistry. However, that is when I try to relate physics topics to the biological systems, like how electricity applies to nerve impulses or how we discussed in our last class that circuits can also relate to biochemical pathways. Another key strategy is using active learning methods, rather than just reading out of the textbook. For example, I prefer to talk to classmates in groups of a few people which helps me understand things I am confused on, or even help explain things I understand to other classmates and make sure they get it because that is also a way for me to double check and make sure it makes perfect sense to me.

The strategies I can put in place to keep myself focused throughout the end of the semester are strategies like: keeping up with my weekly schedule, keeping track of due dates, keeping track of midterm, final and other exam dates so that I can make a study schedule before hand to be sure I have ample time to study. Other ways that I usually utilize to keep myself motivated are ways like: spending time outdoors, making time for my hobbies that help me de-stress like listening to music, watching my current Netflix show "Grey's Anatomy," spending time with my boyfriend, spending time with friends and not procrastinating (because then I just fall into a rabbit hole of assignments, work and personal life chores/tasks/etc. Overall I feel like today (my first day back from Spring Break) was tough to fight off the procrastination in the morning but now I feel like an energizer bunny ready to fight my procrastination.

Coming back to class after a week off from school is never an easy task. Staying focused for this second half of the semester will require much motivation, grit, and self-care. For one, I will be taking breaks in between study sessions and going outside to recconect with things outside of a textbook. I have found that going outside for fresh air and seeing nature always recharges my energy. Additionally, having designated times for studying and designated times for fun things has been very helpful in this first half of the semester. I think when I am feeling unmotivated, something that has helped has been remembering the purpose of this and why it is important for me to do well in this course. Remembering that it is a privilege to be in this course has definitely helped me push through moments of unmotivatedness. So as I enter the second half of this semester, I will be using the tools I have developed in the first half to ensure I stay on track and continue to work hard in this course.

To keep myself focused through the end of the semester, I like to set short and long term goals for myself because I know that it makes me feel better to visualize my progress! Every Sunday, I have my "reset" where I write out all of my tasks I want to do for the week in my planner along with my schedule for that week. These tasks include school work, things I need to finish for my job, and my personal to-do list. This helps me to stay super organized! I can then visually see what my week look likes, dead lines that are approaching, and how I can best use my time to get all of these things done. Then, I can start to cross things off and it's kind of like a game. This method has really helped me prioritize my time and balance my school work, career, and personal life. I make sure to include on my schedule things that I need to do to feel good and be healthy (going to the gym, exercise classes, reading, walking my dogs), which helps me finish my other tasks. These activities are also good breaks between tasks!

It is no secret that remaining motivated when pursuing a long-term goal is not easy. It is especially challenging when one is getting pulled in multiple directions and has other obligations that come up outside of work or school. However, one of the key things to keep in mind during times like this is to remember why you started and how your current activities will play into your long-term goals. I also think it is essential to reach out to peers and mentors so that there is a safe and effective way to express your feelings regarding the challenges youre facing, and to realize that youre oftentimes not as alone as you may think. In addition, I think its important to continue making time for yourself to mitigate burnout, while also giving yourself space to acknowledge that this endeavor is hard because it feels hard. Ultimately, challenges and lacking motivation are very normal and expected but its important to take ownership of your situation and remember why you started.

I think being strong at physics-chemistry builds a very good foundation for any further education if I stay in STEM major. As a Biology student, although physics seems non-related, I find it very helpful for the same reason above- to understand better chemistry and biology.

I am here to gain a strong foundation in physics and complete a year of physics with lab. This class is a requirement for my major (biology/ physiology) and one of my goals for a successful future is getting my degree! My goal of this class is to strengthen my understanding and comprehension of physics concepts. Not only will taking this class prepare me for the studying that I will go through for medical school, it will help me see the world a bit differently because physics applies to everything we do just as every other science subject and knowing the concepts and how to apply them to my daily life will be very beneficial. However, knowing these basic physics topics will make me more knowledgeable and more aware of what is going around me all the time.

My goals are finish my minor in physics and to improve my understanding of the world around me. This class can help me achieve my goal in multiple ways. My goals are to enter a physical therapy program with hopes of becoming a physical therapist and one day open my own PT clinic! My parents are business owners and are encouraging me to open my own clinic to be able to have control over my work and personal life. One thing I learned recently is the physics behind why we should stay inside our car if there's lightning from a thunderstorm as the car as if lightning strikes the car, we are protected because the lightning will travel around the surface of the car and the ground will absorb the current flow.

My goals are to work in a lab. I believe that this class will help me understand how certain pieces of equipment I may use work, and how it will affect the work I do. My goal is to become a physical therapist or occupational therapist. This class can help me achieve my goals by checking off the requirements needed for physical therapy school when I apply. Since the Physics 2 lecture and lab are requirements for PT school. Physics is used in physical therapy in many different ways, like angles, forces, and degrees. It is seen through different forces applied onto the human body or how the human body exerts forces onto different objects when performing exercises or activities. It also is used when looking at injuries with how forces were applied to cause an injury and how a physical therapist can go about helping the patient recover. Degrees are used when looking at normal body angles and comparing them to the patient's injured angles and seeing how much of a difference there is to be able to diagnose and treat the patient to help them.

Ultimately, I plan on working at the VA hospital as a doctor of physical therapy (DPT). In order to get a DPT I need to get into grad school. In order to get into grad school I need to fulfill the prerequisites for application. General Physics I & II are part of that prerequisite. This class is a stepping stone to my larger goals. Aside from that, physics is used in my field in the form of biomechanics -- essentially meaning mathematical physics in movement of the human body. Therefore, things like (work = force * distance) has its use. Also, physics helps us scientists to understand the world we live in. Right now we are studying electrical circuits and this has applications, because we humans are essentially bioelectrical circuit boards. The switches are like cellular channels that open and close and the battery is stored ATP. Also, having general knowledge about physics has real world applications, as I now can remember that electricity flows from the negative to the positive. Therefore, when jumpstarting a car, hook up the dead battery's negative side first, then the positive.

My goal is to become a physician specializing in womens health, with a focus on supporting socio0economically marginalized communities. To achieve this, Im completing my pre-med requirements and preparing to apply to medical school. A major step in that process is taking the MCAT next year, and this Physics class is playing an important role in helping me prepare. The MCAT isnt just a test on memorization, it challenges critical thinking, problem solving, and the ability to apply scientific concepts in unfamiliar contexts. One of the most difficult aspects of the exam is staying calm under pressure and working through tough complex problems effectively. Beyond Knowledge, this class will help me develop the discipline and problem solving mindset I need for medical school. The process of struggling through difficult concepts, seeking out different ways of understanding and practicing until they become second nature reflect show I will need to approach my MCAT studies and ultimately my medical training.

My goal is to take what I learn about physics and use it on the MCAT in the future. Since physics is a big part of the test, I want to understand key topics like motion, forces, energy, and electricity, not just memorize formulas. The MCAT focuses more on thinking through problems than doing complicated math, so Ill try my best breaking down questions and spotting patterns. I also want to connect physics to other subjects, like how fluid dynamics relates to blood flow or how energy laws apply to chemical reactions. By building an understanding and practicing how to apply it, Ill be more able and ready to tackle MCAT physics questions when the time comes. Hopefully it does help me with the test. Or at least understanding the world around me as I go through medical school. Since physics is necessary for all applications of life in general.

My goal is to better understand earth's processes, which is why I have decided to major in earth science. I think physics is such an important subject because it helps us understand how and why things around us in the world work the way they do. For example, gravity plays a very large role in many processes on our earth such as: plate tectonics, how water flows, tidal movements, erosion, atmospheric circulation, and many other events. I learned in my previous physics class how important it is to understand of how gravity effect things on the earth, so you can better understand how some of these earth processes work. I remember also learning about buoyancy and density in my previous physics class, and found it really helpful in understanding how different types of fluid interact with each other on our earth. For example, salt water is more dense than normal water, so when the two mix, salt water will sink under the fresh water.

My goal is to become a dentist, but be more than that, I want to help people feel confident in their smiles and overall health. Some long term goals of mine that correlate with this class is the ability to get into med school by passing this class and bring this knowledge to the mcat. This class in shorter term is helping me meet my major requirement while also teaching topics that can be applicable to real life. An example of the applicability is how in today's lab we had talked about how knowing whether your electricity to where you are living is a series or parallel, can help you turn the power back on without affecting the rest of the house. My house back in so cal was built very similar to the one in the problem (electrically) because if we plugged in to many appliances the circuit overdo it causing the fuse to blow and loosing power, but in the kitchen. This meant that the wiring in the kitchen would be considered a series while the electricity to each separate room in the house, each with its own fuse, would be a parallel circuit. My parents would get so mad because it would always happen right before a huge catering event, of course, and so much tension and stress in the air you could chop it with a knife and serve it. But it would always end with a huge relief and feeling accomplished each job we finished, knowing we would have enough money to survive the next month. I miss home but, then again reminded with memories flowing back, I definitely don't haha. Complicated!

My goal is to become a doctor so I can help people, especially those in underserved communities. To do that, I need a strong understanding of science, including physics. Learning physics also improves my problem-solving skills, which will be useful in diagnosing and treating patients. Even though physics isnt my main focus, I know it will help me in the long run. My goal is to achieve a profession in Biology-related field or medical-related profession. I believe Physics and Chemistry are the main basis of all science subjects. My goals for this class is to gain a strong foundation in physics especially since content for this course is extremely relevant to my MCAT studies. The majority of physics content on the MCAT is based on electric field and magnetism. Im hoping that this course makes these difficult topics on the already difficult MCAT exam more manageable. I am really enjoying the content and am managing the workload well.

I think I have to focus on making it to every class to ensure I dont fall behind the rest of the semester. It gets harder to stay motivated to show up but I find I do so much better when I attend class as much as possible. Staying organized is important as more assignments get assigned. Writing everything I need to do and their due dates keeps me on track and helps me remember all of the assignments I need to do. I dont forget to do assignments when I stay organized.

Concentrating near the end of the semester feels like trying to run in mud. Everything is possible initially, even somewhat exciting, but I am now worn out. First, I really need to commit to breaking things into smaller tasks. Sometimes, I avoid certain assignments because they are gigantic, but telling myself to work for 20 minutes makes it feel less daunting. I also want to reward myself a bit more like, after finishing a paper, I treat myself, or I let myself enjoy the guilt-free pleasure of watching a few episodes before studying. Another thing that helps me is checking in with friends or classmates. Knowing that someone else is going through the same slump is comforting, and we can motivate each other. Maybe even forming a little study group or accountability chat could help. I need to remind myself why I am doing all these long-term goals to keep me grounded. I want to finish strong, and I know that I will be able to be proud if I persevere.

Some strategies that I personally use to help keep me focused through the semester are to self reflect, take a break, and do consistent reviews of the material. I find self reflection to be important as it helps remind me why I am taking these classes and keeps me grounded in the work that I need to complete. I also find self reflection soothing and tends to help when I feel very overwhelmed with work. Taking a break for a bit is also a great way to de-stress and help keep me focused. I find that when I feel overwhelmed I am unable to focus on my work and lose motivation. Taking a day off of homework or just an hour break helps me a lot with concentration and motivation. Finally I like to do consistent 30 minute reviews of the material to keep the topics fresh in my mind and so I never feel very overwhelmed, confused, or behind in my studying.

One strategy that I can put in place to help keep me focused to end the semester is taking time to study a lot more since more work may be added to finish off the year. Also keeping a calendar of all the assignments and things coming up so that I can keep track of it all because it will pile up as the coming weeks approach. I can keep myself on task by reminding myself that there are not that many weeks left and that once the last week is done it is summer and I can relax all that I want, but for now, I have to lock in and give my all over the next weeks. Although it will be tiring the end goal is worth it and I know that if I slack or do not live up to my expectations all the work I did previously for this semester may have been a waste.

This semester I feel really burnt out. I'm projected to shadow/intern around 120 hours, and that's since the very tail end of February with a 12 day-gap in Brazil for my son's birth. I feel as though I am barely hanging on in my classes to stay in the running for the 4.0 that I so desperately need to get to have an edge over the 1,000+ other grad school applicants fighting for 50 annual seats. My primary strategy is to not lose focus on my goals. I have a whole family and extended family that depend on me for survival. That is my motivation. Not friend outings, not video games, not YouTube, not movies, nor anything else in the secular realm supersedes how important finishing this semester successfully is for my career's future. Cut everything that inhibits. In 7 weeks from now, it'll either be tears or triumphs, but it'll be over. How impactful these next 7 weeks are. I'm nearing the finish line. It's not time to get complacent. Staying focused through the end of the semester feels like trying to swim the last 10 laps when fatigued. What helps me is breaking things down into small, manageable steps. Instead of looking at everything thats due in the next few weeks, Ive started planning one week at a timeor even one day at a time. I make checklists, and even started using post-it notes as reminders of what needs to get done -- and I've never used post-it notes before.

One of the most important strategies I can put in place is to try not to procrastinate. I tend to procrastinate when I have important homework and projects that are due, and it causes me to be stressed and not do the best that I can do on those assignments. For me, listening to music while I do my homework can help me stay focused and motivated. I also try to put away my phone and other items that may distract me and deter me from my work. This has recently helped me get through working on assignments and has stopped my from procrastinating and putting my work off till the last minute. I also have been keeping a schedule of my assignments that are due so I can make sure that I don't forget about anything important and possibly miss an assignment. This has been very helpful because I can get distracted very quickly and forget about assignments that are due.

Honestly, staying focused through the end of the semester can feel like an uphill battle. The excitement of starting new classes has worn off, and the finish line still feels far away. One thing that helps me is breaking big tasks into smaller, more manageable pieces. Instead of thinking about finishing an entire project, Ill set a goal to complete just one part of it today. It feels less overwhelming, and checking off small tasks keeps me motivated. Another strategy is reminding myself why Im doing all of this in the first place. I think about my long-term goals like becoming a dentist and how each class is a step toward that future. It doesnt make the work itself more fun, but it makes it feel more meaningful. Also, finding time to recharge is key. Sometimes it feels counterproductive to take breaks when theres so much to do, but Ive noticed that a quick walk or chatting with a friend can reset my mind and help me focus better when I get back to studying. Talking with friends who are going through the same thing also helps. Its nice to know Im not alone in feeling this way, and sharing tips can be motivating too. At the end of the day, I just keep reminding myself that pushing through now will make the accomplishment at the end feel even more worth it.

Since my first year, I have had several strategies to help me focus through this semester's end. One of them is to create a schedule by planning what assignments and exams I need to complete and study for that are the closest before doing anything else. However, doing advance can help remove stress and anxiety as assignments are assigned every week, and it goes by fast. Another main strategy is to go to the library or at home to work on my studies as it helps me focus more and prevents distractions from other students. Finally, I would take breaks between my studies to refresh my mind and body. It's very common for students to experience instances where studying a lot could cause their minds to burn out and feel very tired, which causes them to lose concentration on tasks. Overall, these strategies helped me balance my studies and the hobbies I like doing in my free time.

Staying focused this late in the semester feels like dragging myself through mud some days. The excitement from the beginning is long gone, and now its just this marathon of assignments, exams, and deadlines. One thing that helps me is breaking things down into small, manageable pieces. If I look at the big picture, I just get overwhelmed. But if I say, Okay, just finish this one assignment, or Study for 30 minutes, it feels more doable. Ive also started using a planner more seriouslycolor coding, to-do lists, even little checkboxes to feel that satisfaction of crossing something off. Accountability helps, too. I text a friend when Im about to start studying and check in after. It sounds silly, but it makes me start. Im trying to build little routines so that its not a question of motivationits just a habit. And finally, Im reminding myself why I started this in the first place. I want to be a Clinical Laboratory Scientist, and each class gets me one step closer. So even when its rough, I try to keep that goal in the back of my mind. Were all tired, but were also tough. Weve got this.

Some strategies that I am using to stay focused through the semester include continuing to use my planner to track assignment due dates so that I dont miss anything. I will also keep motivating myself through positive self-talk. I know I did not make it this far just to stop now. Ive got this, and this is goodI am getting educated!
