I also fully believe in work hard, play hard which motivates me to work Monday to Thursday so I am able to enjoy Thursday to Sunday going out and hanging out with friends as a treat for working academically, my minimum wage job, and research position.

I am going to try to keep myself on track my making sure not to slack on my lecture and lab note taking. I have noticed that I have been taking less detailed / organized notes the past 2 weeks of lecture, which makes it more difficult for me to learn material. I am going to make an effort to maintain the quality of my notes through the end of the semester. Also, I want to continue to make the effort to start the expert TA homework assignments at the beginning of the week so that I have time to ask questions and work slowly through problems. When I save homework to the last minute, I may still be able to finish on time and get a rough understanding of the material, but I am able to understand concepts much better if I work through the problems very thoroughly and take my time.

One key strategy that help me stay focused throughout the semester is to come up with a study plan. What I mean by this is that I try to see if there is anything important coming up for one of my classes and see if there is some free time that I can use in order to study for said topic. This helps me not only refresh myself on important knowledge and key notes, but it also helps me be more consistent and focused compared to me trying to cram a bunch of topics all at once at the last second. Additionally, with this strategy, I'm able to do this for any kind of topic I need study time for for about 20-30 minutes, which helps me study while giving me enough time to do other activities that I enjoy, improving my mental health by not forcing myself to due study sessions that last hours, which helps with my focus, motivation, and mood, making it more likely that I would go back to study other topics. Not to mention, this strategy helps with my interest, helping me absorb the information and not just breezing through the material.

At this point in the semester, staying focused feels harder than ever. The initial excitement of new classes has worn off, and the finish line still feels far away. I know I need to push through, but motivation is low, and distractions are everywhere. One strategy I want to implement is breaking tasks into smaller chunks when an assignment feels overwhelming, I tend to procrastinate. If I can just focus on one small step at a time, maybe I wont feel so stuck. Another thing that helps is setting up a routine. I do better when I dedicate specific times for studying instead of hoping Ill feel like it later. Also, I need to take breaks, but the right kind scrolling on my phone for an hour isnt helpful. I want to use breaks to move around, stretch, or even go outside for a few minutes to reset. Most importantly, I need to remind myself why Im doing this. Its easy to get lost in the stress, but I have goals, and finishing strong will get me closer to them. Maybe making a little motivation board with reminders of my future plans could help. One step at a time I just have to keep going.

I have been really considering a lot about the strategies I can use to help me through the end of the semester. One thing that keeps me motivated is taking each week as single unit. I plan for work on the Monday, set a schedule for homework and studying and then do my best to follow through. This technique has helped me through very challenging semesters and is a tried and true method of managing stressful school weeks. Another strategy i take is to create a macro scale plan for the end of the quarter, making sure I know when exams are and when final paper are due. This helps me keep the large items in my agenda without forgetting. I use these two strategies to make sure like I can handle the stress of finals season. This will be a difficult exam season due to the level of coursework I am taking. So I am prepared to implement these strategies.

I'm here because I want to learn about physics. It's a subject that helps explain how the world works, and even though it's not always easy, it's important to understand the basics. Plus, it's a requirement, so l might as well make the most of it. Knowing the fundamentals of different science classes is useful, even if I don't end up using physics all the time. It connects to other subjects like biology and chemistry, and having a general understanding of how things move, interact, and transfer energy is just good knowledge to have. Lastly, l'm here to get through the class, learn what I can, and take something useful from it. At the same time, I'm here for my family. I want to make them proud and show them that their sacrifices were worth it. I want to create opportunities for myself and for those who come after me. Maybe I don't know exactly where I'm going yet, but I know that being here is part of the journey to figuring that out.

When I think of "Why am I here?" I think of the answer to what made me take this class, specifically Physics 2. When I took Physics 1 it was three years ago, so I feel like I'm finally catching up by taking Physics 2. The reason I am in this class is a combination of curiosity and requirements. I am taking this course to develop my physics knowledge in electricity and fluid dynamics, which were the parts I did the worst on my first MCAT attempts. Then part of it is required because the majority of medical schools require a year of physics for their applications. Overall I say I'm pretty excited as well since it is one of the last classes I'm going to take before I graduate and start applying to jobs and medical schools and deepen my knowledge in physics to apply it outside the class.

I am here because I have a vision for my future. I am currently pursuing Kinesiology here at SFSU and to me, it is more than just earning a college degree here. Instead, I hope to use it as a stepping stone toward something bigger. I want to deepen my understanding of the human body, movement, and rehabilitation so I can make a meaningful impact in peoples lives. My ultimate goal is to get into UCSFs graduate program, and as result, I have to meet one of their requirements, this being completing physics .There have been moments of doubt and exhaustion, but I remind myself that I chose this path for a reason. I have a passion for helping others regain strength, mobility, and confidence in their own bodies. I see myself in a career where I can be hands-on, making real changes in peoples health and well-being. Hopefully I am able to achieve this dream.

For me, being here means that I'm learning. It means that I put in the effort every day to come into class and be prepared to learn; even in circumstances that make me not want to be here, I still push myself to ensure I am here. On the other hand, I am also here to make something of myself. Taking STEM-related classes, such as physics, is something that I need to do to expand my knowledge in the field that I am currently interested in. As a first-generation college student, I hold the bare responsibility of holding myself accountable and making sure I succeed. I am here as a sole reminder that school is something that is of importance to me and my family, knowing that this is one of the ways that I can guarantee to get a career in the future. Despite the complaints I say about having to be here and having to study, I still love to learn.

why am I here? I am here because my family wanted a better life for me and my brother, they immigrated from Lebanon since they knew that they would have a better life for them and their future kids (me and my brother). I am at sfsu because the kinesiology program is really good, and I want to become a physical therapist. the school also has good connections to ucsf which is the school I want to go to, and a lot of opportunities to be involved.

I am here because not only is this a major requirement for me but I need to actually find out what I want to do in my life, I want to find out my purpose in academia and how I want to present myself going forward in my life, I want to find out what uniquely makes me qualified to be a scientist, what can I provide to the world and what can I learn so I can do better providing my help to the world and going forward. I also want to find out just more in general, physics 1 was a class I loved but really didnt engross myself in, but from what my past professor said, she said physics 2 would challenge us further and really provide us with a better understanding into the subject and the world around us as well as the impact to our lives

I am here because of my parents. Throughout my life, my parents have supported me through everything I have done. I am the son of two immigrant parents from Iran that both had to go through the whole build your self up from nothing to live the American Dream process. They have both become successful and made in such a way for me to not have a hard childhood as they did. However, their stories have pushed me to be the best version of myself that I can be. I started playing basketball in the 4th grade and had a goal to be a collegiate basketball player. I worked hard throughout high school to achieve this goal and eventually got a scholarship to play at SFSU. Along that I had a goal to go into the field of health and medicine and as I am currently still trying to achieve this goal, I am determined to work hard to get there as I did with basketball.

As a first-generation college student, I have many reasons to be here at SFSU taking PHYS122. My family has worked so hard to support me in my academic career. Even though my journey here to this class has been tumultuous going from high school to college, then a quick stint at the military, finally back to college here at SFSU. I don't regret any moment of my journey as I have gained experiences that not many will have in a lifetime. During my time in the military, I was a navy medic and coincidentally found interest in practicing medicine. Medicine requires a lot of critical thinking to find different solutions as patients have different diagnoses. At SFSU, I am majoring in Biology with a focus on physiology. I believe that this major would be the most relatable to practicing medicine. PHYS122 is not surprisingly one of the major requirements. Physics applies to many concepts and treatments conducted in medicine. I need to learn and know this material before going further in my journey in medicine.

Why am I here? I am currently trying to finish up my B.S. in Biology, Concentration of Physiology. The original goal was to take up nursing, but I think that will have to look into later. I was never drawn to any one singular dream career, school, or life. Well, if there is a dream life it would be to have a comfortable way of living, being stable and getting to enjoy other activities outside of supporting myself. When I picture my future there is no one career or degree from a prestigious school that I envision, but a quiet life where I work, have a nice place to call home, host and go out with friends frequently, and get to travel and explore often enough that it becomes my personality. I have always grown up with the mentality of to move in silence, as in to not let anyone else know your big moves, only to let them see your successes as the come. I want to pursue all kinds of different professions until I can say Ive had enough experience and settle into my quiet but exciting life. Nursing, med school, pa school, dermatology, pharmacy, hygienist. I want to be so much more, but I like being comfortable just as well.

The question of why I am here It's a question that Ive contemplated many times before, because I seek to find some meaning in the obstacles I have encountered, some of them being immigration. However, no matter how many times I think, I still find it challenging to find the perfect answer. Im currently a junior at San Francisco State, working on getting all of the prerequisites that I need for medical school. Furthermore, Im taking this course to fulfill my prerequisites, and as a cell and molecular biology major, I know physics is important, even though I don't consider myself the best in the subject. To be real, physics has always been a challenge for me, and this is my first time taking it in college. Its been a rough start, but Im hoping to push through, and I am trying to learn from it. At the end of the day, Im here because I want to build a stable future, provide for my family, and achieve my goal of becoming a doctor.

The reason that I am taking this class it to be one step closer to achieving my goals. One of my biggest goals is to be either a trauma surgeon, er doctor, or a physician scientist. All of these careers seem so rewarding and fit in very well my personal values that were taught to me by my family. In our culture family, friends, and community are some of the most important things that we have close to us. My goal as a physician is to make my patients feel comfortable and secure in the treatment that they are receiving. Growing up and even now I rarely see physicians who look like me in any way which has made certain moments during visits like they do not understand me or where I am coming from. I am going to add to the small percentage of Latinx physicians out there in the world.

Im here because I have a goal to become a dentist. Ever since I was a kid, Ive been interested in teeth and helping people. To get there, I need to study Biochemistry, which is why this class is important to me. Its not always easy, but I know it will help me understand the science behind dentistry and prepare me for the future. Im also here because Ive worked hard to be here. When I came to the U.S. as a refugee in 2016, I didnt know any English, but I learned it in a year. That experience taught me that I can overcome challenges if I keep pushing forward. Now, my education is my way of building a better future for myself and for others. At the end of the day, Im here because I want to succeed. I know what I want, and Im willing to put in the effort to make it happen.

I am here because I want to study biochemistry and I chose SF State as the college I wanted to study at. I still don't know what I want to do with my major but I'll just see where it takes me. I am also expected to go to college by my family, especially my parents so that's also a contributed factor in the reason I am going to school. Since biochemistry is a challenging major, I, in addition, want to see if I can manage it and graduate with a degree in biochemistry.

I am here because I chose to go to class today. I am also here because I love science and I love educating myself and leaving the classroom and being able to say that I learned something new today. Although physics is not my strongest subject, this gives me even more of a desire to attend every physics lecture and lab and become better at the subject, as it will broaden my knowledge in science and connect to my medical knowledge. I want to go into the medical field, and there is a a lot of physics to learn surrounding how it correlates to the human body. I am very appreciative that I am able to wake up and go to school to get a college education amongst all other things I am grateful for. Being able to learn physics in a nurturing environment at SF state makes me willing to try, even if I get a couple problems wrong or do not necessarily understand a topic at first.

"Why am I here?" I can provide multiple different reasons for different places, but I'll start with why I'm here for this class. Bottom line, I did take it because it was necessary for being a Biochem major. But, as I started to get into more physics, I realize how useful it is in every day life. Balancing things, understanding why things move and how objects can affect others more than the other with the use of momentum and gravity for example. I truly believe that Physics is something that will ACTUALLY carry on into my everyday life, as some classes do not (haha!). Getting a little more broad, I'm here at SFSU because I wanted a place to get away from SoCal for a bit. I was stuck in a loop at community college and didn't know what to do with my life. I wanted to be a contract or contest pianist for so long, and the money didn't matter to me at the time. Then, I realized that the only way for me to make a decent living nowadays is to either go into science or medical. So now, I'm here until I graduate and I don't regret it at all. Thank you!

I'm here in physics because I want to become a physical therapist one day. I want to take advantage of my education and do my best in each class, not just fulfill major requirements. While this class and lab is a physical therapy school course prerequisite, I see the importance in a holistic education. I actually pay for my own education; my parents don't help me, and as a result, I take my education very seriously. When it comes to why I want to pursue this education and why I want to be a physical therapist, I want to work in healthcare because I want to help people who need help performing their everyday functions to live a happy life. It's important that your body works well enough to perform the things you want/need to do. That value of mine was really fleshed out after I was diagnosed with a chronic pain condition during high school. I wasn't in good enough condition to go to public high school anymore and spent most days in bed during endless cycles of medication treatment. After that experience, I know not to take my abilities and time for granted. I'm here because I chose to be and it makes me happy. I'm excited to see what I make of this education and honestly, even the things I get to learn, despite the stress of academics.

I am here because my parents wanted me to attend college. My dream is to become a pediatrician, it has been my dream since I was in third grade and was inspired by my very own pediatrician. I tell myself, I keep wanting to do that, when I talk about it to people, I get so excited. But lately I've rethinking my life choices, I can't start over since I am more than halfway, I don't seem to remember a lot of the things I have learned and that worries me for when I need to take the MCAT test. I honestly think I am drained, and I am afraid I won't achieve my career goal. So I'm really still trying to figure out why I am still here

I am here because of my father. Because of his hands that built a life for us, only for his mind to slip away, piece by piece. I am here because I have seen what dementia does, how it erases memories, how it steals a person while there still breathing. I am here because I want to understand the brain, to fight for those who cant fight for themselves, to make sense of something that has left my family in pain. I am here because I believe in science, in discovery, in pushing past what we know to find something better. I am here because I dont want to stay stuck in the uncertainty that has defined so much of my life. I want to build something meaningful, to move forward, to turn struggle into purpose. I am here because I refuse to let circumstances define me. I want to create a future where people like my father dont have to suffer, where families dont have to watch their loved ones fade away. I am here to learn, to grow, and to fight for something bigger than myself.

Why am I here in this class learning about general physics? I am here learning about physics because I am required to take it for my major and for my career. I am trying to be a physical therapist and the school that I want to go to requires me to take physics 1 & 2. I took the first physics last semester and now I am going to be taking this semester to finish this requirement. I am also taking this class so that I can brush up on my physics. I am excited to take this class and take this learn more about physics. In physics 1 I was very confused most of the time bjt that was because I was not taking the time to study. Although I got an A in the class, I was not learning. I would just do the homework and participate in class but I was compl confused. I would cram the materials the day before the test. But I would do good on the test. I want to study more and hope to do so i this class

I am here because this is a prerequisite for my major, my major is microbiology. I am this major to qualify for medical school. I want to be a pediatric doctor. So in this class we are here to work on physics labs in order to help us understand the atoms and molecules from the lecture. The main focus of this lab is charges how they repel and attract each other based on the positivity and negativity. So using the tap and ballons and different resources allows us to visually see the different type of charges.

Why am I here? This is a good, yet vague, question. I'd say I'm here for many reasons. For example, I'm here to complete my degree, here to get good grades, here to make my money's worth, etc. Generally speaking, I'm here for external reasons and not necessarily because I wish to be here. This is likely the same thought as many other students. But in terms of a physics class, I'm mainly here for the degree requirement and maybe for the premedical prerequisites. Still not sure if medical school is my thing. We'll see where I am when I graduate/if I get any acceptances from medical schools. Besides that, maybe I'm here to meet people. I said "maybe" because it's hard to meet people and get close with them, especially when going to a commuter school. People are always in a rush to leave class and do other things rather than to make friends.

I am at San Francisco state to get my bachelors in cell and molecular biology. I am here because I am a first generation college student, and I want to make my family proud. I have always loved school growing up, and I was always fascinated with learning about biology. My parents sacrificed a lot to be here and support me during college, so I owe it to both of them to give them a college degree. I am in physics because it is a prerequisite for my degree, however, I started to really be interested in the topics we covered in physics 1. I have always heard that physics is a hard subject to understand, but I think since I really enjoyed the material, it was not bad at all. I am here to make myself family and myself proud, and go to medical school after. After San Francisco state, I want to go to medical school and be a obgyn, because I feel. It would be very rewarding.

I am here for many reasons. I have to take Physics 2 because it is required of me for my degree if I transfer to Sac State. I do not particularly like physics, but I am relatively good at it. I am here today to reach my goal of getting my degree so I am prepared for my future career. In terms of being at SF State, I am here because I am on a track scholarship. I practice every day before class, which can make the rest of my days really tiring. But I am determined to finish out the school year with good grades and a good season. I had a really hard semester in the fall, so I would like to make this semester as good as possible. So I will do my best to show up to class, do my homework, and set myself up for success.

I'm taking the class, because not only it is required for my degree but also I think it is interesting. I'm a chemistry major, and physics is very closely related to chemistry. You can have physics without chemistry but you can't have chemistry without physics. So, having a better understanding of physics can improve my understanding of chemistry, such as particle distribution, charges, and intermolecular forces. I believe that having a better understanding of physics can change the way you see and interact with the world, in both large scale and small scale.

I am personally here in this physics ii lab course because this is a lower-division requirement for my major, that being Biology with a concentration on physiology. This class is also to be taken concurrently with the physics ii course which is what I am taking this semester so that is also why I am here. I have taken physics i course and lab here with Kim Coble, and I really enjoyed it as I learned a lot and I enjoyed it. Nonetheless I am actually quite excited to see what this course and lab have in store, as I have enjoyed what I have been learning so far and I believe with my good professors can very engaging, too. Just as much as last semester. I am not sure how much I will enjoy this course so much but then again, it is just the beginning. So I suppose you could say Im also here because it is interesting to see how physics is involved in everyday life and even academically intertwined with my major.

I am here because I want to pursue a higher education. I am an aspiring research scientist hoping to get into the biotech field or the medical field. I am also here because of my parents. My parents have sacrificed everything in order to come here to have a better life for their children. My dad came here with nothing and is now a huge business man. I owe them everything for everything they have given me. I enjoy learning and expanding my knowledge as well. I am extremely grateful for being here and being able to expand my knowledge. I understand that there are people in the world that would love to have the spot I have here. With my education I also want to help make the world a better place. I want to change the world, make it a better place for people. So thats why I am here. And I am extremely happy and grateful for that!

My goal is to do well in my physics class so I can build a strong foundation for the MCAT and my future in medicine. Physics is one of the hardest subjects for me, but I know it's important because it teaches problem-solving, logical thinking, and how to approach complex situations-skills that will help me both on the MCAT and in my career. This class will challenge me, but that's exactly why it's valuable. It forces me to think critically, break down problems step by step, and apply concepts in a way that goes beyond memorization. These are the same skills I'll need for the MCAT, where understanding the logic behind formulas is just as important as knowing them. More than just a grade, I want to use this class to develop the discipline and problem-solving mindset that will help me succeed in medical school and beyond. Even though physics isn't easy, I know that pushing through it will make me a stronger student and a better future doctor.

My main goal right now is to study and prepare myself for the MCAT and to finish strong for the last semester of my undergraduate career. This course will specifically help me achieve this goal. A big part of the exam was physics, and I thought my Physics knowledge was enough to handle it. However, there were mostly concepts from Physics 2, so that is why I took the course to complete my physics knowledge and try and attain a better score on the MCAT. Then, I wanted to finish my last school semester strong, and no better way to do it than by taking this challenging course, my goal is to maintain my GPA and be able to graduate proud of myself. So overall, I will feel accomplished if I do an extra semester of physics I do not need to take and complete a full year of physics.

My goals is to become a physical therapist in the future after completing both undergraduate and graduate school. However, in order to complete graduate school, I need to complete some prerequisite courses that'll eventually allow me to enter into graduate school. Hopefully I am able to stay in the Bay Area and attend a variety of graduate schools - those including UCSF, Samuel Merritt, and more. This class will allow me to use a variety of skills that are present in a biomechanics course as that class revolves much around physics. Examples include using lever arms and using pythagorean theorem to find different angles to calculate forces. Additionally, schools like UCSF require two semesters of physics and physics labs to be completed in order to qualify for their Physical Therapy graduate school program. Hopefully I am able to achieve these goals as it is one of my biggest goals. It is hard for me to explain how much I want to get accepted and to better my odds, I need to do good in this class.

As of now, I am particularly focused on one thing, and that is to finish school. That is my main priority; however, that is just another small aspect of what I intend to achieve in my life. To sum it all up, my goal in life is to basically make something out of myself and become successful and I know that education is a huge part of that. Though I am more focused on medicine-related topics, I do believe that learning physics will help me out in the long run. Being able to at least have basic understanding in a subject such as physics will be helpful seeing as physics is something that we encounter everyday, and we just don't know it. I also know that in my case that physics will continue to show up in health/medicine- related subjects. The MCAT is one of those places that I know that physics will appear in and I do plan on taking that test in the future, so this class is considered to be a step that I need to be closer to that goal.

My goals are to become a physical therapist. My goals to achieve that are to finnsh school and then maybe take a gap year and then go to DPT school, hopefully UCSF. This class will help me get there since its a requirement for DPT school as physics as physics helps with kinesiology related topics like bio mechanics, physiology, neurology, blood flow, etc. Its important concepts that make everything else make sense.

Personally, this class is a degree and post-grad school requirement as I am required to take 2 semesters of physics. Some of my academic schools are to get a good score on my dental admissions test and to be able to be accepted to dental school. After that, I want to specialty in periodontics. In order to do this I need to pass this physics 2 class with a good grade, preferably an A. Before I took my physics classes I was not really aware of how much physics ties into everything of not just the health care profession field but even everything you do in every day life. I thought physics was mainly space and gravity related but it involved everything outside of that. That is why learning and locking into this physics class will be beneficial in my future goals in not just sports but for my academic and profession goals.

My personal goals are split within sections. My long-term goal is just like everyone else. Longterm, I want to have a good stable job and be able to provide and support my family. Nowadays, it is very difficult to survive on a salary of five figures within a major metropolitan area in the US. However, before all of that, my short-term goals must be met first. I need to graduate from SFSU with a major in biology, then apply to physician assistant school. I am hoping to attend a school on the east coast as that is where a majority of my family and significant other is located. Even before this can be achieved, I need to get better grades than my last semester. So far, I am doing really well with my schedule adjustments and excelling within physics 2. Physics applies to many fields and aspects of life that should be known by all. It can be used in many applications and not just used to go to medical or graduate school.

My goal is to graduate this semester. I understand that it would be difficult given how much I have gone through - failing and retaking classes, finding it difficult to attend or even do the work, and not feeling a sense of accomplishment despite fulfilling requirements - but I still look forward to attempt at being on track. If I could draw out my journey, the expected linear line of progress would have a looping line behind it representing the true progress. Other goals I have in mind are deciding to pursue all of the following: dermatology, pharmacy, and nursing. There are varying levels of all three and thats what excites me, is that there are different ways to approach my goals. This physics course has encouraged me to look forward to the future of these fields. This class can help me achieve my goals as it will provide a way to be able to get my major done, it will also help me because it will teach me things that will help me better undertand how biology works. As a cell bio major I have gotten told that the fundation is chemistry, however, the fundation to understanding chemistry is understanding physics, therefore I must be able to do well since if I don't do well than I risk not getting an A in this class which is something that I constanly think about. Therefore, passing this class with an A is the key to getting reaching my overall goal.

My long term future goal is to become a trauma surgeon, emergency room physician, or a physician scientist. No matter what specific area i go into they are all related to medicine. After undergrad, i hope to be prepared to start medical school. Physics two lecture and lab are prerequisite courses for most medical schools and they will teach my the skills necessary to be successful in medical school. From this class I will learn the basics to then go into the harder stuff. I will also learn what study mechanisms work best for me and will help me be as successful as I can be. This is a time for me to be open minded and willing to try anything.

My biggest goal right now is to finish my biochemistry degree and get into dental school. Ive wanted to be a dentist since I was a kid, and everything Im doing. studying, working in the lab, and improving my skills is to make that happen. Its not always easy, but thinking about my future keeps me motivated, even when things get stressful. I know the path to dental school takes a lot of hard work, so Im trying to build good habits now, like managing my time better and staying organized. I think this class can help by teaching me how to think more critically, solve problems, and communicate better. Those are all skills Ill need for dental school and my future job. Learning how to explain my ideas clearly, work with others, and stay focused under pressure will definitely help me in the long run. Also, writing like this helps me stay focused on why Im working so hard. My goal is to obtain my biochemistry degree in hopefully 4 years while staying in the school's cross country/track team. This class will help me achieve this goal as it is one of the classes I need to do get to that point. My goal is to pursue a career in neuroscience, specifically focusing on dementia and brain research. Watching him struggle with this disease has shaped my perspective on life, memory, and the importance of scientific advancements in brain health. I want to contribute to research that helps people like him and families like mine. This class is a stepping stone toward that goal. Understanding biology, physiology, and the fundamental mechanisms of the body, including the brain, is crucial for my future studies. Every piece of knowledge I gain brings me closer to making a difference in this field. More than just facts and theories, this class helps me think critically and problem-solve skills I will need when tackling complex neurological questions. Beyond academics, this class also reminds me why Im doing this in the first place. It connects me to my purpose, reinforcing that my studies are not just about passing exams but about making a meaningful impact.

Honestly, staying focused through the end of the semester is tough, especially in a class like physics where concepts keep building on each other. At this point, motivation starts fading, and its easy to feel overwhelmed. One thing that helps me is breaking everything down into smaller goalslike focusing on just one problem at a time instead of stressing over an entire chapter. Also, reminding myself why Im taking this class in the first place helps. Even if physics isnt my favorite subject, I know its important for my bigger academic and career goals. Another strategy is finding ways to make studying more engaging. Study groups help a lot because talking through problems with others makes it easier to understand (and keeps me accountable). Changing my study environment also helpssometimes just moving to a new spot makes a difference in my focus. And honestly, taking breaks is important too. If I try to push through exhaustion, I just get frustrated and stop absorbing anything. A short walk, a snack, or even just five minutes away from my screen helps me reset. At the end of the day, I just remind myself that Im already halfway throughmight as well finish strong

Itll also help me not get into bad habits. If I get into the habit of prioritizing other things over school, then it will be harder to get back on track. Not only to catch up with all missing assignments or studying last minute for exams, but to find the motivation to do so. School can be difficult sometimes and after stopping its harder to be able to start in the middle vs at the beginning of the semester.

At this point in the semester, Im definitely starting to feel the burnout. Its tough to stay motivated when were so close to the end but still have so much left to do. This school year has been really hard on me both mentally and physically. It just seems like every aspect of my life (personal, athletic, school, work) is going wrong. To stay focused through the end of the semester, Im setting clear, realistic goals for each week. I break big tasks into smaller steps and use a planner to prioritize what needs to get done each day. Im sticking to a routine that includes focused study blocks, regular breaks, meals, workouts, and enough sleep. To avoid distractions, I study in a clean, dedicated space and use apps that help me stay off social media. Im also holding myself accountable by checking in with a friend or mentor weekly. To stay motivated, I remind myself of my end goals whether its a certain grade or just finishing strong. I celebrate small wins to keep my momentum going, and when I feel overwhelmed, I take quick breaks and try to be kind to myself. Most importantly, I keep reminding myself why I started and how far Ive come it helps me push through.

The role of AI in stem is to help make the tasks and accomplishments of the student easier. What is the role of AI in STEM? How can I ethically and productively use AI as a student? Hello, I came in late; I was seeing my friend from Japan. I don't know the answer to this question, but I think AI should be used to answer genial questions. As a student I use it to answer questions I have about assigned readings. I think AI is miss used when we use it to answer the homework questions for us instead of clarifying questions or formula questions. AI is a great resource, but it can also hinder education depending on its use, so students should try to limit its use. I actually want to go into AI research for my masters, currently one of my professors is working in AI and told us a lot of fascinating /worrying things about AI. Thank you for reading :)

In STEM fields, AI is often used for problem-solving, data analysis, automation, or to give ideas. STEM field student use AI to assist them in doing their assignments and projects as they can get stuck on a problem/situation that needs more information for them to understand. However, AI can cause errors in its calculations, and we would have to evaluate its output and check if its calculations are accurate. In addition, many students can use it to complete assignments without understanding the assignment completely. We can ethically use AI by not copying its output and pasting it onto any homework assignment and calling it our work. Instead, we should use AI for suggestions on how to continue, start, and end our work. We can also use AI to give us more information about the task at hand while making sure it can cite sources where it gets its information.

AI helps in STEM by providing help to solve difficult problems and also expanding on basically any subject. It also helps give more accurate data and analysis on many subjects. AI can also help students learn faster by summarizing notes. It can also make life easier by organizing tasks, checking grammar, and helping with research. Also, if you're taking hard engineering classes, AI can help you find easier ways to solve math problems and debug codes.

The role of AI in STEM should be to help expand thoughts and ideas of topics some may find difficult to comprehend or are confusing. You can ethically and productively use AI by not using it to just search up answers, but to use it when you need clarification on topics or parts youve missed are have trouble understanding. AI is a tool that can also be wrong, so its only so helpful as to consider outlines of subjects, and you may or may not need to search elsewhere for more in-depth explanations to the subjects you are searching. For example, sometimes I can get stuck on pieces of code for HW. Instead of just searching for the solution to my problem and copy/pasting, I instead use AI to help explain the parts Im missing and give hints as to what I may be able to implement to fix the issue Im having. It can be used as a good trouble-shooter before looking else-where.

I use AI to help me when I have questions that I don't understand. I don't use AI everytime, because I don't want to rely on using AI.

The role of AI in STEM is to offer the tools for data analyzing and problem solving. With their tools, we can just plug them in and will give us the solution that we cant solve.
