It can also help increase the speed at which you learn at, since it is basically a teacher, you can ask it infinite questions and it can help teach you in different ways. It allows you tostupid questions to be asked without being judged which can help any students regardless of how shy they are.

As a student I can ethically use AI to gauge my understand of concepts and gather resources for increase my understanding. I do not believe that AI should be relied on, nor do I think that it has the same capacity to be taught the nuances of human experience even with extensive training and constantly evolving models. - started late, my laptop was having trouble, sorry!

AI is a tool. The only potential issue with AI is that it helps too much. Which softly restricts the human mind. If every time, where we were troubled or stumped, we would turn to ChatGPT or chegg or some other tools. Then we will never learn critical thinking, we will restrict our own mind and only learn to memorize and copy over texts. What AI currently fails to do is give meaning and have understanding of a topic. In STEM, our work, engineering, medicine, sciences(biology/physics/chemistry), and mathematics help us to understand and benefit the world. Students can use ChatGPT in moderation.

AI can have many roles in STEM. One example can be for faster and more effective data analysis. Since AI can do tasks more effectively than a human, it can help us detect things we cant see with our own eyes and can turn hours of work into a couple of minutes. Using AI can have its ups and downs because it gathers information from different sources, that can be reliable or not, and puts it all in text. This can be bad because the information can be wrong or not accurate. To ethically use AI as a student, we can look up things we are confused about and use it as a way to help understand it a lot better. So instead of using AI to use it word for word, we can use some of the ideas and get a better understanding by doing more research on the topic.

I think AI can definitely have a role in STEM. AI's role in STEM should be that of a work checker for small mistakes in our calculations or to bring up multiple points and perspectives on how to solve a problem. The artificial intelligence we have today cannot reliably answer complex equations and even if future AI models can, we should not rely on them. For one, there will always be something wrong with it and a problem can have too many factors involved in it that explaining it to an AI could be complicated. Aside from solving equations, AI should not be trusted when dealing with ethical issues in STEM. Due to these reasons, AI should 'augment' us rather than replace us. With this mindset, a student can use AI to help understand complex topics while not relying on it heavily. We should use AI scarcely so we can keep developing and growing as a student.

I dont know. I feel like I dont know enough about the capabilities of AI to answer this question. What is it even used for besides writing and drawing? It cant be reliably used as a search engine, I know that. What other kinds of AIs are there? Self-driving cars arent really a thing yet. As far as I know, right now, AI is only really relevant to the people who create it.

In STEM, AI is used for many things including, writing essays, doing math problems and other similar things that include completeing our assignments. Even I personally need the help of AI at times because a certain math problem isn't clear to me and I need some guidance for what to do next. But because of how accessible AI is and how it can give answers to students just by inputting a prompt and pressing the button, many students rely on it to do all their work. In order to ethically and productively use AI as a student, we can begin by only using it for guidance and not to complete the work for us. By utilizing the AI as a guide it will allow us to better understand what we are trying to do, while not reaching a dead end due to no access to help. And prevent us from becoming lazy to a point where we are unable to do any work for ourselves.

In my opinion, the role of AI in STEM is to make certain things easier, and this applies to other areas as well and not just STEM. For example, let's look at ChatGPT and what its role is. ChatGPT has answers to literally everything and anything you ask it. Whether it's like the easiest thing like finding out when sunset is going to be to a really advanced mathematical formula that you have been stuck on for a while. To ethically and productively use ChatGPT, you need to understand that just getting the answer isn't going to help but you will have to fully understand it and ask for explanations. This will help when you are taking an exam or even in the real world. For example, if I just look up a certain part of a code that I need for my program, I can get the answer but when I get the same problem in the exam, I will get stuck. And when my employer asks me to demonstrate how to write this line of code, I won't know how to because I copied it from ChatGPT.

The role of AI in stem is to help people such as students or even experienced people understand new things since there is always something new going on in the world. You can easily ask AI anything and it can answer complex question in a matter of seconds or even ask for simple things such as a recipe. Us as a student can use AI to check if we did our homework the right way, ex as a CS major I can ask AI if I have any errors on a code and ask it how I can go on to fixing the code. I can even ask AI how I can start an assignment if i'm confused about it. Another way I could think of is using AI to find resources for classes.

The role of AI in STEM is to ease lives, solving problems in ways that are unique, having the whole internet to based of the thinking off. I can ethically and productively use AI as a student by making gathering resources easier, using it as a helper, by making sure that give credit where it's due.

AI plays a role in STEM by being able to help with problem-solving, automating tasks, and analyzing data. In computer science, it can assist you with coding and debugging, while in science and engineering, it could help you with research, modeling, and simulations. AI is also useful in math for calculations and predictions. As a student, I can use AI to learn productively by getting explanations, summarizing information, and organizing my thoughts. It can also help improve my writing and check my understanding. However, to use AI ethically I cannot rely on it to do all the work for me, I have to make sure I actually understand the material, and avoid plagiarism. It is also important to verify AI-generated information for accuracy. When used ethically and responsibly, AI can be a helpful tool for learning and problem-solving.

The role of AI in stem recently i think has been used in wither one of 2 ways: 1 as a tool to do more monotonous work like administrative work or like course scheduling. As a student there's a plethora of way to use it unethically like having AI do your entire assignment or parts of the assignment by plugging in the prompt your originally supposed to be doing. Ethically there are ways to use it without having it pump out the answers or making it do all of the work. I personally use Ai as more of a study tool. I will write my own notes and organize them, once that is done I will have Ai create flashcards or turn my notes into a podcast solely based on my own notes. You could also use it to create practice problems based upon the subject you are doing; or even be used to create a study schedule.

I think AI can be used as a tool because they can help me understand more on what I am struggling with. For example, I can use AI to understand why I am stuck on a problem by giving my answer to AI. The AI will give me some steps on what I have been missing when I approach the problem. This can help me get a better understanding on what I did wrong and use for feedback so I can learn from mistakes. I can also use AI to help me understand some topics that I am not strong on. For example, if I am struggling with doing something related to calculus, I can ask AI to give a small review on the topic so I can use them during my time working with STEM courses. I think using AI can help me learn more during my STEM courses by giving quick reviews on past topics and steps on how to fix mistakes instead of copying.

We are in a point in time where we have to be extremly careful of what we use AI for. In terms of STEM it is important to know that you can't rely on AI to solve all your problems because it is inaccurate and isn't neceserly made to solve difficult problems. At best, AI can be used as an organization tool and to answer simple guiding questions but it should not be doing your work for you. AI is a program made by other stem people and you shouldn't rely on their work to do yours because then you're not adding anything to the community.

What I do when life gets challenging is to pray, meditate, calm my mind, make myself understand that pressure and challenges are all opportunities to rise. If it were easy, everyone would do it. To be focused and calm during tough times is a sign of good discipline. In my religion, Sikhism, there is a saying to always remain in Chardikala. Chardikala means to always remain in high spirits at all times, even in times of adversity. To always remain positive even in negative times. Its a state of mind and a state of being that requires years and years of practice. To be able to smile, genuinely, when a relative passes away, when things dont go your way, when you didnt get the job you wanted, when you didnt get the grade you wanted. Etc etc. Once you have reached this state, there is nothing that can defeat you.

When life gets challenging, there are many ways I deal with the pressure or feeling of being overwhelmed. One thing I love to do and have such easy access with, is the beach and walking or sitting during sunset. I'm lucky enough to be living in the Outer Sunset and have such easy accessibility to the beach whenever because it really relieves any sort of stress in life that I'm enduring. Another way I like to deal with my challenges in life is head-on and apply myself to whatever situation I'm going through. Allowing myself to take a step back and focusing how to process in the most healthy and fluent way.

Usually when life gets challenging, I try to indulge in the little things such as drinking tea in the morning because it is a small act/ritual that energizes me. I might also sometimes eat a little snack, or do something fun like applying nail strengthener on my nails. Little acts of affordable self care bring me down to earth. I also like to spend time with my friends when life gets challenging academically because I realized sometimes talking to people really gets my mind off the stress. I mostly find a lot of my stress in academics, so sometimes to counter that academic stress, I go on notion and just sit down with all the things I need to do. Writing things down helps me feel more relieved when I have to manage my time with all my assignment deadlines. Sometimes also stressing with friends in a group study session at the library also helps

What do I do when life gets challenging? Usually I attempt to break the challenge down into segments to complete it. Somewhere at the beginning I exhibit some self destructive behaviors in the since that I stall or avide the activity in the hopes that it will go away. When I get overwhelmed or feel like i'm drowning I take a break then eventually return to the activity. When I get confused or feel like its to much to do by myself I go to tutoring or go to the teachers office hours.

I found a weird pattern when things get challenging in life. Some days I would not want to commit to the challenge and want to do nothing. On other days, I shrug it off and try to overcome the obstacle. I think it has to do with my emotions in some way. If I am drained, I would not do it and hold it off until the last moments. If I am not and feel productive, I would challenge myself to get through the situation and overcome it. But sometimes, I do not do things if it affects how others look at me. I understand that I should not care what others think, but I always had to fear being an outcast, which always puts me in a spot where I do not want to leave my comfort zone. But I always put off challenges in my life until the end due to having more of a drive to do so.

When life gets challenging there is many things I do or at least try to do. The first thing I do is get away from the thing or situation that is getting me upset or frustrated. Then I do other things to distract myself like going out on a walk to catch some air, spending some time with my family, playing some video games with my friends, going out to eat, hanging out with my friends, going to the mall, and clean around the house. Overall, I just try to distract myself with things I love to do and be with people that make me happy. Lastly, the best thing to do when life gets challenging is to rest or catch up on some rest.

When things go wrong, I tell myself that I've lived through hard times before and I still existed. I try to step back and breathe, even when everything feels too much. Sometimes, I enlist the aid of my family and friends, hoping that even a short conversation will be helpful and actually it is . When I get stuck, I go for a walk, listen to some music, or write down my thoughts in order to clear my head. Academically, when things get tough, I break down my work into segments so that it is not as hard to handle. I remind myself of why I'm here and why I'm hanging in there with my classes and that continues to motivate me. I know that I can always seek help from professors or fellow classmates if I'm having a hard time, and there's no shame in struggling. Above all, I attempt to remind myself that difficulty is not permanent. Even on my worst days, I realize that I possess the strength to keep moving forward. I just need to keep moving one step at a time.

When life gets challenging, its best to take one step at a time and plan things to make your life adaptable to the challenge, or less challenging. Finding resources to support yourself is important. There are so many aspects of life that can be challenging. For example, life can get challenging when you are enduring a hard workload, whether thats from your job, school, or both. Creating a list to figure out what to do and when can alleviate the stress. Journaling your frustrations and keeping a daily/weekly/monthly planner can be helpful to plan out when to do everything. Now, if there are financial troubles, you can find many resources that can help you get through life. There are government and state incentives that help those who are struggling making a living. If you are in school, many universities have helpful incentives, like food pantries and assisted payments.

When my life get challenging, I will play video games to relax and go outside to take a walk. I think if I want to pass a challenge then I should have a good emotion first. Trying different ways to solve the challenge of ask someone to help when necessary. Facing a challenge is one of the part of our life, I will try my best to solve the challenge then if I have a same question or challenge I can solve it easier. Learning from the challenge is important, we should learn something from the challenge and do better next time.

When life gets challenging, Ill just leave the house and spend time with friends and/or be on call with my girlfriend. These two are mainly the two things that are my getaway from life/work/school. And sometimes Ill just go out on my own, just to be alone enjoying the SF weather and views. I tend to forget whatever thats happening in the world to escape reality. Before college, I would play volleyball at an open to get away from any hard situations Im in.

When life gets challenging I usually rise to the occasion, meaning I do what needs to get done to come out successful, that usually entails working a bunch rather than giving myself time to relax. When midterms roll around I usually prepare heavily and come out okay. I feel like If I constantly was under this amount of pressure I would be a lot more productive. That being said it does take a toll on someone to be under constant stress so. If Im under a bunch of stress Ill make sure that my eating habits and exercise stays in tact so that I have a healthy mindset when Im facing hardships.

When life gets challenging I tend to use a lot of tools to support my efforts and rely on the support I have around me to keep me motivated. Breaking down bigger goals into more manageable tasks to help with the feelings of being overwhelmed has consistently helped, but I know that life is not always as predictable. Currently, I am working though health concerns with a packed class and work schedule. I try my best to maintain a standard of well-being that will allow me to persist though deadlines and trust that I know the limits of my abilities and what I am capable of. In the midst of unpredictable and ever-changing schedules, I am simply along for the ride and hope that the joy and interest that got me here will continue to act as a driving force and eventually, I know that I would be able to enjoy the process and journey too.

When life gets challenging, I find solutions to the problems that are creating the challenges. If I don't have the resources to the figure out a solution to the problem by myself, I'd probably look to an external resource, like friends or family.

When life gets challenging, or when I face something challenging in my life, I simply slow down and try to make sense of a situation. Take each step forward slowly, retrace my steps if I have to/am able to. Education is a simple example of this, when I get stuck on a topic, I try to make sense of what I learned and what I will learn. And by understanding the foundation and fundamentals more. You can make sense of beyond that. Live by the quote; Life is only unfair if you make it unfair. If you start being unfair to the world, like businesspeople are. You will have a much easier time.

When life gets challenging, I try to find ways to make it easier through splitting up the work or looking for support. For example, when it gets challenging school wise, I try to organize my different assignments and prioritize anything that is upcoming. Being organized really helps me calm down and helps me realize that maybe the workload i'snt too much. I also really try to get things done early to make sure I never get tot he point where I have many assignments due soon and I am rushing to get them done. Some ways I cope when life gets challenging is by listening to music, distracting myself a little to calm down, or I do something that I enjoy.

When life gets challenging, I like to calm down and escape my situation for a bit. Lots of problems and challenges sometimes overwhelms me and I get lost and unsure on what my next step should be. To do this, I play games as they offer a quick and easy way to distract myself and get my mind in a better place. Other times, I go outside to play soccer and get exercise. I really like going outside and playing soccer because I play until I get really tired and then my mind clears up and stops thinking for a while. This gives me a bit of peace in my mind and after a cold shower, I often feel refreshed and ready.

Normally when things get challenging I panic and retreat from the world. What Im supposed to do is ask for help, but Im really bad at that. What I want to do is lock in and figure it out myself, but Im bad at that too. I need to get better at staying calm and be more organized.

Personally when I reach a point where life gets challenging, I would typically spend some time doing things that help me relax and allow for time to refocus on the challenge with a refreshed mind. For these things that allow me to relax, it's commonly listening to some music or just doing some other activity that will keep my mind off of worrying about any difficulties. Once I have had what I feel to be enough time away from the issue, I take another look at it to see if I'm now able to look at it more calmly and find it to be less challenging now. If that isn't the case, I now go to someone I've known for a long time and speak with them to see if they have any advice with the specific challenge I have or anything general for dealing with challenges. After reaching this point the challenges in my life at the time seem to have been solved and I can go back to living my life as I usually would.

When life gets challenging, I go through a series of events, which I realized I can't change because that's just how I am. The first stage is overthinking. I start overthinking about that one certain problem and then it leads to a chain reaction of me thinking about other possible things I could be overthinking about. After that, I try to distract myself by doing something I really enjoy like gaming. But at some point that also gets boring and I move onto the next step, which is actually trying to get a solution to fix the problem. For example, if I am worried about my grade in a certain class, I will start studying and reviewing the curriculum. I am usually able to go smooth from there but in between I get distracted again and will start gaming or just be on my phone. At some point, I realize how deep of a challenge it is and then I get back on track.

When life gets hard, I like to take a step back from everything for a while. Drop whatever i'm doing and do something to take my mind off of things such as go to the gym, go out with friends or play some video games with my friends. I think if i'm left alone it makes things worse so doing things with others helps me realize you should enjoy the moment and not worry too much about whatever was bothering me. Sometimes I also end up doom scrolling on TikTok or instagram reels when I feel like life is getting hard, just another way to take my mind off things although it isn't the best option it helps me in the moment.

When life gets challenging, I listen to music to calm my mind down or I take a nap to not think about it. Also, I remember that this small obstacle is temporary, and that my life could always get worse. I start appreciating what I have and thinking what I would have. I start thinking what makes me happy and start doing it, because thinking too long on your problem is not healthy. Also, solve the problem/challenge, the sooner the faster.

When life gets challenging, I take a step back and think about what Im dealing with. I try to break the problem down into smaller parts so it feels more manageable and so I understand it better. If I have too much on my plate, I figure out what needs to be done first instead of stressing over everything at once. Sometimes, I realize that the problem isnt as bad as it seems once I look at it more clearly. Other times, I know I just have to push through, but having a plan helps you stay focused. I also remind myself to take breaks. You can always just keep pushing and ignore how exhausted you feel, but I know that never helps in the long run. Stepping away, even if its just for a short time, gives you the energy to keep going. If things feel too overwhelming, there is always someone to talk to, friends, family, or even a professor. Just having someone to talk to makes a difference. No challenge is everlasting, and you have to remind yourself that you've been through hard times before. Even when things can feel impossible, if you take it one step at a time and keep moving forward you will eventually get past it.

When life gets challenging I have few ways to help myself cope. Depending on the issue I will just push through, but more often recently I have been holding space for myself to feel more. For school this might mean that I have too much on my plate; so for example when I feel overwhelmed I like to take a step back and prioritize what i have thats most pressing and and then organize my tasks to correlate with whats due most recently. But since im neurodivergent i have to "work" with my brain thats in a way trying to work against me. If my life in general was getting challenging i would take a different approach; in which again i am fighting against my brain. My first instinct would be to ignore everything and go into a state where i move away from everything, however more recently i have been asking for help which is a bigger and harder step for me.

When life is challenging for me, I sometimes take a break and drink some water or go hiking outside for air. For example, if I need a break from work I can go outside for a hike and also drink water. Another way I can get some support when life is challenging for me is getting help during class. If I am stuck on a problem during my lab experiment, I can ask my peers for help so I can understand more on the problem and the solution. I can also ask the professor if I need more support on the problem. If I am asking for help, I can be less stressed on trying to solve the problem by myself. I have a lot of ways I can try to be less stressed when life is challenging like asking for help and also going on hikes sometimes so I can be more comfortable.

Something that I do when life gets challenging is work out. Weather thats a walk, run or a quick workout some for of excersise always helsp clear my mind and balance my emotions. Something else that helps is reading. I use reading as a form of distraction and it allows me to momentarily forget about all my stress and problems. I think these tools are helpful during stressful times like midterms or exams.

The values of my family have helped me through my journey through college by making me focus on confronting weaknesses. Its challenging and can be tough on people going to college. My family prepared me for that and made sure not to sugar coat anything. My community has helped me apply my mindset from basketball, I used to play professionally, into my college journey. The mindset to always practice and keep on practicing. The idea that your one dot and there are a million more dots in just this state alone, that want to be in the same position youre trying to be in. Imagine the country and then the world. You have to always put 110% on and off the court.

From a young age my family taught me the importance of discipline and being patient and its helped me in my academic life as well as my personal life. A lot of my personal life habits bleed onto my academic life such as learning how to be calm in deadlines and how to curate an environment for myself that doesn't allow me to stress. My dad in general is a very calm person and always had a collected way of speaking. I've learned to value having a gentle voice towards others and myself and I think because of that, I am not too critical. My mom is a very hardworking person so seeing her be ambitious and always working hard, makes me want to work hard. In academics, I haven't always been naturally as talented or smart but seeing my mom be hardworking and my dad be calm, Ive learned that you can achieve any academic goal with those values. Not everyone is super smart but anyone can work hard in order to become smarter. And my dad's strength in his calmness and patience allows me to find a kind voice within myself whenever I struggle or stress academically.

I am not sure if any values from my community or my family have helped me navigate through college. College has been a different experience for me than my experience from primary school to high school. The values that I have been given about equality, honesty, and selflessness have been not useful at all in the slightest. It made me some friends and such, but in all honesty, it hasn't affected my education or communication in any way. I feel like everyone has been walking their own life and doing their own things to get by and graduate with a degree. The only things that I felt were still kept are being respectful to others and doing things responsibly. However, I feel like that is broad as we find these two values to be needed for our day-to-day lives. Either way, these two values have helped a lot with keeping a neutral and passive tone when talking to others.

Being with my family it has taught me the benefit of hard work, and why we need to keep learning for our entire lives. If you you enjoy the process of learning and keep learning throughout your life, you will be able to solve problems with ease as you age.

Throughout my life, while growing up, I was always told that working hard and trying your best at anything will help you accomplish your goals. Now that I am in college, I can see that it is true that if you put in the hard work, you can complete anything. Going to college for me was a really big deal since I am the first in my family to ever go to college. This mindset has helped me navigate through college because whenever I feel lazy and start lacking in work, I always think back so I can get my motivation back. Also, now that I am in college, my goal is to finish my 4 years and get my bachelor's degree by trying the best that I can and always remembering what I was told, working hard will help you accomplish your goals.

Being an international student has made my familys values even more important in helping me navigate college. One of the biggest values theyve instilled in me is resilience. Moving to a new country for school is challenging , adapting to a different culture, academic system, and even daily life can feel overwhelming at times. But my family has always taught me to keep going, even when things feel unfamiliar or difficult. That mindset has helped me push through moments of doubt and homesickness. Another value I hold close is independence. Since Im far from home, Ive had to learn how to take care of myself in ways I never had to before , managing responsibilities, making decisions on my own, and figuring out solutions when problems arise. At the same time, theyve taught me the importance of staying connected. Even though Im far away, I know I have their support, and that gives me strength. Ive also learned to build a sense of community here, finding friends and mentors who help me feel at home. These values remind me that while being an international student is tough, its also an opportunity for growth, and I have the tools to navigate it successfully.

Some values that my family and community have helped me navigate through college are compassion, responsibility, and gratitude. I am still learning these, but they are important in creating lifelong lessons to take with me outside of college. I have, in some ways, learned to be more compassionate towards my peers and faculty. I am learning what responsibility means in a college setting, and how important it is, especially as a new adult learning the way of the world. I express more gratitude in college than I have previously, as I know now that education is a privilege to have and that alone can be good motivation to keep going, even on off days. It is a privilege to learn from this faculty, to sit and learn with my peers, and to get my degree. I want this values to carry on with me into the next phase of life.

I'm the the first person that go to college in my family. My family support me when I need help, they always want to do something good for me. For example; support me with financial and emotional, they are the important part of my life. I need them to help me to graduate college, also I need to learn more things from college and help them in the future.

The values of my familys origin helped me navigate through college by how they got to America. The struggles that my ancestors had to go through in order to get to the US was terrific. My ancestors helped fought along the US military in the Vietnam war and Secret war which is how my people was brought to the US. I used this as my motivation because of the how work and dedication to fight for their own freedom. Just hearing stories of how they got to the US makes me think to do my very best in school even if theres obstacles/challenges.

The value I put on friends and family have helped me get through college because I have people to rely on whenever I need help. If I need help academically I can ask friends Ive made in class to help me, if I need more help with pressure and expectations my family is there to help provide that. Also it helps that my family doesnt make me pay rent which allows me to work on my studies more. Without the value of family college would become extremely hard to keep up with, Id have to work full time while also being a student full time. There would be no time for socializing which is also a detriment to my learning as I can form study groups with friends. Ultimately the value of family and friendship has allowed me to manage college in a healthy way.

The values of my community and my family have always lingered in the back of my brain throughout my academic journey, well before college. There had always been a distinct value and emphasis placed on education, especially since neither of my parents attended higher education once receiving their high school diplomas. Unfortunately, it often felt that my educational milestones were no longer accomplishments and that "good" academic performance was the standard. While I've taken a few steps back and around certain areas of my life, my family is finally at the point of trusting that I know my abilities and what am able to and willing to do within the system of education. While it has taken a while to get there, I am able to balance my academics with working and the creating the lifestyle I was for myself outside of my career too. Overall, a much better approach than the forced expectations that I'd been living prior reaching this clarity and area to prioritize my routines and lifestyle.

The only value that my family and community has taught me that also translates to college is working hard doesnt mean you are working well, but its still work. Running into a wall constantly in your life, you might be demoralized. Just stay at it. Trying to do something new might take courage, but actively doing the same thing over and over takes strength.

I think one of the values in my community that has helped me through college is to be persistent no matter what. It gets very hard at times and when you feel overwhelmed, sometimes you want to just leave it all behind and just run away. My family and really everyone in my community doesn't just give up or even postpone it, they keep pushing through no matter the extent of the effort they will have to put in. Even if it means sacrificing somethings, they will push and won't give up until they reach their destination. During my childhood, I was always taught to value this core trait and I still do because it has helped me during school up until this point.
Fuck idk. Ketamine helped me get here, not my values Uhhhhh I guess my family values hard work, but Im not a hard worker. I just try my best to balance what I want to do with what I have to do.

Since starting college the Fall 2024 semester, my family and friends have helped with guiding me onto a path for myself that I am content with. While applying for classes last semester, I was unsure of what it was exactly I wanted to do in college to prepare for the future when I would have to find a job to make a living. My friends and family who knew me well were able to provide some advice and guidance as to what they think I should do to begin my time in college. From my family, mostly my parents, they recommended I take more classes that would cover GE requirements and worry more about my major classes later on. This was quite the helpful advice as I was still unsure at the time what major I wanted to focus on. As for my friends, some of them are following a similar path in college as I had decided for, so we were able to consult each other for our experiences and what we thought to be best for how to navigate through college.

The values of my community and family have really helped me navigate through college. Growing up in a North Indian family, I have learned many values that have helped me in college. My parents always taught me the importance of hard work and discipline. They believe that education is the key to success, so they encouraged me to stay focused and never give up, even when studies get difficult. My family also values respect and responsibility. Because of this, I know how to manage my time, complete my assignments on time, and stay organized. In my community, there is a strong sense of togetherness. Whenever I feel stressed or homesick, I can always talk to my family or friends for support. Their encouragement gives me confidence to keep going. Another important value is patience. College has many challenges, but I have learned to stay calm and keep trying. These values help me stay strong, motivated, and positive as I work toward my goals.

Ever since I was young I was told that hard work is the key to success, doesn't matter if you have talent or not. If you have talent but don't work hard you only ever get so far in life so in order to succeed you have to put in effort in everything you do. I was taught to never quit and because of that I've gotten this far in life. Another thing is my mom has always told me to be responsible. Decide whats best for you and don't let anyone else tell you otherwise because at the end of the day only you know whats best for you. These are just 2 of many things I was taught ever since I was little and has helped me get through a lot in life.

My family and community have taught me values that help me to navigate through college. Hard work is one of the values I have learned, because I was raised to believe that if I put in the effort, I will see it in the results. This can help you stay motivated even when you feel overwhelmed. Another value is independence, which I was always encouraged to have. To try myself before asking for help, which is something I appreciate learning and use today. In college, it helps you take responsibility for your learning, your time, and to be able to get through it when things are tough. But at the same time, it is important to know you can ask for help and support when you need it. Helping each other is important, and its a good reminder that you are not alone, and you don't have to do everything by yourself. Being able to talk to someone, knowing that you have support help you stay stable and keep moving forward.

For me personally i am the first person in my family to go to college so its been interesting to say the least. They have been emotionally supportive in the i will cheer for you from afar type of way. Especially since i a nontraditional student i dont even live with my parents or with my family so it can be a little isolating when it comes to school and my family. As far as my community it mirrors revlatively the same way. My friends from high school or my cousins didnt go to college so it can be iosolating when i think or feel overwhelmed there a lack of empathy. Thankfully i have one person who knows what im dealing with or going through, my partner grew up the same way as me, in a lower income tax bracket so its pretty easy to rely on him, which can be a lot to take on since that would mean he is my entirre support system. But i have created a network of friends on campus that i am more comfortable relying on as a community.

My family has helped me navigate through college by finding scholarships for me and also helping me fill out the FAFSA so I can get aid to help with my tuition. During my time in SF state, my peers also helped me navigate through college. For example, talking to peers who take the same major as me about what classes I should take so I can be able to get my degree. This can also help me with my classes I am taking such as work that I am struggling on in class and can discuss on a solution. I am thankful that I have my peers and my family helping me getting through college without any stress on where to find help.

I think that my family has played a big role in my succes in college. They have taught me the importamce of education and the pathways that it can open for me. They have also taugh me the importance of dedication and that if i start something I have to finish it no matter what. These are all great qualities to have as a college student and I hope to learn more from them as I continue my time at SFSU.
