Overall, it is a way to better understand the science behind how things move in the world around me.

My goal for this class is to apply the knowledge I have learned from the lecture portion into real life. In addition, I would also like to continue practicing finding directions of vectors as well as the magnitude. I want to eventually be able to pass the FE exam for Electrical Engineering and the PE exam for ECSS. I want to create all kinds of systems and electronics, such as robotic prosthetics and audio hardware. I would like to create a strong foundation of knowledge to build up my confidence in my abilities and skills. I am also kind of required to take this class, but, I am looking forward to having fun and exploring new things in physics.

In STEM, Ai can be used for many different things. Ai can make specific problems easier to solve with it or even help students learn in a better way. It helps by identify what problems the students have and gives them more support than a regular person could do within a short amount of time. With the amount of information that is on the internet, AI could actually be a great source to collect that information efficiently and then use it for any assignments or tests that a student would have. Things such as processing data easily and identifying trends, creating and solving highly advanced problems are something that AI can help do. AI can also help teachers by helping them grading assignments and creating newly made problems for students to solve. In the future, AI can become even more advanced and help us even better than it does now.

The role of AI in STEM is so important, that the world is shifting its resources toward the development of AI. AI is being used in all sorts of ways that makes jobs and the application of tools trivial. It's a powerful tool that can provide better insight toward developing other aspects of society. As a student, my use of AI needs to be careful and calculated in order to not take advantage of it in unethical ways. Critical thinking should be my own, but I can use AI to facilitate the development of new thoughts and ideas. AI is able to answer mysteries in STEM way faster than humans, but its humans that need to put those answers into practice. Work should never be copied and pasted from AI, and its important to disclose the usage of it so work may be evaluated on the basis of AI. Ultimately, AI should be used carefully, not to do work, but to help it.

I feel that AI in Stem should be used to assist the learning pathway within STEM, emphasis on assist, since AI has access to a lot of information, it in theory, should be able to explain any sort of concepts that we as STEM students may have during our higher division courses, for example in courses like calculus and physics, some of the concepts may be too confusing for some students to understand, even after reviewing all sorts of material provided by the professor, attending office hours, tutoring, AI in my opinion should be used as an absolute last resort or in an emergency when all of the other resources are exhausted. I personally have never used AI because i've heard of instances where there were mistakes in the output form the AI, this could lead to inaccurate results during a problem that will only cause more problems if the student continues to ignore these errors and just copy pastes the answer.

After week two of this class and of the lecture I believe that physics more than anything helps as a better understanding of the world around and beyond us. There's a reason we've gotten so far in space exploration and in research and that's because thanks to physicists we've been able to explore and understand why gravity works the way that it does and why Earth's gravity behaves the way that it does. Even beyond scientific application I believe that physics also allows us to create any toy, car, or really any product that needs to move or has moving parts because it interacts with physics and the designs need some kind of physics knowledge to make the product usable which is why I believe I still want to stay in this class to also further my knowledge of the world of design and it's connection to physics, and how those two subjects are connected.

AI will revolutionize how STEM scientists approach their research. Even now, before AGI systems exist, AI is an incredible. It can already be used to conduct background research or to solve complex calculations. Thereby not replacing the scientist, but working alongside them. However, some time in the future, AI might be capable to come up with its own scientific questions. Similar to todays's scientists, students should use AI as a tool to facilitate their learning but not to replace it. Using AI to get solutions to problems is useless to the student bacuse the simple copying of work will not help the learning process. It could however be a fantastic assistant similar to a TA or tutor. AI could also be used to brainstorm ideas for essays and presentations.

AI is a powerful tool in STEM. The development of AI is very STEM Based and because of that, it can help STEM related activities. I can ethically use AI when I need some idea generation, or if I need to talk to something to help think. AI can help explain difficult subjects like a person, but is available 24/7. I think that cheating on tests and assessments with AI is very bad and an ineffective use of AI, as people should truly work on learning information by themselves without the help of outside tools. AI can help learn, but should not be a crutch that takes the place of student work. Sometimes, AI can be helpful if someone is tired, and needs some extra support. I remember being too tired one day to figure a math problem out from scratch, and AI helped me explain the answer and process, then I used it to apply to the problem.

The role of AI in STEM has become very prevalent in the last couple of years, especially with it's incorporation in a lot of everyday appliances and devices. The most noticeable boom of AI in STEM, and in general, is definitely in school settings because it's a quick resource that is available 24/7. I can see this first hand, being a stem major myself, as my friends and other peers will use AI applications such as chatgbt or symbolab to solve difficult or tedious equations and homework problems. I feel like these applications can be a very good resource for learning from your mistakes when doing any stem course or class, such as calculus, however, these systems can be easily abused and exploited. I have seen videos online where people will use AI applications to complete online midterms, finals and quizzes. AI has also taken a noticeable advance in companies like Apple, Samsung, and more that all compete with each other in order to have the better application. This competition will only create better versions of AI, but I personally am not a huge fan of it. AI can be used in tandom with society, but it shouldn't become the number one resource.

AI has many applications in STEM, but it can also be negative. Handled appropriately, AI could help research protein structures to develop new medicines, enhance space exploration and radio telescopes in their search, and help engineer new technologies for a better future. Currently, AI is not there to be able to do that. With current AI, as a student, I don't like using AI too much because it stunts my educational learning. It can be useful for feedback and critiques when writing or of thought processes to find ways to be more efficient. As a programmer, AI is helpful when working on my personal projects. It can teach me new things that I would otherwise be completely unaware of. Even then, I try to solve problems on my own and use Google to find what I don't know rather than getting AI to write my entire code for me. Once I gain more understanding of programming, AI will be a much bigger part of my life to quickly code what I already know. I acknowledge that, but I am also slightly repulsed by it because I find genuine joy in writing the code and facing all the challenges associated with it.

I think AI is a very powerful tool that has many uses, some of which are better than others. AI has been helpful to me in explaining things I couldn't quite understand and helping me check my work on various assignments for different courses. It can be used to edit and improve things you've written and fix minor errors in grammar and spelling. That is mostly just for me though. I think were AI is most useful is for running complex simulations or experiments that would be incredibly difficult to do without it, especially efficiently. One I head of most recently was that AI was used and was able to brute force the problem that was something about how proteins folded that we haven't been able to solve for some time. I think the least ethical use of AI is for creative work like art and writing unless artists and writers create things specifically to be used by AI or give permission for AI to be trained on it. It's most useful for refining and checking work as well as running complex simulations and I think this is among the most ethical uses of it as well.

The role of AI in stem is to be used as a tool for students to further understand concepts that they need more help with. Ethically as a student I should use it not to form ideas that are not mine as that would be considered as academically dishonest.

AI is making a huge impact in STEM, changing how we learn and create. Its basically like having a supercharged assistanthelping process tons of data, solve tricky problems, and even push the boundaries of discovery. For me as a student, using AI ethically and productively is a big deal. First off, I need to actually understand how it works instead of just being impressed (or intimidated) by what it can do. That means staying curious, asking questions, and not letting AI do all the thinking for me. The key is to use AI as a tool, not a replacement. Its there to assist, not take over. I need to interpret results, double-check findings, and be mindful of biases in AI systems. Fairness and diversity matter when working with data, and its on me to keep that in check. AI can also boost my learning by tailoring resources to my interests and strengths, but I dont want to fall into the trap of passive learningjust absorbing whatever an algorithm throws at me. I still need to engage, apply what I learn, and ask deeper questions to actually understand the material. Looking ahead, AI is becoming a huge part of careers, so staying adaptable and open to new skills is a must. The field moves fast, and keeping up with it means always being ready to learn. At the end of the day, AI is just a toolits about what I do with it. Whether in STEM or beyond, the goal should always be to solve real problems and make a positive impact.

AI helps in STEM by making data analysis faster, solving complex problems, and improving research in fields like science, engineering, and medicine. It can find patterns, run simulations, and help with big calculations. As a student, I can use AI in a fair and helpful way by using it as a learning tool. I can ask AI for help with research, coding, or understanding data, but I should still learn the ideas myself. I wont use AI to write full assignments without my own work. I will always check if the AI answers are correct and fair. By using AI wisely, I can learn better while staying honest and improving my critical thinking skills.

Artificial Intelligence is used a lot. Everyday we wake up and use it without knowing it, such as either asking your phone for the weather or even opening up your phone with your face. It is truly fascinating yet scary how far artificial intelligence is integrated into our society. In terms of any student pursuing a field within STEM, I believe it is a stellar tool for learning. However, it can be a double-edged sword. For example, an individual can either use it as a way to verify, validate, and gain knowledge of a certain topic, but it can also be used somewhat to perform a certain task without the prior knowledge required. The education system already has a big problem and that is academic integrity. There is a common comparison between two different types of students, which is the student who just gets the right answers but doesnt really understand the concept versus the student who tries to understand first and doesnt really get the right answers every single time. There are many concerns with artificial intelligence since it has made it substantially harder to determine a students retention of knowledge especially within an online learning environment. This does not mean that all students use it as a way to get answers. Personally, I have used ChatGPT during one of my open-note exams in math but it was only to make sure that I am going through the right steps and procedures. As for the mathematical calculations, I had to do it all manually because ChatGPT was unable to perform them correctly and accurately. This was used after referring to my notes and I even scored full points on the open-note final! I even looked at my answers after it was graded and I did not have to use artificial intelligence, but it doesnt hurt taking the time to check and ensure everything is correct. All in all, artificial intelligence is a very useful and powerful tool. However, it is up to the user to determine if it will be a sharpening stone or a crutch.

There is a lot of things that someone can do when life gets challenging. Some of what I like to when life gets challenging would be taking time to relax by myself by reading, sleeping or watching a movie. I also like to play games which is my favorite hobby to do and that helps me forget and relax myself so I don't have to worry about problems that are happening currently. Obviously if you need more help in order to get yourself back on track you can always ask others to give you advice or help. Mental health is really important for not only students but people in general and in order to actively function well and be productive you will need to fix that. There are a lot people that you can ask such as counselors, friends and your parents to help with problems that you have in your life.

Remember why you started. What are your long-term goals? What are you hoping to achieve? When you're feeling lost, it can be helpful to remind yourself of why you started on this journey in the first place. Break down your goals into smaller steps. When faced with a daunting task, break it down into smaller, more manageable steps. This will help you feel less overwhelmed and more motivated to take action. Celebrate your progress. No matter how small, take the time to celebrate your accomplishments. This will help you stay motivated and focused on your goals. Find a support system. Talk to your friends, family, or mentors about your challenges. Having people to support you can make a big difference. Don't give up. There will be times when you feel like giving up, but it's important to remember that everyone faces challenges. What separates successful people from others is their ability to persevere through difficult times.

When life gets challenging, I prefer to take a step back and take a break, starting back up with a fresh mind is a great way for me to become more productive. it's helped in the past for finals week and midterms week since a lot of my courses have exams in sequence over the course of the week, for example, this week I have a calculus and physics quiz in the same week, along with some tests in my engineering programs. instead of cramming for all of them the night before, i try to space out my study sessions in order to get the most effective amount of studying done before my exams take place. this is tricky however because studying does get boring insanely quick, so i tend to get distracted by going on my phone or browsing on my laptop instead of studying, it doesn't help that a lot of my material for my exams are only accessible online, making it easier for me to get distracted.

T-R Last week we are learned the motion of ball, we using the ball to get the information to the table, we are hand on how to catapult the ball out and using ruler to check how for we did, also we using a paper to checking the ball placement. That make me feel a lot of the motion, in a life, we can see many things it have relevant with motion the football, we kick the ball, the ball like we did the catapult the ball, the angle, the power it will improve the football movement trajectory. It applicable to most ball, like the basketball, rugby even the mortar, and I think it very applicable to the mortar, because the mortar also have the same thing with the football and I feel it was good, and we can using the 9.8/s^2 to calculate the speeding and the placement

One example of when life was challenging was whenever I had a big test coming up and I procrastinated so I needed to study more but I only had a few days. When something like this happens, I would usually pull an all nighter once or twice and spend that time studying. Sometimes it does work and I end up doing well on the test but most of the time, it just led to me being tired during the test. I'd still pass but I wouldn't do as well as I know I could.

When life gets challenging I try to do the little things that make me feel better any day of the week things like going out, playing games, or even just reading, and if I'm too busy to dedicate time to myself then I try to appreciate the good things that did happen that day or look forward to the things I can do after. Life is always going to be challenging but I do feel learning to navigate that tough wall of challenge with appreciation for not only myself but for other things that have happened around me can me feel okay with the situation in a way. I feel this is also an important skill because if have no healthy way of navigating the world and it's challenges you could end up with serious burnout or turn out with zero motivation for the things you could in your life, negatively impacting you in the long run.

When life, or course work, gets challenging, I like to step back for a moment. I usually take a short break doing something that is completley unrelated to the thing I am worried about. Afterwards, I my mind is often a lot calmer and more focussed, which makes it easier to think if a plan of action. Then, I try to break the problem down into many tiny, individual steps I can tackle. By ranking and sorting the individual problems by urgency, I get a clear path forward. With such a plan in mind, it becomes significantly easier to assess the problems that hindered me in the first place. When things are too dificult to manage on my own I try to find help either by asking my professors or looking online.

When life gets challenging, I feel myself drift away a little bit. I lose focus and become very isolated. I think that this is how I deal with stress. My usual outlets for dealing with stress are going out, playing video games, or hanging with my friends. If the workload becomes too much and I am not able to do any of these, I isolate myself and dig deep to just finish all of the workload stuff and I dont have time to do anything else. This happens especially when school work becomes difficult and I need to lock in for weeks at a time. This semester has been more difficult and I am adjusting accordingly. With linear algebra being my hardest class and my other easy classes piling on hours of homework, I wasnt able to effectively manage my time so I got super depressed in the beginning of the semester.

When life gets challenging I tend to get discouraged and become very unmotivated when it comes to getting past my current situation and or roadblock. I start to question how I got to that point and become very uncomfortable, stressed, and not at peace. That was my past mentality and way of thinking that honestly still lingers today, but I try to see the challenges that I face and will face with a different perspective. For example, when life gets challenging I try to stay positive by thinking of all the good outcomes and things that I will learn from what I am experiencing. Something that I will remind myself every time I feel hopeless is that I will get past that moment in my life. I like to think back to all the other times in my life where I was challenged and remember that I crossed that hurdle and if I could do it then, I can definitely do it now. I try to also not overwhelm myself by taking life each day at a time so I can give it my undivided attention, however it's still good to think ahead and use that to your advantage when it comes to planning of course.

I really like it when things get challenging. I feel like when things are challenging, they bring out the most in me, and I get to showcase and improve my strengths. At the same time, it can wear me out a lot to be constantly seeking out new challenges so a balance is definitely required. I know that I can do anything as long as I work hard at it and don't give up. Fortunately, I've got determination in abundance as well as stubbornness to keep working on problems until I can see them completed. I'm still open to listening to others' suggestions on how to solve problems. If things don't work out one way, I'm also adaptable to try new things that will hopefully get me to the solution. I'm also aware of other resources that are available, but currently, I don't feel a great need for them, and I enjoy the struggle of not understanding. I think it is also really useful to help out other's who are struggling more because it helps me understand the concepts that I know by finding edge cases where I hadn't thought to try.

I'd say it really depends on what is challenging. I don't really care about much in life, I have a pretty nihilistic view of most things. So if I genuinely care about what is difficult at the moment I will try to figure it out. I will talk to people that I think may be helpful and do what I think would be best for me depending on what the issue is. It also depends how feasible solving the problem feels. If it won't take much time and or effort I will usually try to fix or work through whatever the problem is depending on if it's worth solving. For school I will usually look online or ask friends if they can help and that has worked so far. In general though, like outside of school and just in life, I don't have a great solution. I do have some people I can talk to and whatnot but it can start to get kind of dark which isn't a great combination with my typical nihilism as it tends to lead to a bit of apathy and general lack of any will to do much of anything.

When life gets challenging I usually just try to play things out accordingly. This means looking at my schedule and allotting time to what I need to get done and this usually works for the most part. On the other hand I usually just try to assure myself that things could be harder and I usually come to find that the things I thought were going to be super difficult were actually not that bad.

When life gets challenging, I tend to take a step back and remind myself that Ive been through difficult situations beforeand Ive always made it through. I try to break the problem down into smaller, manageable pieces rather than letting it overwhelm me all at once. Sometimes, I take a deep breath and go for a walk, play my guitar, or just listen to music to clear my mind before coming back to tackle whatever is stressing me out. I also remind myself that I dont have to go through things alone. Whether its friends, family, or even just reaching out to a professor or mentor, I know there are people who are willing to support me if I ask. Thats something Ive had to learn over timeits okay to ask for help. Another thing that helps is staying organized. When things get tough, I try to make a plan or a to-do list so I dont feel lost. Even small progress is still progress. At the end of the day, I remind myself that challenges dont last forever, and as long as I keep moving forward, Ill be okay.

When life gets challenging, I always remind myself why I started and focus on what I can control. When Im struggling with something, I will break things down into smaller steps instead of feeling overwhelmed. I also remind myself that Ive overcome tough times before and will get through this too. Also, leaning on support like friends, mentors, or moments of self-reflection will somehow help to ease my stress. Sometimes, I need to give myself grace and take a break, recognizing that rest is just as important as hard work. Most importantly, I shift my mindset by seeing challenges as an opportunities to grow instead of thinking it as a setback . Every struggle teaches resilience and adaptability, and each time I push through, I come back stronger, knowing I have the tools, mindset, and support to keep going.

When life gets hard I like to disconnect myself and proceed with letting all the thoughts settle down. This kind of feeling is very common and my go-to method for combatting such adversity is to divert my attention towards other things. I have learned time and time again that the best thing to do when faced with such a problem is to step back, especially when I get too emotionally invested. Even still, I continue to make mistakes quite often. I let my emotions run rampant rather than being collected and logical. I think that sometimes it is best to completely step away from all of my responsibilities for the time being. This can be a double-edged sword but it is very important. I believe that mental health is often disregarded, especially at the state of which our society currently resides in. I was scared of seeking professional help as I believed it will take away the opportunities of pursuing a career in the field I dreamt of being in. I finally got the help I needed, but only when my family helped reach out for me. I am very thankful for their decision. I harbored feelings of distrust towards everyone. I realized that just like everyone else even doctors make mistakes and dont know all the answers in the current moment. I have gone through many trials and found that it almost always never worked as planned, but after every single time I believed to be a step closer towards getting better. In the end, I found that it was the result of not being open with my emotions or explicitly stating how I feel in the moment. I would rather walk away without saying anything or just completely lash out a splurge of nonsense. Miscommunication was the main factor for my problems. For example, I would walk away without saying that I just needed space to calm down and regain my composure. Another example would be that I just start yelling out my emotions, which wont let be heard nor be understood. This goes further as I often go into a downwards spiral and I would have to pull out entirely. All in all, I discovered my tendency to disregard myself and prioritize others, which is not entirely a bad thing. Before, I would rather help others succeed instead of helping myself, as I believe that I never deserved the spotlight. As of now, I have been focusing on loving myself more, which helped me realize that many things which happened in my life are for a reason. At the time, I thought that certain things were good and they werent. It also happened vice versa. I started to tear down bonds with people who were only trying to help. During the points of my life where I was at my lowest, I completely cut myself off from everyone as I projected the image of several people onto everyone else. I am grateful and appreciative towards everyone for helping me get this far whether noticed or unnoticed and I hope that this message is heard to those who were unnoticed. I hope to clear up all the misunderstandings and miscommunications and if not I will learn from it and apply this lesson towards everyone moving forward.

With the right amount of values and people that are important in your life, you have the potential to get anything done. Parental guidance offers a huge boost and is a way to guide us through our college careers with giving advice on work or just in general, setting realistic expectations in order to achieve them, and giving personal insight on ways to improve yourself and your studies. The value of community and friends however are a little more different because you can relate to them more than your parents or family. This is because your friends are most likely also in college and may share the same experiences as you. Look to them for guidance with anything that you need help with because in the end friends are a key way to help you get back up on your feet if you are struggling. Depending on your community that you are in, they can also give that same help

Emphasis on Education: Many Chinese families place a high value on academic achievement. This can translate to a strong work ethic, dedication to studies, and a drive for excellence. This value can provide motivation during challenging academic periods. Respect for Elders and Authority: This value can influence your interactions with professors and other academic figures, fostering respectful and productive relationships. This respect can also translate to a willingness to learn from those with more experience. Emphasis on Family and Social Connections: Italian culture often prioritizes family bonds and social interactions. This can lead to a strong support network and a sense of belonging. This can help you build strong relationships with peers and faculty. Passion and Expression: Italian culture is known for its expressiveness and passion. This can translate to enthusiasm for learning and a willingness to engage in discussions and debates. This passion can also help in creative fields of study. Diversity and Openness: San Francisco is a city known for its diversity and open-mindedness. This can create a welcoming environment for individuals with diverse cultural backgrounds. This environment can allow for a rich college experience where you can learn from many different cultures.

Having a family thats willing to support you through college is quite nice because sometimes college can get overwhelming to the point where I feel like nothing is possible. for students that have to commute back home, living at home can remove the extra stress of being home sick if you do dorm at your college. also if your parents major in the same major of your choice, you have an extra person to ask for help in case you don't understand a concept. I ask my dad for help with physics since he is a physics major. My mum always makes sure i am doing good menatlly sinec she knows that commuting and college academics are stressful to deal with on a daily basis

Last week we are learned the motion of the car, we put the 500kg thing in the black car, and we use the another car to move it, also we need to check when we move this black car and see the laptop how to graph it, I saw the computer graph it very bad, but it just going negative first and going positive, that make me thing more, I try to thinking the truck, if the box has 100kg, how many mile than the truck can move it, like the last lab we do, but this is different its not just 100kg, it can be more and more, so we can try to think if the box have 4t, how many mile than the truck can move it? And last lab we are trying to draw the free body to know more about the black car and the another car

The values of my community and my family from both Mexico and LA have shown nothing but excellence in college, my family from Mexico have always stayed true to the idea that hard work in the right places will pay off eventually, and that every step in the right direction will have it's benefits through bringing good into my life which has helped stay on track with college whether it be assignments, staying on track with the gym, and general balance in life. Living in Los Angeles helped me navigate college with adapting to public transportation, enjoying the city's most obscure places, and adjusting to the new space and it has done nothing but help me get through these two semesters and I feel that these are values I will continue to hold and build upon during my years at SF state which makes me feel more prepared for any obstacles that'll occur along the way.

When it came to grades, my parents have always valued support and a general understanding of struggles more than pure pressure. This allowed me to pursue my education with a general sense of curiosity as opposed to simply studying for good grades. This does not mean that they didn't want me to succeed, nor that they didn't push me to do the best work that I could, but that I knew I had something to fall back onto in case of failures. This approach also allowed me to work based on my own internal motivations.

The values of my family helped me navigate through college by influencing me with a mindset to get through college successfully. I was told that college was the path to success in life and this is true. It is difficult, but my self motivation drives me to do well and succeed by learning here. I want to do well and through my parents, ive been influenced to want this. It is difficult at times, but I know I can do it and I know I have their full support and backing to do whatever I can to succeed. I signed up for difficult major, so I am taking difficult classes as well. At this school, the difficult classes are truly a challenge especially the upper division math class that I am taking. Its truly been a struggle this semester. I hope that I can continue to take hard classes and succeed and pass them.

The values of community and my family have helped me navigate through college by being my main foundation and motivation for staying mentally strong. Moving to a new place and new environment was really scary for me because I wasn't used to not being around people I know in general for so long. Being able to call my family and friends when I felt lonely or frustrated was a great way to help me calm down and remember that I have a community at home. Getting advice from my siblings who have already experienced what I am going through this year has also proved to be helpful because I can have another opinion on what I chose to do and get advice on what not to do. Some values I hold to myself that have also helped me throughout my first year of college is to not judge yourself to others, not care about what others think about me, and most importantly not letting my grades define me. While I'm still trying to use those values in my everyday life it hasn't always been easy, but trying to stay positivie and fake it until I make it has been very beneficial as of recent.

My family has shaped many of the ideals I hold today and encouraged me to continue pursuing my education in college. They've also provided a lot of support of all types dealing with how to deal with more responsibilities I've previously never encountered. I was fortunate to receive help from a lot of different sources on what to expect and deal with various situations in college. However, outside of college, my parents have helped teach me how to deal with the everyday tasks that come with being an adult. I was also fortunate enough that they supported my dreams of pursuing computer science. Outside of my family, the friends and teachers I had gave me the strength to do everything that I wanted to do. Many of them encouraged me to be better for myself and participate in challenges I would've otherwise avoided. With their help, I was able to achieve tremendous personal growth over the last few years. I am very thankful for everyone who has helped me come this far, and I hope to continue taking advantage of the opportunities I've been given.

My family has always been super supportive and helpful for anything I have wanted to do or anything like that. I can ask for help with most things and they will at least try. Both my parents went to college, I don't know much more than that but I'm glad I can ask them about it and they are willing to help. My best friend is also in college and we can talk about it sometimes, usually complaining but it's always fun to do that with friends. He has helped me a couple times with coding and math when I needed it as he's ahead of me in classes. I also have my dad I can ask about coding and math, although he's much more specialized in coding than he is in math. They've all just generally been helpful and have been able to give me what I felt I needed to succeed in school.

My family always tells me to put my 100% into what I do, so when I arrived to college I wanted to do just that. My family has helped me realize what I want to do for the next 4 years and they continue to help me achieve my goals and aspirations. I look forward to the coming years as I continue to receive support from those around me.

Growing up, my family always emphasized resilience and hard work. They taught me that no matter how challenging a situation gets, persistence will eventually lead to success. This value has helped me navigate college, especially when Ive felt overwhelmed by coursework, deadlines, and responsibilities. Instead of giving up, I remind myself that every challenge is an opportunity to grow. Community has also played a huge role in shaping my college experience. Whether its my friends, classmates, or the organizations Im part of, Ive learned the importance of supporting one another. The Chinese Student and Scholar Association, for example, has given me a sense of belonging and purpose, reminding me that even when Im far from home, I have people who understand and uplift me. Another value that has guided me is curiosity. My family always encouraged me to explore new ideas and never stop learning. This mindset has made me approach college not just as a series of requirements but as a space to challenge myself, engage with new perspectives, and develop skills that will help me in the future. At the end of the day, my community and family remind me that success isnt just about achievementsits about growth, connection, and resilience O

My familys values of resilience and perseverance have been key in helping me navigate college. When I faced setbacks in secondary school, their belief in hard work and patience taught me that growth comes from persistence and eventually success comes later. This mindset has carried over to my college experience, where balancing academics, swimming, and adjusting to life as an international student can be challenging. But remembering their advice to stay consistent and trust the process has kept me grounded, even during difficult moments.

Theres a lot of reason for someone wanting to go into the STEM field. My main reason is because STEM really interests me because theres a lot to do. Obviously STEM majors do STEM because of the high paying jobs that they can get in the future but there are many benefits to learning STEM. One is making new friends and peers, that you can relate with and do work together. Not only can you find new friends, but you can also find new opportunities whether that comes in internships or links to companies. Another reason, would be that STEM is a field that has a lot of different problems relating to engineering, physics, math, computing and so much more. Me personally, I think that I'm very good at solving equations and plugging in formulas in math and physics so it interests me heavily. There is also a huge market for STEM workers, and there is no shortage. Since the job demand of STEM is high, many people take majors related to STEM. I followed my father's steps who is a mechanical engineer himself and I wanted to become one.

1. High Demand and Job Security: Growing Fields: STEM careers are experiencing significant growth, often outpacing other sectors. This translates to ample job opportunities and a greater sense of job security. Technological advancements and global challenges drive the need for skilled STEM professionals. Essential Skills: STEM education equips individuals with highly sought-after skills, such as critical thinking, problem-solving, and data analysis, which are valuable across various industries. 2. Potential for High Earning: Competitive Salaries: Many STEM professions offer competitive salaries and benefits, reflecting the specialized knowledge and skills required. The demand for STEM professionals often leads to higher earning potential compared to other fields. 3. Opportunity to Make a Difference: Solving Global Challenges: STEM professionals play a crucial role in addressing pressing global challenges, such as climate change, healthcare, and sustainable energy. Contributing to advancements in these areas can provide a sense of purpose and fulfillment. Innovation and Discovery: STEM fields are at the forefront of innovation and discovery, offering opportunities to explore new frontiers and contribute to groundbreaking advancements. 4. Continuous Learning and Growth: Evolving Fields: STEM fields are constantly evolving, requiring professionals to engage in continuous learning and adapt to new technologies and advancements. This dynamic environment provides opportunities for intellectual stimulation and professional growth. Transferable Skills: STEM fields teach valuable transferable skills, that can be used in many different careers. 5. Diverse Career Paths: Wide Range of Options: STEM encompasses a vast array of disciplines, offering diverse career paths to suit various interests and skills. From research and development to engineering and technology, there are numerous opportunities to explore. In essence, a STEM career can offer a combination of financial stability, intellectual stimulation, and the opportunity to make a meaningful impact on the world.

I joined the STEM field because I was always interested in how things work, i used to disassemble my toys when I was a kid just to see how they worked, eventually i got good enough to where i could put them back together, for me, learning how things worked was a common past time, i'd read books and watch tv shows that revolved around engineering and how things were made. it helped me understand how most items that i use on a daily basis were made and how they work. then i got interested in cars, this took up a majority of my childhood and most of my time today, in my free time i design cars and engines on a simulator that i have on my pc, some times i go and help my friends and their families with any car troubles they may have, since now i've started working on cars in real life too since i have a decent understanding of how a car works.

Last week we are learned the newtons law, the Newtons law is talking about a push or Paul the one body exerts in another. Its an action, not a thing or property of a thing. It can be contact or non-contact. The 1n(newtons) = 1kgm/s^2, 10n=10kg*1m/s^2 or 5kg*2m/s^2 And we knowing the newtons second Law its F=ma, Fg=Mg About the F=ma, we need to calculate the a first, the function is Vf^2=Vi^2+2a x, a=vf^2-vi^2/2 x and for get the F, we ust just get the a *mass, so thats the F, for the fg, we need the g, the g is 9.81, so we just need to using the mass*9.81(g)=fg, and finally we use f/fg get the final answer. So thats what I learned last week

At first, my reason for going into the stem field was because math was always the easiest subject for me growing up. After I transferred to SFSU, I started majoring in Computer Science but at that point, I had no idea what I wanted to do as a career. I want to be apart of a STEM field because when I was a kid I grew up with an uncle who was a mechanic, which led to want to be apart of a STEM field specifically in mechanics, and the automotive industry. Now studying the basics here at SFSU has only fueled my passion for mechanical engineering. Now I do understand that mechanical engineering still has to do with way more than just car design but I still feel that even if I'm exactly learning the exact I want to find a career in I believe seeing all these different applications of mechanical engineering I feel that I can find interest and/or what I want to do in this field and that I will be satisfied with my career choices, whether it's in the automotive industry or something else such things like cnc machining, mining, or anything that this degree can bring me too in the future.

I want to go into the STEM field bacause of what science can do. Science is our best way of describing the world around us and predicting what it will do next. I also chose a STEM major because I had the most fun in those classes during high school. Having fun in all of those classes and being fascinated by the different subjects made it significantly harder to choose a major. However, in the end I chose to enroll as a physics major, simply because the unanswered questions in physics seemed the most interesting.

The reason I chose to go to STEM field is because I have always enjoyed the hard sciences. I like that there are so many different types of fields to go into through stem. I want to do things in STEM because i find it interesting. In science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, I find everything from chemistry to calculus to aerodynamics to computers interesting which is why I wanted to do something in STEM. STEM also pays really well in professional fields. I want to have a stable job and life after college which is one of the reasons why I chose the field. With job security, I can plan my life accordingly and can live my life to the fullest potential so that I can enjoy myself after my years at work. I would like to travel the world, and do many different activities on my bucket list before I get too old and STEM is my way to do that.

I don't know if I have a clear answer for why I really decided to further my education with STEM career wise, but I have smaller reasons. For one, I feel like doing equations is easier because I am better at following a formula and math components such as algebra than other concepts like English or Philosophy. I have some interests like Sports, specifically the NBA, and a little bit of dentistry, so I guess STEM would compliment at least one of those fields of profession. While I am going through the STEM process, I am trying to find more reasons as to why it interests me. For example, for Chemistry, I enjoy immersive and colorful experiments. Another example is algebra because it can be incorporated to basically every component of STEM and I feel that it's easier than geometry and also makes calculus more enjoyable. I am still trying to find more reasons why I chose STEM and figuring out new things about it that I would gear my career towards.

I have a deep love for STEM simply because I think the natural world is incredibly cool. I want to understand it and make cool things from it. I really want to be able to help out with space exploration in some way. Space is full of so many amazing objects that nearly break the laws of physics. Pulsars are literally dead star cores that shoot out tons of radiation like lighthouses. Quasars take black holes, which already put a huge strain on our understanding of physics, and make them impossibly bigger and older. Those things are amazing. Life might exist out there too. It would be really cool to see some intelligent species other than us in the galaxy even if it is incredibly unlikely. There are so many interesting things out in space that people can barely conceive of, and I want to discover more about those things. I really hope that by doing so, we can harness the knowledge to improve people's lives. I hope that my work will be applied throughout a variety of fields, including non-STEM ones, to help people and improve lives.

There are a few reasons for me. First off I find the stem fields to be the most interesting classes I have taken. Physics specifically is probably the most interesting class I have taken as it's essentially the science of the universe. Another reason is obviously the pay for stem jobs is pretty good and since I find it interesting it seems like a good choice. I will say I really dislike straight math classes. They feel both mind numbingly boring and they get pretty difficult with calc two and beyond. The fact that you just memorize a bunch of different methods for doing the same thing makes me hate it, especially when we have calculators for that type of thing now. Even if I knew how to take an integral I'd still run it through a couple programs to check my work. I wish the focus of the course would shift at least a little bit given that information but it doesn't seem like it has. The math classes alone may be enough to discourage me from actually getting a STEM degree. I don't actually care that much and the amount of work just doesn't feel worth it to me.

I've always been drawn to STEM because its where curiosity meets creation. Ever since I was a kid, I wanted to understand how things workedwhy the sky is blue, how computers process information, and how machines can be programmed to think. Theres something exciting about breaking down complex problems, solving puzzles, and then building something new from scratch. Its like magic, but with logic and code. STEM is also about impact. Technology isnt just about writing code or running experimentsits about solving real-world problems. Whether it's AI, robotics, or software development, I see it as a way to create tools that improve lives. I want to build things that matter, whether it's an AI model that helps people learn or a system that makes daily life more efficient. Beyond that, STEM constantly evolves. Theres always something new to explore, always a challenge to tackle. I love the idea of never running out of things to learn. Thats why Im herebecause I want to be part of that change, to push the boundaries of whats possible.

I want to go into the STEM field because I enjoy learning how things work and solving problems. When I was young, Ive been curious about the world around me. Whether its understanding how machines move, how data can reveal patterns, or how athletes improve their performance, I find it exciting to connect science and real-life situations. Swimming has also played a big role in this. Ive seen how analyzing things like body position and stroke technique can make a big difference. This made me realize how powerful science can be in improving performance, and its something I would love to explore further. STEM fields allow me to think critically, find solutions and make things better.

why am I here? Is such an open ended question, If I am asking myself this in relation to school. From a broader perspective, I think I am here to create things; I am by nature a very creative person, and I am interested in computer science because it allows me to better realize creative projects. As for why I am in this physics lab, it's a requirement!

I think I am here because my parents decided to have a child and that child happened to be me. I want to enroll in PHYS 222 because I am eager to deepen my understanding of electromagnetism, circuits, optics, and modern physics. Building on the foundational concepts from my previous physics coursework, I am excited to explore how these principles apply to real-world technologies and scientific advancements. This course is essential for my academic and career goals, as it will strengthen my problem-solving skills and analytical thinking, both of which are crucial in STEM fields. Additionally, PHYS 222 aligns with my interest in understanding the physical forces that shape our world, from electricity and magnetism to the behavior of light and quantum mechanics. I am particularly interested in how these concepts are used in engineering, medical imaging, and modern technology. By taking this course, I hope to develop a deeper appreciation for the role physics plays in innovation and gain practical skills that will help me in future studies and career opportunities. I also want to see how this class come in play with my engineering degree as a civil engineer.

Hello, my name is Gabriel Silveira. For this semester, I am taking PHYS 222 as it is a requirement for my major and as of right now, it is different from what I had first thought it would be. At first, I thought that we would be more focused individual work and that it would be a lab that requires us to write more, however, after these two weeks in taking this lab class, my opinions were wrong. I say this in a good way since I prefer the more hands on and group orientated style of this lab. I was like that for our lab report, we work together as a group to finish our assignment and that it should be done before the lab of that day ends. Another aspect that I like about this lab class is that we can have a safe space to put our thoughts into about what we have in our minds.

Why I am here? I think this Is asking why am I here in physics specifically and my answer to that is to learn more about the world. "Why am I here?" I am currently majoring in civil engineering and this class is, I believe, essential to all engineers. For example, as a kid I remember watching shows and movies in which it looked so easy to smash a window of a car. When I tried it myself I realized that I could not break the glass because I, at the time, could not create enough force to do so. Starting then is when I started looking from a physics view to everything in life. Fun fact, majority of video games today include physics to add the realism of the real world virtually. I play a good amount of video games and I can tell you that the games that involve the most physics are my favorite. It is very interesting to me that everything in the world runs on physics, kind of scary to also think about. I believe that studying physics and understanding it will help me become the best engineer that I can.

I'm here because I'm a computer science student and this lab is required for my degree. I am here to learn more about how the world around me truly works in terms of physics and math. So this is why Im here today at SFSU pursuing my education. Lastly, being able to do good and achieve financial freedom in my 50s would be an amazing last goal for the future to come.

"Why am I here?" is an incredibly broad question. My first thought was that it was referring to the world. "Why am I here on the earth?". However that is quite a big question, especially for a 5 minute free-write. The next logical idea is that "here" refers SF State. Following that version of the prompt, I am at SF State to get my BA in mechanical engineering. I wasn't planning on going to SF State. It was actually my last choice, but in the end, I decided to enroll here and I actually like it. I hesitate to say I love it; I don't really enjoy school that much; but I'd rather be here, learning, than living at home doing nothing. I enjoy the freedom that comes with living on campus. It gives me a sense of adulthood. I feel that I am somewhat capable of taking care of myself without needing my parents' help constantly. Overall, choosing SF State was a good idea and I have enjoyed my classes so far and have made some friends, but this all happened, because I had no better (or cheaper) option for college. So despite this being a last choice, I'm glad that I came to SF State.

As a requirement for my major, Im beginning to understand physics profound importance. I believe the reason I'm here is to grow as a person. When picking a college, I wanted to go somewhere that isn't home so that I could have the space to make mistakes and learn from them. Growing up my parents would always bring us here and the older I got the more I wanted to live and exist here. I feel like most people pick their college based on academics or sports but I chose based on location. San Francisco feels like such a busy and welcoming space, I knew I would love being here. I see being here as a great opportunity to be more independent but also surround myself with new people. I feel like I've placed myself here because of my future goals, specifically wanting to further my understanding with computing. I truly want to expand how physics is intertwined with calculus, computing, and economics. In order to expand on the knowledge I've already acquired, I want to be challenged on concepts that did not stick as well or may have not been know in the first place. I want to further expand my critical assessment behind trigonometry, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, and linear algebra because I feel physics intertwines many of these concepts. There also seems to be concepts that are similar to chemistry in terms of unit analysis, so I'm glad I've experienced different science courses (I've completed chem 1, 2 and organic chemistry). I did a lot of trigonometry in a pre-calculus course I took a few years back, so being able to conceptualize angles in conjunction with trig functions is not completely foreign to me. However, I would like to enhance my understanding with this physics course for broader, conscientious, examinations. All in all, I hope to enhance my confidence behind STEM subject matter as I continue my journey into cyber security.

At first, I thought I was here because this lab is just another requirement for my course. But when I really think about it, I realize Im here for something more than just a grade. I think a big part of it is curiosity. Physics is everywhere, in everything. Im here to learn, to understand how physics works beyond just reading about it. Another big reason Im here is to work with my group. Here physics isnt something you figure out alone, its about solving problems together. Sometimes an experiment wont go as planned, or the numbers wont make sense, but thats okay. Thats where teamwork comes in. We can discuss, troubleshoot, and help each other learn. Each person in the group brings a different way of thinking, and that makes us stronger. Im also here to challenge myself. I know this class wont always be easy there will be moments when I feel stuck, when things doesnt make sense, or when an experiment doesnt go as planned. But thats part of learning. And I feel like with my group I could figure out any problems and succeed in this class.

I am pursuing both an art degree and a computer science degree, a somewhat unusual intersection, so that I have a better chance at some degree of financial stability in the tech industry while I pursue my real interests in art. By taking this class, I am hoping to gain a better basic understanding of classical mechanics in case it ever becomes something I need to know about for applications in certain programs I might be working on in the future. By understanding the basic mechanics of movement, it will be much easier to know how to approach these types of problems with a basic education in physics. Overall, my goals mainly center around landing on a salaried career that I can be proud of. Additionally, PHYS 222 prepares me for more advanced courses in physics and engineering, where electromagnetism plays a critical role in areas such as electronics, energy systems, and communications technology. The lab component (if included) provides hands-on experience with circuits and electromagnetic systems, reinforcing theoretical knowledge through practical application. Furthermore, this course strengthens my critical thinking and analytical abilities, which are valuable not only in academics but also in professional fields such as research, engineering, and data science. By developing a strong foundation in electromagnetism, PHYS 222 directly supports my aspirations, whether in engineering, applied physics, or technology-related industries. Overall, PHYS 222 is an essential step toward my academic and career success

I think that many people feel that AI is a destructive tool, that will remove jobs and will take over the world. But personally, I believe that AI is a useful tool that we can use in stem to obtain answers that would take time to figure out. It can also be used to create and solve for simple or easy work to save time on the more difficult action items that would take alot of time to solve. For computer science, giving certain AI to write reoccuring code that can take a lot of time, which helps out coders to be more productive with their time. Like many intovations, AI is for us to use to make our lives easier. As a student I feel that the best and most ethical way to use AI is for studying. It can take an hour or sometimes even longer to compile study material to study for an exam. But with AI you can feed the course material and have it summarize all of the information into a study guide. With that information to create a study quiz or practice quiz to take can really benefits students to be well prepared for their test.

AI can be a useful tool in STEM fields--it's not particularly new, in fact. LLMs have been used in applications like protein-protein interaction networks, AlphaFold, and countless others for decades. But generative AI is quite new. The reality is, generative AI is not at a stage (and probably never will be) where it can operate completely free of human influence. Humans are still needed to check outputs, because it hallucinates all the time. As a student, AI can be useful, particularly in programming applications, but it cannot be used effectively if you can't check the work and don't understand the underlying principles at work. That's why it's disheartening as a student to see people relying entirely on AI in order to cheat their way through work--they're doing themselves a disservice, because they will never be able to explain how to do basic concepts and will have no way to tell whether what the AI is telling them is correct or not. That's why I use it as sparingly and in as limited a capacity as possible.

I think the role of AI in STEM is really good and productive because it helps everyone since it makes things easier and faster, especially when tasks are long, difficult to understand, like finding formulas that you forget, looking for data, or even coming up with ideas. AI is a powerful tool that can really boost productivity in science, technology, engineering, and math. Personally, I really like AI, I actually use it a lot every day. Of course, I also use it in class, but not to do my homework for me. I feel like if I used AI to just get the answers, I wouldnt actually be learning anything. Thats not the point for me. Instead, I use AI as a tool when I need some help understanding something, when Im looking for ideas, or when I need help finding a formula or more information about a topic. In those cases, it helps a lot. Its like having a super useful assistant whos always there when I need it.

AI in stem can be used to figure something given data or information that has already been discovered but would take an impossible amount of time to figure out if a person were to go through it by themselves or even with a team. I could ethically use AI as a student by using it as a tool like a ruler or a pencil rather than a second brain. If I need to figure out a certain calculation that is too complex for a regular calculator then I think I would rather consult and AI model to help me come to a conclusion for my problem. The point of AI should be to help you work towards something instead of trying to figure it out for you straight up. It shouldn't replace your thought process but rather guide it to the right direction.

Being a computer science major, I have heard from many in-person as well as online, with the saying that AI is going to take over the workforce and drive people out of jobs, and for me I think this is a false statement. There are so many fundamental aspects of computer science that a computer just can't do by itself. Front end development for example, being intuitive and accessable on a website is what keeps people engaged and coming back for more, but AI is many many many years away from being able to think like a human would, and for example create an "intuative" button for a website, or know how to create an artistic style that will catch peoples eye. I think AI in the workforce as of the present day is a helper. If you need someone to write up some code for a data structure like a tree, AI is perfect in creating that code, but you as the human also need to make decisions based on your project where that code should be implemented, or whether that code is even necessary, which required the "human" element.

The role for AI in stem is to present a better understanding rather than just finding answers. In order to use it, you have to make sure you are also learning in the process, taking notes, asking questions and also finding challenge problems. I use AI in my math classes in order to understand what I haven't understood in class. This helps improve and review some materials that werent covered in class and it is also a great opportunity to ask for more clarification. Using AI can have its downsides, like for example, your getting interested in the final result rather than how you got the step by step solution. Its always good to not get yourself very stuck with it, if your not learning with it. In my own personal experience, I have to avoid using it in the long terms because I would also want to apply the math on my own.

AI plays a transformative role in STEM by enhancing research, automating complex calculations, and facilitating data analysis. It accelerates the pace of scientific discovery, enabling researchers to simulate experiments, analyze large datasets, and identify patterns that might be missed by human observation. In education, AI-powered tools can personalize learning experiences, offering tailored feedback and adaptive learning pathways that help students understand challenging concepts. As a student, ethically and productively using AI means leveraging it as a supplement to learning rather than a shortcut. Its important to use AI tools to enhance understandingsuch as using them for practice problems, explanations, and brainstormingwhile ensuring that the work submitted is genuinely my own. This involves being transparent about AI usage and maintaining academic integrity by avoiding plagiarism or misrepresentation of AI-generated work as personal effort. Productively, I can use AI to explore complex topics, simulate STEM experiments, or even organize and manage research data more efficiently. However, its crucial to critically evaluate AI-generated content, understanding its limitations and potential biases. This reflective approach allows me to maximize the benefits of AI while maintaining ethical standards, fostering a balanced relationship between human creativity and artificial intelligence in my educational journey

The role of AI in STEM seems to be growing faster than we can fully process it. It is an incredible tool that can solve problems in ways we never imagined, analyzing massive amounts of data, making predictions, and even simulating experiments that would take humans years to complete. But at the same time, it raises questions about trust, creativity, and ethics. If AI can do so much, where do we fit in as students? For me, I think the key is balance. AI is not a substitute for thinking of it as an improvement. Ethically, that means using AI to support learning rather than bypass it. If I use AI to brainstorm ideas, check my work, or get explanations, then that is effective. But if I just let it do my homework for me, then Im not really learning anything. Additionally, I have a responsibility to question AIs answers, because they are not perfect. I want to use AI in ways that help me become a better thinker, not a passive observer. Perhaps that means treating it as a tutor, something to challenge and refine my understanding, rather than something to rely on completely. The future of STEM will involve AI, but it is our job to stay curious and engaged so we can guide the ethical use of AI.

AI can be used to research specific topics and get more information about topics. You can use AI to problem solve and find different solutions or ideas for a problem. Its good for help solving complex and difficult problems that youd struggle with on your own. Students can also use AI for feedback on their work and how they can improve it. This can help overall with how they solve and answer questions benefitting them for the future. AI can also be used to clean up data or find the most important parts of the data the students have. This can help so they arent super repetitive or focusing on not as important points in the data they found. AI is also pretty accurate so students dont have to worry as much about if the information they are getting from AI is correct and relevant. There are many ways AI can be used for stem students. Its very useful and resourceful and can be beneficial if used correctly.

AI in STEM is can be very useful if used correctly. If you only use AI in STEM for cheating and finding answers, that is not ethically nor productive. I believe that using AI can be used to help you learn and research certain topics. For example, when I need help understanding something in math, AI does a pretty good job of explaining and breaking down step by step what to do. Using AI for cheating does not help you or anyone, but you would just be delaying your education. Anyone can go on Chat GPT to find answers to math and/or have them make a 5 page paper. AI is a useful and helpful resource, but it is different when you use AI to complete all your work. These are my thoughts on AI, definitely is used to help everyone, but easily can be taken advantage of. Use it ethically and productively is using it for assistance, not to do your work!

I think the role of AI in STEM is both helpful and harmful. It can be used as a tool to automate jobs and increase efficiency, but it can also be used to replace humans and harm our environment. As a student, I find AI to be a double edged sword. I use it ethically to help increase my productivity by using it to compile long readings into shorter readings. This allows me to save time on reading. I think student use of AI can also be harmful. For example, many students these days are using AI to do their work for them completely. This is harmful in the long run, because they aren't actually learning the material. On an individual level, it can be hard for these individuals to get a job in the future. On a larger scale, if our entire society is educated by cheating with AI, the skill of our general work force will go down.

AI (Artificial Intelligence) plays a crucial role in STEM. Using suck technology can help speed up the process of solving problems. Not only is it useful for solving problems or finding new ways to come about resolving an issue but, it can be a tool to further better your understanding. You can ask for instance ChatGpt which is a well know ai tool to help guide you through the procedure on a given problem and how to go about getting the solution you want. Knowing how to ask AI what your looking for is important because at the end of the day its just like a calculator, you need to make sure that what you want is what you get by giving the proper instructions and pressures to complete the task at hand. Furthermore the academic integrity of your work is not at stake with AI if you use it responsibly. One thing is to just cheat by copy and pasting answers directly from AI like ChatGPT but another is to actually use AI to figure out how to solve a problem to learn. The key word being to learn is why using AI still shows academic integrity by using it justfully. Your not only cheating your way through your courses but more importantly your cheating yourself and your ability to learn new topics and continuing to grow your understanding even when met with difficultys.

While AI can be abused greatly, such as creating deepfakes/fake videos, it can still be incredibly helpful. AI is useful for easy simple, especially monotone tasks. AI can do these repetitive and time-consuming tasks more quickly and efficiently than humans, so it can be helpful to help people. The issue is, that AI is becoming so smart that it's slowly taking over, not just helping out. Having AI robots instead of waiters, for example, reduces the number of jobs available to people. While it can be helpful to have a robot to carry the orders to the tables, and it is much cheaper since you don't have to pay it, it may seem like a step forward, but it is actually a step backward. As a student, it's important not use AI to cheat and do homework and tests for me. It can be helpful though to help explain how to solve a problem or perhaps reinforcing that your answer is correct. One issue with students using AI is that the AI gets all its information from the internet, and if a student copies that information, it is most likely plagiarizing sources that the AI tool found on the web. Overall, as a student, having AI help out when youre stuck, in my opinion is fine, as long as you've tried to find the answer on your own.

AI is becoming more important in STEM, changing how we look at data, solve problems, and create new ideas. It helps in areas like medicine and engineering by making tasks easier, finding patterns we might miss, and even coming up with new questions. As a student, I think AI can help me learn better if I use it the right way. One problem is making sure AI is just a helper and not something I depend on too much. Its easy to let AI do the thinking for me, especially when it gives answers so fastly. But real learning happens when I try to understand things myself. I think its okay to use AI to check my work, explain tough ideas, or get inspiration. But using it to finish homework without effort wouldnt be right. Another thing to think about is that AI can be wrong or biased. AI only knows what it has been taught, so I need to be careful and check if the information is true. Learning to double-check AIs answers and not always trusting them completely is important. In the end, AI is just a tool, and how I use it matters. If I use it wisely and honestly, it can help me learn instead of holding me back.
