Also, AI is more of a learning system so when it was first shown to people it wasnt that well, but as time went on it would get better but it still with mistakes. Still, my point stands that AI in STEM should just be used to help people understand what they are doing and not do the work for them.

The role of AI in STEM is to help automate the monotonous tasks that would require a lot of work for people to do. For example, AI can look through all the given dataset and analyze at unbelievable speeds that would take a while for humans to get through. Having AI go through this can give more time for scientists or researchers to do other tasks that are not as time consuming. AI can also help with giving suggestions based on their given data. Since it can go through data very fast, it can effectively give information from this. AI is very flexible and adaptive because it is always learning from the data that people give it. This is why giving AI a vast amount of data is important to fine tune it to a very effective model that can be used for many people. It is always adapting and evolving.

The role of AI in STEM is to help with complex processes such as complex problems. It can help us predict stuff and solve complex problems that are too complex in different ways. Another way it can help is to figure out how to analyze data strategically and process patterns like large datasets. In certain science fields and classrooms, it can help people understand how science works. If science had complex topics to understand, people would get the help of AI to use in STEM so that it will be able to give an understanding. Hopefully making it easier to know if the topic has confusion. I can ethically and productively use AI as a student by using it only for learning resources. To typically help with getting clarity on confusing topics. To get help on topics when someone is not readily available to help at a certain time.

AI is rapidly becoming an integral part of STEM, revolutionizing the way scientists and engineers tackle problems, analyze data, and make groundbreaking discoveries. Its ability to identify patterns, aid in disease diagnosis, and contribute to the development of new technology is truly remarkable. For students, AI holds potential, but its crucial to harness it responsibly. AI serves as a valuable learning aid, assisting in understanding challenging concepts, validating work, and inspiring project ideas. While its a powerful tool for brainstorming and learning, it's important not to over-rely on it. Without engaging in critical thinking doesn't contribute to my learning, if over using AI. Using AI ethically in education requires a clear understanding of its role. It's not about letting AI do the work for me, but about using it as a guide. Seeking assistance is acceptable, but it's crucial to think critically and verify information. AI is a tool, much like a calculatorit aids, but it's not a substitute for learning. Using it judiciously can enhance my learning experience, rather than just providing quick answers.

AIs rol e in stem hopefully helps us by acting as tools similar to the calculator with maybe some simulating data implications with the track that its heading .I think about how it can complete tasks faster than I can sometimes, or interpret complex ideas in terms I can understand. As a student, it's tempting to have the AI simply give me the answer, but I realize that's not the point and can be super detrimental to my education if I abuse it. The right way to do it is to use it as a study partner. I might forfeit the basic skills I need to be capable of solving problems independently. But if I use it to check if I get a question or otherwise to test an issue in a different way, it really does me good as its supposed to be used as a tool to enhance my learning not replace it.

Artificial intelligence can play a huge role in STEM because it can be used in many different ways. It can be used for more simple things like summarizing texts and explaining concepts. If there's a question, or anything you're having trouble understanding, you can ask it to re-word it in a way that makes sense to you. Ai can also be used to challenge yourself. If you use the same ai program repeatedly, it can figure out what you struggle with and come up with personalized questions to improve your learning. It is always able to give you feedback on your answers and assignments to show you how you can make it better. All of these are productive ways to use ai. This can be ethical because you aren't stealing work directly or just coping down answers. As a student, the use of ai can be a great study tool.

I don't think it's useful to use AI if there hasn't been an initial attempt to work through a subject or thought process on your own. I do, however, believe AI can be utilized in ethical and productive ways. One way it can be used is to help students explore additional study aids. By quantifying our questions, AI chatbots can be used as a tool that reinforces critical thinking and conceptualization. Another way it can be helpful is to double check the work we've already completed to observe how machine learning evaluates the situation. This doesn't necessarily mean what is being generated is 100% correct, but it may provide room to draw comparisons or identify contrasting information/processes. In terms of ethical use, it's up to the user themselves to make that choice when using tools to enhance understanding. If there is lack of effort to try and think about concepts on your own before these tools are used, it will become a crutch to how you learn and seek information.

AI is everywhere in STEM, and its honestly kind of amazing to see how much its changing the way we solve problems. In medicine, its helping doctors diagnose diseases faster. In engineering, its making designs more efficient. Even in environmental science, AI is predicting climate patterns and helping find ways to fight climate change. As a Computer Science student, I see AI as both exciting and a little intimidating. Its a powerful tool, but it also raises a lot of questions like, how do we make sure its fair? How do we stop people from misusing it? As a student, I want to use AI in a way that actually helps me learn, not just as a shortcut. Its easy to let it do the work for me, but then whats the point? Instead, I can use it to explain tough concepts, debug my code, or even generate practice problems. But at the end of the day, I still have to put in the effort to understand things on my own. I also think its important to be honest about using AI if I get help from it, I should acknowledge that.

When life gets challenging, I am lucky in that I have a lot of wonderful support systems in my life. It's easy to get caught up in the hustle and bustle of school and work, and sometimes that means I stop taking care of myself as well as I should. When that happens, I take time to withdraw as best as I can, and turn to people like my partner who might take on more chores than usual, or take over cooking dinner. I do my best to use what little time I have to do the things that are the most important in terms of deadlines, and then use the time I have afterwards for some uninterrupted self-care. This might look like getting lost in a really good novel, working on my artistic pursuits, practicing calligraphy, rollerskating or doing yoga. These things restore my battery for work and social life, so I try to fit them in where I can. Sometimes, of course, all I really need is to sleep in and laze around, and I make sure I leave space for that in my life wherever I can, too.

When life gets tough, it's very difficult to take a step forward, but I always try to do it, although first I stop and reflect, saying that bad things don't last forever. Although sometimes it's difficult to know where to start, the first step is to begin. It doesn't matter where you just have to start, since it's better to start than never do it, and this will make you get stuck in a place where you can't easily get out. I often try to seek help from my friends or family, since oftentimes you can't do everything alone, and I need support, since talking about things that aren't going well usually helps me feel better. I often start things well organized, but some bad day or days make everything fall apart, and that's when you see the road more difficult. But I once read a saying that went: "If you have a problem and it doesn't have a solution, why worry? And if you have a problem and it does have a solution, why worry?" I feel like after reading that saying, my mentality changed a lot, although this sometimes makes me someone who procrastinates because I always think there will be an option to solve it and if there isn't, then I can't worry because it's something I can't change.

When life gets challenging I like to remind myself that whatever I'm going through in the moment is only a temporary feeling in a longer timeline of life. But when it's difficult to imagine that I like to wind down my state of mind if it feels like there is a lot piling on top of me by doing the things I love. Some of these things consist of listening to music, going for a walk, playing basketball, or playing video games. I also like to spend time with my friends as they can often distract me from the weight of life and give me something to laugh about and to my more trusted friends I feel safe to talk to them about the challenging things that I may be going through. Overall I like to take a step back and assess my life and take a deep breath and reassure myself that I'll be okay.

I take a moment to pause and breathe whenever life gets tough. That brief reset helps me clear my mind and think more logically. I also remind myself that Ive faced challenges before and made it through, even when it felt impossible. To stay on top of my academics, I break things down into manageable tasks by creating a to-do list, which helps me feel more in control. For school, I find that breaking things down into smaller steps makes a big difference. A long list of assignments can feel impossible, but checking off one task at a time gives me a sense of progress. Even small wins help me stay motivated. Outside of academics, I turn to things that help me resetCameras, Golf, or talking to my best friends and hanging out with them. These little things remind me that tough moments dont last forever. I know that as long as I keep moving forward, Ill get through whatever comes my way. 4o

When life gets challenging, I take the time to nap, I find it a time to forget my problems and just get a rest from the world because sometimes it does get very challenging; you'll just need to take a deep breath and relax. I've been having challenging times, and it does get hard to manage myself whenever anything unexpected happens. I should start to do more meditation for the sake of my mental estate and also keep myself organized whenever needed. I know lots of people have there life challenging and its because of work, college and even about problems at home. Ive been managing myself as much as possible and I know I can make improvement to myself. I have been making progress day by day and as an adult I can make more changes and even big improvements to myself. I am a hard worker and i can make a change.

Life often presents unexpected challenges that can feel overwhelming, yet these moments also offer opportunities for growth, reflection, and transformation. When life becomes challenging, it is essential to acknowledge your feelings and understand that experiencing a range of emotions is natural during difficult times. Begin by taking a deep breath and focusing on self-care, such as ensuring proper nutrition, adequate sleep, and regular physical activity, all of which can strengthen your resilience and provide a stable foundation. Establishing a consistent daily routine, even amidst uncertainty, can instill a sense of control and order. Additionally, reaching out to trusted friends, family members, or mental health professionals can provide invaluable support and fresh perspectives, reminding you that you are not alone in your struggles. Reflect on past experiences where you overcame adversity, and draw upon that inner strength to build confidence in facing current obstacles. Setting small, manageable goals can create a series of accomplishments that gradually rebuild momentum and optimism. It is important to recognize that progress may not always be linear and that setbacks can serve as opportunities for learning and self-improvement. Allow yourself the time and space to heal, and practice patience as you navigate through challenging periods. Embrace vulnerability as a sign of courage, and view each hardship as a stepping stone towards a deeper understanding of yourself and life. Ultimately, facing lifes challenges with determination, self-compassion, and the willingness to seek help can transform adversity into a powerful catalyst for personal growth, paving the way toward a more balanced, fulfilling, and enriched existence. By taking small, thoughtful steps each day, you gradually build resilience that empowers you to confront challenges with renewed hope and clarity. Every setback is a lesson, every victory a reminder of your strength, and every moment an opportunity to grow in your journey

When life gets tough, I try to remind myself that Ive been through difficult moments before, and I made it through. Its easy to feel overwhelmed in the moment, but taking a step back and breathing helps me refocus. Sometimes, I write things down just getting my thoughts on paper makes them feel less heavy. Other times, I talk to a close friend or family member, even if I dont necessarily need advice just knowing someone is there makes a difference. I also try to shift my mindset. Instead of seeing a challenge as something thats happening to me, I try to think of it as something I can work through. Even when it feels like I have no control, I remind myself that I can control my attitude, my effort, and how I react. Taking small steps helps too if Im stressed about school, I focus on just one assignment at a time instead of everything at once. When all else fails, I take a break. Whether its going for a walk, listening to music, or just getting some sleep, I remind myself that recharging is part of the process. No challenge lasts forever, and I know Ill get through it, just like i always have.

When life gets challenging I try to think of what my purpose is and what is going to make me want to keep going. For example, the thought of taking care of my family and being stable gives me purpose to keep going when I'm struggling. Taking a minute to see the bigger picture and how things can be way worse also helps me get grounded down to earth and be a little more grateful that my challenges aren't as bas as they could be. I also feel like venting is helpful for me when I feel life is getting challenging. I like to talk to someone and just let it all out. This brings me relief and comfort. Especially when I talk to someone who understands and talks me into reality and knows how to calm my nerves. Like my mom or boyfriend for example know how to make me feel less stressed and calm me down.

When life gets challenging, there are many ways to handle what to do. I grew up in a very Filipino household so there are things I was never taught what to do when life gets challenging. In our household, growing up my father did not know how to show emotion so the way I saw it was men do not show emotion or else they are weak. When life gets challenging for me today, I like keeping myself busy. I do that because it gives me time to forget about all the stress and just focus on myself. I do stress a lot about homework, family, and just life itself. I do not process things regularly, I always need some time to clear my mind before I can clearly see the challenge and how to solve it. That is the best way to describe it, when life gets challenging I like to clear my mind first then face the challenge so that I can see all the different solutions.

When life gets challenging, I make sure to take time for myself to reset. I usually make sure to eat good food, workout, and spend time with friends and family. For example, this semester was especially tough for me since it was my first semester back in the states after returning from a year studying abroad. It was hard for my to adjust to living, working, and going to school in the states again. During the adjustment period, I made sure to stick to a routine that helped keep my day to day life in check. I find that routine especially helps me when life gets challenging. It's nice to wake up and do the same thing everyday even when life feels chaotic. I established a good workout schedule, and I made sure to maintain a good social life despite being busy with school. Both of these things were main contributors in pushing me through this semester, especially with a heavy STEM course load.

When life gets tough I suck it up and move onto the next thing I got going on. Usually Ill stick to something I know and enjoy like a quick workout out or even just relaxing and watching a movie. There is many instances where I have faced challenges but do not make it know I just continue with life and overcome it by trying to better myself. For example with my studies if Im not understanding something I will turn to some platform for help like ChatGPT to workout a problem or even YouTube professors. Then if I feel like Im not satisfied I ask questions during class to professors or even seek peer tutoring at the task center even if I dont need just to keep a good habit of being open to criticism and help. With that being said, there is never a time where something challenging will cause me to not move forward with life and I always jump those hurdles and straighten out and curves in my path to success here at SFSU. I also want to add that sometimes life can get overwhelming quickly especially in college but all you need sometimes is to just take a breather and relax while doing something you enjoy to then come back with a clearer mindset and attack head on your troubles to overcome them.

Usually, when life gets challenging, I try to keep my anxiety from surfacing and soldier on. It's not necessarily a good habit but it sometimes allows me to try and continue living normally instead of letting fear consume me and hold me in one place. For example, I am a little behind in my Calc class and we were going to have a test today. I did a little studying here and there, but today, the day of the test, I sat down and studied for a few hours. It was so refreshing be able to sit down and actually focus on and do my work. If I had let my stress get the best of me, I would have felt less calm going into the test. Luckily the test was cancelled so now I have time to genuinely study. When life is challenging due to different circumstances unrelated to school, I like to be alone a little and think, which helps me calm down and think clearly.

What I do when life gets challenging is a question I wish I could answer truthfully but I can't because in the face of challenges I am inconstant on how I work around them. Life throws a lot of obstacles in our way, in academia, social, and systemic therefore I have different ways of dealing with challenges. However what I find most challenging out of the three types of obstacles is academia that I am not particularly interested in because I find it hard to get started and stay engaged with the material especially if it is hard for me to understand at first. These types of challenges appear a lot in academia and even social life therefore I have to have a plan to go around it and that is usually to have a day for just the most challenging issues. However that can be unrealistic and waste time.

When life gets hard, I have a few things that help me feel better. One of my favorite things to do is play games. Sometimes I play competitive games, and other times, I play just to relax. It helps me take a break from stress. I also like watching YouTube. Sometimes I watch for fun, sometimes to learn new things, or just to have something playing in the background. Another thing that helps me is spending time with friends. Even though Im more quiet, being around people Im comfortable with makes me feel better. We talk, play games, or just hang out, and it reminds me that Im not alone. I know hard times dont last forever, and having these things helps me get through them. Taking a break helps me feel ready to face whatever challenge comes next.

Jonathan Marcial 3/6/25 When something for me starts to become challenging I kind of just put it to the side and try to not fully think about it since there is a lot that I went through and don't want to stress myself out. What I do while not doing that thing/work I try to look at the steps on how to solve it. What I also do is just work on something else trying to get my mind off of what I was doing before. If that doesn't work out for then I would just ask and look around on how to do it. If that doesn't work then I just sleep it off and try again and if that don't work then I ask for help on what I am doing and what I did wrong. Well other then that, that is what I would do if I was faced with a challenging things.

When life starts to get challenging, I think it is important to talk to people that you really trust. You can't just keep it bottled up inside hoping things will get better. Those people you consider friends or family would want to help you. Talking about the problems to others will help try to point your life toward the right track. It is also important to keep a positive mindset. Having a negative mindset where you think of the worse possible outcome would make yourself even worse than before. But is is important to not ignore those negatives. It is important to be realistic but to try to solve those problems by seeking help. Asking others for help or even talking about your problems can help instead of being at a sort of limbo with nothing else to do. People have negative thoughts all the time, but it is important to not think about it too hard.

When life gets challenging, I look for ways to get better at the challenges. Or find some way to overcome the obstacles. I try to see the brighter side, like a silver lining, like it's not the worst that could happen. I also try to find solutions if possible. For example, if I fail a test for whatever reason, I would have that test after it gets graded to reflect on it. Then, I will try to practice more and more so that I will be better prepared next time. That would help me to understand what I need to work on more to achieve better results in the future. If I were to say that I did my best, then that is all I could do. Afterward, I can learn from it to be well prepared for the next test. I also try to say that it is okay and move on because then there's nothing I can do about it if I can't do anything about it which is okay. That is very hard sometimes, but growing from that will help you develop as a person from the challenges that life faces.

When life becomes overwhelming, I turn inward. Instead of seeking external support, I rely on meditation and self-reflection to help me regain balance. Taking even a few minutes to sit still and focus on my breath creates a space between my thoughts and emotions. It's a reminder that no matter how intense things feel, I am not my stressI am simply experiencing it, and it will pass. This realization brings a sense of relief and a hopeful outlook. Journaling and self-reflection are my trusted companions in navigating challenging moments. The act of writing down my thoughts helps me process them, transforming my problems from chaotic to manageable. Through self-reflection, I gain a clear understanding of whats bothering me and how to move forward with a more focused mindset. Instead of seeking reassurance from the outside, I trust in my inner strength to handle whatever life throws at me. Meditation and self-reflection are my anchors, reminding me that challenges are temporary and that I possess the tools within me to overcome them. No matter how tough things get, I can always find peace within myself.

When things start to get difficult, I slow everything down. My mind starts racing and everything is an emergency, but I've learned that stepping away really does help me think things out better. Sometimes I take a walk or just sit in my room with music playing until I can breathe normally once again. I attempt to remind myself that I have survived tough things in the past such as attending college, being away from home, trying to balance school, work, and life. I do speak with people as well friends, family, or on occasion even professors when I'm actually stuck. I used to think that seeking assistance made me weak, but now I understand it's the complete opposite. I also write things down a lot just to empty the stress in my head. Making to-do lists helps me break chaos into infinitesimal steps. At the end of each day, I know problems are unavoidable and I just have to push on, no matter how slow. I remind myself that I'm giving it my all, and that's all one can ask.

I'm trying to get the phrase "Everything's going to be okay" engraved in my mind, and so far I think I'm doing a pretty good job. Throughout this past year, every part of college has been a learning experience. Whenever something goes wrong, whether it was my fault or not, I try to learn from my mistakes. I'm doing a really good job of not stressing out and having a negative mindset. I just tell myself to do better next time I'm dealing with a challenge. I also remind myself that I have many resources and people that can help me when I'm struggling. Often, I battle between being independent and dealing with everything myself, and reaching out for help. I'm trying to have an equal balance of the two so I can deal with challenges better. A recent example is when I missed an exam this past week. I had a full twenty-four hours to complete it and obviously I decided to procrastinate till the very last second. This had terrible consequences and I have learned from them. Reminding myself that challenges help me grow as a person is how I get through them.

When life gets challenging, I try my best to find a point of grounding. If I'm getting overwhelmed, I will find a stopping point and allow my brain to rest. I don't further review why I'm going through a challenging point because it's meant to be reflected upon at a different time. I allow myself to fail in order to gain some understanding when I'm ready to re-engage with something that didn't work out the first time around. Once I've given myself a break and found a point to review, I tackle the objective once again with new perspectives. One important aspect of how I handle challenging moments is to physically rest and make sure that I am eating properly. Without both, I tend to burn myself out and lack returning to the point at which I was struggling. I also accept things that are out of my control. If i truly did not understand a concept or an experience, I accept it for what it was an move on with my life. Dwelling does not allow for forward momentum and evolution/acceptance of self.

When life gets tough, I try to remind myself that Ive been here before stressed, overwhelmed, unsure if I can handle it all. And yet, somehow, I always do. It doesnt always feel that way in the moment, though. Sometimes, I just want to shut down, scroll mindlessly on my phone, or take a nap and hope things magically fix themselves. But I know that never really works. What does help is taking a step back. A deep breath. A reminder that I dont have to figure everything out at once. Maybe I go for a walk or call a friend. I remind myself that Im not alone there are people who care, who want to help. And when everything feels like too much, I focus on one small step at a time. One assignment. One page. One thing I can do right now. Most of all, I try to be kind to myself. Its easy to be my own worst critic, but Im learning that I dont have to be perfect I just have to keep going. No matter how hard things get, I know Ill make it through. I always do.

When it comes to the values of my family, the thing that helps me stay motivated and navigate through college are the sacrifices my parents made to put me in the situation that I am. It is important to them that I get a high education, which pushes me to do better in school. The values of my community and peers are not fair from my parents values. Many of my peers are striving for the same thing that I am, to graduate. So it is comforting to know that if i have any questions or need someone to study with I can ask my friends in my classes. I believe that it is important to keep myself surrounded with people that think similar to me and have my end goal in mind just to make sure that I stay on the right path. Which is the great part about the labs, since it forces us to get to know eachother and to work together.

I am very lucky in that my family has always been supportive and understanding of any direction I want to go in. When I made the difficult decision to leave my prestigious liberal arts college after two years, I was met with nothing but understanding and support. When I decided I couldn't ignore my dreams of enrolling in art school any longer, my family was so excited for me and understood that I was following a passion that I had neglected for years. My family values one's right to pursue what is most important to oneself, and that nothing should come between that. They also did something I really appreciate, which was to give me the breathing space to make my own decisions and my own mistakes without trying to helicopter or puppeteer my life. This meant that I felt like I had the space and agency to learn from mistakes and find my own path without the commandeering of another person. This has been one of my biggest strengths as I have navigated through college.

A value I carry with me every day, and which I learned from a very young age thanks to my family, is respect. They taught me that if you don't respect, you can't expect to be respected. But also something deeper: that even if someone doesn't respect me, I don't have to respond in kind. Being respectful isn't just for others, it's for yourself. I believe respect defines you, opens doors, and helps you build more real and human relationships. They also taught me to never give up. I come from Peru, a country where studying is often not an easy option. There are people who struggle every day to eat, to pay their way, to simply keep going. And seeing that from a young age has left its mark on me. Every time I feel frustrated or tired here at the university, I think about that. I think about my family, my people, and everything it took to get here. And I pick myself up. Because even if life gets difficult, I will learn to keep going, with respect and without giving up.

The values of my community have taught me to keep my head up and power through difficult times. I have had several courses where I end up feeling like I can't take on the work load or the concepts seem to challenging and I just feel awful because my grade is tanking and my mental is not in the best place. But after I collect myself and refocus on the goal I'm able to power through and try my best to get the best grade I can get. This also applies on the smaller scale of things like if I do understand something but I am having difficulty with a certain area of the course and its during finals period or midterms I just take it on the chin and focus on other areas. Another thing my community has taught me is to be aware which is something I do a lot because I commute to and from school.

The values that my dad gave me have been the most valuable tool I have used while navigating my college life. Being respectful, being mindful of your surrounding, and a whole host of ideas have sticked with me and made an impact of who I am and how I act on a day to day basis, but I think the two most valuable skills he always preached to me was being on time and never wait to finish something. Being on time is essential not just practically, but is a huge respect builder with people like co-workers, employers, and even just your friends/relationships/marriages. Being on time shows you care, and you are committed to whatever you might be doing. Never waiting to finish something was also a valuable skill that has given me tons of extra time to do things I love. Why wait to turn in an assignment when I can do it now and not have to think about it later. That new free time I have for me personally has been going to golf.

The values of community helped me stay in college for the longest. When I started college I really asked myself what reason do I have of going to school again realizing that Im just going from Oakland all the way to sf just for some classes and regret some of the work I do. I had these thoughts go back and forth because I realized that I had nothing ahead of me at that time. When the months past by I made a bigger connection to my family because I would ask them if what Im doing is worth it ? They told me its only worth it if you believe itll benefit you and doesnt matter how long it takes aslong as you manage to make success out of it. I was relieved that my parents taught me a valuable lesson of staying strong even at hardest times and dont show weakness.

Growing up with parents who immigrated from Mexico and worked tirelessly to build a better life for our family has profoundly shaped my approach to college. Their dedication and resilience taught me the value of hard work and perseverance. I watched my parents work long hours, often sacrificing their own comfort so that I could have opportunities they never had. Their example instilled in me a strong sense of responsibility and determination. Whenever I faced academic challenges or moments of self-doubt, I drew strength from their sacrifices and unwavering support. Their journey reminded me that success isnt always easy, but with commitment and hard work, its possible. My parents also taught me the importance of humility and gratitude. They reminded me to appreciate every opportunity and to approach my education with the same work ethic that they applied to their own lives. Their sacrifices motivated me to push through difficult times, knowing that my success is not just for me, but also a way to honor their hard work and resilience. Their story has been a guiding force, helping me stay focused and determined as I navigate the challenges of college life.

Growing up, my family always emphasized resilience and hard work. No matter what obstacles came our way, we always had the mindset of Youll figure it out and keep going. That value served me well during college, especially when things seemed overwhelming  whether it was a difficult class, a heavy workload, or just feeling lost. I learned to push through, find solutions instead of dwelling on problems, and believe that I could handle more than I thought. Another core value in my family was the importance of community. My parents always made it clear that no one succeeds alone  you have to rely on those around you and in turn, you have to support them. That shaped how I approached friendships and mentoring in college. I find that having a strong support systemwhether its friends, professors, or even just classmates who are going through tough times togethermakes things more manageable. Ultimately, these values have helped me feel grounded even in moments of uncertainty. They remind me that I have the tools I need to overcome challenges and that Im never truly alone in doing so.

The values of my family have helped me to navigate through college and also made it a little harder in a few ways. It has helped me make genuine friendships and network with people in my classes. My family has always taught me it's good to know different people and how it can help me through college and even life to have friends and connections. Which is true because if I miss a class I always know someone I can ask for notes. I also have people who are going through the same things as me and understand me better than my family might. My family also taught me to work hard and helped me become more independent. I work while being in college which has its pros and cons. A pro is having my own money. So I can buy food, still go out and enjoy my free time, and save up. It also can be stressful, sometimes I feel like I have a lot on my plate and tend to be more tired since I have to find time for homework around work. School is valued and advocated for very highly in my family so success amount my classes is a must for me. My parents sacrificed a lot so that I could get a better education and hopefully one day find a well paying job in the future. Everyday when I look at my phones home screen (picture of my family) I am reminded why I am here and why there is no room for failure in my academic career. While I am not. A greedy person, I dont chase money to an extent. My goal in life is not only to help as many people as possible but also to help put my family in a better position then the one I grew up in. The values of my community and my family have helped me navigate through college in many ways. I believe that from my upbringing, I am more mature than the other people in my age group. The value I believe that helped me the most is hardworking. Growing up, I had two younger siblings and a mom supporting the three of us; I am the eldest. There are many times where we did not get to see her because she made sure to work enough so that she would be able to put us in the best education and put a roof over our heads. We were definitely in the lower class, but growing up I got to understand that life is not easy. Of course I had a typical fun childhood, but when it comes to grocery shopping, toy shopping, etc. I had to be mindful that I was not spending my mom's money on something that could have went into something better. My mom has showed me in many ways that being a hard worker can bring you a long way in life!

I think my family's values have greatly helped me navigate college. My family is not strict, but they are still extremely disciplined and they raised me to be the same. I think this combination creates good work ethic, because it enforces structure without also creating pressure. For example, my parents always made sure that I knew the importance of punctuality. When I was a kid, they always taught me to be on time for everything and for school they taught me to turn in everything on time, even if there was wiggle room for deadlines. Now that I'm in college, I appreciate that they raised me like this because I feel like I'm more responsible and punctual than most of my peers that are my age. Most of my generation is chronically late, and it reeks of carelessness to me. The value of punctuality also ensures that I never fall behind in school, which is important in a STEM degree.

The values instilled by my family and community have played a crucial role in guiding me through college. Additionally, values such as integrity and responsibility, deeply ingrained in me, have helped me make ethical decisions, manage my time effectively, and maintain a strong work ethic. Ultimately, the foundation built by my family and community has shaped my ability to thrive in college, allowing me to navigate challenges with confidence and purpose.

I believe that the way I grew up overall positively influenced how I approach and act, but it definitely isn't the only aspect of my upbringing and life that affects how I navigate through college. In conclusion, my family's values shaped a big part of who I am, but it was the past experiences and the growth from those experiences that truly have impacted who I am and how I approach the world.

Pursuing a career in the STEM field (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) offers numerous benefits that can positively impact both your professional and personal life. STEM careers are known for providing job stability, competitive salaries, and opportunities for growth. As technology and scientific advancements continue to shape the world, the demand for skilled professionals in these fields remains high. This translates to greater job security and the potential for higher earnings compared to many other industries. A career in STEM also allows you to engage in meaningful and innovative work, solving real-world problems and contributing to advancements in medicine, environmental sustainability, artificial intelligence, and more. The skills gained in STEMsuch as critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical reasoningare highly transferable, making it easier to adapt to different roles and industries. Additionally, working in STEM often provides access to cutting-edge technology and the chance to collaborate with leading experts, fostering continuous learning and professional development. Beyond work, the financial stability and intellectual satisfaction that come with a STEM career can enhance your quality of life, allowing for greater freedom, security, and the ability to support your family. Choosing a STEM career not only opens doors to exciting opportunities but also helps avoid the stress and limitations of low-paying, physically demanding jobs.

One of the main reasons why I decided to major in a field of STEM was because of engineering. To me, engineering allow me to not only learn about theories and materials related to math, but also allows me to put what I learned into practice. Being able to actually put that things I learned into projects that I create is what really makes me stay in engineering, even though I may struggle at times, its just a lot more engaging than the other things that I tried learn in the past. I know that in the future that while my classes get even harder than they are now, I will believe in myself and try to persevere through them because I wish to get a career doing the thing that I love to do and learn.

Ive always been fascinated by the way the world works not just in a broad, philosophical sense, but in the tangible, logical structures that underpin everything around us. From an early age, I was drawn to problem-solving, whether it was figuring out how a toy worked, solving puzzles, or later, diving into math and science classes. Theres something incredibly satisfying about tackling a complex problem and finding a solution that makes sense. STEM excites me because its always evolving. Science and technology are shaping the future, from medical advancements to artificial intelligence to space exploration. I want to be part of that to contribute, to innovate, and to push the boundaries of whats possible. Its not just about personal achievement; its about making a difference. STEM fields have the power to improve lives, solve real-world problems, and create a better future. At the same time, I know STEM is challenging. There will be moments of frustration, where things dont work, where problems seem impossible. But thats part of the journey. I want to develop resilience, curiosity, and the ability to keep pushing forward. At the end of the day, I want to pursue a career where Im constantly learning, growing, and contributing to something bigger than myself. STEM is where I see that happening.

I want to get into the STEM field because it is the continuation of my career of being in the Air Force from 2012 to 2018 as a cyber security specialist. I aim to gain more understanding with computing/programming, as well as the regulatory and security aspects within this field. As we transition our cyber infrastructure into the AI realm, I'm extremely interested in generative AI, natural learning models, and clustering in general. After working within a government network frame, my curiosity for the civilian sector has always been curious with how they manage themselves from tier 1 to tier 3 archetypes. I plan to curate systems that aid human experience and allow people to be more imaginative with their work rather than learning logical processes that can be managed by AI systems. Redundancy is not a creative human experience in my opinion. It has it's positives, but we are always adapting and I believe a lot of this redundancy can be housed with primed models that stay within a parameter while we as people curate infinitely.

I'm an engineering student and taking this class is more than just fulfilling a requirement, it is quite literally a foundational step toward understanding how the world works from a scientific and mathematical perspective. Engineering is all about problem solving, innovation, and designing systems that improve lives, and physics provides the principles that make these advancements possible. One of the main reasons I'm taking physics is because of the problem solving mindset that physics developes. Physics challenges me to really think critically, analyze situations and apply mathematical reasoning to find solutions. This skill is not just useful for exams but will be important when I work or real civil engineering projects, where precision and logical thinking will quite literally make the difference between either killing or saving human lives. I find the physics helps me appriciate how engineering innovations are grounded in the laws of nature, everything I look at a bridge, and airplane or even a simple cooling system, I realize the the physics principles that make them function properly.

I'm taking physics to get my computer science degree. The goal is to have a high paying job down the road. SFSU has physics as part of that degree. I'm very interested in the advanced concepts of physics and what we've been able to learn about the universe from just math. Thankfully there are plenty of youtube channels out there that go into what we've learned about how the universe works with a broad overview of the math. The more concepts I learn in school, the more fulfilling those youtube videos become. I'm just not very good at math. I'm sticking with math despite having to retake several classes because I know it's good for preventing diseases such as Alzheimer's, mental fortitude, and a better understanding of the mechanics of the universe. I look forward to learning more about the laws of the universe. There is something quasi-spiritual about how the universe arose form a point smaller than an atom and here we are 14 billion years later.

Why am I here? Great question. Honestly, I question that myself. Sometimes, walking to class, I go through that same thought. Even in class, it is challenging not to go through the motions. I'm here to get my degree. I'm here to improve myself and grow my knowledge. I'm here to represent the aspirations of those who were denied equal opportunities. I've witnessed hardship, and I don't wish to remain mired in it. For myself, my family, and possibly even other people who are similar to me, I want to make things better. Being here keeps me going even when I feel lost. I'm trying, but I'm not perfect. And that is sufficient justification to continue attending. To be honest, I want to develop and show myself that I am more capable than what life or other people may have thought I was. I'm here because I think I'm pursuing a stronger, smarter, and more focused version of myself that I haven't yet encountered.

I'm here for many reasons, starting with the most important is that I want to learn more about physics because I just like learning about math related things because I've always been good at them and obviously people enjoy things that they're naturally better at. Secondly, because I need credits related to computer science and physics is one of the required classes to take. Also, I typically don't like doing group work because most of the time the groups are randomized and I have to meet new people who I've never spoken to for each group thing I do, but lab work is the exception because most of the time you stay with the same group for a majority of the time and that's much better for me. Finally, I like doing group work when it's primarily on paper (which we didn't do for the most recent lab) but I want the rest of the labs to be done on paper because group members can pass around the paper and each person can write what they want and edit the problems of others.

The reason why I am in the class is because it'll help me complete future coursework for my degree. I'm currently taking physics 1 with calculus 1 and concurrent enrollment in this lab is required. I am excited to learn new things in my physics lecture and physics lab.

By taking this class, my goal is focused on trying to reinforce my knowledge on concepts, to be confident in my answer choice during exams. Physics labs are important because they help students understand what you learn in class by letting them experiment and see things in action. In a lab, you get to test ideas and see how physical principles like motion, energy, and force work in real life. This helps you understand the concepts better. Labs also teach you useful skills like problem-solving, thinking critically, and working with scientific tools. Students learn to collect data, analyze results, and work with others to solve problems. These skills are important for jobs in science, engineering, and technology. By doing experiments, you can see how theories match up with real-world results, making learning more interesting and practical. Physics labs are key to turning theory into understanding and preparing you for a future in science and technology.

My main goal is to build a strong foundation in both physics concepts and their mathematical applications. I want to understand how the laws of motion, forces, energy, and other physical principles apply to the real world, especially in relation to engineering and technology. Another goal is to improve my problem-solving and critical thinking skills by learning how to design experiments, collect and analyze data, and draw logical conclusions based on evidence. This class can help me achieve these goals by giving me hands-on experience with physical systems and the tools used to study them. Working in the lab allows me to see how theoretical concepts connect to real-life situations, making the learning process more meaningful and memorable. It also gives me the chance to practice using calculus to solve physics problems, which strengthens both subjects at the same time. By working in a team and communicating results clearly in lab reports, I also develop collaboration and communication skills that are important in any career. Overall, this class supports my academic and professional development by teaching me how to think like a scientist and approach problems with curiosity and precision.

I find myself thinking about my future and what I hope to achieve. I believe the analytical skills and problem-solving approaches I'll learn here will be invaluable since I'm entering the field of computer science. The combination of physics with calculus is particularly exciting because it shows how mathematical tools can describe real-world phenomena with more precision. I'm hoping the labs will give more hands experience with real-world modeling. When facing complex problems, I want to learn to break them down methodically and approach them with more confidence. This class is satiating my curiosity and drives me to ask deeper questions about the world around me. Understanding the universe's laws can only help me in a broad range of situations.

Doing this lab really helped me slow down and notice the details in how things movesomething I never really thought about before. When we used the motion detector, it was kind of eye-opening to see how walking at a constant speed is actually kind of hard. I kept thinking I was moving steadily, but the graphs told a different story. It made me realize how valuable it is to have tools that can track and visualize motion in such a precise way. I also liked how the lab connected different ways of understanding motiongraphs, equations, and just describing it in words. I usually lean more toward verbal explanations, so translating that into a graph or equation challenged me in a good way. It showed me that science isn't just about numbersit's also about learning how to communicate clearly across different formats. This lab reminded me that learning isnt just about getting the right answer. Its about asking questions like: What does this slope actually mean? Why does the graph look like that? That mindset is something I want to carry into other parts of my lifeslowing down, observing, and being curious instead of rushing to the end.

I think in order to use AI in stem is only to have a better understanding for topics that you may stuck on. If your using AI to get answers your not getting any benefit from learning to become better in that subject in which you are using AI. I think that AI plays a good role in STEM, it can accelerate research, by improving data analytics. AI does a better job at sifting through large datasets, it can quite literally identify patterns, and generate better summaries, that can help in everything from finding out a new drug to everything else. AI for me is so helpful for brainstorming, problem solving, and clarifying hard concepts instead of using it as a shortcut to complete homework assignments. I also double check my work using A.I, sometimes whenever i think that my work may be incorrect or severely out of place, i use A.I to see if my answers are actually correct. Beyond just school, I use AI tools to learn new topics all the time, this type of engagement will help build practical skills for the future of STEM.

I'm cautiously optimistic about AIs potential. AI has become my personal tutor in many ways, especially when tackling complex math problems. While it may struggle with comprehensive mathematical solutions, I've found it invaluable for breaking down some of the smaller concepts or sub-problems. Human tutors have a mixed record with me, but AI has been consistent, when the answers are available online. The comparison between AI and traditional online learning resources feels particularly relevant in mathematics. Just as I might turn to Khan Academy or other video tutorials, AI serves as another tool in my learning arsenal. The fundamental nature of mathematical concepts, which are unchanging and timeless, makes AI particularly reliable in this domain. However, I recognize the limitations in rapidly evolving fields like biology. Scientific discoveries and breakthroughs happen regularly, and AI might lag behind these developments. This reinforces my belief that AI should complement, not replace, traditional learning methods. I'm pragmatic about AI's boundaries. It can't take my exams or do my work for me. The reality is that AI is here to stay; the toothpaste can't be put back in the tube. The key lies in learning to use it ethically and effectively as a support tool rather than a crutch.

AI is very helpful as a learning tool as it can be used as a tutor of sorts. I have found it fvery helpful in helping me to understand complex subject matter in Computer Science, Math, and Physics. The use of AI however for just getting the answers to homework problems instead helping one have a deep understanding, is however not a helpful use of AI, as when test time comes, you won't be able to refer to AI for assistance. If students keep this in mind and use AI and a way to clarify concepts, it is a very useful tool. I haven't attempted to use AI to help me with constructing papers. I can see how it could be helpful in helping get over writers block by helping to give the user a sense of structure of how they might one to break down the formation of a paper on a particular subject. But of course again, it would not be helpful for a students learning to have an AI just write out a paper for you.

AI is beginning to have a significant impact on STEM fields; it is altering how we learn, solve problems, and even think. AI is a tool, in my opinion, much more sophisticated than a calculator or lab instrument. It can assist in solving equations, running simulations, and even providing more comprehensible explanations of complex ideas. However, I am aware that it cannot take the place of comprehension. I'm not truly learning if I just copy and paste my answers. As a student, I believe that treating AI like a tutor or assistant is the most moral way to use it. When you're stuck, use it to check your thinking, ask it for advice, or gain a better understanding. However, don't let it make decisions for you. It's simple to become lazy with it, but then what's the point of going to school? Instead of taking shortcuts, I want to use AI to advance my skills. AI can help me grow and accomplish my goals more quickly if I'm sincere and purposeful, while maintaining the authenticity of the learning process.

For someone like me who sometimes likes to draw, I have a more negative opinion on AI in general. But when it comes to AI outside of art I think that it's usage is a lot more useful as a tool to makes things easier, but it can't replace actual human work. You could use AI to sort things, search things up faster while not necessarily increasing the quality of research, and to do simple but long tasks much faster. STEM is a field that relates a lot to numbers and AI can easily get accurate results because the steps in math equations can very quickly and easily be done by a computer so AI can be very useful when computing. But I feel like physics related and engineering tasks should still be done by humans because I can't see myself putting my trust in AI to create stable, but also nice looking architecture unless they can make decent AI art without just copying from other things.

The role that AI in STEM plays is that it is a helpful tool for students can use to study. AI is a personal TA that a student has access to at any point in time. This tool should be used responsibly and ethically. It should only be a helpful hand and not actually do the students work for them. If a student is stuck on a problem they can ask AI to help guide them through the problem but not tell them the answer to the problem. It can be used for clarification if a student is confused on a step in their notes from lecture. It could also be used to check if a students work is correct and compare answers. AI is a helpful tool in STEM as long as it is used ethically as a learning tool and not to solve your work for you. It is worth to mention that AI is not 100% accurate so it is good to question AI's responses.

AI is really changing STEM in many ways. In science, it helps researchers analyze data way faster than people can, like in medicine to find cures or in space to study planets. In technology, AI is in coding, making apps, even in robots. Engineers use AI to design buildings and machines, and in math, it helps solve hard problems that take people long time to do. AI is everywhere in STEM, and its gonna be even more in the future. As a student, I think AI is really useful, but I have to be careful how I use it. It can explain things to me when I dont understand, like a tutor, but if I just copy what AI says, Im not really learning. Like if I use AI to help with coding, I should try to write the code myself first, then check if AI can fix mistakes, not just let it write the whole thing. Also, using AI the right way is important. I shouldnt use it to cheat, because then I dont learn anything. And AI can be wrong sometimes, so I have to think about what it says instead of trusting it blindly. AI is a great tool, but I need to be smart about how I use it to really learn and not just take shortcuts.

AI is becoming a powerful tool in STEM, helping scientists, engineers, and researchers solve complex problems faster than ever before. It is used for data analysis, simulations, automation, and even medical breakthroughs. As a student, I can use AI to enhance my learning, such as by using AI-powered tutoring systems, generating ideas, or checking my understanding of difficult concepts. However, ethical AI use is important. Instead of letting AI do my work for me, I should use it as a tool to support my learninghelping me brainstorm, edit, and refine my work rather than replacing my effort. Academic honesty matters, so I must ensure that my work remains my own. By using AI responsibly, I can make the most of its benefits while still developing critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

In STEM, AI would be a huge help with a lot of things. It can help summurize things in a way that is easy to understand and it can also help with giving information. AI has become a controversial topic as students have come to use LLM as some sort of cheat code. When in actuality they are doing themselves a disservice as it stops them from developing effective problem-solving skills that will be needed in the career they chose to pursue. However, I believe that AI is an incredibly powerful tool that can be used to explain topics in greater detail similar to a tutor. This is very resourceful since many students have busy schedules that prevent them from going to office hours, Ethical use of LLM's can be used by creating notes, summaries of advanced topics, example problems or steps to get to a solution without actually giving them the solution. I personally, use the following prompt when tasked with difficult problems "What is this question asking of me and provide me hints on how to solve this problem, but do not give me the solution." I find this approach to be incredibly helpful without depriving myself from the hard work of figuring it out.

This lab honestly made me rethink how I understand acceleration. Before, I always thought acceleration just meant going faster, but now I get that its more about how velocity changeswhether somethings speeding up, slowing down, or even changing direction. I never really paid attention to how important the sign (positive or negative) is until we looked at the graphs. Like, the idea that something can be speeding up with negative acceleration kind of blew my mind. Using the fan cart made things way easier to visualize. Watching it speed up or slow down, and then matching that to the velocity and acceleration graphs, helped everything start to make more sense. I think the most interesting part was when the cart turned aroundthe velocity hit zero but acceleration was still happening. That moment made me realize how much more is going on than we notice just by looking. Overall, this lab helped me slow down and actually think about whats happening during motion. It made physics feel less like a bunch of formulas and more like a way to tell the story of how something moves.

The way I used AI makes me believe that their role is to provide a solid grasp on STEM and have us learn from it. In addition to this role, the AI can be incorporated in algorithms to provide valuable insight and adapt to the demands of the users. However, I also learned that the AI algorithms are flawed because being fed the wrong information or not enough would result in biases via patterns. As a student, it is my responsibility as a stakeholder to use AI responsibly for my learning and calculations. It should also be ethically important that I rely on my own experiences to make good judgment, rather than to rely on an imperfect AI. What I can do to be ethical is to provide feedback on the AI I utilize so the developers of the AI would make improvements. In conclusion, it is okay to use AI for learning, but we should rely on ourselves and send feedback for future improvements.

AI is changing STEM in a big way. It makes calculations faster helps analyze massive datasets and improves problem-solving in fields like physics, engineering and medicine. Its basically becoming a necessary tool for efficiency but like anything powerful it comes with responsibilities. If I just let it do everything Im not really learning. I see it as something that can streamline studying and coding but I still need to put in the effort to develop my own skills. At the end of the day AI is here to stay in STEM and knowing how to use it the right way gives me an edge. The key is finding that balance between leveraging its power and making sure Im still thinking for myself.

AI in stem can be really helpful but I can see many students using it the wrong way. AI's role in stem could be used as a computer to help you check if your work is correct and help spot potential issues in work. Many students use AI the wrong way by instead of using AI as a way to help to double check work or help create practice problems or help you in a step by step way, they will rely on AI completely letting it do their homework and projects for them. Doing that doesn't teach the students anything and makes the AI the student since the AI is the one doing the homework and taking in the material. How I can ethically and productively use AI as a student is to instead of doing the homework for me, I would do the homework and the AI could grade it for me. I could also use AI as a way to study by it giving me some practice problems or it assisting me in understanding concepts that I didn't understand before. Like if it was a constant 24/7 teacher. That is how I could see AI being used ethically and productively as a student.

AI plays a huge role in STEM by helping solve problems faster and more efficiently, sometimes in ways we cant even predict. It can process massive amounts of data, automate tedious tasks, and simulate complex scenarios that humans might not be able to handle. In research, AI can help identify patterns and solutions that would have otherwise gone unnoticed. It can revolutionize how we approach everything from medicine to engineering to environmental issues. As a student, I think AI can be incredibly helpful, but its important to use it responsibly. Its easy to get caught up in the convenience of having a tool that can do so much for you. But I think the key is to use AI as a supplement to my learning, not a crutch. Its okay to use AI for brainstorming ideas, checking calculations, or even helping write a first draft. But the real learning comes when I engage with the material and challenge myself to understand the concepts. Ethically, I have to be careful about relying too much on AI for answers. I want to be sure Im still learning and growing, and that the work I turn in is my own.

I think that AI is definitely starting to make a huge impact in STEM. AI is very useful in helping with project, assignments, compiling data, and way more. I think AI is used to help in stem. AI is only going to get better in the future which is why I think we should engage in it and use it as a tool instead of treating it as a bad thing for school. AI plays a big role in STEM by helping us come up with ideas, making things more accurate, and improving the way we work. It helps scientists, engineers, and researchers analyze data, automate tasks, and create new solutions. In fields like medicine, engineering, and environmental science, AI makes processes more efficient and reliable. As technology keeps evolving, AI is going to be an even bigger part of our daily lives, so its important to embrace it while also having clear rules and limits on how we use it. As a student, I try to use AI in a way that actually helps me learn instead of just doing the work for me. For example, I use AI to help me study by explaining how to solve integrals step by step and checking if my answers are correct. I also use it to practice my speeches by using the microphone feature to get feedback. Even when writing essays, I ask AI to review my work and suggest improvements. I think AI is a great tool, but its important not to depend on it too much. At the end of the day, we still need to think for ourselves and develop our own skills instead of letting AI do everything for us.

AI is obviously an incredibly versatile tool that can be used for a lot of things. I'll start by saying what I don't think AI should do. AI shouldn't be the decision maker behind what gets researched in STEM fields. I think that human judgement is needed when directing and making key decisions on how human lives are affected. Of course AI data can be used to help human decision makers make decisions. In many ways AI is great for making sense of data. It can be used to categorize and sort through large data sets to find patterns. This is already helping in numerous medical fields, which is great for finding cures for certain diseases. AI should be deployed in beneficial, sympathetic, and positive environments. Using AI in warzones or as violent instruments of force should be avoided. I think the international community should outlaw AI in warzones just like chemical weapons because of the possibility for major ethical questions.

When I think about AI in STEM, I feel both excited and worried. AI is very powerful. It can help us learn and solve problems quickly. It can also find new ideas that people might not see. But sometimes, I worry about using AI too much. If we rely on AI for everything, we might lose important skills. We need to be careful and make sure we still learn how to think, solve problems, and understand things by ourselves. As a student, I want to use AI in a good way. It can help me understand difficult things and give me answers fast. It can also show me new ways of looking at problems. But I still need to think for myself. I should not let AI do all the work. AI should help me learn, but not replace my thinking. I want to be able to solve problems on my own and feel proud of what I learn. I also need to use AI honestly. AI should help me become smarter and better at learning, not just help me get good grades. If I use AI just to get easy answers, I won't really learn. In the future, AI and people will work together more and more. This is exciting because it means we can do amazing things together. But I know I need to use AI carefully and responsibly. By doing this, I can grow as a student and be ready for the future.

responsibilities, and personal commitments start piling up. When things get tough, I remind myself why I started this journey in the first place. I think what a lot of people tend to do is trying to attack the problem but sometimes that wont work. When life gets challenging, I remind myself to take a step back and breathe. Stress and pressure can feel overwhelming, but I know that Ive been through tough moments before and made it through. In these times, I turn to the resources available to me whether its talking to a friend, seeking support from professors, or just taking a break to clear my mind. Sometimes, a short walk or even a deep breath can help reset my perspective. I also try to remind myself why I started. Whether its school, a project, or a personal goal, I know that challenges are just part of the journey. Instead of letting them discourage me, I try to use them as motivation to keep pushing forward. Its okay to struggle, to feel tired, and to need rest. The important thing is to keep going, even if its just one step at a time. Most importantly, I remind myself that I am capable. Ive handled difficult situations before, and I will handle this one too. I have support, I have resilience, and I have the strength to keep moving forward. No challenge is permanent, and Ive got this.

balls at us all the time, and I've learned to develop my own toolkit for handling these challenging moments. When things get overwhelming, I've discovered that physical exercise is my go-to stress reliever. Whether it's a quick jog or some stretching, moving my body helps clear my mind and reset my perspective. I've also found that meditation and getting extra sleep are crucial for maintaining my mental balance. These practices help me stay grounded and remind me that challenges are temporary. Sometimes, I just need to pause and tell myself, "Hey, you're doing your best, and that's all anyone can ask for." One of my most effective strategies is having multiple life goals in progress. When one path feels particularly challenging, I can temporarily shift my focus to another priority. This approach helps me maintain forward momentum while giving myself a mental break from whatever's troubling me. It's like having different paths to the summit  if one route becomes too steep, I can take an alternate trail while still moving upward. This system of self-care and goal flexibility has helped me navigate through numerous challenging periods, reminding me that I have the tools and resilience to handle whatever comes my way.

When life gets challenging I try to set some time aside to plan out my objectives and outline the good order set of actions toward the completion my goals. I have a many animals that I care for which is both time consuming and physically draining. Guided Meditation has been one resource that has helped me find a sense of grounding, which has been particular useful during challenging times. Also talking to a friend about my challenges has been very helpful as a way for me to feel like I am not alone in my struggles and I feel encouraged to press forward when I feel heard and supported.

Hmm. Good question. Typically, I would prefer that to be on my own. Generally, when that does not solve things, I would turn to the people closest to me. When life gets challenging, I try to remind myself to take things one step at a time.
