A nap helps remove any negative emotions and when I wake up I feel relaxed and ready to do stuff. Another thing I can do is do something relaxing. Some examples of relaxing things for me are watching videos or playing easy games. Videos help me turn my brain off and I can just enjoy what I watch. For games I enjoy simple stuff where I don't have to worry about anything. Not all games work for me though. For example, multiplayer games can make me feel more stressed sometimes because I have to deal with other people and other people can be very annoying. If I play a game alone I don't have to worry about anything and I can do whatever I want, including trying stupid stuff, like getting an army of pets that I can send to eat my enemies.

The force lab I was able to analyze and see the different types of forces and their effects. The forces I am referring to are gravity tension and friction. One thing that went well was how I was able to use the diagrams to help me visualize the direction and magnitude of forces acting on the objects. I also see how it was helpful to use the force probes to measure and confirm and reinforce the relationship between mass force and acceleration. One big takeaway for me how understanding that normal force does not equal weight, especially on inclined surfaces. Another takeaway was that friction is dependent on the normal force and not just the weight alone. This helps explain why heavier objects do not always experience more friction if the contact force is constant. Another observation was how tension is constant in a string but will vary when you apply other forces such as pulleys or more if more mass is added the weight. I need clarification on tension and multiple forces. Overall, the lab made it easier to understand newtons laws and made a hands-on approach easy.

When life gets challenging I like to just take a slow things down and really reflect on why I am so stressed. Once I find the source of my stress I can begin to find ways to reduce it. That may be me going for a walk, hanging out with friends or partaking in a hobby. The reason I choose to do these things is because it allows your mind to focus on something different. Simply taking your mind off things can really allow you to gain a different perspective about your situation. How we percieve a challenging situation is important because as many tend to stress we can chose to look at it from a different lens. Where we see the challenging time as a motivator to work more effectively or can see it as a learning experience.

When life becomes difficult, I try to remind myself to do these things step by step. It is easy to get caught up, but I've found that breaking problems down into little tasks makes them easier to deal with. One of the best things for me is to take a deep breath and be still before I act. No matter what, whether school stress, personal problems, or uncertainty of the future, I remind myself that difficult times pass and I've beaten them before. Also started some habits to ground myself. Talking with a good friend or relative makes me feel less alone, and getting things out in writing clears my head. Now and then take a short walk or listen to music to shake my head out. If the obstacle seems too overwhelming to tackle by myself, I remind myself that it is okay to ask for assistance. There will always be challenges in life, but I think resilience lies in how we react to them. By remaining patient with myself and concentrating on what I can control, I am able to find the strength to continue moving forward.

When life gets challenging I am very prone to staying in bed and not leaving. I have been trying to get myself to leave my house and go out to at least see the sun. I also tend to lean on others when life gets hard and have help for basic things so I can focus on the hard overwhelming stuff.

Usually, when life gets more complicated than usual, the first thing I feel is very depressed. Especially when conditional problems go one after another. It doesn't make it any fun, and sometimes it feels like giving up and never coming back to it again. But the only thing that doesn't help me fold my hands is my thoughts, long and deep. I talk a lot, almost always. And my reasoning leads me to the fact that the things that happen to me are trials from above and only you, the creator of your desires and ambitions, can overcome them. With my little experience in life so far, I have already realized that there will always be problems, and the main goal of any person is to get used to it and consistently solve it based on priority. The most important thing is that all problems do not come to you at one point in your life, then it will be very painful and unpleasant, and the only way out is to ask for help and pray for universal luck.

When life gets tough I try to take a step back and breathe. Sometimes everything feels like too much at once and just pausing for a second helps me clear my head. I usually reach out to someone I trust maybe a friend a family member or even just writing things down. Writing helps me untangle my thoughts and figure out what is actually bothering me instead of letting it all pile up in my head. If I am overwhelmed I break things down into smaller steps. Thinking about everything at once just makes it worse so I focus on what I can do right now. Sometimes I just need a little reset like listening to music taking a walk or watching something funny to help me recharge. And when I start doubting myself I remind myself of all the challenges I have already overcome. If I got through those I can get through this too. Most of all I try to be patient with myself. It is easy to get caught up in stress but I know that taking care of myself is just as important as getting things done. No matter how hard it gets I remind myself I have got this.

When my life gets challenging, I find myself searching for answers to overcome it. Most of the time when I'm put to a halt, I ask either a group of people or one of my family members what I should do in this situation. However I already knew that there won't always be a time that I can take the easier route for my problems. It has been a very uncomfortable lifestyle to adapt towards, but I believe there is some benefits in trying to find alternative approaches. This can be said when I had my first college experience here at SFSU, trying to organize workflow and comprehending concepts that they expect for me to learn in a matters of a few days. In conclusion, I had to rely more on myself to take responsibility for my learning and utilize an AI assistant more frequently to further my understanding when some of these classes don't ever give me further insight, but only when it fits their schedule and not mines. But I don't spite them, because I know I must learn to carry my own weight.

Life gets tough every day, and to be honest, I just get through it the best that I can. Sometimes that means taking a step back, taking a deep breath, and reminding myself that things aren't going to stay bad forever. Other times, it's about having to push through, even when I don't feel like it. When school gets tough, like with this physics lab on forcescontact and non-contact forces, all these different interactions, it is easier to make things simpler. Just as in physics, where forces occur in ways that we do not always perceive, life brings me things that I might not necessarily perceive at the moment. When things get overwhelming, I stick with what I know will work. I make lists, I write things down (because that makes my brain work), and I remind myself that I've handled worse in the past. If I'm stuck, I seek helpwhether it's classmates, professors, or just talking it out with friends. And sometimes I just give myself a good frustrating for a minute before getting back to work. I know that no challenge lasts forever, and even if things feel stuck, Ill figure it out. I always do.

When life gets challenging, I go through many different states of mind. At first I would feel like it's too much and I freak out. But then I would just stop and either go on a walk or go breathe. Other things that I would do is go eat while talking to my friend to clear my mind. Having someone to talk to or share the challenges really softens the blow. It helps because it reminds me that I'm not alone and there are others feeling the same. Other things that help me is my motivation. I remind myself why I am here and what lengths the people in my life went through to get me here. That keeps me pushing no matter what. Without my family and friends, I would definitely be in a lost state of mind. But I also have to know my limits and when I need to ask for help because there are resources that are there for me to use.

When life gets overwhelming, I turn to Elden Ring and puzzle games to help me unwind. While Elden Ring is known for its difficulty, I find its vast world and methodical combat surprisingly therapeutic. Exploring breathtaking landscapes, uncovering hidden secrets, and gradually mastering its challenges give me a sense of control and accomplishment. Every tough boss I defeat reminds me that persistence pays off, making real-life stress feel more manageable. On the other hand, puzzle games provide a different kind of escape. Whether its solving intricate brainteasers or working through logic-based challenges, puzzles help me focus and clear my mind. The process of breaking down a problem and finding a solution gives me a small but satisfying sense of victory, helping to replace stress with a feeling of progress. Both Elden Ring and puzzles offer different yet effective ways to relieve stressone through immersive adventure and the other through mental stimulation. No matter how tough the day gets, I know I can always lose myself in a challenge, reset my mind, and come back stronger.

When life gets a little challenging, I have my ways to deal with it. I would try to do something that can calm myself down like playing a game or watching some videos. If there's were going rough and I just want to relax for a little, I can play a game with my friends to keep my mind off the stress for a little. In this time as I relax, I can start to think of ways I can deal with these hardships. It's important to not let challenges and stress take over your live and to give yourself a little break in order to think, process, and understand what your going through and the possible solutions. Also I could eat something that I like. I like eating food and if I eat something that I like, that can help relief me a little as I'm eating something yummy.

When life gets challenging, I meditate and exercise to find clarity and peace. Taking long, deep breaths helps me calm my mind and refocus on the present moment. It reminds me not to get too overwhelmed by stress or to worry about the future. Instead of letting anxiety take over, I use meditation as a tool to center myself and regain control of my thoughts. To deepen my practice, I joined the meditation club at SFSU. Being part of this community has been a valuable experience, as it provides a supportive space where I can practice mindfulness alongside others who share similar goals. Group meditation sessions make me feel more connected and remind me that I am not alone in my struggles. The club has helped me develop a more consistent meditation routine and has encouraged me to prioritize self-care. In addition to meditation, I go to the gym and run regularly to keep my mind fresh. Physical activity helps me release stress and clear my thoughts. Whenever I feel overwhelmed, I remind myself that challenges are temporary. Meditation and exercise teach me resilience, helping me push through difficulties with a clear and focused mind.

When life gets challenging, I try to focus on one thing at a time because I don't want to be overwhelmed by multiple things. It is better to take it down one by one since you can have the most dedication and spirit in the world but can break down by a series of small things at once. To relieve or relax myself, I do things I like doing. The more positive I'm feeling, the better my experience is. Also, one of the most important resources anyone could have is people. I find myself confiding in people, whether it is emotionally or just hanging out. It is good to surround yourself with your friends and family because it is easier to take things on if you're not alone.

When lifes get challenging, I pray or meditate or find a hobbie or something I like to do. Praying helps me relieve stress and talking to God about life is a good way not only to build my faith and relationship with God but also help make like more easier. I know I can talk to God about anything im dealing with so when life is gets hard and stressful, I ask God to relieve the stess. Meditating is also an activity I do when life gets hard. Breathing is lways helpful when being stressed especcially for me because the more stress I am about life, the more overwhelmed I feel. . Taking deep breaths helps me calm my mind and refocus on what actuallt matters. Meditation allows me to clear my thoughts. I helps me gain perspective and approach challenges with a clearer, more positive mindset. Another way I cope with life's difficulties is by engaging in hobbies that bring me joy. Going to the gym, Playing basketball and listening to music are activities I engage in. These activities serve as a healthy distraction and an outlet for my refocusing my joy. They allow me to endure my stress into something productive and makes me happy.

I think I am in a challenging situation right now. Theres a lot can happen in a span of one week; what can be considered a short period of time. A lot of work that needs to be done, things to catch up on, and just have some sense of progress. Sometimes, I procrastinate and cram, which makes things even harder, but there are times when I dont take breaks at all. The feeling of restlessness takes over me and I guess somehow consume me; which is bad. Even so, I am reminded that there are people and resources that can help me. I am always grateful for my friends. Despite the distance and time difference, we find ourselves supporting each other. I would ask for help in both personal and academic situations. Furthermore, I appreciate the resources SFSU providesTASC, Advisors, etc. I like that its readily available for students. What do I do when life gets challenging? I try to solve it, then complain, and when things get too much, I reach out and ask for help. I think that its important to ask for help. You can only do so much alone, so I guess, just know that there are people who will always help you.

I think the way to deal with challenge is to keep a resilient mindset. A bend but don't break philosophy that is all about eventually solving the problems and addressing the challenges over time. It is important to avoid a defeatist mindset and to always keep a belief that the challenges can be overcome eventually. Also, it is important to analyze what particular events or problems are the root cause of the difficulty. Analyzing what these causes are, whether they be self inflicted, the result of bad luck, or the doing of other factors is important to finding solutions and ultimately overcoming the challenges. I think that getting your own thoughts organized is another good way to address challenges. Being overwhelmed is one of the worst challenges and it can make other problems a lot worse. Finally, It is definitely advisable to reach out to find other people to provide support because it is difficult to overcome difficult challenges alone.

When life gets challenging, I turn to God. In those moments when I feel lost or overwhelmed, I find comfort in prayer. It feels like Im having a private conversation where I can let everything out without the fear of being judged. Somehow, God always shows me a path forward, even if its not immediate. Ive realized that I dont have anyone else to talk to about what Im feeling. Its not that my family isnt supportive; its just that I cant seem to express my emotions to them. Maybe its because, as a man, Ive grown up thinking that showing emotions is a sign of weakness or something to be ashamed of. I guess I worry about how they might see me if I open up. So, I keep things to myself and rely on faith to get through the hard times. In a way, I think that makes me stronger, even if it can feel lonely sometimes. Knowing that God is listening helps me keep going.

Community have been my foundation through college. From a young age, I was taught to work hard, stay humble, and always look out for others and that mindset has carried me through every tough class, every long night, and every never giving up. Seeing how much my community has sacrificed and poured into me gives me a reason to keep pushing

The values that I carry from my family is trying my best. This is because there will be ups and downs during college and the journey won't be very easy. So, it is a constant motivation to do my best and become the first in my family to graduate college. Since they have worked their hardest to get where they are now and help me get the chance to go to college. I think taking breaks is also a part of what is helping me get through which has helped me because you also don't want to overstimulate yourself with a lot of school work as well as things that may happen in the personal life. Other than that my main value is trying my best no matter how many times I may fail, eventually you will succeed on what you have been struggling with throughout those tough times in college.

The values instilled in me by my family and community have played a crucial role in shaping my college experience. Growing up, my family emphasized perseverance, hard work, and the importance of education. These principles have helped me stay motivated, even when facing academic challenges. When I struggled with complex coursework or overwhelming deadlines, I relied on the resilience my parents taught me reminding myself that effort and persistence lead to success. Additionally, my community has always valued support and collaboration. Whether through church, school, or local organizations, I was raised in an environment where people uplift one another. This has influenced the way I approach relationships in college, encouraging me to seek help when needed and to support my peers in return. Study groups, mentorship, and campus organizations have become an essential part of my success, reinforcing the idea that no one achieves greatness alone. Moreover, my family's strong sense of integrity and responsibility has guided my decision-making in college. Whether choosing my major, managing my time, or balancing social and academic life, these values have helped me stay focused and make ethical choices. Ultimately, the principles of hard work, community, and integrity continue to shape my journey, allowing me to navigate college with confidence.

College requires you to have a support network. My partner, friends and family support me going to college and I couldn't do it without their support. My family has always emphasized working efficiently rather than just putting in hours, a principle that's been crucial during exam seasons when time management becomes everything. One of the most important lessons my community has distilled in me is to never half-ass things. This value has pushed me to give my best in every project, even when I'm tired or overwhelmed. It's about respect for the work itself and for my own capabilities. When I struggled with difficult courses, my friends reminded me that failure is part of the learning process. This perspective transformed my relationship with setbacks, helping me see them as stepping stones rather than roadblocks. My mentors consistently reinforced that mastery comes through practice. This patience with the learning process has helped me persevere through challenging subjects, understanding that expertise isn't built overnight. Perhaps most importantly, my community taught me to enjoy the journey. College isn't just about the degree at the endit's about growth, discovery, and forming connections that last a lifetime. This mindset has helped me find joy even during stressful periods, reminding me to appreciate these formative years.

My mom has been especially supportive with me going back to school. I didn't think I would be able to go back to school. And her friend Cort and been very helpful to take me to school and pick me up from school on occasion. I has also been emotionally had to go back to school. School often causes me a lot of stress. Which in tern has caused my mom a lot of stress. I am trying to handle school better, at least in part to lesson the stress on my mom.

I've been educated in multicultural environments with multicultural persons and communities around me and those who've taught me the value of work ethic, devotion, resilience, and equity in family. My family has always instilled in me the idea that no one is going to give me anything everything is earned with that mindset, it's helped me get through the hardships and late nights even when I'm tired studying and working in between classes, trying to pay attention with distractions. The other takeaway from my community is my responsibility to care for my people. Whether it's assisting peers, advocating for my needs, or perpetually engaging in a volunteer search, I have that instinct for others. Brotherhood, respect, and loyalty to myself mean everything in my life, primarily in operating systems I neither need nor enjoy. When college gets too much to handle, I remember that it's all for me but also for my family, my people, and my future. That's what keeps me going.

My siblings have both been to college but most of their advice has been for what classes to take and help with scheduling. When it comes to decisions during lectures and for homework, I do those on my own and this is where my values of my community come in. I have a very neutral/noting opinion when it comes to my interacting with the community because I dont like talking to and meeting new people. I do pretty much all of the work by myself and if I ever need help with something I use the internet. For group work I just power through it and do as little talking to others as possible. However theres an exception to all of this, and thats if someone goes out of their way to ask me for help for whatever reason. Im completely fine with helping others as long as they ask me first

The way the values of my community and family have helped me navigate through college is it has brought me strength to be in college. My family values hard work which motivates me to work hard in college. My family values honestly and integrity which makes me turn in honest work in college. They also value education and knowledge which is a huge reason why I am in college. They have many more values and these values are what help me stay focused in college.

The values of my family and community have served me well in making it through college. One of the strongest values I was raised with is perseverance. My family always emphasized the importance of working hard and never giving up, even when things get tough. This mindset has helped me push through difficult classes, late-night study sessions, and moments of self-doubt. Another important value is education. My parents always taught me that education is the key to a brighter future, and the encouragement they have given me has pushed me to stay focused on my goals. Even when I am under pressure, I remind myself that my education is not just for me but also for my family, who has made every sacrifice to allow me to succeed. Lastly, I have learned to ask for help and build relationships with my community. Through discussing with professors, group studying, or emotional support from friends, I have understood that I am not alone. I do not have to endure the struggles alone. Support and guidance from the people I love have motivated me to keep going.

My mom has been the biggest help for me since she helps pay for my college tuition. She can also help me whenever I need help with my homework since she is smart. She is also useful for whenever I need another person for my homework. My friends have also helped me since they help make me feel less bored here and when I need help I can ask them. They can also help when I miss a class since they can help tell me what happened when I was gone. My sister has also been a huge help since she already went to college, so she has helped me with choosing my class and planning out a good schedule. She also helps a bit with choosing my classes since she has an idea of what teachers are best and what teachers don't really care if I show up. She also helps me with my homework sometimes.

Growing up it has been obvious to me that my community values education. Because I am now old enough to see how similar beliefs have imprinted on me as well. My surrounding community has influenced ideas and the role that education plays in my life. By me living in Evergreen community in the Bay Area I was able to be influenced by my peers. A lot of people in Evergreen are hard driven people who take education seriously. So, when I think back to all the times life has had a negative impact on the relationship between my education and I it lets me reflect on the positives more because they both had brought me here. My family itself looks up at education but i would not say it is the biggest staple for people of my culture/ethnic background. But other than that, I can totally see how my community has influenced me for the best.

College is an incredibly challenging aspect of life that requires a strong support system. For me that is my family and friends their unwavering support gives me strength to stay up late to finish assignments or get in an extra hour of studying. Their belief in me reminds me why Im pursuing my education, even when the workload feels overwhelming. Additionally I have friends who aren't able to go to college due to the cost of tuition. I look at their situation with an empathetic view and use that as motivation to make the most the opportunity given to me. This is a big reason why I tend to put a large emphasis on work ethic. Not everyone has the same chances in life so it is important to thank those around you who support you and the best way to show your gratitude is to work your ass off and succeed.

During this week's laboratory exercise, I studied Newton's Third Law of Motion, which describes that whenever two objects interact, they push each other with equal and opposite forces. This finding was very clear through our push-carts experiment, which was done with the help of sensors in measuring the forces despite being pulled toward either carts. The conclusion is that forces are equal even with their masses, opposite but equal in the direction they act. This proves for me that it's not a theory but an observable occurrence in real-life situations. For instance, when one jumps from a boat onto a dock when one pushes the boat back, the person moves forward. Action-reaction in everyday life. Perhaps the lab taught me that forces go together and have smooth movements while Newton gives a uniform code under which everything explains the movements where they control the experiments and everywhere in the world around it.

My family is very big on the idea of education and learning the most about your craft. So in college now I try to learn as much as I can to get as much out of my tuition as I can. My parents also are big on not over extending yourself so I try to not take on too much so I can focus on the things that I care about. I end up spending my free time doing things for my class that maybe I do not need to do normally.

First of all, I would like to say that values that were embedded in me from my family really helpful. My parents always say me to talk to people in order to get into any local society, they were international students themselves, so they have already known what I will face in the United States. Their most important words were that I need to learn more languages as many as possible because in adulthood I probably will not be able to learn new ones. And they were absolutely correct, right now to learning a new language is very tough, because I already got to used to speak 1 language perfectly and my mind with tongue cannot reorganize smoothly without struggling. Also, my parents recommended me to learn very well in my school. Because, my gpa and results will be very positively affected on my chance in getting into a certain university. That recommendation saved me from sorting universities by the gpa requirements and I was choosing that ones that I like. Thank to parents.

This lab really shifted how I think about forces and motion. I always assumed the heavier object pushes harder or has more influence, so seeing two carts interact and show equal and opposite forces through the probes kind of surprised me. It didnt feel intuitive at first, but then the data made it clearNewtons Third Law is real, even when the objects have different masses. What also stood out to me was realizing that force is related to acceleration, not just movement. Ive definitely made the mistake of thinking constant motion means a force is being applied, but this lab helped break that habit. Drawing free-body diagrams and comparing the graphs with our predictions forced me to slow down and really think about what was going on physically, not just what looked right. Honestly, Im starting to enjoy how these labs challenge my assumptions. Its one thing to memorize Newtons Laws, but actually applying them and seeing them in action makes them feel way more real. This lab was a good reminder that in physics, whats true isnt always what feels obviousand thats kind of the fun of it.

If I were to determine whether my community or my family helped me more through college, I would like to believe that my family contributed a lot to my growth. My brother especially, he is older than I am and has always served to be a parenting role model when my other family members don't teach me the things I need to know. I didn't like my brother at first, he would point out my flaws and I could not even utter a single word that justifies I'm not. But ever since I've toned down on my immature attitude, I feel that it was right for me to be criticized and judged because if I have never known what to do with self-guilt, I might have never been a better person in the future. Finally when college swings around, it is usual that I find most people not more passionate about who they are and what they want to be. However for me in this case, I developed a certain degree of self respect that allows me to pursue my passion for not only computer science, but a way to express myself.

I think that one of the best things that has helped me push through college is the mindset my family had towards me  that you don't stop because things get hard. My parents were not able to go to college, but they've always urged me to keep going no matter what. Even if I am stressed or tired or doubting myself, I always hear them whispering in my mind just telling me to keep going. Humility is something else that I learned from my family. They taught me how to work hard but not to assume that I know it all. That has helped me a lot with group projects and with learning in general. I don't feel like I have to be the smartest person in the room, I just want to keep on learning and keep on going. My own community is invested as well  seeing people from where I originated working and trying to do something with nothing gives me that reminder that I'm not alone in this. I carry that with me when I'm exhausted. It's not about me, it's about all the people who helped bring me here. It reminds me and gives me strength when I need it most.

My family played a huge role in my choices here at SFSU. My dad is an electronics engineer and watching what he does has really made me want to follow his footsteps. My mom has been very supportive and has been on my side the whole time. Every time I think of them, it makes me want to keep going no matter what and I want to be someone important to my family and I want my parents to be proud of me and I don't want them to be disappointed or think that I can't take care of myself. Whenever I feel down, my mom or dad would call me and ask how I'm doing and just talking with them for a little bit gives me the motivation to keep going. My brother looks up to me and my dad and he has also talked about wanting to go into engineering. So he is also a big motivator for me as well. My family keeps me going and they are the reason that I am not going to give up.

Growing up, my family always emphasized resilience and hard work. My parents constantly reminded me that education is both a privilege and a responsibility, and that mindset has helped me push through tough moments in college. When I have struggled with overwhelming coursework or self-doubt, I have thought about my parents' sacrifices and their unwavering belief in my potential. That reminder has been a source of strength. Beyond my family, my community has also shaped me in meaningful ways. I was raised in an environment where helping others was second nature, whether that meant offering support to a friend in need or standing up for what is right. In college, that sense of community has driven me to seek out relationships that are built on trust and mutual support. I have found friendships that feel like family because we share values of kindness, loyalty, and perseverance. At times when college has felt isolating or overwhelming, these values of hard work, resilience, and community have grounded me. They remind me that I am never truly alone and that I carry the strength of my roots wherever I go.

I think the values of my family has helped me navigate through college as it helped put me in the right mentality and mindset. All my family members have attended and graduated college which plays a role in my journey through college. My goal is to also graduate and accomplish a lot throughout my years in college. It motivates me to work hard in my classes and to not feel demotivated when things aren't working out as there will always be a solution. My family will support me in whatever path or decision I choose for myself as they say as long as I will be happy with the path I take. I hope that I can also finish college and be able to continue on to more school if I choose to or be able to use my degree and find a job that will keep me financially stable.

My familys values of hard work, resilience, and kindness have helped me navigate college. Theyve always emphasized education and perseverance, which keep me motivated when things get tough. When I struggle with assignments or feel overwhelmed, I remind myself that challenges are temporary and that I have the strength to push through. Kindness is another value that helps me build connections. My friends, professors, and meditation club remind me that Im not alone. Their support makes the journey easier and more meaningful. At the end of the day, my familys values keep me focused, strong, and grateful for the people who help me along the way.

My family and community of friends is what keeps me going. All I ever wanted to do was to make them proud and be someone they can look up too. I surround myself with people with the same values of kindness. Being kind or being surrounded by kindness has helped me through a lot of situations. Especially if you are facing multiple at once it is good to have some positive aspects of your life. As I am the first of my family to go through a hard major I cannot connect with them educationally but emotionally. Having a family to go home to or friends to play games with can serve as a back bone to you as it did me. Even if I don't open up to people I still appreciated and am grateful for the fact that they are next to me when i need it.

Values that are brought me by my family is to always work hard and be confident in yourself. Thes values can always take me far because they're important to me. They're important because they not ony get me through struggle and hardships but also when I need reminding. Every time I need reminding I always tell myself to always work hard and be confident in what I do. These words of encourage can help me navigate through college. Whenever Im doing an exam or project, I always know I have to word extremely hard to get through the project or exam but also be confident in my knowledge, answers and work. In physics lab for this week reinforce the principle of conservation of energy-energy cannot be created or destroyed, but only transferred or converted into different forms. Carts rolling as well as pendulums showed different examples of experimentation on how kinetic energy became potential energy depending upon movement or height changes. Much as these changes occurred in part, total energy remained very constant in the entire system and thus true conservation of energy. Amongst all the interesting things during this lab, one of them happened to be how theoretical things come alive in the laboratory as they applied experimental basis. And it was so interesting to see how as kinetic energy increased, potential energy decreased, validating very well what we learned on energy change. It is so real to me for a scientific theory applied to life situations like roller-coasters. At a high point on this ride, it is all potential energy, but as it goes down, that potential energy is converted to kinetic energy, still holding nearly constant total energy and transformation of energy type.

I want to pursue a career in STEM because I am passionate about solving real-world problems through innovation and critical thinking. As a girl in STEM, I want to challenge stereotypes and contribute to a more diverse and inclusive scientific community. I love the logic of math, the creativity of engineering, and the endless discoveries in science. The idea of creating new technologies, conducting research, and making meaningful contributions to society excites me. Representation matters, and I hope to inspire other young girls to follow their curiosity and break barriers in STEM. With determination and knowledge, I believe I can make a difference and help shape the future of technology, medicine, and scientific advancement.

This lab really helped me see energy in action instead of just reading about it in a textbook. Ive always understood that kinetic and potential energy are connected, but actually watching the data change in real time made it click in a different way. Seeing the balls gravitational potential energy turn into kinetic energy as it fell was fascinating because the total energy stayed the sameit just shifted forms. It was like watching physics prove itself right in front of me. Another thing that stood out was how important it is to define a reference point for potential energy. I hadnt really thought about how energy is always measured relative to something else. It made me realize that even in science, perspective matters. Overall, this lab was a great reminder of how physics explains the world around us. Whether its a ball dropping, a roller coaster moving, or even a spaceship launching, the same energy principles apply. Its crazy to think that something as simple as this experiment is tied to how the universe works.
