AI has a very important role in STEM as it can be used to find patterns in complex systems far better than humans can. Ultimately, AI is a pattern recognition software and can be fed large amounts of information and process that information. For example, AI has been used in protein folding which drastically increased the rate in which proteins are understood. Additionally, AI has a practical use for students where complex topics such as electromagnetism or electronic diagrams can be describe in plain English. To productively use AI it should be used to enhance my own understanding of a topic. By using AI to create questions to practice a subject or describing a concept to AI and seeing if my understanding is correct. There is a large ethical issue with using AI as many of the things that AI makes is due to thousands of low payed employees in other countries doing menial labor like filling out CAPTCHAs. The toll on the environment with how much computing power AI requires which leads to the depletion of materials like silicon, lithium and usage of water and electricity to run the computers. Understanding that AI is something that should be used with intention and to further one's own development rather than doing the work for someone is most important.

I think AI can be a used as a tool in stem. there is a fine line between abusing it and using it as a learning tool. I see it has a 24 hr tutor that can ask any question i have without out right asking for the answer. I has been really useful when learning new concepts because any questions i have I can ask ai and get a pretty reliable answer. I always check the answer with other sources just to make sure it's correct, but for the most part it's good. I think ai can be a great tool to enhance learning, but can also be abused and make you think you are learning something but your just memorizing how to do it not how you got it.

AI is used to help students in STEM in a lot of ways, it can help them understand the subject with more depth than what their taught if they don't understand the concrete idea, it's also useful to use AI as a tool to help you form examples in STEM with different situations graphs tables, and a lot more to give the student a better example of things that way they can have more thoughts and ideas of the subject their learning, and can help them learn sometimes faster with it being so advanced. It can help them if their facing difficulty understanding their work like projects, homework, slideshows it can help giving ideas of how to get to your answer or how you should format things in your projects and slideshows to make them as presentable as possible for you to get a better grade and have a better chance of succeeding in your classes, so their a big useful tool that can help in any and every form of problem you can have.

The role of AI in STEM is to make the calculations faster than humans. AI can do much faster, quicker response, and explains it better. AI can automate repetitive tasks and replicate experiments with high precision, ensuring consistency and reliability in research. By providing the necessary prompts and data, AI can simulate experiments multiple times, allowing researchers to test various hypotheses without the constraints of time and resources. This is invaluable in fields like chemistry and materials science, where experimentation is key to innovation. As a student, to use AI productively is to familiarize yourself with AI to use tools effectively and interpret results accurately. Using AI as a tool to augment, not replace, critical thinking. Staying updated with AI advancements and integrate them into your learning process to enhance productivity and innovation. By using AI as a student, students can enhance their learning progress more effectively by consuming less times and AI explaining it in more effective way.

The role of AI is to enhance our critical thinking and to use it as a tool to understand our knowledge in the aspects of STEM that we don't have complete understanding yet. With new developments of AI, I think it is important to know that we shouldn't be using it to cut corners in learning and have it do all the work in school and at our jobs, but rather we can make sure with ethical usage to have it support us with our problems that we come across, so that it can guide us towards making conclusions to the questions that we don't have answers to. I believe I can use AI ethically and effectivley by asking it for the steps needed to a question I don't understand.

I believe that the role of AI in STEM should only be used as a guide, not the solution. The only ethical way I see AI being used as a student is by guiding you. For example, you can ask AI the process of solving a problem is without directly giving you an answer. It can also help you explain further on a concept you might not understand right away. Along with explaining a concept further, it can also give examples similar so you can understand better. I've also seen AI being used as a really good study tool by making practice quizzes for the students. In my opinion this is one of the most ethical ways of using AI. Personally, the main ways I used AI was definitely through explaining a math concept to me or asking specific definitions for words I'm not familiar with.

As a student in STEM, studying engineering principles and skills, I believe that the role of AI in STEM is to be used as a tool in the workplace. I have a deep belief that AI in no manner should be used to directly teach a student, maybe I am biased in a way that is against AI, but I think it should be reserved as a tool for students to help themselves understand or practice an already taught subject. This weaves into the realm of ethics, where in an unethical scenario AI could be used to cheat on a test or come up with a project that is unoriginal. To further develop the role of AI in STEM as a whole, I believe that it can be a dangerous advancement for an uneducated society. I am fully onboard with AI being used to progress, however the human condition and systemic fallacies are a bleak predictor. When something that is meant to emulate human labor has run completely out of labor to emulate, what is left? Human essence? At what point is progress too far intertwined with control?

I think AI was created by and for STEM. I think contemporary society prioritizes efficiency so AI was developed to assist in work that would normally take longer. I also believe that AI is such a new technology that there is always something more to develop from it. However as a student, AI should be used to learn from. For the sake of efficiency, AI assists so that a student can get a reliable explanation for certain struggles. Furthermore, discussing STEM based questions through email comes with its challenges and neither the student nor the professor always has time to answer small homework questions. Which is where AI can assist during times where other resources (humans) are not available.

AI has been the best and the worst invention of manhood in technological field so far. As a student it has been benefit in many ways but this has been misused in a lot of ways in educational sector. Students can get an easy access to find information . As a student I would like to use it as an information center or sometimes as a teacher to understand the topics . You can also use it as a referance which can give us a wider point of view on the topics. Don't try to simply copy done what AI has shown up , instead try to understand things from it rather than copying it down. Use it as a source do not misuse it. But what we can see is students loose their ability to think as they just jot down what is already there using AI without understanding what does that really means.

Artificial intelligence plays a huge role in STEM. While AI is considered as a threat by many, it helps us and the scientific fields in many ways. It really helps us to get the speed and precision for problems, as it is considered working faster than our brain. For instance, the usage of ChatGPT, it solves the problems in a much faster way. It explains the steps and methods used and helps us understand concepts. This saves time. The same way, it helps STEM, it saves time in solving problems. And it helps to analyze datas and also in giving feedbacks. Thereby helping us in personalized learning, research and it also has many other uses. This helps the scientific world to get a greater output and be precise on datas they are providing. Provides new opportunities for people and our scientific community. These are the roles I believe ai plays in stem.

AI has its advantages and disadvantages but the advantages outweighs the negatives objectively. AI has been revolutionary in just a very short amount of time just like the other revolutionary technologies like smart phones, electricity and the internet. AI is useful not just in STEM but almost everywhere. The main argument against AI is we lose creativity and critical thinking which is true but it is up to the user on how they use it, same thing we can say for phones, it depends on how you decide to use it. AI can be your own personal teacher, help you do repetitive mundane tasks so we can do the work that humans do which is the social aspects, would you rather do the long long division to solve a problem or let a calculator solve it and apply that number to an equation.

I think that AI is just going to continue to integrate further and further into stem fields because its such a useful tool. It can also help with coding for python would is very helpful (chatgbt). I think in order to use it ethically I would say that you shouldnt be using it to do every problem for you but instead to use it as a learning tool because chatgbt always lays out the steps and how to do a problem. I think AI is only going to get bigger and better as we all use it and I think it can play a beneficial role in stem hopefully without eliminating many jobs for people.

I believe that AI can be used in STEM fields to improve workflows, or do tasks more efficiently or quickly, which otherwise would have taken a lot of time and effort done by hand. For example, AI can be used to proofread any academic writing for any errors such as grammatical errors, spelling errors, etc. Another usage for AI in STEM fields would be to clean and validate any data gathered through experiments.

I think AI is a major development in the field of STEM, maybe just after the invention of steam engine in 1700s, I think within 20 years AI will a part of every engineer, scientist workflow, using AI will be inevitable to achieve the productivity that will be required by the job market. There are many examples of how AI is going to integrate into the workflow of STEM jobs, including brainstorming ideas and suggestions, searching for specific information in a web of overwhelming information, and doing tendious and dynamic task instead of doing them manually. How To use AI ethically: I think a counterproductive way to interact with AI is to delegate all work to it or not digesting the output of AI before implementing its suggestion in the real world. I think you should use AI as copilot where you are going to be able to judge if its output is valid or not. lack of critical judgment against its output would be unethical way of interacting with it.

No AI, ever. That's how I feel. There is legitimate, good work being done with deep learning algorithms, but nobody calls that AI, because the big marketing push is in calling the current LLMs like ChatGPT AI, even though they're not even close. The only ethical way to use it is like, as a search engine? but even then, it's prone to errors and just generally worse than an actual search engine. I think worse of people who use chatGPT to do things, whether it's classwork or an email. Large Language Models are built on an industrial amount of plagarism from artists and creatives, and I think the best thing that could happen for academics would be if the funding dried up and all these tech startups moved on to the next bullshit tech bubble. I think the label of "Artificial Intelligence" that's been applied to these things is a symptom of marketing hype, and I don't trust them to competently replace any work I could do myself.

AI in STEM has helped with many things such as solving difficult math problems that could have taken an hour and writing code, but AI isn't perfect yet so people shouldn't trust it fully. It's because AI has a difficult time solving massive complex problems or writing full apps that work flawlessly so they need human assistance. As a student AI could be used for studying for example translating a video into notes or using things such as Grammarly to help with students' papers. But if a person uses AI for everything then they won't learn anything, so when it comes a time where they can't use AI then that person will struggle a lot. Then there is also using AI to take notes for your lecture for example transcribing everything the professor is saying into nice organized notes. Then you could use AI to elaborate on a topic you're unfamiliar with and tutor you into understanding it.

The Role of AI in STEM is all what you make of it. For me, I can use AI to teach me and not just give me the answers. AI is especially good for learning because you can tailor it to whatever you want it to specifically teach you, with really high accuracy. I remember using AI while learning AP Calculus in high school it helped me understand complex concepts like limits, derivatives, and integrals in a much clearer way than the textbook did. I could ask follow-up questions, get visual explanations, or break problems down step-by-step. It felt like having a personal tutor available 24/7. AI also adjusts to how you learn best, whether thats through examples, visuals, or short explanations. In STEM subjects that can get very technical or difficult, that flexibility is really valuable. Instead of just copying answers, I used AI to strengthen my understanding, which helped me do better in class and gain confidence in solving problems on my own.

Some ways to use AI in STEM is check your solutions, summarize papers, possibly brainstorm, or use it to complete a monotonous tasks. Basically use it on small mundane things so you could focus more on the bigger/complex tasks or issues.

AI is supposed to be a tool for students to further their understanding of the topic they have learned in class. Or fill in the role of a teacher at home when you have questions that need to be answered that evening about a hard problem on the homework or something along those lines. Its what has been in testing in certain schools here in the U.S through Khan academy's program where they are integrating Open AI's chat gpt into their lessons plans/assignments that Khan Academy already offers. But in practice most of us are using to not further our understanding but to just get through an assignment quicker or do a project/essay for us. Which is a practice that only become reinforced as the measure of a student performance is based on the quality of the assignments they turn in and not based on the total understanding of the material. So until we come up with a better way to measure a student performance in a certain class or subject. This unethical approach to using ChatGPT is the reality for many students.

The role of ai in STEM is to help people in whatever it is they are doing, but not to do all the work for them. This is so that people do not become dependent on it and are able to live one their owns. I will use it ethically and responsibly by only using it to learn and not as a ahortcut to complete my assignments. I can use it productivly by using it only when I need to. One example of this can be when I need help learning how to solve a math problem.

The role of Ai in stem is to help improve processing of information on a scale humans cannot. I know that they use AI in astrophysics to identify different types of planets and stars in raw data at a speed that humans cannot compare to. I also know that I will have to learn some Ai to help improve my own code in the future.

AI is useful in a number of ways but it is admittedly tricky to define the line between ethical usage and using as a way to cut corners for convenience. I personally find it useful for checking your answers and method to getting those answers but I am a bit too prideful to use it anymore than that. I think that it is a bit unregulated right now so everyone is kind of using it for everything. Eventually laws and rules will be made and when that happens I hope things settle to a place where it is a merely a supporter of humans and not a replacement of them. But who knows, maybe it'll become more accurate then us as well and at that point wouldn't the most accurate data provide the most insightful research? Or maybe someone will make their own from an open source original and instead make in function with the directive of taking over the world like an overplayed supervillain. I think that would be kind of funny.

Ai plays a big role in stem by helping people solve problems and create a new technology.It helps doctors find medicines and predict diseases. In technology ai improves cybersecurity and voice assistants.

Ai is more of a accelerator in the STEM fields as searchin vast amounts of information or trying to read some information regarding a certain concepts can be strenuous. I believe that if AI is used to learn rather than use it to complete or do your work, it is perfectly alright to do so and doing so will enhance the learning, the understanding to a more deeper way and to also attain new information or knowledge about the concept which was preciously not mentioned. Many people use it to complete their assignments or to cheat on the exams which is not the right way to do it especially in a STEM major because STEM majors work in the future and knowing what you are doing is extremely crucial.

AI (artificial intelligence) is a useful tool with many different applications across a broad scope of tasks. An unethical use of AI in STEM would be using it to obtain passing grades in school with out actually learning the required knowledge needed to perform as a STEM subject matter expert in a particular field. Approaching education like this will result in less competent workers who are depended upon to effectively execute their jobs. For example, a Boeing engineer working on an airplane perhaps?? An ethical use of AI would be to use it as a learning tool to answer questions one might have on a particular subject. AI breaks down answers to questions very thoroughly and is able to simplify explanations if a person is not able to comprehend subject matter. This can make the learning process much less of a chore since students can get to the core knowledge of a subject without as much frustration. A better learning experience may result in a better understanding of a subject which, in turn, would potentially yield better performing workers. As in the field of work, AI should not be relied upon too greatly as it can make mistakes that could be costly. It could be used to streamline processes that would typically take much longer than usual.

The role of AI in Stem in my opinion is meant to process information, do calculations and enhance our ideas. AI will never be able to creative think like a person. The role of stem is to do the simulations, number crunching and enhance on what we think and build. At the current state of technology now, it is advantageous to leverage AI's need for not sleeping, working 24 hours a day, not complaining, or calling in sick. Productivity is increased and reduces cost for the processes in STEM. That's not to say that we should not learn the steps as people still need to gain the skills and knowledge so that they may be able to create new ideas and invent knew things. As AI is right now, it can only do the thinking part. We still need people for the hands on part of Stem. Ai cannot build a skyscraper, but it can enhance the blueprints or even design it on its own.

Witch certain challenges I prefer to just attempt it over and over and over again until i figure it out. For example if I am having trouble with a concept in homework and I can have a fast turn around from attempt to knowing my answer and trying again I will attempt it until i understand it. However, when life as a whole gets challenging it is usually due to my delicate mental state so I end up getting depressed and lying in bed for a few days or weeks. Before it would lead to suicidal ideations but now I am on antidepressants and therapy so that helps. Now I have a mindset that difficulties can be overcome and no matter how bad I think it is I will probably end up okay.

I make an effort to remind myself that it's acceptable to occasionally feel overwhelmed and bewildered when life becomes difficult. After all, we're only human, so things won't always go smoothly. Whether it's accumulated schoolwork, personal problems, or the weight of everything happening at once, it's simple to become overwhelmed by the pressure. However, even in those situations, I am aware that I have friends, family, professors, and even simply a quiet time to think and relax as resources. I make an effort to keep in mind that it's acceptable to proceed cautiously. I don't have to sort everything out at once. Things feel more doable when they are broken down and approached gradually. I also make an effort to remember myself of occasions in the past when I overcame adversity. Even when I can't see it, I possess that resilience. And occasionally, simply admitting that I've faced difficulties in the past might provide me with the courage I need to keep moving forward. Even though life can be difficult, I have the resources, the support, and the strength to persevere.

When life gets tough, its important to acknowledge how you feel and take small steps forward. Talk to friends, family, or a professional to get support, as sharing your struggles can help you feel better and see things from a new angle. Taking care of yourself is also key, whether its by exercising, practicing mindfulness, or doing something you enjoy to recharge. Try to focus on what you can control, instead of stressing about things you cant. A positive mindset, even during hard times, can give you the strength to keep going. Remember that challenges are a normal part of life and they usually dont last forever. You have the inner strength to get through tough times, and things will get better. Stay patient, take it one day at a time, and know that you can overcome obstacles with time and effort.

When life gets challenging I try to look at the positives, and understand what I know I am able to improve. Instead of staying stuck on problems I am unable to understand by myself, I can try to reach out to people to help me understand and solve my problems. I will use knowledge and learning to get out of challenging obstacles I come across as well as keep myself accountable and finishing tasks ahead of time so that I won't struggle to do everything last minute. Even if I don't understand what we are learning in the semester, I can still ask for support from the teacher and my classmates.

What do I do when life gets challenging? I think it varies on the situation for me. Sometimes I would heavily think about the situation. I would wonder what I could change if I could go back. The things I would get most embarassed by would haunt me everywhere I go. On the other hand, sometimes I would completely phase it out and feel nothing. In the end, I would try to learn from the situation and try to better myself..

When life gets challenging that first thing that comes to mind is to tell someone about. I dont know why its the first thing I try to do but it is a little comforting when someone validates my worries. Usually during these times, theres a huge stack of work that needs to get done. And usually anxiety of not knowing whether or not I can complete it all is the most stressful part. Because of this Ill always start with what I can do. Working my way from the bottom up, in manageable, but still challenging, doses of work. I am actually in a pretty overwhelmed state as of late. Theres so many tasks I have to complete, so many steps I need approved. It can get stressful but I know what I can get done and will work to finish those tasks first.

When life gets challenging , at first I used to worry a lot but now my mentality has changed so much that now its go with the flow. What I have learnt in my life is that everything happens for a reason and life has its own timings . And life is all about timings. So when it gets challenging I used to face the problems. You cannot always run from those problems and that is not even a solution . One or the other day you will have to face it. Running away from problems is just a temporary solution not a final one. So if life gets harder just go with the flow and try to face it . Either you will win or loose but you will definetly learn lesson during that period and that can help you face the challenges that comes to you.

When life gets challenging, I will try to create solutions for the problems. Being sad over the problem won't give any solutions for our problem. We have to get over our emotions and try to create solutions. Problems makes us stronger, if life does not have any difficult times, we will become weaker. Each problem is a lesson for us to study and this gives us the strength to go forward and be better than we actually are. Yes, it is true that sometimes we can't get over our present situation but then I always remember that everything happens for a reason. What ever was our worst actually made us what we are today. Our intuition and thought processing, changes as our life gets harder. At that point of time, we gets more connected to ourselves and get to know us better, make good decisions in life and be prepared for any challenges.

When life gets challenging, I try to figure out what exactly is causing it and work on ways to figure out the solution. The term challenging depends on what context we are talking about, "challenging because of failing class", well did i study? was it my fault? Usually we try to find resources and ways to mitigate a challenging situation because thats human nature, we dont want discomfort, we avoid it at all cost, but its isnt totally avoidable all the time, sometime you just face it, you have to increase your stress tolerant and work load during these times because it isnt a usual situation either.

I would say through my college career so far the thing that has been most helpful to me when Im struggling is going to tutoring. I think going to the professors office hours has also been really beneficial to me. But taking advantage of the TASC center has been very helpful in improving my understanding. Which helped me pass calc 1 and will also hopefully continue to help me get through Calc 2

When life gets too challenging, I like to create to-do lists to reorganize my everyday life. I also tend to break down complex tasks into simpler ones so the tasks do not seem impossible or too demanding.

There are many ways I address this issue, 1. one way would be to try to distance my slef from the problem I'm trying to solve temperarully, this can be just taking a walk, listening to music, or making my self a cup of coffee 2. try to address the issue with different aspect that what I'm trying to sovle it with

What do I do when life gets challenging? Personally, my first response to any personal challenge is to ignore it, and hope it goes away. This isn't healthy, but I'm just Not built for this shit, at all. Usually, this doesn't work, but it gives me the space to tackle it at my own pace. I ddon't think there's anyting wrong with this, really. It's procrastinating, but as long as i'm not impeding someone else's work by delaying my own, I think it's fine to do what I do. I also shut myself off from people, a lot. Especially living in dorms, it's really easy to just not leave your room except for meals, and I do this all the time. part of it is just insecurity about my own appearance, but it's also just because it's a habit. I spent so much time on my computer as a child that it's where I feel the most in control, and being able to split my attention between so many tabs lets me keep myself busy so I don't have to worry about schoolwork.

When life gets challenging, I turn to video games or doom scrolling on my phone. When I'm overwhelmed by assignments or other things that's usually what I turn to so I'm hoping to stop this bad habit and focus on my work. When I try to get back into the mindset of getting these things done or studying for an exam I fail to do that and go back into my bad habits. I'm going to work on it soon and hopefully, it will work out and if not I'll create some limits to those things. I will replace those with habits involving studying or creating a schedule that will work to balance these bad habits with new ones. Another thing I do is play the guitar or bass because it keeps my mind off of the problem, but I don't think playing an instrument is bad so I'm just hoping to play when I have free time.

When life gets challenging I usually go to my family or friends for support but most importantly I go to myself. I reflect and if I need to I go to the gym or even better go on a run. Sometimes you need those activities to get your mind off it because its pretty difficult so pass your body limits. Physical activity helps me reset mentally. Theres something powerful about pushing your body to its limits it reminds you that you're stronger than your circumstances. Its not just about fitness; its a form of therapy. Running especially gives me space to think, breathe, and regain control. My family and friends or just my support system in general is so strong because of there faith and belief in me. They took a lot of loans for me to be out here and I know I can't sulk and stay stuck. I have to succeed!

Lock in. If its an academic challenge I will usually watch some you-tube videos on the topic and take notes (shout out to The Organic Chemistry Tutor), I will also contact class mates to see if they understand the material and if they could help me understand it.

Challenging point I have had this semster is waking up from my 8am class which is CHEM. To wake up and sit there and actaully lock in is hard. The professor is really good don't get me wrong, but I'm just so tired from waking up early to get to the class that its really hard to concetrate and not fall asleep. Since the seats in those class are so comfortable and the class is nice and hot. I have tried every trick in the book. Coffee, splashing cold water on my face before class, chewing gum apparently works; but none succeeds in helping me wake up early enough to really lock in. Cause I am awake but not really awake you know. Even went to bed early like I'm 50 but that don't work, either, got me sleeping at 7-8 pm to try to wake up more energetic but to be honest I think I gotta call it quits and come to terms with that I am not a morning person.

I just responded to this. do they use the same prompts for every class? anyways My life has never not been challenging. I keep getting thrown curve balls and Im sick of it frankly, but it has made me stronger. When life gets challenging, I buckle down. And by buckle down I mean buckle down. First I get focused and serious instantly and cut off any and all distractions until im through. I wont allow myself to panic or freak out until I have a handle on whats going on because otherwise that panic might make me fail. The second thing i do is analyze the situation and see what exactly im dealing with. Then I examine all my options. possible solutions, and pick the route that has the best likelyhood to give the outcome I want. Then I create a backup plan, and begin working. I have been through more than enough to handle basically any challenge given to me and I do not back down.

This week we moved into the third dimension with velocity and vectors and stuff. It has been pretty easy to grasp since its mostly just the same thing but with one more vector to add. A lot of this has just been rebadged calculus so it hasn't really been hard. We had the midterm yesterday and I think I did pretty well on it besides the extra credit which i am admittedly more unsure about. Honestly my biggest struggle this semester with all my classes is forgetting to check canvas and just just simply not doing the homework until its too late. It is getting to an embarrassing point though because I am legally able to drink and yet can't seem to remember to simply check an app that I have access to all day on my phone. That is all kind of besides the point though, the physics itself has been fine. I do kind of resent a notebook check though since my notes are barely legible and pretty unfollowable if you are trying to glean what my thought process was on any specific problem.

When life gets challenging, I try to stay calm and think about what I can do to make things easier. I remind myself that Ive faced tough situations before, and I got through them, so I can do it again. When I feel stressed, I like to take a break, maybe go for a walk or play some sports to clear my mind. It helps me feel better. Sometimes talking to a friend or family member helps me feel supported. Other times, I just need to be by myself and take a little rest. Its okay to take a break and not feel bad about it. I also try to break big problems into smaller ones. That way, they dont feel so overwhelming. I remind myself that challenges dont last forever, and I just need to keep going. Every tough moment is a chance to get stronger, and I know I can handle whatever comes my way.

I am sorry i was a little late to the lab, i talked to you in the lab about it as well. It is quite a difficult and general question and personally when life gets difficult i usually remind myself of what I've been through, who i am and that what i can gain by completing this ordeal. Usually i am positive since easy things bore me and i like challenging things because the satisfaction in the end is worth it therefore i always try to focus on what to do rather than how hard something is or how miserable the situation might be. I take breaks in between such as listening to music and watch some motivation to boost my morale, mood and confidence as well as go for small walks.

When life gets difficult I have to look at what is causing the challenge to begin with and then evaluate all of the different elements in my life and determine how they're affecting my current situation. After I have found the issues in question I begin to have a dialogue with myself about what types of changes I need to make in my life to alleviate the pressure I'm feeling. This could many different things like financial issues, relationship problems, family issues, health issues, mental health.. If I'm not feeling good about how I feel physically then introducing healthier foods and attending the gym may be a good solution to getting my mind back on the right path. If it's money, I may need to audit how much time I'm spending on certain things like entertainment, going out, or just lounging and divert time into getting a part time job so I'm not only spending less money but supplementing my income at the same time. It's about identifying the issues and making the proper adjustments in your life to accommodate more pressing needs. Failure to adjust could lead to more dire consequences, which is a lesson you only want to be taught one time.

Life in itself is meant to be a challenge, and to live life is to constantly over come challenges. There are trying times when it seems like life is challenging you more than usual. Like going to school full time and raising 3 kids under 4 is the challenge of a life time for me. But when I do a those moments of being overwhelmed, I take a look at the outcome once I overcome the challenge. I put into light why I am doing things and not let it bother me. I will blow of steam by exercising, hanging out with my little ones, or just taking a chance to get a meal outside with my wife and kids. I combine a bunch of the little things to overcome the big things in life. Take a moment to breath and look into the blue sky is always a good way to clear my mind and relax.

My family has a strong importance on education. I think generally in the Filipino and Black communities since we often have less generational wealth to rely upon we feel that we have to work extra hard to create it ourselves. There were times where I wanted to quit college because I felt that I was not good enough and my family really pushed me through that feeling and made me reconsider these ideas. Additionally, growing up in school they always push going to college, getting a degree and then a career so its not really a thought to me its just something that was ingrained into me.

See the struggles of my family has pushed me to seek opportunities that they never had a chance to have. They have worked very hard to give me the opportunity of going to college and doing something they would have done given the chances. In my community family is something very important and to have them a s support system has really helped me there have been some tough times inside and outside of college and if it weren't for my family I think college experience would be a lot worse. I also have 3 younger brother and want to set an example and show them there are other paths if up to them to decide there's but I want to show them that college is one of them.

Throughout college, the principles of my family and community have served as my compass, providing guidance and encouragement when times were difficult. My family has always stressed the value of diligence and tenacity. They have taught me that hard work and learning along the way are just as important to success as the final product. Every time I've had a problem, I've found myself thinking back on what they said and persevering because I know that resilience is essential. Furthermore, the community I've established at this college has been equally important. They give me a feeling of community and serve as a reminder that I'm not the only one going through difficulties. These relationships have produced a support system where I can be vulnerable and develop, from late-night study sessions to exchanging anecdotes about our families. My family and friends have taught me the principles of empathy and teamwork, which have kept me grounded by letting me know that I don't have to confront obstacles alone; I can overcome them with others. In the end, these principles have served as a reminder to me that everyone contributes to my success. Every day, I take the lessons learned from my family and the spirit of my town with me, which gives me the strength and confidence I need to succeed in college.

My community and family have been essential in helping me navigate through college, especially when facing the pressures of classwork and homework. They constantly remind me not to feel bad when things aren't going well. Their encouragement helps me avoid self-blame and keeps me motivated even when I'm struggling. My family, in particular, has been a steady source of support, always there to reassure me during tough times and offer guidance when needed. This unwavering emotional support has been crucial in maintaining my mental well-being, helping me stay grounded during stressful moments. Additionally, my community has been incredibly helpful whenever I get stuck. Whether it's academic challenges or navigating college life in general, having a group of people who are willing to lend a hand makes a huge difference. Their advice and support alleviate the pressure, reminding me that I'm not alone in this journey.

My community has helped me navigate college by showing me support whenever I seem to be struggling with anything related to college. I know that when I struggle with getting my assignments done on time, or having trouble fitting in with my peers, the community can help me out to make I succeed in whatever challenges that college has put me in. It is fortunate that my family will be willing to do whatever it takes to ensure that I don't trail behind and give me encouragement that I am just as intelligent as my peers and can keep on top of all my assignments and exams.

I am not too sure at the moment. Right now as I'm typing I feel like I am a little bit tired and my mind is a little foggy. It doesn't feel like I'm all the way there yet. The first thing that popped in my mind is that my family always wants the best for me, but it also feels like they're very competitive with it. For example, they would always compare other people's accolades and make it strive for it. I know this is their way of motivating me, but all I felt was disappointment because I wouldn't think I could reach that goal nor it's a goal I would want. Regardless I would feel like a failure whether I even try to reach that goal or not. They never known how I felt nor they will ever know in the future.

Since living in San Francisco, one of the if not the most tech heavy city in the world, it has influenced me toward the computer science path. In highschool we had few internship and local organizations like mission bit recuirt students for coding projects and learning which strengthened my love toward computer programming and engineering, but even before that I always had passion toward computers, growing up in the digital era where everything is related to and toward computers, my parents recognized this is the future and encouraged me toward this path as well. When it comes to choosing career path and navigating collage, my high school assisted me a lot as well there was a collage and career course where we discussed different collage and career paths, this also helped me distinguish between computer engineering and computer science.

I would say that my family values have helped me create relationships with those around me because my parents have always taught be to be nice to people no matter what. And to not judge people because you really dont know whats going on with them. I also think that my parents also helped encourage me to go to college and are probably the reason Im here right now so I think my family values and goals have definitely played a big part so far for me in college

My family has always been very strict about getting good education, and by proxy, I am also keen to complete my education with flying colors. The motivation and eagerness to complete college comes from my family.

The values of my family and community have really helped me get through college. My family taught me to never give up and to work hard, no matter what. I think about their struggles and how they pushed through, and it motivates me to keep going, even when things get tough. My friends and mentorsthe people Ive chosen as my support systemhave shown me the importance of teamwork and kindness. Theyve helped me realize that I dont have to face challenges alone. Their encouragement has been a big source of strength for me. One big thing my community has taught me is to stay curious. Theyve made me want to keep learning and growing, even on days when Im really tired. These values have shaped who I am and keep pushing me to be a better version of myself.

how have the values of my community helped me navigate through college? Honestly, they haven't at all. Where I grew up, everyone I surrounded myself with had a very laissez faire attitude to their schooling, which also translated to the curriculum. I'm struggling to adapt to college, especially with so much more homework compared to high school. That said, my community back home bas been a great emotional support structure, especially given the issues I mentioned before. It's hard to meet people like them in San Francisco, so I'm grateful that they're so supportive as I make my way here.

The values that helped me navigate college was a sense of belonging that helped me boost my confidence in college and brought a sense of belonging with it. My family and friends helped encourage and motivate me to navigate through college and supported me through my time at college. My community and family helped me build a strong foundation so that when I face any problems I can take them head-on without worry. Also, my programs and scholarships support me financially and help me navigate through my first semester of college.

My community and family have been instrumental in my success while navigating through college. Their support has provided me with both the motivation and the resources needed to overcome challenges and stay focused on my goals. Knowing that I have people who genuinely care about my well-being has given me a strong sense of stability, which is crucial during stressful times. My family, in particular, has been a lifeline, always just a phone call away. Having that immediate access to encouragement, advice, and emotional reassurance has done wonders for my confidence and ability to persist. Beyond just emotional support, my family has helped in practical ways. Whether its offering financial assistance, helping me strategize for my future, or simply reminding me to take care of myself. My community also plays a key role, whether through friends, mentors, or even professors who genuinely want to see me succeed. This network of support has made all the difference in my college journey.

The values of my community or family haven't helped me navigate through college yet, or maybe I just haven't noticed yet. I am sure that they most likely helped even in a subtle way. I have been free balling it through college so far and with most counselors not of much help as well when it comes to navigating courses or future courses.

I mean the only thing would be the dicipline to show up early and on time is a value my dad takes seriously, he wants make sure we are always punctionsl everywhere we go. And to Make sure we are disciplined to have our work done first then we can do whatever we would like too. Saved form a lot of missing assignments cause there are time where Ive forgotten about an assignment till the day of but since I had already started it prior, all of them were usually Partial or almost done. Otherwise I would be cooked more than my grade already is in alot of my classes, which I mean arent too low, I think lowest currently is a C but mostly due to my attendance, I didnt realize how much of a time slot its in and cant really make it too consistently

The values of my community and family have helped me navigate through college by encouraging me to do more and to be better. My family really only values if I am happy and moderately successful, so there really isn't too much stress that is placed upon me by them. My friends are the same though I do think that they expect me to go through with college and complete it. I want to live up to these people's expectations, so that I do not disappoint them and because it is what I want for myself as well. I want to be both happy in life and somewhat successful. These people in my life have also always been there for me and constantly offer assistance which is greatly helpful to me. Overall, I think that my friends and family have been a major reason behind my decision to go to college and I am grateful to them for that.

The main community value around me is that I get an education. It's been drilled in me that education is a source of freedom and I have experienced it first hand, which is why I am devoting myself entirely to my studies. One other community value that has massively helped me navigate is one that my favorite track coach instilled in me: stay light on your feet. While he mostly meant it for the 100m, its something I carry with me in my actions every day. I am always prepared to take or dodge a blow of any sort and do not let any challenge take me down. I think the number one value i have is from the kid i consider my little sister. She reminds me that I need to suck it up and deal with everything, but also that there is light in everything. She reminds me that not everyone is out to get me, that there are good people in the world. Most of all, I need to make the world better for her, so she never has to deal with what I did. She reminds me that there is a future, but i have to fight for it.

I think I am very frugal because of my parents and I think that has helped me keep stability in dire times. Morally my family is also pretty sound so I guess I have them to thank for that as well. I also took 2 gap years because I didn't really know what I wanted to do, and my parents were very courteous of that, or something, or something. Maybe I take my strengths for granted though. Like unbelievably easy. Like indescribably easy. Like otherworldly easy. Like immensely easy. Like superficially easy. Like absently easy. Like badly easy. i definitely needed this as during this time ive been so caught up with everything that ive not taken the time to reflect. There are many values but the number 1 value that is important to me is to have confidence in myself no matter what the situation and i think this quality of value has helped me tackle everything without any problem. Another one was to value learning or understanding how to do it rather than to just copy paste or memorise because in india you are taught to memorise everything and a lot of people do but do not understand what it actually means and i think me putting in effort to atleast use my time to understand helped me gain an advantage on everyone else. That along with my sense of importance of what im doing as well as the importance of time has helped me navigate through college without having much trouble

I am a unique case when it comes to family as my family essentially abandoned the raising of me when I was 12. I was emancipated at the age of 16 and began living on my own during my senior year of high school. With that in mind, i never had a formal upbringing where family shows you how to navigate life. Instead, I have had to learn everything on my own along the way, which has taught me to be independent to a fault. None of my family was especially religious so we didn't have any real framework surrounding how we should live our lives outside of "treat others the way you wish to be treated". Most of what I have learned on how to navigate through college has been trial and error in life, along with some good habits I picked up during my time in the military. I started college after I finished serving so my work ethic and how I build relationships have carried over to a roughly 3.7GPA on my 3rd year of college.

My family, being my mother was the initial drive for me to navigate through college after I left military service. I didn't immediately start school until until my main motivation, being my kids were born. My mother worked hard as an immigrant so that we did not have to and I wanted to show appreciation by completed school as she wished worked hard for me to. Most of my younger siblings have already completed the upper level education and I figured I should also. Another thing that motivated me was my 3 kids being born. I wanted to set an example for them in regards to education as my wife had already obtained her master degree. I wanted to show my kids that both parents completed formal higher education and that is was a norm in our family to do so. I find that creating a norm through example is a good way to set the mindset of kids and setup their personalities.
