my goals are just to pass tbh. most of the stuff we're gonna do in this class should be review i think, im assuming i did a lot of this in highschool physics. i hope to have fun though, most of the physics labs are usually decently fun. i wanna get a degree in physics so i can have a decently well paying day job, and im focusing most of my energy these first few semesters on audio engineering and getting involved in the sf state radio station. this class should teach me the skills i need to do well in the later labs and whatnot. :)

I want to be able to understand how computers are built from the logic gate level up to high level programming languages. This class will give me a foundation in physics that will allow me to progress to more advanced physics topics that will give me an understanding of electricity. An underderstanding of electicity and circuits is crucial to working on computer hardware and building circuits. Learning to decribe anything using mathematics is a skill that is important to all engineering fields. Physics 1 teaches you how to use math to model observable physical phenomena. This practice will make it easier to create mathematical models for all kinds of systems whether they are easily observable, easily comprehendable, or not.

My goal is to be able to understand the basics of physics with calc 1. To achieve these goals I would have to show up to class and just pay attention and try to learn something new. I don't really know what else I have to do other than show up do the work, go home to study, and that's it, nothing else really.

My goals aligning with this class are admittedly first and foremost to pass and get the proper credits to satisfy this requirement. This class would help me achieve that goal by allowing me to pass the Physics I class, as the lab is a concurrent requirement to passing PHYS220. However, beyond that, I think gaining a much more fundamental knowledge of physics and how I solve adjacent physics problems is a goal that I would like to achieve as well, I think especially given how I want to go into game development as a field it would be really useful when trying to create things such as trajectory calculations, simulating a vehicle, or predicting the motion of objects. Whenever I have to try and solve one of the problems, I find myself turning to already solved solutions that do things that I may only vaguely understand. I hope with this class I can have a deeper understanding of those topics and be able to dissect what those solutions are doing, so if I need to change or alter the solution to put in my own game I would be able to with ease. This class seems like it would be helpful in aiding in said learning and understanding, and is more of a personal goal that I would like to achieve.

My goals are just to provide a good basis for learning math and physics. Sometimes physics is hard to visualize and just using equations can make it even more confusing. In lab we connect what we learn to real life and physical problems, which Im hoping will help me understand what were learning in lecture better. Im also hoping to learn the basics of doing a college level lab in a group. Ive done labs and lab write-ups before, but not like this.

My main goals are to achieve as high of an education as I can, as well as a high level working experience for my future. I want it to be something I can strive for by hard work. In order to achieve this goal, I believe that I need to pay attention during the class, study during my own free time, and recreate assignments and tests in order to become one of those successful people. This class will help me achieve my goals through the different techniques given throughout the course.

My goals are to learn how to be a dedicated learner, not only as a student, but as a person in life as well. Part of that process is going through college to get my bachelors degree, where I'm always learning and working on building better habits and absorbing all the knowledge that I can. I think that this class can help to me reach these goals by offering my challenging topics to learn and to study on. I also think that what can be offered by attending this physics lab is learning to work collaboratively with my classmates in order to further our knowledge together. We, as a group, can work on these new topics and help each other, while also trying to not override one another and for each of us to work at our own pace.

My goals for this class are to understand and be able to use the information I learn in order to build a good foundation in physics. Being in this physics lab I feel will help greatly with this goal as the work is hands on and I'm able to see how physics can be applied in real life experiments. I think that carefully studying the material, as well as reaching out for help from the professor as needed will help me to succeed in achieving my goals. I also hope to be more comfortable in lab environments.

2 main goals for me I suppose out of this class is to understand physics better and get my computer science degree. I believe this lab will help me understand physics better because this is a more hands-on/practical experience. Practical learning is always a great way to get better. This class is also a requirement to complete my undergraduate degree so I will need this for that too

as AI advances I belive its role will to as of now I see AI as a toold and helper to achieve our understanding, however as it advances and it can help us to create many multiple forms of how we are able to describe our As AI advances, I believe its role will evolve. For now, I see AI as a tool and helper that enhances our understanding. However, as it continues to develop, it has the potential to assist us in creating various ways to describe our world..4\

I can ethically and productively use AI as a student by not using it to cheat or using it to simply give me the answer. I can make AI actually useful to myself by asking it to explain things I don't understand, show me examples, or guidelines and advice to follow if I'm lost. This way I'm actually learning and understanding what I don't know rather than having the answer given to me and moving on. AI also requires tons of energy and resources, so I can ethically use AI as a student by not relying on it. If it is my first instinct, I may be spending more time using AI than actually thinking. It's like constantly turning a light on and using electricity without really using it. The role of AI in STEM is to be a tool that makes searching for informati

I believe that AI already plays a large part in STEM, assisting in research, data analysis and other such matters. I won't say it plays a critical role, but it is a very nice luxury to have, especially when the team doesn't have many resources at their disposal. For students, AI is a much more trickier matter. Some will use it to cheat, to complete their homework, etc. But despite that, I still believe it can serve as an excellent learning tool when used correctly. Especially acting like a teacher any time the student needs, not needing to be reliant on office hours or the availability of the professor.

Artificial intelligence or best know as AI is a great source for students when having difficulty in understanding a difficult subject. Many students use AI due that it can help solve problems that a student might have difficulty solving or finding an answer. Not only it gives an answer it can also help you understand in which step you might of gotten confused or wrong. I usually use AI when I am lost or confused in a homework problem. I try to find the answer my self then I use AI when AI gives the answer it shows me where I aaa wrong and why I was having problems solving it. Its a great source for many students and helps with better understanding and leaning. Sometimes in class it can be difficult to understand a subject which will be a great part of a quiz or exam but when I use AI it can also provide tutoring and help with many things. So AI is a great source for students in STEM.

I think AI is important because most people say ai can replace teachers and can replace people who do mathematics and coding. In my coding classes I would use it to check my code and sometimes I would use it for study guides. It isn't ethical to cheat and the ai can still make mistakes but can be helpful.
AI helps makes takes easier and faster, for example if you want to code something, we can get help from AI and get a gist of things or an outline. It can also help in learning perspective.

AI can help us gain a better understanding of STEM. As a student, I can ethically use AI by making sure I am not plagiarizing by claiming that results I got from using AI is my own work. I think that AI is a very helpful tool especially if you wanna use it for homework help or general questions about a STEM topic. But if you are using it purely to get answers then it is not ethical nor productive. It only hurts yourself if you use AI for answers and not actually learning. I think AI is very helpful for a lot of things but I think people are starting to use it for cheating purposes.

AI has the power to change the way we approach STEM, making everything from complex problems to basic tasks easier. As a student, I think of AI as a tool that can make learning more efficient and interesting. For instance, it can break down difficult concepts in science or math, giving me a better understanding when Im stuck. Its like having a tutor available whenever I need help, which is awesome. That said, AI shouldnt do the work for me. Ive got to stay involved in the process, think critically, and make sure Im actually learning. Its easy to get lazy and rely on AI too much, but then Im just cheating myself out of the real value of education. So, using AI ethically means finding that balanceusing it as a tool to help me understand better, but not as a shortcut to avoid putting in the effort. When Im mindful of how I use it, AI can really enhance my learning without replacing the hard work.
The purpose of AI in terms of steam should be mainly used as a tool to assist with steam work but should not be the only tool a person uses for example when conducting an experiment.

I think the role of AI in stem is to be used for doing all the heavy lifting as in calculations, processing a lot of information. It would be used to speed up unnecessary work. I think I can use it ethically to help with learning and not using it as a tool to do my homework. I think most people use it to cheat and not learn the actual material. I think it would be best to use it as a tool to help you learn not for it to do the learning for you.

AI is very important in the STEM field and it can cause people to get smarter and expand our knowledge. AI can help us check our answers and help us improved our work by our knowledge and mind growth. The only problem I have is that its not 100% accurate so we don't know if the question can be correct to double check our answers and work. This awesome tool would improved our learning status though by making us smarter.

I think Al is very useful for STEN students. Sometimes, we can not understand a problem, and we can not solve it. It can give us advice to solve it. And in study, AI can be like a tutor. When I don't understand something in a class, I usually ask AI, and it can answer in another language. When I can not understand English or English is too difficult for me, it can be translator. It is better than Google Translate. And when I don't know what to say my opinion in English, it helps me. AI can explain specific ideas. Sometimes when I asked to how to say something in English to Google, it answered not natural, and then I used the word to team members but they can not understand. However, after that, I used AI, and then I got natural words. So It is so helpful and this way is ethically.

The role of AI in STEM is pretty crucial, as it helps in analyzing data and also in helping solutions; however, I believe AI can't solve complex problems related to STEM. AI can be used ethically only for research purposes and not for the whole solution to a problem. It can be a productive research tool as well.

AI should be used as a supportive tool, something to support/help students rather than a crutch. Using it as a tutor rather than a source to pull answers from. In STEM it should be used as something to support, like a graphing calculator. We should know how to do the work without its support, but we should still be able to use it to make our work easier.

I don't think AI has a role in STEM education. AI is a useful tool to outsource repetitive or relatively simple tasks for the user, or a search tool to potentially speed up the research process. As a student, simple or repetitive tasks are useful exercises for internalizing key concepts. Outsourcing these tasks to AI takes away opportunities to engage with new concepts and results in a worse understanding.

I think AI is cool. It can be used to help with studying and understanding concepts when a teacher explains terribly. I can use it to cheat my way through homework and learn from that. Itd be funny if this I asked chat gpt to write this and make it sound like a person. But yeah, AI is chill to some extent; you can rely on it but you should NOT abuse it (maybe I dont care).

The role of AI in STEM should be to supplement the learning of said STEM subjects. I think that its really great in producing answers, but even more important the processes of getting to said answer. While its more than important to understand that AI won't produce the correct answer 100% of the time, from my experience its rarely from my own personal use of it produced something that was entirely wrong. I think however, to use it ethically in an educational environment, it should only be used to learn the processes from, rather "plagiarizing" from the AI. In this sense, its almost like a personalized tutor, rather than a test-taking machine. I think when its used in a context like that, it can be an extremely helpful tool when its difficult to outreach to get help, or when you might not be able to have the time or resources to get a personal tutor. It can aid in filling in little gaps of knowledge, such as how to apply a formula or think about a problem.

When we talk about STEM as a field, I think AI plays a huge role. It's the future of STEM and anyone going into the field should learn about it. However, using it as a STEM student is a little different. Once again, I think it's super important for STEM students to know how to use the tools, but we should learn the foundations first. Honestly, I find it mildly infuriating when students or people in general use AI for stuff they could do easily. As of right now, many AI tools like ChatGPT are bad for the environment, and we shouldn't be wasting it on trivial use.

We are able to use AI in STEM as something that can help us calculate the best path to success. AI has seen many different adventures through the STEM community, so it can help us as experimenters to determine the safest and most successful route.

AI is a really useful tool in STEM. It helps solve problems, find patterns in data, and even helps scientists make new discoveries. But as a student, I think the hard part is using it in a way that helps me learn instead of just doing the work for me. It is easy to ask AI for answers, but if I do not think through the problem myself, I will not really understand it. I think the right way to use AI is to help explain things or give me ideas. But if I just copy what it says and turn it in, that is not fair. Also, AI is not perfect. It can make mistakes or be biased, so I shouldn't trust it completely.

I believe that, like with any use of AI, it should be used as a tool and not the only means. The moment that the use of AI transcends its purpose, and overtakes humanity's capability for creativity, I think that at that point AI oversteps the purpose of its creation. In STEM specifically it should be used as a data checker, where it simply corrects any mistakes being done. I believe that this trend of AI being used generatively will be corrected, because the basis of AI at the end of the day, is human work and once we reach a point where AI is incapable of generating new and creative work, generative AI will be used far less. Of course, over a large period of time it is possible for AI to go over an extremely large number of data points and draw conclusions from it, but even then the goal would be a goal set by humans.

The role of AI in stem is that its a product of the concentration itself. As a result our our continually changing and advancing understanding of computing and advanced algorithms we've reached a point where questions which usually required extensive studying and application of different techniques is now done by simply asking an AI program to do it for you. I feel that although this is definitely an amazing tool, it can easily stifle advancing our own personal knowledge. Too much reliance can make us overly confident in relying on technology to do the job for us. Due to this I feel that its important that we keep it to a minimum overall.

I believe AI is a great technological advancement not just for stem but for humanity in general. Having sad this, it definitely has its disadvantages. We need to incorporate AI in our life as a helping tool instead of a relying tool.

When life gets challenging, I resort back to my peace, Nature. Throughout this semester, I have kept in mind of mindful practices that ensure stability within my mental health. I enjoy taking a break from any of my stresses with a quick nature walk through Golden Gate or perhaps a quick beach trip to Ocean Beach to catch the sunset. My mind clears and I feel ready to tackle the challenge at hand.

When life gets challenging, the first thing I always do is disconnect from my electronic devices and/or social media. I have a variety of things that I do to help me ease my mind and release stress and they're usually broken up by category such as physical, mental, and emotional. For physical I find being in nature like hiking trails or especially the beach help me a ton. I love the beach. Or going for a walk or hitting a workout help me release stress and process my thoughts. For mental aspects, I find meditation and journaling help me to process and release thoughts. Emotionally, doing things with my hands especially making art or

When life gets challenging I tend to go for a walk to try and think of nothing. Listening to music also helps me to stop overthinking. As for when something doesnt go how its supposed many start to overthink and sometimes spacing the mind helps to see more clear. Life is always challenging it all depend how you cope with the challenge. Either you give up or fix things to improve. Its great to also find other opinions if you are in a place where you dont know what to do.

When life gets hard I try to spend time doing things I like and being with loved ones. I used to cycle when I got the chance and it was liberating but now I am too busy so just spending time with family and pets and hanging out with friends helps the hard times go by. Music is also really helpful at regulating my emotions.
When life gets challenging I just get my own space, find solutions to make it easier and talk to my friends and family for any advice and go for a drive.

When life gets challenging, I should take a moment to breathe. I can do that by taking a step back from whatever is stressing me out. For example, if a certain class is stressing me out, I will decide to not show up for a day. I can also take a break by choosing to miss a homework assignment. I think its always worth taking a small hit to my grade when Im too stressed out. When life gets challenging, I can also talk to a friend about how Im feeling. It is always nice to be able to vent about something that is giving me trouble. Its also good to journal when things get hard. I feel good whenever I get to release whatever is bothering me. Journaling has always been a helpful outlet.

When things get challenging say when it comes to a homework problem I don't know how to do I will usually look up a YouTube video on how to solve the problem or if I am struggling in a certain class I will schedule a tutoring session in for the subject usually with TASC since it comes free with our tuition. When it comes to life being challenging in general I usually like to talk with friends about it as it helps me calm down.

I think when life gets challenging I try to keep moving forward. I don't try to stay in the same place. If I keep moving forward at some point it'll get better. I think there are people that just stay in the same place which I might be also doing at sometimes but regardless of that I try to do my best. Other than that I am not too sure what else I do aside from that. I think regardless of that if life pushes you down, you try to get back up!

When my life has been challenging in this semester because I have a lot of homework and exams. If I have a lot of homework, I have to do it as soon as possible. And also if I have exams I just have to study until I am able to get a good mark. So, I just have to study hard. If I don't have motivation for these, I will do something I really like. For example, surfing, snowboarding, and traveling. When I am watching beautiful nature, I can chill. It helps remove my stress. So surfing is very good. I can see a good view and I can feel how big and strong nature is. And when I ride on the wave, I feel so refreshed. I haven't been surfing recently so I really want to go surfing. These are so helpful to refresh. Also tallking with my friends and hanging out are helpful.

i continue on, like life isnt any different than it usually is. i'll reach out to friends, i'll get sleep, i'll relax, ill try to live like its not really happening. it depends on what kind of challenging i guess, if its a lot of school work i'll just continue on like everythings the same, if its mental health stuff i make sure to do stuff that makes me happy! im not sure what else i do tbh, i just live and wait for it to get easier.

When life gets challenging, I like to reflect on whether I have been tackling the challenges in the best way. There are many ways to tackle problems, so if I am finding that I am unable to accomplish a task using my current method, I check if there is a more efficient method to use. In a statistics class I am currently taking, I've been finding that it's hard to keep up with the lectures. The professor moves past topics faster than I can understand them. Even though there is not assigned reading, I found that reading the textbook before the lectures helps me keep up.
Give up. I call it a day and move on fr. I can't do nothing else, so just move on fr and call it a day.

When life gets challenging, what I like to do is firstly to take a step back from whatever was challenging me and take a breather. I can't work well if I'm stressed out or anxious due to whatever may be challenging. After that, I try to break things down into smaller, more manageable bite-sized chunks. For example, one case could be an overwhelming amount of homework. What I found really helped was instead of stressing about the big picture/pile of homework, planning out which homework needed to be done first/had the highest priority and which could wait/be done later really helped me digest the challenge at hand, as well as stress out less. In the case that something doesn't need to be urgently done, I do also like to relax and reflect on life, to put things into perspective in the sense that even despite things being challenging now, it won't always be that way and will get better.

When life gets challenging I usually dont respond super well. I dont love talking to other people about my problems and sometimes I dont reach out when I should. However Id like to start dealing with problems right when they begin, rather than when they become overwhelming. In order to do that I would like to use the resources given to me depending on the challenge, like counseling or tutoring. I also should work on giving myself grace. Sometimes something comes up that keeps me from working at my full potential and thats ok. Sometimes its an issue that I could have prevented, but theres no point in moping. Its best to just push through and do the best you can from there.
When life gets challenging, I just move on and move forwards with the next challenge. When things get tough, I get tougher. Its a dog eat dog world.

I make sure to spend time with friends and family and force myself to continue good habits. When you feel bad it's really easy to spiral into negative habits that will only further your negative mood. That's why it's most important to continue good habits not when you're already doing well, but when your doing poorly the most.

When life gets challenging, my personal choice of action is to take a step back and look at things from a different perspective. I find that when doing this, there is always a positive outcome that can be seen when viewing things differently. As the saying goes, "every cloud has a silver lining." Usually, doing this makes it easier for me to accept the outcome of things, and helps me create a new goal or a new path that I can follow. Something else that helps is talking things through with a friend or family. More than gaining a new perspective, talking with someone helps me hone in on my true thoughts about any situation that is happening to me. By speaking my thoughts out loud, I confirm within myself whether my thoughts are misguided or not, and another bonus of talking with a friend is the different perspective they can give to me.

Usually when life gets challenging, I try do a number of things. I feel like at this point in my especially a lot of the techniques or problem solving skills Ive used are pretty basic in general but are nonetheless work the same. The main I do is to make sure that I maintain a strong self awareness and monitor my emotional state throughout however long a challenge lasts. When I do this it helps me to regulate my moods and to work effectively throughout things. If I ignore myself and my limits then Ill inevitably work myself too hard and burn out.

I guess I try my best to control the things I have control over and not worry about the things that I dont have control over. Challenges are a part of life. As hard as it is, You got to overcome it and grow as a person.

I am a Pacific Islander College student, moreso I am of South pacific Heritage. My community, Pacific Islander community remains present throughout my college journey and as I wrap up my undergraduate studies, I honor my community. I am Tongan and Samoan, two distinct islands close together in the South Pacific Region. My family instilled key values that I have relied on to navigate through college. Grounding values such as compassion: both in the mind, words, and actions I enact, kindness, respect, loyalty, and a personally favorable one of mine, humbleness. My grandmother nurtured a core principle that guides me throughout my life, E Faigata Le Alofa . This saying is in Samoan, translated to english, this principle means to love until you can't. This touches on the practice of unconditional love, a principle that is much easier said than done. However, day by day this principle guides me to continue growing and my success, all while grounding me.

Some the values of my community/family are self-determination, laughing, home-cooked meals, and discipline. These values helped me to navigate and even get through college because I find myself turning to these in times of stress or when I least expect. For example, the value of laughing helps me to value having a work-life balance. It reminds me to have a life outside of school and working and to destress. Which in turn helps me to prevent burn out and stay emotionally happy. Hom

I came to the U.S at a very young age. Since then I been all my life in school. I even had extra classes at the end of school which I stayed until 7pm in school. My parents were not around since they had to work in order to provide for us. So now school is a place which I dont find stressing now boring since Ive always been in school. My parents didnt have the opportunity of finishing school back in our country so now with the opportunity I got I hope to graduate and become someone more successful in life. Also our culture we have a belief that we will be one day successful to give our parents all that they need and provide just like they did to me when growing up. This helps me push thru challenging moments. Also me being always in school has helped me not to be shy and ask when I have questions due that my only help were my professors when I was growing up.

Family helped me stay motivated because we all value each other's needs and wants. They have always supported me even as a child when I said I wanted to be an illustrator to now that I want to be an electrical engineer. My Mom put me in a young engineers program where a group of peers and I along with a mentor would do the tech challenge in San Jose.

The values that my family has taught me has helped a lot and has kept me the same person I always was. I have followed a vegetarian diet despite having less options and have kept it that way which does help me get through college. I have followed my religion as well.

The values of my family/culture of origin has helped me navigate through college because they have always emphasized the importance of higher education. I am a first generation college student in my moms side of the family, they were not fortunate enough to go to college. My mom is an immigrant so she moved to the US to ensure that I have an opportunity to pursue things past high school. She has always pushed me to do better in school and so has my dad. My dad was lucky enough to go to college. He was an engineering student, so he understands my struggle currently. Physics and STEM in general is not at all easy. Im lucky to have parents that are making sure of my future career/endeavors.

The values Ive learned while growing up , the main one I learned was it's always better to be early rather than late. So I am rarely late to my classes in college though I have missed some classes. And to try my hardest in whatever im doing.

My father is a person who challenges a lot of things, and he taught me how challenges are important for my future. And he really cares about me. After I took the exam to enter university in Japan, I struggled to choose my course. I got offers from universities, but these were not my first choice. First, I was thinking about going to the university that offered me a place, or I would study one more year, then I will take the exam again. At that moment, my father gave me a new choice: I could go to another country's university. Then I chose it. Thanks to my father, I am getting a lot of new experiences. If he had not suggested it to me, I could not have had these experiences. Not every family can let a son study abroad, so this is one of the big strengths. I really appreciate my family.

No one has graduated from a college in my family, so I am the first-generation student to graduate from a university/college. However, my dad has attended some college classes but couldn't finish them due to family responsibilities. His experience in life without a degree helped me navigate through college and helped me understand how important education is.

My family has always encouraged me to follow my passions, so I've decided to use my college experience to both follow my passion of music, but also to study something that I find interesting and something that could support me in the future.

My parents have always encouraged me to go to further my education and go to college. They were never pushy about what I wanted to learn, they only wanted me to follow my curiosity wherever it led me. Growing up, my teachers tried to foster an enviroment where everyone could follow their curiosity even if it deviated from the lesson plan. That helped me learn to ask questions and think about how topics I learned in class related to other things I knew. This has helped me a lot in higher education because college is not as linear as middle and high school. In college, you have to direct your own path to a certain extent. Engaging with topics from class beyond the scope of the class helps me know where I want to go next.

The values that I've found to be the most helpful that have been imparted to me through my community are being kind, helping others and being respectful. I've found these to be the most helpful because they have had positive impacts in real world scenarios. Being kind generally makes people more receptive to conversation and it generally makes other people feel good. I know that when people are kind to me it makes me feel more open to talk with them and it gives a positive first impression. This can also apply to being respectful, which though I understand respect is generally earned not given, showing a certain level of respect to strangers and treating them well is a good value. Respect also applies towards teachers and workers, it's essentially not taking people for granted. For helping others it doesn't necessarily mean you need to join some activist group, it can apply on any level. I could generally mean giving someone a hand if they're carrying too many things or just holding the door for somebody. Overall these values help a lot.
I dont know. I just wing it college and try to do my best. Maybe they value me passing my class so that could be a drive for me to finish college, I dont know.

Some of the values that were instilled in me through my community or family that have helped me a lot during my navigation through college is probably the importance of hard work to achieve your goals. I think this is the most major one because its been a value that I had instilled through me through both my family from a young age and the community I had before college. I think its that work ethic that has helped me achieve what I have so far, as a lot of it wouldn't be possible without the values of dedication and work that I had to motivate myself to do. Another really important value that mainly the community/people I had around me that has helped me navigate through college would be trying to have new experiences. I personally really value having a variety of viewpoints and experiences, even ones that differ a lot from what I'm used to. It's this drive to experience as much as I can that has helped me take on new opportunities, branch out, and achieve even more than if I just stayed in my comfort zone.

I think the values of my family and community have pushed me towards college and my degree of choice, but not necessarily on purpose. Not a lot of people in my family have degrees, and most went into the arts like photography and such. They make a decent living of stuff like graphic design and photographing events, but that wasnt really the path I wanted. I always knew I wanted to go to college and Ive known for a pretty long time that I was interested in STEM. My family has always been supportive and proud, but it definitely has been hard navigating college without so much guidance. When all my friends were applying for college it seemed like them and their families had done this a million times, whereas I was pretty confused for the whole process. Even now my family kind of has no idea what Im talking about, but they still support me.

Not many things have helped me navigate my way through college. I had no one to back me up in hard times, I had no one to assist me in regular activities whenever I needed help the most. No person in my own community or family have actually helped me get to where I am today.

Having a supportive community and family is essential to my ability to progress in college. They provide me housing, take care of me, and support me through tumultuous times in my education. This allows me to continue to persevere academically even if Im facing tough times because I will have them to help me in areas where I fall through.

For me, family and community have been the main driving force behind not only my choice of career, but also generally my choices in life. My father has only worked in computers in various roles his entire life, so growing up meant that I was exposed to the daily happenings of a software engineer. Of course. as kids are wont to do, this also meant that I wanted to also work with computers when I grew up, yet I ended up actually switching my mind when I got to high school, and wanted to work in psychology instead. Eventually I ended up turning right back around to computer science and chose to pursue a similar job to what my father did. I am also integrated into a community within which there are many people who are in the tech industry as a whole, as well as surrounded by peers who are pursuing similar things to what I am pursuing.

My family puts great value into being hardworking and authentic and I feel that these ideas have definitely stuck with me throughout my current college career. Hardworking obviously have an impact as thats what needed to succeed in college, being able to overcome and work around Obstacles definitely hasnt been the easiest thing so far, but the encouragement and values which I was taught definitely help. The idea of being authentic although a little hard to quantify and see through work as is the precious value hardwork, has also played a big role. This plays out most in my feelings of integrity, and responsibility into giving things my most, and not taking shortcuts or taking the easy way the easy way out in most things.

the environment I grew up has definitely helped me a lot to navigate my college/university life. I was taught to be hard-working, good student, respectful from very early on. My mom also faced a lot of challenges in her college life and she told me her experiences and how she overcame them. Those stories and qualities I learned early on helped me a lot to navigate through my own struggles and college life in general.

There are many ways of ethically and productively using AI as a student. I often hear people saying not to use AI, personally this reminds me of grammar school when we weren't allowed to use calculators. It seems rather pointless because nowadays everyone has calculators in their pocket(their phone) just like we do with acess to AI. While I understand the need for understanding basic knowledge, I think it is not smart to not use AI at all. I think it is a beneficial tool that will only be bigger and used more frequently in the future. As far as using it ethically, it is important to not use it as a crutch or use it to cheat. I find it very useful to ask AI to expalin things in "layman's terms" or to "explain something to me as if you were my teacher". It is also helpful because you can ask it to break down or explain parts you don't understand or check your work to see if you made any mistakes. It is a good research and learning tool but it is important to use it for just that; a tool, and to not rely on it too much!

I assume the role of AI in STEM is to be the equivalent of an assistant who does basic things that would normally take the operator a much longer time to do but would still be doable by the operator. For instance, AI could solve math problems that are numerous but simple, saving the operator time and allowing them to use it on higher-level calculations and conclusions. I think AI can be used by myself as a student to help me understand concepts that would be difficult to understand without help of another, because AI is somewhat able to replicate human speech and mimic an instructor to explain concepts to me. I don't really enjoy using AI in academics because it seems like a shallower understanding of the concepts I learn from it is obtained, as opposed to figuring it out completely on my own. In other words, AI is like having a hand to hold every step of the way, which is not, in my opinion, the way one should always learn.

The role of AI in STEM is to create possible outcomes or solutions to someone working in STEM may not know how to do. For example, if you happen to forget how one command works in coding, you could give ChatGPT a description of the command, its operatives, and its use cases. This is how I'd ethically and productively use AI as a student, because sometimes there are many operations at work that all have different solutions, and AI can provide most or all of them to you, and to our benefit, we could decide which solution or outcome is the most beneficial. STEM is also the driving force behind AI, as engineers and mathematicians alike collaborate on these AI engines to cooperate with the user properly, and offer their best pieces of advice utilizing publicly-available information. However, as ethics are in question here, there should be protocols in place to prevent what information should be fed into it, since private information could be made public by incident or accident.

Using AI ethically and productively is important. It shouldnt replace my thinking but rather support it. In my personal opinion, the role of Artificial intelligence in the STEM majors in university and college is to be used as a learning aid. It should help students break down complex questions into more manageable, digestible problems that can be understood more easily and help someone comprehend the material being covered in class. This would be an ethical use of AI. Currently, from my understanding, some students use I in this way, but most use it in a manner that answers all the questions, using an AI system to input the problem being asked and a text related to the topic, and the AI system answers everything, while the student does nothing, not even proofreading what the AI system wrote, not learning anything in the process. This leads to the students being able to pass their classes but not learning anything in particular or meaningful.

AI is great tool in STEM, as it can help with tedious task like organizing and arranging data, as well as perform calculations. While many students often use it to get a quick answer (which may not always be correct), AI can help you and show the necessary steps required in solving a problem. The role of AI in STEM is that it can be used to help analyze data and discover new things. AI can also be used to solve difficult problems in physics or mathematics that cannot be solved by real people. AI can also maximize people's efficiency in STEM-related experiments since it can do tasks that may seem repetitive. I can ethically and productively use AI as a student by asking it to help me with projects from different classes, go over homework problems I'm stuck on, and grabbing information from the AI if traditional search engines like Google doesn't help. AI can also help me come up with ideas of what to write if I'm stuck on writing something, and it can also summarize documents for me if I do not have enough time to read the entire document. Lastly, AI can also summarize concepts for me if I'm having trouble understanding something I've learned from a lecture.

The role of AI in STEM is to assist on various occasions such as being there to correct homework or grammar. It can also help with curriculum development as it can analyze student data to help educators design customized lesson plans and identify gaps in knowledge. This will allow the classroom to be a more effective learning journey for everyone and no one gets left behind. It can also be and ethical use for students as they can use it for research assistance. Using AI can gather and analyze data for research projects and ensure that the information given is reputable. It can also work as a tutoring system since AI can help to give guidance on difficult topics to ensure that the user is focused on understanding concepts and how to get the answer rather than finding shortcuts. AI is still relatively young, and many improvements are yet to come, but we shouldn't be fully reliant on it.

The role of AI in STEM is to help students with their learning in a constructive way instead of the student just using the AI to cheat. AI can be useful in a handful of classes, using it as a tool to guide you in the right direction, help structure your paragraphs, or use it as a tutor for your classes. The role of AI in STEM is to help with making the process of making certain tasks more efficient. Some people fear it might take jobs, but I've known people who have STEM occupations that have used it at work. Usually it's for the tedious things that don't need to be problem-solved by people (like reviewing and summarizing reports). AI can also help with calculations too -- depending on how well-made it is and what is its purpose. Even some scientific discoveries were only made possible due to AI. In order to ethically and productively use AI as a student, I should always check what the AI is taking its information from and check whether those sources are valid or not. Additionally, I should always cite that I got my information from AI. I shouldn't use AI as a crutch, but more of like a supplement. I could use it to help me understand how to handle certain problems (ex asking ChatGPT how to solve an equation), but I can't use it to strictly give me answers.
