I think that the majority of the times I felt that my life got challenging was when I either had a lot of school work or I had challenging school work. In moments where I had a lot of school work, trying to come up with a "schedule" often times helped. I would see what assignments were due and when, and then figure out what I needed to work on during what days; if I was lucky, I only needed to work on one or two things per day in order to get everything done, meaning I had time to relax. I think that having a plan on when I was going to work on stuff helped me push through the challenge.

When life get challenging I try and "lock in". Right now is a good example as I found myself falling behind in school and have been non stop trying to pick at my work load. I find it is helpful to just sit down and get things done, only focusing on the task at hand. The moment I start to multitask or check my phone is when I start finding myself taking too much time to get something done. It is hard balancing however, because each class or assignment takes multiple hours and its hard to focus on one thing for hours when there are so many other subjects due swell. Also I find myself getting burnt out after finishing an assignment or too. I've found short breaks are helpful, but sometimes It is hard to get your self to go back to work after a break. I think my main issue is struggling with motivation. But when I realize I am behind I do not allow myself to go outside the house or do fun activities. I am either doing work, or procrastinating in my room.

When life gets challenging I try to brute force through it and see if I figure it out. If that doesn't work then I rethink my approach and consider reorganizing my life to accomplish my goals. For example, if I am struggling with a homework assignment (it is most likely that I lose willpower and focus) I try to power through it and not take my attention away from the homework assignment until I am finished with it. If this doesn't work, then I stop, take a break and usually I realize I haven't eaten in six hours. By the time I get back to the assignment, I find it easy and wonder why I struggled with it in the first place. Another example is if I am struggling with something bigger and more difficult to overcome in a short amount of time. In this case, I spend a lot of time analyzing my situation and evaluate it in relation to the overall direction of my goals. If this situation is objectively and logically monumental then I at least understand why I am struggling with it and feel more confident in putting in effort to overcoming it. If it is insignificant I most likely disregard it as an annoyance and "deal with it." Overall, I feel like one of the best ways I overcome challenges is by understanding why I am challenged.

When life gets challenging, realistically, I really focus on the one thing that's making me stressed out or angry and vent it out by shouting first and breathing after. It really gets the energy out & the blood flowing. After that, I like to find a temporary solvent for my problem or tell myself that it'll be okay & take a real step back from my situation. It helps to talk to other people about my problems as well, like my girlfriend or my friends. After some time, I'd revisit the situation and think about what I can do differently. If my solution doesn't work, just rinse & repeat pretty much. I feel like I'm a very emotional person and tend to let things get the best of me, so I tend to prioritize stepping away before a situation escalates before attempting a temporary fix. So, I try to keep my initial emotions in check, then try to find a solvent, then repeat if that solution isn't functional.

When things get really tough, I turn to simple but effective strategies: making a to-do list, going for a walk, or even just getting enough sleep. I know that burnout happens when I ignore my needs, so I try to stay balanced. Most importantly, I remind myself that challenges are temporary. No matter how difficult things feel in the moment, they always pass, and I come out stronger. Ive gotten through hard times before, and I can do it again. I just need to take it one step at a time.

When life gets challenging I often tend to meditate on my own free time on how I can work with my problems and how to approach them. Since I'm often get stress with school work, I always try to take a break so I don't get too stress out with assignments. But I not always have free time, mostly when I'm on midterms and exams, plus work, I just deal with it and when we are done midterms or finals, I take a break from life, so I just enjoy myself sleeping more and doing hobbies I enjoy. I think looking for ways to distress you and keep you focus with your things like hanging with friends, listening music, reading, and going out just for fresh air can work to help your mind not feel too stress about work and other stuff that can affect your school or daily life.

I am the only one in my family living in California, so usually, when life gets challenging, it isdifficult to deal with it since I'm alone. Normally, I like to call my family members or close friends and talk to them for an hour or so to clear my mind. Another thing I like to do is go out in nature, go for hikes around the beach, mountains, or parks, just relax, not pay attention to any sort of electronics, and take in the scenery. I also enjoy the gym and working out. It is super fun, and it is a good stress reliever for me. It also gets me so tired that I do not have the energy to think about what was bugging me to begin with, and I end up falling asleep almost immediately. All of these are the things I do when life generally gets hard.

When life gets challenging, I tend to feel more tired and sad like majority of other people. I also end up procrastinating more on my work. Times like these I have to frequently rely on my close connections, like my family and my close friends from class. I started going more frequently to tutoring sessions and attending visiting my professors during office hours when the homework becomes difficult. Since lots of my effort goes toward school, and keeping up with all my college and living expenses, I need to disconnect more frequently and recuperate before going back to any unpleasant task. From what I've heard from multiple podcasts, humans have a limited energy capacity when it comes to decision making, and overthinking trivial decisions can often get in the way of that. I tend to be an over thinker and think ten steps ahead but ultimately end up feeling drained from it towards the end of the day. If there is anything that I was taught this year, is to value the people closest around you and to not worry about something that has not happened.

When life gets challenging, I try my best to embrace that challenge, because I am aware that the challenges I face in life will help me to get better If I truly fight against them and keep working towards my goals despite the setbacks. If you truly want to achieve something great, there has to be challenges throughout your journey. Key point is being aware of them, and trying to solve those challenges,

When life gets tough, I just remind myself that Ive been through hard times before and made it out. School gets stressful, deadlines pile up, and sometimes it feels like theres too much to handle. But I know if I take a step back and break things down, I can get through it. I try not to overthinkjust tackle one thing at a time. The gym helps a lot. Even when I dont feel like going, I know Ill feel better afterward. Talking to friends also helps, even if its just random stuff to take my mind off things. Back in the Air Force, I learned that no challenge is really faced alone. Sometimes, its about pushing through, and other times, its about leaning on the people around me. Ive handled pressure before, and I know I can do it again. Stress comes and goes, but I always figure things out in the end.

When life gets challenging, one thing I try to do is to not overstress too much. I feel like when you have a lot of things going on at the same time, stress is a really easy thing to start getting affected by, so I try to handle that as much as I can. I think when you're stressed it kind of multiplies the mental toll things have on you and skews your judgement a little bit so I usually try to do what I can to deal with it. Another thing I try to do is just get things done earlier than I would normally, because when I finish something I have to do, like let's say homework for example, not only does it take a bit of weight off my shoulders, but knowing you did something already and not having to worry about it feels really good, and it usually ends up in me having more free time.

So as we know life can change really quickly and can totally take another angle, so we have to be well prepared, preparation has to be main solution for challenges if you know what probably will happen, you will be aware of all parameters that will be part of the situations. In addition, you need to be cool blooded to react efficiently to those difficulties, and don't stress out on just seeing something you are not ready for. Furthermore, you have to accept, acceptance will halve you to control you mind and don't rush out and loose the control of the situation. finally you need to help, ask for assistance, people will help you give there maximum to assist you and reach what you want, ask family guidance, generally some soft words from your mom will get you better, mentally and emotionally, so don't be shy to ask for advices and life experience

When life gets challenging, in the short term I just stress out and take like 30 minutes to an hour of doing nothing and just thinking about the situation. Depending on how challenging the situation is, I try to think of a long term plan to get through it effectively. I know that there are resources that this school provides in case I go through challenging times, and I know that I can turn things around. An example right now is the fact that I'm doing poorly in my Calculus II class, with a C+, and one way I can motivate myself is that if I change my habits, I can pull off an "academic comeback" and I can think about the fact that I've done this before in my junior year of high school, where I was close to failing Algebra 2 and I turned things around and went from an F to a B within three months.

When I think of life getting challenging, it usually is because I have many different events going on that I can't seem to keep under control. When I experience this sort of thing, my plan is to break stuff down into smaller, manageable parts so I don't feel overwhelmed. This allows me to sort and consider which things I should focus on, and are more important to me rather than trying to solve everything at once. An example of this is during finals when I have to study for all my courses and I just feel overwhelmed. I can sort all the courses I have into which final I have the least confidence in and what I can do to expand my knowledge. This way I can feel more prepared when I used to have no confidence in taking an exam on a subject I barley study. After taking the final, I feel less weight off my shoulders and I can move on to the next and start preparing.

When life gets challenging, I don't panic like most people and take a deep breath to focus on the problem. When you panic or worry when something is hard the situation will only become worse and you won't be able to focus. Instead of panicking when something gets hard, you can ask other people for help like for studying for a test or having trouble with some homework problems. By asking others for help when you don't know the answer, you can vastly improve your situation and you won't have to worry anymore. Furthermore, by using the resources SFSU provides for its students like TASK, you can get a lot of help studying for tests, help with homework problems, and more. You can also ask your professor for help on things that you have trouble understanding. Finally, you should have faith in yourself when something gets hard and ask others for help.

Actually I like to take challenges. When life gets challenging, at first I like to stay calm and think about the problem. I believe that every challenge has a solution, so I try to solve it by my own. If the problem is too hard, I do some research to understand it better and find my own way to solve it. If that still doesnt work, I look for existing solutions and learn from them. I believe that with patience and effort, I can overcome any challenge. No matter how difficult it is, I dont give up easily. I always try to find a way to keep moving forward.

When life gets challenging, the first thing I do is take a step back; this is usually just going on a walk or just doing an activity that will help relax me. After I try to reflect on what is making my life challenging. Usually it has to do with something related to school, and when it is thats when I try to either break down the issue into steps I can deal with. If life is challenging just because something is going on in my personal life, I approach this different. While I still try to go on a walk or do an activity that relaxes me, I then try to talk with my mom to get her advice on what I should do. However when I want to handle the issue alone, I find myself using the same steps as when I am handling school work, where I break down the issue into smaller steps that are far easier to deal with. When life gets challenging, I believe the most important thing I do is starting off by relaxing yourself, then facing your challenge.

When life gets challenging, I distract myself. And usually, that makes things worse. But usually my challenges are school-related, so that's why I put it off and procrastinate. It creates a sense of urgency that makes me get the things done after procrastinating for so long -- it's like guilt-tripping myself into doing it -- and then concentrating to finish the work. But for things not related to school, I'd usually go to friends for help. Spend time with them and confide in them, usually as a way to process the problem, or take my mind off of it. Other times, I'd draw. Drawing is something that I do when I'm incredibly bored, or when I am procrastinating too. Sometimes journalling comes along with the drawing, but I haven't been using journalling as a coping mechanism as much lately. Usually I'd draw random things, maybe vent things out, it's not really in a way that's purely emotional and angsty to me, I kind of detach myself from it. If I were journalling, usually it'd be a stream of consciousness until my hands would get tired or I'd be done with saying what was bugging me. But at the end of the day, I suck it up and move on. I don't usually slump for too long when life gets challenging because I find it as a waste of time. I could be doing other things. Probably it's not good mentally that I tend to compartmentalize things, but it's the best I can do. I've seen so many people slump for months, and I just don't want to be like that and trouble others. It's not necessarily that I "focus on happy thoughts", but I realize there are things more important than just laying in bed not wanting to get up and face life. I have a life to live and I might as well use it to the fullest.

When life gets challenging, I would find something to do that would keep me calm so then I don't overboard and run myself to the ground. In times when you are in tough situations, you must be able to see it through in its entirety so that you would know that it's over. There are a lot of things that I would do when it gets challenging. Some of them are just playing some games or just going on YouTube to chill and take a break from the challenge. That's usually what I would do mostly. Even though I would take a break, I still have to complete the challenge now or later, but pacing is kind of the key here because you don't want to overwork yourself to the point where you are willing to give up, but you also can't do so little where you just don't care and give up as well. So for me, I would do some work and then catch a break and then do some more work until the challenge is complete.

A example when life got hard at school was in the beggining of the semester for last semester it my first college semester and I haven't got used to the college work and I was taking calc and chem. I was struggling a lot and I was doing pretty bad on my exam. Then I started to form a routine to make things work and have time for everything. WIth a routine and good schedule I planned out all that I had to do for the week and the rest of the semester went pretty smooth. So sometimes you just need to take a step back and try to find something that works for you and keeps you going. Not giving up is also hard to do sometimes when you have a lot going on and its not easy to keep your head up. But it has never failed me and somehow I find a way.

What do I do when life gets challenging? What I personally do when life gets challenging is listen to music and draw to distract myself for a little then think about how I can overcome the challenge because I know that things happen and that I will ok, I can also learn from these challenges and in the future I will know what to do so I dont end up in the same situation.

I think being with friends is the most therapeutic and helpful. My friends are super reliable and I love them to bits. I like to play video games when I have the free time, but sometimes when I get bored of video games I like to do artsy things. I draw, paint, mold, I do arts and crafts when I feel I have nothing else to do or feel too stressed. I think when life gets thoroughly challenging I like to try and simply power through as best I can. I think the driving motivation is the fact that I'll be able to do fun things after the fact. If I am especially and deathly stressed, I think I would just set it aside and go for a walk. I'll linger over such problems and try and understand what I could maybe do to make things better for me. I think these methods usually work for me whenever I feel I am having an extremely difficult time.

When life gets challenging I like to take time for myself. One thing that I'll do is spend some time in my room playing video games or watching stuff to sort of recuperate. I also like eating sweet things like candy or brownies. Which I know is not a good coping strategy if I overuse it but I think that it's okay with a bit of moderation.

When life gets challenging, I think that I tend to either immediately give up, or keep trying, at least for a bit. It usually depends on the situation and if I can easily get help. If I can't manage to solve my issues, I usually try to ask for help, but if that fails, then my final resort is to give up. My mindset is that, at least I tried my best.

When life gets challenging, I try to let myself rest for a short period before I evaluate and face what is causing my life to get difficult. Sometimes it might be something that was out of my control in the first place, or it could be something that I would have to resolve with the help of my family. However, in the case of my current classes, I would be mostly alone on this. I would usually try to plan out how I would divide my time between each assignment, if my attention span can keep up with it without being bored out for most of the tasks.

My family has always made me complete my homework when growing, so I've almost always made sure to get all of my work done while in college, never allowing myself to skip an assignment when I don't feel like doing it. I feel that this is part of the reason why I manage to be consistent with my relatively high grades. They also have always been willing to offer me help whenever I need it, whether it be help on my homework or advice relating to living on my own.

My family has helped me navigate through college in many ways. This includes financial help but also in motivational ways aswell. My parents help pay for my tuition, and I live with my grandmother. Without this help, I would have to take out loans and be in debt, possibly making me reconsider going to college in the first place. They also helped me in motivational ways, such as instilling good educational values into me at a young age. My community at school has helped me pass my classes and stay on track. Friends have proved helpful for getting caught up in class, and the TASC tutoring center is a great service that is provided for free at our school, which is super cool. Office hours are also another place where I can receive support. School counselors help me choose classes and stay on track to graduate on time. My friends help me stay motivated by encouraging me to pursue my degree and end goal of a career in the engineering field. Overall I am completely surrounded by outside support and am not alone in my college journey. I have all the tools at my disposal to succeed.

My community, I'd consider, is in part the society I live in. Since my community is the people around me, I use my experience with the people around me to help me navigate through college. The values of my community are having a loud annoying polluting car, eating out every single day, being poor but still buying substances that harm the body, and listening to music while crossing the street while not looking with noise cancelling on. I wish to get through college so I can see another community that has different values. Basically, I want to get out of this city because I hate many parts of it. I do not dislike everything about this city, because I grew up in the Bay Area, but I do want to have the ability to leave and the way I will do so is by getting through college. Once I get through college, I'll be able to accept a job and make money and most likely relax a little--enough to spend some time on myself.

The values of my family and community have helped me navigate through college by asking myself constantly if I am capable of doing something myself. If I feel any sort of self-doubt or can't handle the situation I've brought onto myself, then I reach out to people who can put that belief into me, and remove the self-doubt. I also believe that my family has taught me how to learn, as we have a very hardworking family with a busy schedule. It's gotten better now, but the commutes that both of my parents have taken throughout the years have been pretty insane -- both of them driving to San Jos (1h 30m away from us) on and off. With that experience, they've also taught me that sacrifice is worth it, as we're able to live pretty comfortably, which contributed to a stronger and strengthened household. Since my brothers and I used to be alone with each other so often, we learned to cook, clean, fix, and do many other things by ourselves, which helped us grow up faster.

My family always emphasized the value of humility and respect for others, regardless of their background or circumstances. This has helped me build meaningful connections with peers and professors, enabling me to collaborate effectively and seek support when needed. Ive learned that being open, kind, and respectful not only fosters positive relationships but also creates an environment where I can thrive academically and personally.

Community and family have helped me by giving me a support system to rely on when I feel lost or unsure of something. Community can help from keeping college feel lonesome especially at a school like sf state where most students are commuters. Family is a big help because they are a constant source of positive energy and are always there to remind me to keep pushing forward and achieve my goals. These things all help me make better decisions as I am more focused on an end goal and feel more like I have the freedom to be my self.

Since none of my family members attended college, Im a first generation college student in my family. I received a lot of help from my high schools teachers and counselors, with applying for financial aid and scholarships. My journey to college was stressful because I couldnt rely on someone close to me to help me with how everything work, what classes I should take, and how to apply for any kind of programs in collage. I think my way to collage has always being reaching out to teachers in high school, asking them for recommendations in major choice, what I should be expecting in collage, and benefits I could receive.

As the only family member living in the state of California and somewhat new to this area in general, I do not really know the values of the community I currently live in, but I do carry the values instilled by my family. This involves hard work, treating each other how one would like to be treated, honesty, and respect. I think these values are excellent for navigating through university, work, and life in general, and I have had some success with this already, both in making friends and acquaintances and maintaining relationships that stretch through time and distances. I am very happy that my family taught this to me from a very young age, and I know that I will carry them long into my golden years far into the future, and I hope I can instill the same values in the children I hope to have one day.

My family stressed the idea of clear communication and honesty, which helped me foster great relationships with my classmates and professors. Likewise, my dad also loved to talk about the dip, a metaphor for describing work and managing tasks in your life. Its always easy to start a task and enter the dip, but its hard to get out of the dip and finish it. Therefore, running a school project or hosting your own passion projects - both require effort, willpower, and discipline. Even in doing little, and showing up for both your work and your people is important when it comes to development of good character. The Bay Areas local dance community also introduced me to a wide array of people of various ages and backgrounds, allowing me to develop pretty good friendships with some of them. Those people taught me how to be less self conscious and helped me improve my social skills and be more open. I tend to be more of an outgoing person, so anxiety and self doubt were really holding me back a couple years ago, and dancing with other people around the Bay Area helped me feel more comfortable in my skin and made me appreciate people more in general.

My family have always encouraged me to do my best at the academic field. And that is basically how I grew up. Prioritizing. my academic success. Obviously that lead me to discover my field of interest and apply to college. Based on my experiences until now, I believe that I made the right decision. And this is the place where I am able to improve myself and get better in any way I can think of. Therefore, I am both grateful and happy to be here.

The values I grew up with are discipline, accountability, and resilience. These values have been a huge part of how I navigate college. My family was always big on hard work and responsibility, and that stuck with me. My time in the Air Force reinforced that mindset, showing me that success isnt just about being smart but about showing up and putting in the effort. Thats helped me push through tough assignments and long study sessions, even when I dont feel motivated. Time management has been another big one. Juggling responsibilities in the Air Force taught me how to plan ahead and stay on top of things, which has made handling deadlines and balancing coursework a lot easier. I also learned the value of teamwork from both my family and my past job. Whether its working on group projects or studying with friends, I know that collaborating and asking for help makes a huge difference. Most importantly, my background taught me how to adapt. College throws a lot at you, but I know I can adjust and keep moving forward. No matter how hard things get, I remind myself that Ive handled challenges that are way harder before and that I can handle this too.

One thing that has helped me navigate through college is my family. I'm the last of 3 to enter college, so the previous two helped me a lot when it comes to college related things, from helping me deal with the transition to college to how to be a good roommate. Without them I probably would have gotten in trouble and in some tough spots all by myself. Even just knowing that my other two siblings made it through college helps me get through hard times because I know that they could do it, and if they can do it, I could too probably.

So as you know, the values are the basement of a person, he rely on them to find his trajectory in life. The way he acts and the decision he takes are depending on them, when he is reflecting he uses them. the values of your community helps you to have different points of view, you got the view of your family and community and the vision of some one else, you can deduct which one is right for you, two different optics that you have the chance to see and compare. family useably teach you good values, for example, for me I have two backgrounds, being French, taught me how to take life seriously and be hard worker, and being Algerian, taught to stick to, religion and god, and not to be ashamed of were you came from. yeah those gave good values that I used in my personal life and college life.

The values of my community, especially my high school friends, have helped me navigate through college because despite the fact that we're different majors and some of them at different colleges, we're all going through the same or similar things. My friends are there so I have someone to talk to, and vent to if I have problems. There's a lot I had to deal with navigating through college, such as difficult courses, assignments, and just simply managing my time, and I feel like this community is what's keeping me motivated. They have made me feel that I belong, despite my struggles. Some of my friends aren't STEM majors so they likely have lighter workloads than me, but one of my closest friends in this school is a biology major and I saw the assignments he has to do for his chemistry class, and the fact that I can relate to him despite me taking different classes makes me feel that I'm not alone in going through difficulties in a STEM major.

The value of my family led to me to going to a university and preparing myself to do my best and excel. I am the first in my family to attend college, so I believe it is my duty to make everyone proud. I want to be successful not only for me, but for my family as well. I know it won't be an easy task and I will have to fight for what I want and put in the most effort as I can, but I believe in doing so I am taking a big leap forward for my family and myself. I was taught discipline through martial arts, so I understand that in order to make the best of what I can, I have to be able to manage and not give up easily. Being successful is something important to me as I would have a title to my name and profession.

The values of my family have helped me navigate through college. My father heavily influenced my major in Electrical Engineering because he is also an electrician, and he inspired me to study electricity and engineering in college. Also, my parents have always supported me throughout my education career and have inspired me to study what I love doing most. By studying electrical engineering in college, I get to do what I love most and make money while doing it too later in life. By getting a job in electrical engineering, I get to work doing something I love, and will make my job so much more fun. My family helped me navigate my way to college and has always pushed me to do even better in school. Finally, my family especially my father inspired me to work with something that I love because then I will never truly work a day in my life while doing something I love.

My parents, they always support me. When I first decided to study abroad, I told them about my future plans. They listened to me and supported my decision. After that, I researched universities in the USA. When I found one, I told them about it. They trusted me and believed that I would not make a bad choice. They said they respected my decision and would support me no matter what. Because of their trust, I feel strong in college. When I face problems, I remember that my family believes in me. This helps me keep going. I also learned to be independent from them. They never forced me to do something I didnt want. Instead, they always encouraged me to follow my dreams. Sometimes, college is hard, and I feel stressed. But I know I am not alone. My parents support makes me confident. They remind me that I am capable and that I can succeed. Their values of trust, respect, and love help me navigate my college life every day.

How have the values of my community or my family (of origin or of choice) helped me navigate through college? The values of my family have helped me navigate through college in many ways. To start my family has always valued to treat every one you meet with respect, to never push someone down. This is an important value to have in college because of the amount of new people you are constantly going to meet. Another value from my family that has helped me navigate through college is the value of staying on focused and on time; no matter what. This value has helped me the most when focusing on school and work. It helps me stay motivated, which is something that I find myself needing to be more of while attending college. Throughout my community being involved was always a super important thing for anyone in that town. So keeping that same mindset in college has helped me to try to look for activities to be more involved in school. While I havent been that successful yet, I hope in the future I can still be more involved in the school.

Both of my parents got some form of higher education. And considering they moved to the US, they definitely had plans of making sure that they'd raise a child who definitely would go to college. Because of that, it was practically expected for me to go to college when I graduated high school. I didn't have any problems with the idea, since I thought going to college was probably the better option rather than going straight into the workforce and having my salary capped because I'd be doing an entry-level job. Also, the things I did want to do were available to study in college, so that's why I ended up there... and I worked really hard to get good grades in high school, so it'd be a waste NOT to go to college. From my parents, I understood the importance of hard work and discipline from a young age. My parents always made sure I was doing something, such as studying a different language, practicing an instrument, or doing chores. They even tried to make sure I was doing some form of physical workout at least one hour a day. Obviously I slacked on it the older I got, but overall because of that, I took my classes seriously. Even if I procrastinated to death, I'd always make sure to turn the work in on time and do it to the best of my ability. Another value would be the importance of having a community to depend on (or a good friend group). My mom would always tell me about how she'd have a bunch of friends in her major and they all worked together to get through their classes and graduate. Because of that, I made sure to go to clubs and interact with my peers (especially the ones in my major). This helped me build some friendships that I can lean back on to make sure I have a social life, have support in classes, and to make sure that I don't get lonely.

The values of my family helped me navigate through college by being a good role model in my everyday life. The challenges I face would have been impossible to complete without my family. Though the most important thing of being a family is probably sticking together. As long as we have one and another, we could face any obstacle that comes our way. However, that doesn't really navigate how it led me to choose this college out of the few I've picked. That part was all my decision. Even though college can be tough, I would know that I am not alone in all of this. The challenges that each university has to offer is something that must be faced with hard work and integrity. My family helped me when I was a kid and now I might tried to return the favor once I finish college if I could.

I guess to follow God , I am from a religious family and they always tell me to put God first in my life. By following these rules it has prevented my from making bad choicing like smoking and drinking and being on a good path. My parents also thought me not be be lazy, I've always work with them growing up and they don't have jobs that pay by the hour and get paid by the work done and it helped me learned to bot just try to get by and get the hourly pay but to make the most of my time because this time I'm wasting is never gonna come back. One thing that I try to do more myself is to try talking to more people because as I got older it was harder for me to meet new people and it makes school really boring if you are alone, at least for me. And this semester is getting better than my last one.

How have the values of my community or my family helped me navigate through college? The values of my family have helped me by teaching me that I have to treat others with respect and kindness even if we dont see eye to eye and also that I should always be on time and responsible with my assignments. My values have also helped me with staying on track with my school work and that if Im ever stuck or dont understand something that asking for help is ok because that shows that you care and that you want to make sure that you understand the stuff you have been learning.

Yes, my values directly stem from my older brothers and father. My brothers both graduated college a couple years ago, my second eldest brother had instilled in me a determination to get through college and find a career. My father encouraged me to do my best in school, I think it was this that motivated me to try and perform as well as I possibly can. My eldest brother is living the good life, being independent and free from the parents. I want to achieve such things, to be not only freed from my parents, but to relieve them of their stresses of having to maintain me and 2 other brothers. It is this determination that doesn't help me navigate through college, but rather motivates me to efficiently carve my own path through.

My family values college and getting a good education a lot and so they have been really helpful to me. They have been supporting me in a lot of different ways like helping to get me all of the equipment / supplies that I need for school. They have also made me have an attitude towards school that lets me approach it in a good way. I have been using this approach to get grades that are pretty good and to do my work ahead of time by prioritizing it above other things that I have to do.

The support of my family is what allowed me to attend college without worries and what allows me to focus on learning in order to have a better future for myself, while not having to be stressed out on countless other issues I might have faced.

When it comes to college, my family would want me to perform well there and gain something of value that will help with any future careers that I might get so that their money wouldn't go to waste. I think they might value "doing your best," which I wouldn't be so sure about when the pressure here is much higher than in high school. Trying to stay in peak performance 24/7 can be very tiring and it might not even be physically possible because of factors outside my control, and I myself tend to value taking breaks when needed, which only my mom agrees with. My family doesn't know much about how SFSU works, so I have had to do most of the navigating by myself and telling them about how the college system works according to what I find and interpret.

I am taking this lab right now because it is a requirement for my computer science major. I'm not sure if computer science counts as a STEM branch, but I'm interested in getting into computer science because I feel that programming will always be a useful skill in today's society, even with AI rising in popularity. I hope that having experience in computer science will help me get a job.

The reason I want to break into the stem field is for the money, I think my education is of high importance to due the fact that it is the one of the most securest ways to be of high value in a market but also applying my skills to wherever it may fit. And unfortunately being selfish is one of the things that I have learned about being in STEM and taking the opportunities wherever, however they may come. Another reason would be my family, I think it will secure and maintain my future financial independence by pushing myself to work in the STEM field. I value my family and goals to a higher reason beyond my understanding due to beliefs engraved as a child. A reflection of myself that I am beginning to understand more and more, the more I find myself feeling accomplished. Another reason would be technology, I find it very fascinating how things work at its core and building those core structures, understanding what is the known and making it better is something I can work hard towards especially in the corporate environment.

I am unaware of what the STEM field is, So I can not exactly say why I want to go into it, let alone if I even want to. Ahh, I see after a quick google search I was an able to find that STEM stands for Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics. I chose to go into this field because I have always done pretty good in school, and have taken the honors courses throughout middle school and high school. I think I chose to continue this path because it is what I am good at, and if I was going to college I wanted to do something that would be considered a "good degree". It's not necessarily that Im jumping over heels for math, but the fact that I know I am capable of doing it and that it will produce me a decent career in the end of it. However sometimes I debate whether it's worth it to follow the money or follow my passions. I really like motorcycles and am already currently making money selling motorcycle parts, It would be amazing if I was able to upscale my business and succeed but this is a risk. Maybe with an engineering degree I can still find myself in the motorcycle industry, just in a higher paying position.

I like the STEM field because it is mostly logical and fair. If I think logically and fairly, I will probably excel in the STEM field. This is different from other jobs where the way one looks might play a bigger part in their salary and status, or the way one acts might determine the way one's fortune goes. For instance, I prefer the STEM field to sales because I think sales requires too much social exuberance and is possibly like gambling. One's earnings might differ from day to day despite their work ethic being the same, purely dependent upon the amount of interested customers. Basically, I want a steady source of income where I know how to do my job and I don't have to worry about too many factors determining my success that I cannot control. I would be a salesperson or a professional pianist if money weren't as much of an important necessity in my life, but currently it is.

I'm here because this course is required for me to continue with my degree in computer science, yet it's not my only motivation for being here. My end goals are to develop an understanding of technology at a software level, and to use that knowledge to both understand how things in the vast world of technology work, and how to use them for my personal interests. Physics is an important tool for understanding the mechanisms of life at a fundamental level, but it's also important for some of my interests in computer science, such as how electromagnetism makes the hardware on my machine work, or how physics needs to work so that I can translate it into game development. The classes also set a good foundation for a good work ethic, and doing something productive helps to keep me in a good headspace and motivated both for university, and for life outside of it.

I heard these reflections are for a research project. I advise you not add my entries to the data pool, as my reflections are usually complaints about the reflection exercises themselves, or dummy data. Here's an example of the dummy data you may want to keep out of because its a description of a pirate on the high seas answering the question why am I here: Why Am I Here? Aye, the question gnaws at me like a barnacle on the hull why am I here? Rockin on these cursed waves, with naught but the winds howl and the creak of timbers to keep me company. The sea stretches endless, a great blue maw that swallows mens hopes whole. But here I be, a pirate by choiceor was it fate? I werent always this salt-crusted soul. Once, I knew land beneath my feet, soft earth instead of splintered planks. But the land held no promise for a man like me, born into the gutter, eyes sharp and belly empty. The sea, she whispered of freedom. No lords, no mastersjust the horizon and what ye could take with yer own two hands. But freedoms a fickle mistress. The longer I sail, the more I wonder if it be freedom at all or just another prison, this one with no walls, only water. Each dawn brings the same: the hunt for plunder, the fear of the gallows, the endless, endless blue. The faces of me crew blur together, all of us chasing fortune, yet finding little but blood and salt. So why am I here? Perhaps tis greed, or the thrill of the chase. Maybe its the devils own luck thats kept me afloat while others sink. But deep down, I reckon Im here cause the seas the only place left for a man whos burned every bridge behind him. Theres no going back to land, to a life I never truly had. In the end, Im here cause the sea let me be here. And when shes done with me, Ill sink beneath her waves, just another nameless soul swallowed by the deep.

In summary, I am here to reach the gateway of the rest of my life by striving for my degree in Computer Engineering.

I am here because this physics lab is a requirement for my computer science degree. While my main focus is on coding, algorithms, and AI, physics teaches problem-solving skills that are valuable in CS. Understanding how the physical world works connects to areas like simulations, graphics, and even hardware design. Beyond just fulfilling a requirement, I see this lab as a way to strengthen my ability to think critically and analyze data. In computer science, debugging code is similar to troubleshooting an experimentboth require patience, logic, and attention to detail. Learning to apply the scientific method will help me in programming, where testing and iteration are essential. Ultimately, Im here because earning my CS degree is part of my bigger goal: to build a future in technology, whether in AI, finance, or another field that excites me. Even if physics isnt my main passion, I recognize its role in shaping the way I approach complex problems. So, Im here to learn, to get one step closer to my degree, and to develop skills that will help me in my future career.

When I think about my goals, they all revolve around growth both intellectually and personally. As a CS student, I want to build things that make an impact, whether thats through AI, robotics, or innovative software. But to create something truly groundbreaking, I need to understand the fundamental forces that shape our world. Thats where this course comes in. Electricity and magnetism are everywhere, powering the technology we use, the circuits that run our computers, even the way information travels wirelessly. If I want to develop better AI systems, smart devices, or even work on robotics, I need to grasp the principles behind electric fields, circuits, and electromagnetic waves. I dont just want to memorize equations, I want to see the connections between these concepts and the innovations they enable. Beyond academicss, I hope this class pushes me to think critically, problem-solve, and embrace challenges. Physics isnt always easy, but neither is anything worth pursuing. By the end of this course, I want to walk away with a stronger ability to tackle complex problems because thats a skill that will serve me in anything I do

Contributing to STEM means fostering curiosity and making science accessible. Its not just about big discoveries, but breaking down complex ideas and showing how they relate to everyday life. I believe my personal values align significantly with the scientific community's core principles. I deeply value curiosity and the pursuit of knowledge, which mirrors science's fundamental purpose of expanding human understanding. Critical thinking is essential to mequestioning assumptions, evaluating evidence, and remaining open to changing viewsmuch like how the scientific method emphasizes testing hypotheses and revising theories. Collaboration is another value I hold dear, believing the best work happens when diverse perspectives come together, similar to how scientific progress accelerates through shared findings. I value honesty and integrity, which reflect science's commitment to transparent methods and accurate reporting. Where I sometimes feel tension is in balancing scientific objectivity with compassion; while science strives for detachment, I believe human values must guide how we apply knowledge, ensuring scientific advancement serves humanity's wellbeing rather than progress for its own sake.

When times are tough, I remind myself that I dont have to go through things alone. The first people that come to mind are my loved onesmy wife, my close friends, and my family. They dont always have the perfect advice, but just knowing that they support me helps a lot. Talking things out, even if its just venting, makes everything feel more manageable. Aside from people, I also turn to the things I enjoy. Music has always been my escape, whether its playing guitar, writing a song, or just listening to something that matches my mood. It helps me process emotions in a way that words cant. Gaming, especially when Ive been productive, is another way I recharge and take a break from stress. I also remind myself that tough times are temporary. If I push through, I get to enjoy the things I love even morewithout the weight of unfinished work hanging over me. That balance between effort and reward keeps me going. In the end, I know Im not alone, and I have both people and passions to keep me grounded.

My sisters understands my upbringing, and my therapist has an updated idea of what I have been going through. I aim to develop a more efficient water filtration system to improve access to clean water for communities that don't have the option of getting their water. Contaminated water remains a global issue, and better filtration technology can help address shortages and health risks. This class and lab of Physics 2 play a crucial role in achieving this goal by deepening my understanding of fluid dynamics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetismkey principles in filtration systems. Fluid dynamics will help me optimize water flow through filters, reducing resistance and maximizing efficiency. Thermodynamics will allow me to explore temperature-based purification methods like distillation. Electromagnetism can contribute to innovative solutions such as electromagnetic or UV filtration to remove bacteria and pollutants. By applying these advanced physics concepts, I aim to design a system that is cost-effective, energy-efficient, and accessible to underserved communities. This course will give me the technical knowledge needed to innovate and create meaningful change in water accessibility.

One of my core personal values is the pursuit of understanding; im driven by a constant desire to learn, question, and explore new ideas. That curiosity lines up perfectly with the fundamental spirit of the scientific community where critical thinking and open inquiry fuel progress. Theres a shared passion for discovering the the truthwhether that means revisiting old theories , testing new hypotheses or shining a light on blind spots in established ideas. Another value I truly hold dear is honesty. In my experience with science and technology, facts have a way of resisting spin so its crucial to stay transparent when you make a claim or to share data. The scientific method itself demands accuracy, replication, and peer review echoing this commitment to trust. Its not enough just to say something works; you have to show the steps and the failures, and the evidence, inviting others to poke holes in your conclusions. Finally I value collaboration and mutual respect; science is rarely a one-person show, it thrives on diverse perspectives and shared wisdom. By working together we can tackle complex problems and build upon each others findings. This blend of collaboration and respect for evidence underpins both my personal approach and the scientific communitys collective ethos.

I value curiosity, integrity, and a commitment to the wonders of this world, as well as real-life principles that align closely with the scientific community. Science thrives on questioning, testing, and refining ideas, which I admire because it encourages intellectual humility and continuous learning. I believe in approaching knowledge with an open mind, which mirrors the scientific methods demand for skepticism and evidence-based reasoning. Additionally, I value collaboration and knowledge sharing, just as science relies on peer review and collective progress. However, I also recognize that science is not always neutral; it exists within social and ethical contexts. My values push me to consider how scientific discoveries are applied and who benefits from them. Science should be accessible and used responsibly to promote equity and justice. Ultimately, my values drive me to engage with science in a way that is not only rigorous but also socially conscious and ethical.

Science takes time, and experiments dont always work the first time. I also believe that failure is part of learning, and I try to keep going even when things are difficult. But one difference is that science focuses a lot on facts and logic while I also think emotions and ethics are important. One of the personal values that crosses over with the values of the scientific communities is the value of self-development. Self-development involves coming to know oneself, understanding questions that need answers, and striving for continual improvement. This mirrors the scientific method, as curiosity and the quest for knowledge drive the quest for answers. There is always a question to be answered both in personal growth and scientific inquiry, whether it is about enhancing one's abilities or evolving knowledge in a particular field. By embracing self-development, one is able to recognize his or her weaknesses and strong points, the same way scientists recognize their continued need to understand the world more. This congruence fosters a mindset of continuous learning, critical thinking, and problem-solving that is needed in personal and professional life. Lastly, the pursuit of self-development and scientific inquiry both attempt to enhance our knowledge and contribute to enhancement in all areas of life, creating a synergy between personal values and those that are fostered by the scientific community.

I also have a passion for mentoring and contributing to gender diversity in engineering supports the scientific community's ongoing efforts to create more inclusive and diverse environments which is what the scientific community is about, empowering those willing to pursue a career in STEM. I do this becouse often talking about your problems out loud can help u better understand what is going on to see the problem in a different perspective. taking with others also helps since loved ones can also help you find a solution since they know you best as a person.I think it is imprtent to try to solve your problems when times are tuff.

Who I can go to when times are tough are my friends. Whenever there was a rough patch my friends would be where I would go to for help or comfort because they can give advice or also relate to. I usually go to my friends if not always some people might say parents but I dont think I ever went to my parents when times are tough or had a situation where I would need to go to them yet but my friends have helped me plenty

who can I go to? no one. there is not a soul within 500 miles of this campus that I can go to when times get tough. sure I have two people I consider friends and some people I call family. but none of them are even on the continent much less in the state or city. if times get tough I just have to accept things for how they are and move on. I can't afford to lose myself to the needless panic of a "hard time" so I just ignore it and keep up with my studies. If I accept anything less from myself I would never make it anywhere in my degree or even in this world. if that doesn't seem to work then I just add to my workload to keep my mind from thinking about the "hard times". but to answer the question no I don't have anyone to go to when times get tough.

People I can go to when times are tough are mainly my dad and my girlfriend. My dad for one because he is a civil engineer and is someone who I'd imagine is good at math. So at times I come to him for advice and tips on what to do and where to go for help. He's helped me in the past and told me what he did when he struggled in school and what he read to help him get through classes. Two being my girlfriend who is someone who supports me and is the most optimistic person I know. She always knows what to say to keep my head up and and reassures me that everything will be ok. She is my therapy, I can talk to her about anything and know everything will be ok. She is just someone who knows how to really take care of me whenever I need.

When times are rough, there are a few people that I find solace in. The first one being my mom of course. Our relationship has been rocky at times, as we tend to have differing opinion and perspectives on things, but she has never failed to support me. Even when it was moving to school across the state on my own, to which she had initially been against, she still supported me through it all. When going against her wishes of staying home, I thought our relationship would forever change, and it did but for the better. It was always so hard to talk to her even when it came to the smallest things, but now that I am far away I find it easier to speak about my feelings, and I've noticed the same can be said for her. I guess when it comes to our dynamic, distance is what brought us closer, as we learned not to take the little time we spend together for granted.

Family, friends, help groups or whatever that are sent to my email every semester. What else am I supposed to say for 150 words. Its a straightforward question and answer. I've spent so much time with family and friends that Im comfortable talking with any of them. We need to lower how many words to 100 or something, maybe 75 even. Like theres no way people can talk about their answer to this question for 150 words without typing a bunch of bs. If these reflections are still used in later semesters for people taking the same physics labs then the amount of words needed to get full points need to be lowered. Everyone is yapping a bunch of nothing just to get 1/1. I still need 25 words, what else to say, blah blah blah words, family, friends, people, classmates. 8 more words this is getting annoying omg.

Someone I go to when things get rough is my girlfriend. I actually really enjoy talking about my girlfriend so buckle up (i think). She's been there for me so much even though its been only a year since we met, and I think having her around has healed a part of me I didn't know needed healing. I had a rough time with my rommates this past year, and it was actually so bad staying at home, it would be dirty 24/7 and my gf would come over and always help me clean or clean without even saying anything knowing it would make me feel better. Another thing that has been so hard is getting a job, ive been trying my hardest to get a job and as a international student it is so hard to even try looking for one, because half the people would deny me because they didn't want to go through the long visa process. My gf was there for me before every interview even when I had lost hope, she would help me get ready, print my resume, help me make my file and choose my clothes. Her being around has one of the best things ever and I appreciate every second of it so much.

Today is not related to physics but more to mental calmness and problem advice: " Who can I go to when times are tough? ". Well If I get too tired, can't think straight, or have headaches I would go to my parents for advice on how to manage my brain. If it is a problem with homework, studying for midterm, quiz, or final,l or any problem related to university work I would go to my professor during office hours for advice. For university mental problems if I am struggling to manage through semesters in SFSU then I would go to a counselor by setting up a meeting and asking for advice. To be honest, these times which are sometimes tough may be difficult to solve but will little help from either your parents, therapist, counselor, professor, or any other people you can rely on, can help yourself through these difficult times/

When times are tough, I can go to my brother, or my parents. I can reach out to the Dept of VA if I'm having a mental health crisis. I can call my friends from back home also. It's important to have people to reach out to and to remain connected to people. This prevents you from descending into depression or bad decisions. When you have people you can rely on, it helps.

I really enjoy this topic. Someone that I can go to when times are tough would no doubt be my wife. She has been there for me through thick and thin. I met her at the end of my sophomore year in high school back in 2014 and we became really great friends and I decided to ask her to be my girlfriend. She stayed with me throughout my time in the Marine Corps when I wasn't the most ideal boyfriend/husband at the time but she helped me grow and she helped me understand the importance of having something who is rooting for you no matter what. Finding someone so young who just cares about your well being and only wants to see you succeed is something I was blessed with super young in life and I'm going to be forever grateful to have her in my life. Another person I would say that I could go to would be my mom. Her being a single mother, growing up she showed me what strength and courage was, always reminding me to express myself however I felt I needed. Always there to listen to me talk, vent, cry and all in between.

The answer to " Who can I go to when times are tough?" can be a bit subjective, so I'd like to answer it from a bunch of different perspectives. Firstly, in the academic sense, I can consult my other classmates or the professor when I feel I am struggling with work, whether in keeping up with it or even just knowing what to do. Additionally, the internet has proven itself to be rather viable in providing resources for various subjects and matters. Even so, having another mind at work could be of use. In the more general sense, I feel even such people can be the source of advice or comfort, though the remaining scope is a bit different. In this case, personal close ones such as family or friends can especially provide something to aid in troubles. This can even include the internet if such friends may exist online, as they are just as capable in providing help.

DO NOT READ When times are tough there are a few things I usually do. The first thing I always do is to ask God for guidance. I'm a very God-fearing person, and I know that God is the only one who can help me the most when times are tough or when times are great. I believe speaking to God during the good and the bad times really helps me spiritually, mentally, and physically. Praying to God also helps relieve a lot of stress because doing an act of worship is almost like a detox of the soul that can be extremely healing. Another thing I do when times are tough is get advice from people I trust. Being able to talk to someone about my situation and hear feedback can help me view things from a different perspective. A lot of the time being in a negative space can cloud any possibility of hope, which is why it's super important to talk to someone.

I'm not gonna write about this I feel like it's a dumb prompt for a physics class. Anyways, I like all the battery and circuit stuff we are doing in class.
