Anyways I think that's all I have to say I'm really struggling this time to get to the word count but now I just reached it so now I can stop typing and get to the fun stuff!

When life feels overwhelming, I remind myself that I dont have to go through it alone. The first people who come to mind are my close friendsthose who have seen me at my best and worst and never wavered. Theres something about an unfiltered conversation with a good friend that makes even the heaviest burdens feel lighter. They dont always have the answers, but sometimes, I dont need answersjust someone who listens without judgment. Family is another anchor for me. Even when I hesitate to open up, I know they care in their own way. Whether its a reassuring phone call or just being around them in silence, their presence reminds me that I belong somewhere. Beyond that, I find comfort in solitude, in writing down my thoughts, in music that speaks when I cant, and in moments of quiet reflection. I remind myself that tough times dont last forever, and neither do the feelings that come with them. Whether through connection or self-reflection, I always find a way to keep moving forward.

I was thinking about this deeply recently. I would say I go to my parents when times are tough. I see them as my go to people and safe space as well. I consider myself blessed to have parents as emotionally and financially supportive of me growing up. I feel like in this world your parents are your main source of guidance and support. Whenever I have a problem or an issue, I always feel like the only support I can get to fix it are from myself, my parents, or paid professionals (if applicable). There are certain problems I can go to friends or mental health professionals for, but my parents I feel like are the most supportive people in my life. In this world i feel like my parents are the main source of support who are there for me unconditionally and do not expect payment in return. I realized this in my 20s that the only people in the world who will be there for me unconditionally and not expect payment are my parents.

Some strategies I put in place to keep me focused through the the end of the semester are a couple of thing but the most import think I keep in mind is we are almost done. Make sure to take care of myself first so I do not burn out. For example making sure I get enough sleep and do some activities that can make me feel motivated in my life so I do not always have to focus on the stress. So basically A stress reliever. Another strategy is utilizing resources to help me keep track of martial and get the extra support I need for some of my class that are a bit more difficult then the others. But Lastly is visualizing the end goal in graduating and that summer is right around the corner I can make plans with friends. So those are some strategies I have to give me some motivation.

Ive noticed that as the semester wears on most of students motivation starts to dip, most of us in STEM experience burn out at some point of our life. One strategy Ive found helpful is breaking each assignment down into really small steps, making daily lists with tasks and things that are due soon so putting it on paper helps to ease the mental load. Also focusing on just one subject a day makes the workload feel less overwhelming and gives me little wins to celebrate along the way. I also try to keep a dedicated schedule, blocking off specific hours for studying so I can see exactly when Im supposed to work and when I can relax. I like to check things off my list so I dont have to worry about the deadline coming up. Being late on assigment or being underprepared for a test gives me anxiety so I would rather put in the effort sooner than later to the deadline. On days when I really struggle, I try to reach out to classmates to compare notes, troubleshoot problems. Having a shared sense of purpose keeps me accountable and makes the journey less depsressing. Overall, these small practices remind me of the bigger picture, helping me push through to the end of the semester.

To stay focused through the end of the semester, Im committing to a few key strategies. First, Im breaking down my workload into smaller, manageable tasks and setting specific deadlines to avoid last-minute stress. Im also creating a weekly schedule that includes time for studying, classes, rest, and self-care so I dont burn out. Staying organized with a planner or digital calendar helps me prioritize what needs to get done each day. Im limiting distractions by studying in quiet, designated spaces and putting my phone on "Do Not Disturb" during work sessions. Most importantly, Im checking in with myself regularlytaking breaks when I need to and reminding myself why Im working so hard in the first place. Staying connected with classmates and reaching out for support when needed also keeps me motivated. With these strategies, I feel more prepared to push through and finish strong.

Ive been feeling pretty overwhelmed lately and I think part of the struggle is that everything seems to happen at once around the mid-semester mark. Deadlines pile up, motivation dips and Im juggling so many responsibilities that its easy to lose focus. One strategy Im trying is making daily must-do lists. Instead of writing a huge to-do list that stresses me out, I pick the top three things I absolutely need to finish. It helps me prioritize and gives me small wins throughout the day. Im also trying to build in little rewardslike reading a few pages of a novel or enjoying a snack breakonce I complete a task. Another thing thats helping is finding a study buddy. Even if were just working side by side silently, having someone else there keeps me from drifting off to social media or random internet browsing. Finally, Im reminding myself of the big picture: why Im here, what I want to achieve, and how good it will feel to finish strong. Its not always perfect but these small strategies keep me moving forward.

Planning out which days are my future midterms/ final exams and also writing into my planner which days and what time and what subject I will study and studying multiple subjects in one day rather than cram one subject into one day so that I can grasp the topics better. I can also review homework and midterms and see where ive made mistakes and also rewrite some of my notes to refresh myself and organize them better. The main thing I need to do is plan out which days I will go to the library and holding myself accountable and spending more time in there and going in between my classes and if i dont know what to do than I should just review the chapters or lecture slides or class notes. All i need to do is prioritize class and homework and studying over friends and using my phone so much and I will be able to succeed and pass all of my classes with desirable grades.

one of the strategies that I can do is to have a set schedule to be able to start and focus on working on certain topics and cycle between them and take a break between them with ending of self-testing on the topics that were previously studied and making sure that an understanding of the topics has been developed over the course of the study period. With also have a self-care incitation included with one day just not worrying about the study session and going back to studying and practicing again with the same topics and checking to see if the study sessions have worked by practicing them and checking if the solutions gathered while practicing them again will allow for a better development of the practice and give an insight on the topics that you may still need to work on which in the case you could focus more on those and then later on add different topics into the study sessions allowing for more development over time.

I think I am focused so far, the expert TA and weekly quizes keep me busy and I wouldn't change much of the class. It is engaging and the lab instructions are very interesting. What I like most about the lab is that everything we learn is applicable outside the classroom and after the lab sessions I am able to connect things around me that remind me of the lab topic for that week. You also go out of your way to make sure that each topic is understood and well explained before the lab sessions start and during the lab, this makes engagement easy as I am not afraid to make predictions with my group, confident that we could ask questions and get answers if needed.

As the semester progresses I am definitely having issues with motivation and not procrastinating my assignments, laying in bed for a week and doing little to nothing over break had an impact on my ability to move through assignments and finish tasks. I am beginning to realize how close finals are and how much I have left to do as the semester winds down. I have three finals during finals week and before that I have two more exams for my linear algebra class and a project I need to do this weekend. While part of me is motivated to study and do the things I tell myself I need to do, and the other part backs out whenever its go time. I try my best to just keep doing what I have been doing and sticking with the commitment's I have such as the gym 5 days per week.

Through the end of the semester I can continue to be on track by focusing and putting effort into my physics labs. The week before spring break, I was sick and unable to come which really sucked (my grade!!!! no!!), but I don't expect to be behind at all. I attended the physics lecture and was mostly conscious for it, paying attention and taking notes through most of it, so we covered the main concepts which I totally can't remember right now but they're somewhere in my head. One of my best strategies for studying is to go off campus to cafes. There is a cafe that I frequent every week and I just go for around five hours and get a coffee and study/do homework for that allotted amount of time. I can put in my headphones and just focus on everything I have to do without the beckoning of the couch.

What strategies can I put to keep me focused through the end of the semester? Some strategies that I can use to help keep me focused throughout the semester is by using a planner to help plan what assignment are due and when to do them. I think this would help keep things organized and also help make sure I wont accidentally miss any assignments. I think another strategy I could use, is to take some breaks when doing assignments. This could help deal with stress and being overwhelmed by workload. By spacing out the assignments and adding breaks in between them allows it to be less daunting. One last strategy is to also do work with friends even either by in person or through a video call. Even if youre not working on the same thing together I think just having people to talk to while doing assignments can help make it go by faster and less boring also.

There are a lot of things that I can put in place to keep me in check in order to succeed for the rest of the semester the first thing that I can do is keep a good schedule, this would allow me to make sure I am on task with things that I need to do through the day and it will also set as a good reminder since I often find myself forgetting to complete some assignments this is a strategy I can keep in order to succeed i the second thing I can do to succeed is finding the time between classes to teach my self new things or work on things I am not strong in this is important to be because if you take the time to work on things on your own time you can build a better understanding since you may look at things in a new perspective.

Some strategies that I can do to stay focused during this semester is to keep any distractions away from me like my phone or people. More things is to go somewhere where you can focus and with little distractions to set the mood to do work or study like at a library or cafe. And to have a set schedule to follow so you stay on track

The key to staying motivated and focused through the second half of the semester is quite simple. The secret is to have never been motivated to begin with. I don't need a strategy to stay motivated; I don't even think about being here. I just wake up, go through the motions of the day, and happen to end up here. Once I'm here, it's easy enough to just do the work because there isn't much else that can be done while I'm here. The key to staying focused while I'm here is even easier. I'm bored, and the only thing I can give my attention to is the work in front of me. The Learning aspect is just a happy little side effect of putting the lessons into practice. At this point, we've all made it too far to just stop the party now, so the only thing any of us can do is just keep one foot in front of the other until we all finally walk out of the final for the semester.

Strageties I can put into place to keep me focused through the end of the semester is making a schedule or a goal and sticking to it. Making a schedule can help with staying with a routine and living through the cycle day by day. Doing this will keep me on track to study, doing homework, going to the gym, and eating. Creating a goal will help with motivation to meet my own expectations by a certain time. For making a schedule I can include what times to study and what depending on whats due and when. I can also include things such as when to go to the gym, when to do cardio, when to go to the cafeteria to eat, and when to be in bed and when to sleep. Sticking to all these strictly will help me progress and stay on track to keep me focused till the end of the semester.

I struggle a lot keeping focus for long periods of time, especially when it comes to doing work outside of my classes. I haven't quite yet come up with a plan to keep me focused for the rest of the semester, as most attempts to create a routine fail. Some things I have noticed that help, is unironically, taking enough breaks. Since I have trouble staying focus I found that making sure I have enough breaks throughout my day or studies can mean I can give my mind a rest before resuming. Of course, its all about timing those break/study period correctly and being strict enough with yourself to maintain that routine. Another thing I could do is make sure I get plenty of rest, this is something I have been trying to fix as I used to only get 3-5 hours of sleep a night. Its honestly been really hard adapting to this new sleep schedule but I have definitely noticed a change in my self and productivity. Its going to take a lot of effort but I am almost done with the semester so I should keep pushing.

I gotta get a degree and get a job. If I don't do good in college im probably fucked; market is over saturated withthe amount of people getting computer science degrees. Get good grades, do the work, possibly get internships or something I have no clue. I usually do the work correctly at the beginning of the course then like one third the way through I get a little lazy and stop paying attention but then when it comes to finals and the last third of the semester I lock in. Only strategy is locking in and doing the work I can to complete the course with an A. I don't really focus that often, Im usually in a flow state where I coast around doing work that slowly helps me get better at whatever the assignments are. Staying focused right now is so hard. At the start of the semester, I was actually trying, but now its just feel slike assignment after assignment, and I kinda just want to lie down and do nothing. What helps me (sometimes) is breaking stuff into smaller tasks, If I think about everything I have to do, my brain just refuses. But if I plan to do a singular this-- it's actually a lot easier to start. I like putting reminders for assignments early on in the day few hours before they are due, (unless they are major ones) I have noticed I work well under pressure and I strive to be the best in a stressful enviroment. I also have to remind myself that I do care about school, even if it doesnt feel so in the moment. I want to do well, and I actually like learning. Another this is, I am an international student and I pay over 9500 bucks just to attend school, and that usually keeps me going. I just take it day by day. The semester will end soon and I can finally rest for a bit before I restart.

Today's question is"What strategies can I put in place to keep me focused through the end of the semester?", that is a question I think about every day, and sometimes change in different semesters. For most people including me, the strategies to get them through the semester is to create a schedule, break down tasks, use a planner or calendar, prioritize tasks, eliminate distractions by creating a dedicated study space, turn off notification, Use website blockers, etc, and maintain motivation and well being, by setting realistic goals, reward yourself, practice self care, seek support, take breaks, get enough sleep, eat a health diet, Exercise regularly, and etc. Most of these strategies I use help me get through most of the semesters in SFSU, by helping me know what to do during hard situation, like studying for midterm, quizzes, finals, doing a huge project, making sure homework are done, and etc.

I need to be healthy mentally and physically. Exercise daily, get good sleep, have good social relations. Need to stay focused on why I'm here, which is to get a degree, to get a job and be able to provide for a future family and not have stress related to paying rent. Specifically, I need to prioritize getting my work done on a timely basis. Schoolwork needs to come above all else.

One of the strategies that I can put in place to keep me focused would be the Pomadoro method. The end of the semester tends to be me just studying and trying to keep up with the amount of assignments I get assigned. During this time I tend to notice that I burn out really easy, especially when I'm studying. I found this method I believe last year or the year before that and I can say I noticed a huge difference not only in the quality of my work but the knowledge I was retaining. Another thing that kind of helped me was realizing that my brain was actually a muscle. I work out 5 days a week and I'm super into fitness recovery and understanding how my muscles build and breakdown. Simply putting that notion that my brain is a muscle and needs rest has changed my prospective on trying to cram material when I'm burnt out.

In order to stay focused throughout the semester, the biggest thing to keep in mind is the deadlines upon which things are due. It is important to keep up on assignments as falling behind can make it harder to catch up without allotting a lot of time to work. Another thing to keep in mind is the minimization of distractions, which can take away from needed work and study time without being fulfilling due to the looming assignments facing procrastination. There are many strategies for this depending on what can act as distractions, but the biggest factor is likely that of the Internet, which struggles from being very easy to access and possessing a flurry of addictive content. If applicable, one could use another close one to ensure they don't stray off-task while handling collegework. Aside from these factors, it is important to note that constantly working for hours can be draining, so taking breaks at least every hour could prove to be useful as long as they too are kept in check, and don't overstay their welcome.

Some strategies I can put in place to keep me focused through the end of the semester is time management. This is a huge one for me because I have many things going on in my life, and it's hard to keep up with everything when so many things are happening simultaneously. For example, I have a huge family who always wants to spend time together. In order for me to have a healthy balance, I need to set time for myself to study and spend time with them. This also applies to my job. I work two jobs, one of them part-time and the other by appointment. This is a huge part of my life as well and it can take up a lot of my time if I don't manage my time properly. Another important thing to keep me focused is to take away all distractions. Things like devices and TV are huge ones for me since they are always available. Going to study rooms or locking the door in my bedroom helps very much with getting away from distractions.

Well as a person with adhd there are a couple i can do. The most direct thing I think I can do is remember to take my medicine. My meds really help me focus but it's only half the battle. Even with meds I need to be in an environment that allows me to focus on my WORK not anything else. So it's kind of like removing the baseline distractibility even if there are other distractions that I then focus on very well. So what this means for me is to have my work device out, be in a static location, and to make sure I can stay at that location for awhile. These tips have allowed me to focus on things pretty well and allowed me to tackle hard problems for me as a person with adhd and come out the other side in a position that I actually think is pretty good! since no one reads these tldr is take adderall and go to coffee shops. OH AND AVOID SUGAR.

Honestly, staying focused through the end of the semester is hard. Right now, everything feels like it's piling up assignments and my motivation is not where it was in the beginning. One strategy I want to try is setting daily goals, just so things feel more manageable. Instead of saying I need to finish this paper, Ill say, Today, Ill write the intro. I also want to reward myself after completing tasks even small stuff. Another thing that helps me is changing my environment going to a caf or a quiet corner of the library when I feel stuck. I also need to remind myself why Im doing this and what the bigger picture is. Whether its graduating, making my family proud, or just proving to myself that I can push through. And maybe the most significant thing is just giving myself grace. Some days will be off, but that doesnt mean Ive failed. I just need to keep showing up. One step at a time.

1) That is a tough question. It is one I have tried to ask throughout the semester. We can keep ourselves on task by telling ourselves that school is for a more long term goal and it will be beneficial to future careers. I also tell myself that the semester is coming to a close and I am almost there. I know it is easier said than done but I tell myself its just one final push till the very end. I feel like I cannot give up if I have gone this far already and am more than halfway through the semester. I struggle with my focus, so it is a struggle throughout the semester and not just to the very end. I try to keep prioritizing important tasks and make to do lists of things I have to get done. I ususally go to the library when I have to get stuff done so I have more motivation there.

My passion for stem related subjects and the field began when I was in high school. I had been accepted into a four year program that taught students the principles of design, coding and manufacturing through an engineering scope. Through the years I had a lot of hands on experience with the processes related to engineering by completing various projects each year. I greatly enjoyed getting to work with the machinery in the shop and exploring aspects of design by incorporating them into our projects. Ultimately with my education in mechanical engineering, I would like to enter the automotive industry in the future. From a young age Ive realized that I naturally have gravitated towards the design of cars and really enjoy coming up with new ideas to improve and innovate them. I think that pursuing a degree in engineering would fit well with the type of work I seek to perform in this field.

I would say that I want to go into the STEM field (specifically mechanical engineering) because it was the lesser of all the evils for me. What I mean by that is that compared to all of the other subjects I took in high school, engineering was the most interesting one or at least math and physics. I wouldn't say that I choose this field because it was something that I was in love with or anything like that, but perspectively compared to all of the other subjects I thought that this would be something that I wouldn't exactly dread everyday. I would say another reason why I choose this field is because of my parents in a way and my brother too I guess. My brother graduated with a cellular molecular biology degree and now works as a test engineer and so my parents always had this standard and I'm not saying all the other subjects are on a lower degree than engineering, but I just thought go big or go home in a way. I'm still trying to figure out if I really enjoy this field, but since I am so deep already I might as well just finish it out.

Long story short, I want to be a teacher and Ive heard that STEM teacher get payed really well. :) But also, I was always better at the more concrete subjects like math and sciences instead of the more open-ended subjects like English, and I would much rather teach something like that where each question has a specific correct answer.

I want to be in the stem field because I feel like there's always something new to learn or create. Going in to the stem field is hard work and I like that because it allows me to feel accomplished. I also think I would never get bored in the field, and since its probably gonna do for most of my life that to me is a good thing.

I want to go into the STEM field because Ive always been hands-on and curious about how things work. When I started working on cars at 15, it wasnt just about fixing themit was about understanding the mechanics behind them and figuring out how to make things work better. That curiosity grew into a passion for engineering, especially in the automotive and mechanical fields. I enjoy designing and building things, whether its custom parts with 3D printing, working on UAVs, or experimenting with electronics like guitar pedals and mini amps. STEM gives me the tools to take my ideas further, solve real-world problems, and create things that have a purpose.

I want to go into the STEM fields because there is a high chance I will be paid well if I am good at what I do. I like STEM because it is the most logical field and makes sense of the universe around us. I enjoy solving problems and I feel a great satisfaction when I complete a problem or when I can find a new approach. I like STEM because it is challenging and I like challenging!

I wanted to go into the STEM field even as a little kid when I saw my older cousin went off to college. I remember seeing the engineering buildings and I saw myself actually tinkering with things and building with stuff that eventually I knew exactly what I wanted to study in college. It was a pretty long while ago so I don't really remember the year I saw the college that my cousin went to nor the name of the college itself. I kinda also wanted a challenge but also still wanted a space to still be creative as much as I want to so I was stuck between electrical engineering and mechanical engineering. I stuck with mechanical engineering first and decided that I wanted to study both! I think I choose mechanical engineering because I thought that mechanical engineering was like the foundation toward all branches of engineering but that was before I joined the STEM field and I think I couldn't be more wrong.

The main reason why Ive gone into STEM was because I didnt really have a burning passion for it. I dont know how to explain it to other people why in earth I would go spending this kind of money for something I dont necessarily have a burning passion for, I know, but it doesnt really matter what other people say. At the end of it, I know Im going to have something out of it and itll be enough for me. I do appreciate the STEM field and its attributes and contributions to todays society. Namely, if my career as a Civil Engineer helps build the infrastructure or help stabilize someones home or even workplace, all the while giving me a steady flow of income, then there you go. Its a little weird and Ive definitely given up on trying to give myself space to fall in love with it but hey, its something.

I want to go into the stem field because its the thing Ive been good at for my whole life. Math and sciences were always the things I liked in school growing up. I also like that in stem, the answers are absolute. There is a determined or undetermined right or wrong answer that you can achieve whether or not you did or didnt take the necessary steps to find it. Most recently I found a lot of interest towards electronics and circuitry and that is something that I thought I could actually do as a career. Engineering also feels like a free canvas that I can go any which way and still do something that I could be interested in and I could find fulfillment in if something started to feel stagnant. All in all stem has always been my passion and something Ive wanted to go into.

The reason I want to go into the STEM field is because I prefer working with formula and concept centered topics. The main reason I decided to go into STEM field is because I want to make big money. Also, I want to become the world's 1st Leading Smart Cleaning device producer. I want to go into the STEM field because I always found myself intrigued by the ways of which things function, whether that be the living organisms, or numbers, or machines; I always found myself curious and wanting to know more. I feel like it is also much to say that after having gone through the hardships that I have, and still wanting to pursue Mechanical Engineering means that I still carry much passion and still want to learn more and more.

I want to go into the STEM field because I find it interesting compare to other fields. Mostly with the science in STEM with experimenting and experiencing with anything. The stem field will give me the opportunity to help people. This is why I am so passionate about my majors because I know with this knowledge I could change the world. I want to go into STEM because Im interested in learning more about the universe and how it came to be and how it works. I want to go into the STEM field because I believe it will best support me in the future and will provide stability even with AI developing so much. I want to go into STEM because of two reasons. The first reason is that STEM allows me to be creative while making a living. Theres a third reason I just thought of and its that I feel pressured to do something hard since I didnt go to a big name university like a lot of my other friends. I want to go into the stem field to work on complex problems and to try to solve them. To use team work to solve problem to improve peoples lives. I want to be able to work on something that has material impacts on the world.

I feel like a large number of people choose to go into the STEM field because of the money they could make. While Im part of this large number, it was more of a coincidence. Growing up, I was always surrounded by engineering, my dad is a civil engineer, and I admired the way he could take an idea and turn it into something real. But to be honest, my love for STEM really took root in my love for math. Numbers just make sense to me. I love how theres always a solution, a logic to follow. It just scratches my brain the right way, I understand math quicker than I can read a chapter from a book. At the same time, Ive always been a girly girl for a lack of better terms. I love pink, I love makeup, and I love all things cute. For a long time, theres been this stereotype that engineers have to fit into a certain box. That to me, is serious, practical, maybe even a little dull. But thats not true, and I want to prove it. Im bringing my personality, my style, and my passion into my field because being an engineer doesnt mean I have to give up the things I love. If anything, I think it makes me stronger. The world of STEM needs more diversity with the people, ideas and perspectives. I want to be part of that change, and Im excited to help with change while also staying true to myself.

i believe my support circle is available and extensive. Although they are all not near me in the bay, I also have my friend group to ask for emotional support when I need it. I also have my house mates who I share and keep in contact with the most on a daily basis which is also another resource. Additionally, I am aware that there are also resources available on campus as well.

Someone I can go to when times are tough are to my girlfriend, my brother, and my closest friends. I feel like I am very lucky to be able to have all of the outlets, because depending on the situation that give me a different perspective, and so if I go to all of them I feel like that gives me a piece of mind because I am then able to reflect on the different types of thoughts, views, and standpoints. I would say that besides people something I like to do when times get tough is a just like to go on drives blasting music. I think that music is an awesome way to express all different types of emotions and when I am able to do that I feel a lot less stress on my shoulders. Sometimes I wish that I could go to my parents as an outlet, but from trying before it just turned out to not be the right move. Love my parents and everything they do for me, but we have just never been close like that.

I can go to my sister, my friends, or my parents. I guess I could always go to a counselor or something as well, and there are hotlines if anything goes really wrong, but hopefully it never needs to go there.

When times are tough I tend to go to my boyfriend he is very good listener and I always feel less stressed when we speak. I can also go to my roommates especially about school since we all go to sf state and know what its like to work and go to school full-time.

When I feel like time is tough, I know I can always rely on my partner, who helps me daily, and I can talk to her unrestricted. She won't judge me or make me feel lesser than and always knows how to cheer me up when I feel down or stressed. She works overtime during my finals as it's always a really big stressor to me. Another is my friends are always here in SF for me, no matter what, I can call them and ask if they can come over, and they always reply, of course, and on the way over. Having this connection is amazing cause I don't feel like I'm alone in this and I know I have countless people to rely on, which is a nice feeling when I feel down.

When times are tough, I can go to some types of counseling or help with whatever I need. For example if it is homework or class assignments I am struggling with, I am able to go to TASK or maybe even look for help online. Even just conversing with people can help a great deal, especially classmates I make friends with are able to help me get through my work in the case we work together.

When times are tough I typically go to my parents, my friends, or my girlfriend for support, i usually just rant to them about how that test went or the grade i got on my homework to vent out some steam, I feel like I should talk to my counselor here or the safe place here on campus because I feel like actually using the service here would be more beneficial for everyone but I do feel a little shy. Sometimes I also just cope by just doing my other hobbies to just not think about it and that especially helps if im playing video games with friends or my girlfriend. Times so far this semester havent been tough where I had to vent that much, just little things here and there but its just been chill. I think its just been one professor that Ive been having trouble with who i have two different classes with who has a tough homework grader and my homework grade hasnt been looking too good, but i know if i apply a little more effort by visiting her office hours we can iron some stuff out

When times are tough I can always go to my friends and my girlfriend. She is always there for me and I am for her and we make each other better. My friends are also really good at making what seems like the end of the world into something we can all laugh about and we make a really supportive environment for someone who is struggling. I can also go to my family, they have always supported me and I want to do the same for them.

Depending on the issues that come up that makes times tough, I could go to multiple people. If the problems are related to my school life, I can go to my professors, advisors, or staff of the school. If the problems are relates to my private life, I can go to my family, friends, or in extreme cases: the authorities/doctors. I have, thankfully, many options regarding who I can go to when times are tough.
There are times things get tough since balancing work and school. When this time appears, the primary person we can go to is our teacher then a secondary person would be your advisor.

When times start getting rough, I know that I can fall back on my family and friends. Im constantly talking with my two sisters and my mom and dad, even before things start getting rough because I enjoy talking to them and find that talking with them before the time starts getting rough, I dont reach a breaking point as often.

I can go to many people. A lot of the people I go to are people that I have known since high school. This includes my friend Ray who I would consider my best friend or at least one of them. I also want to consider my friend Maxximus as someone who I actually housed for a year with my family. I also include my friend Hayden who is on the wrestling team with me right now. For the most part the things are tough I go to my friends and if we can consider the library as part of "who" then that as well. When times get tough it depends on what is tough for me to get through before seeking for help. If it's homework or understanding of class that would be tutor or office hour. Previously, I was interested in how submarines work. Since we learned about buoyancy, I have a bit of a better idea. Submarines, like boats, stay afloat because of buoyant force. The buoyant force pushing up on them is higher than the force of gravity pushing them down. We also learned that pressure is higher the deeper you go, so they should be able to control depth by changing their buoyant force until it equalizes at whatever depth they want. They control their buoyant force by filling or draining ballast tanks with water. This works because submarines weigh very close to the weight of the water they displace and adding/removing water from these ballast tanks make them weight more or less than that.

Momentum conservation is a fundamental principle in physics that states that in the absence of external forces, the total momentum of a system remains constant. This concept is crucial in understanding car crashes and how safety features like airbags and crumple zones work to protect passengers. In a collision, a car and its occupants have initial momentum, which must be dissipated upon impact. Without safety features, the rapid change in momentum can cause severe injuries. Crumple zones absorb energy by deforming, increasing the time over which the collision occurs and reducing the force exerted on passengers. Similarly, airbags deploy to slow down the passengers forward motion more gradually, reducing injuries by decreasing acceleration forces on the body. This principle is widely used in automotive engineering to design safer vehicles. By extending the time over which momentum is transferred, car manufacturers reduce the impact force, ultimately saving lives. Understanding momentum conservation helps engineers develop better safety measures and informs drivers about the physics behind collisions, encouraging safer driving practices.

Recently our physics w/ calc 3 class are learning about the zeroth law of thermodynamics. What is the the 0th and 1st law of thermodynamics? Why is it called the 0th law? It fundamentally explains the theory behind thermal equilibrium and temperature. It explains that if two systems (that we will assume A and B) are in thermal equilibrium with a third system (C), then A and B must be also in thermal equilibrium with each other. This explains how temperature is a measurable property which explains the use of a tool like thermometers. An example of everyday life is like if we took a hot cup of hot chocolate and put a thermometer in it, the thermometer will EVENTUALLY reach the same temperature as the hot chocolate. The first law of thermodynamics, is expressed as delta U = Q-W, where delta U is the change in internal energy, Q is heat added, and W is work done by the system. It is important to realize the difference between heat and temperature, they are not dependent on each other, they are both independent variables. heat can change and temperature will remain the same and temperature can change without the heat changing at all. According to the first law of thermodynamics, no system can generate more energy that it uses which kinda explains the whole equation thingy. This information may benefit society as it's important for designing energy-efficient systems such as power plants to small scale stuff like appliances.

The question I had was what is the difference between buoyancy as we know it in everyday life and buoyant force in physics? When looking through the slides I determined that the main difference is that we view buoyancy as the floatability of an object whereas the buoyant force is determined by the upward force exerted on an object by the fluid surrounding it. We think that if an object floats really well then good buoyancy and high buoyant force and if it sinks then the object has low or no buoyant force because the object is not very buoyant. However, the buoyant force is not determined by how well the object floats but by how much fluid the object displaces and how dense the fluid is. The buoyant force is just a force that comes from the fluid surrounding an object pushing up on the object, and if that force is greater than the weight and subsequent downward forces acting on that object, then the object will float but if it is less than those forces, then the object will sink.

Based on the concept of the Ideal Gas Law, how does temperature affect pressure? The answer for this question is that when temperature goes up pressure also goes up. This information might be applicable to peoples lives in terms of safety. Using a pressure cooker that deals with both temperature and pressure can be dangerous if not handled correctly. By slowly releasing pressure, the temperature goes down and the cooker can be safely opened.

Thermal equilibrium From the lab, assume Water A is 70 o C and Water B is 40 o C. What happens to the temperature of the two waters when mixed together? Using what I learnt from class, when an object of an initial higher temperature comes in contact with an object with an initial lower temperature for a given time period, the final temperature of the two objects is the same. This works by heat loss or gain. From the question, as the two waters are mixed, the temperature of Water A decreases as it loses heat to Water B for gain. After a period of time, the heat between the two waters then become the same then the temperature of both also become the same. The application of this situation is mixing hot tea with water. As the water is added to the hot tea, the hot tea loses some heat while the water absorbs the heat loss until the heat of the water and hot tea becomes balanced. And the person can drink freely without getting their tongue burned.

Concept: energy in matter changing state When something, water for example, is changing state from solid to liquid or liquid to gas, its temperature doesnt change, but rather the energy put into it is used to change its state. Once all of it has changed state (ex: all the water has turned to ice), then the energy begins to change the temperature again. Because of this, if youre trying to solve for the amount of energy to get the water from one temperature to another, but at a temperature in the middle it changes state, you need a separate equation for the temperature change and the state change and add them together.

The question I am making is how does energy affect the temperature of a system? At first, I thought the temperature you add or subtract is directionally proportional to how temperature changes, but I was wrong. Even if you add energy to a system, the temperature of the system doesn't change right away, the system will try to reach thermal equilibrium and thats how temperature changes. For example, if you add boiling water to an ice cube, the temperature of the ice cube doesn't change but its energy does. Another subject that relates to this is phase changing. For example, if an ice cube gets energy added to it, like boiling water, the water will melt from the solid to a liquid.

Why is it that heating a gas increases pressure? In the lab we did last week we simulated heating a gas and saw how it effected pressure. When the volume was constant and the gas was enclosed, the pressure went up. This makes sense but why it happens is slightly nuanced. Starting with the equation of the ideal gas law, PV=nRT=NkT, it is apparent that when volume is constant, pressure increases. V is volume in this equation. In the equation 3/2kT=1/2v^2, v is velocity. Where these two equations can be related through temperature it becomes apparent that increased temperature comes with an increase in force and an increase in velocity. Conceptually, the particles increase velocity as heat is increased and then are more likely to collide with each other, increasing force and subsequent pressure. A easy example of this is an instant pot; as the cooker heats up, the force on the inside walls increases and seals the pressure valve to begin the cooking process. Once complete, the valve is opened and steam comes shooting out as the pressure is released.

PV = NkT is the Ideal Gas Law. My questions is if I hold everything constant except one, is it physically possible or what would it look like? But what would it look like in a real life experiment?

A question I could ask about a topic we studied in lab is about ideal gas law. How can you calculate temperature using the ideal gas law? The ideal gas law formula is PV=NkT. If we wanted to calculate the temperature using this formula, we would have to rearrange the variables so the equation can equal T. We would have to divide both sides by Nk to isolate T. After doing this, we get the formula T= (PV)/(Nk) which can help us solve for T. We are only able to calculate the temperature with the formula if the other variables are known.

How does mass relate to the energy it takes for a substance to change phase? The mass of the substance is directly proportional to the energy required to change its phase. The more mass, the more energy needed.

What makes an object or person float in water? The buoyant force is what is responsible for making an object float in water. When an object is placed in water, it displaces a volume of water that is equal to the volume of the object that is submerged in water. The buoyant force is equal to the weight of the liquid displaced, which is equal to the mass of the liquid times gravity, which is equal to volume displaced times gravity times the density of the liquid. So, as long as the object displaces enough water that the weight of the water displaced is equal to or greater than the weight of the object itself, then the object will float. Understanding this principle is crucial in everyday life for people engineering ships, so they can understand how to make a ship float for various purposes. It also helps people understand on how they can make themselves float.

Question: In what ways does Newton's second law of motion relate to everyday things and circumstances, and how may society gain from an understanding of this law? Newtons second law of motion (F = ma) states that force equals mass times acceleration, and this principle is shown in many aspects of daily life. For example, when pushing a shopping cart, the heavier the cart, the more force is needed to accelerate it. This understanding is vital in fields with car and vehicular safety, where engineers apply this law to design features such as airbags and other stuff that reduce forces on passengers during a crash, minimizing injury. I guess you can say, Newton's second law affects everything, from technology to transportation, and it's not just a concept taught in physics. Gaining an understanding of it helps to improve in performance, safety, and efficiency, which benefits society and everyday innovations that raise living standards.
