There is a stereotype that I have seen going around on TikTok and other similar platforms. This stereotype revolves around computer science majors and how they are homeless because they can not find a job in the current market. The current market being oversaturated likely plays a significant role in many people's difficulties in finding a job. Although word on the street says that AI is also playing a factor for these. People say AI is replacing many jobs like computer science. I feel very bad for many people who work very hard to have their jobs taken by AI. I am very thankful to be in engineering, something that requires human innovation and can not be as easily taken by AI.

For the most part, AI as a whole is an easy method or way in which students can effectively cheat but there are some cases where it can be used to productively assist. Rather than asking AI for an answer ask it to maybe confirm or relate certain topics so you can better understand the problems. Through this many students can gather resourceful information that builds up their confidence in topics. You can also use AI to grade papers you have written and provide criticism to improve your claims that maybe you yourself could have not been able to look over. It could essentially be a peer reviewer for introverts through this process and be used to build up knowledge rather than just give you answers to general knowledge.

It really depends how a person uses AI in general, but for STEM I find the possible role for AI is to double check work. For STEM there is a lot of equations and math getting involve so its possible for people not to remember something. People can take notes, but AI can be a decent way to double check even if its not accurate all the time. For students to use AI ethically and productively, I would finish some work or be unsure of some work and having to search up or ask a person to help me understand it. Searching up can be messy depending on the websites and some people aren't always available to help me with the work. I think this way depends on the situation if I really understand the work I don't really need to use AI, but if I am really stuck then AI can be a possible source for me to understand why. I think that AI should be use more like a tool then a answer for students because AI just goes through websites/sources for its information and it does show equation that students might not remember or know. (so mostly depends)

AI is playing a bigger and bigger role each year in STEM. The normal tasks a human would do are now becoming automated thanks to AI. This is very helpful but has led to new issues like AI not giving accurate information. I can use AI ethically and productively by verifying the work that I do. AI is also great for making study guides or creating practice questions. It should only be used to verify work or create things to study. One of the issues we run into now is people letting AI complete all their work. This ruins the learning experience for them and does not benefit their learning.

In stem, AI is important for calculating and simulating things that humans are incapable of doing, such as large and complex math equations or large scale science simulations. Its also important for what collecting data or testing isnt possible for one reason or another, to predict and provide data or analyze something. However, despite how much its used in stem, its important, especially these beginning stages of entering stem as a student, that I dont depend on it for my classes and education, because even though its frequently used in the workforce, and essential part of using it to its full potential is understanding what its actually doing and how to utilize it, which is part of were being taught as students.

The role of AI in stem is for student to abuse and use to do their homework. Just kidding! AI is incredibly useful to stem for various reasons. As a student, its a very useful tool to help me learn. Things like ChatGPT are pretty good at answering questions that would be hard to find otherwise, it also helps in clarifying some questions you have. There are also other forms of AI that help people doing actual stem related jobs compute complicated or inconvenient equations. They use AI as a tool rather than a crutch is what Im trying to say. AI of course can be used in other ways such as in robotics, but Im not sure about the progress achieved with that specific form of AI. Of course, AI is still unreliable, especially when trying to get it to teach you about a subject so I always make sure to double check with credible sources.

I believe the role of AI in STEM can be useful as it can help create plans and data analysis and research. Although AI is not the first option we should have when it comes to doing work, it is helpful when it comes to data analysis, research and designs within our fields, it helps us engage with the major and content a lot better while also making it personal and meaningful to every student based on their own personal learning capabilities. AI has developed a lot through the years and although it isnt always accurate, depending on our usage of it in the STEM field it can work wonders but we should also be able to check the work and not fully relied on it when it comes to our projects but rather get an idea of what it is that we are doing or need to do.

I do not know much about A.I. too be honest. I try to never use it, as it usually gives wrong information to help me complete a problem. I think the role of A.I. is whether or not it is upgraded to the point where it's smart enough to help us with our work, but not just giving us the answers, but actually walking us through the answers.
Ai can be used as a tool to help with tasks but not complete them for you. To use ai ethically you can not have it do everything for you. It can be used to help students study.

I think the role of Ai in STEM is for helping incorporating ideas in the STEM world. For example, in physics, I have a hard time doing integrals for problems we went over in class, so I would often look up a step by step solution on how it was done. I believe you can ethically use Ai in STEM in many ways. Similarly to the example explained, you can have solutions explained to you. In my Differential equations class, our homework only shows us the answer with no solution so Ill ask ChatGPT or Copilot how was this solution made. For some classes with exams, I generate cheat sheets with equations and explanations on when to use them.

As AI technology gets better and better, I can see how it has a lot of potential to be useful in many areas. I was at first very against it because I saw some of my peers around me using it to write essays for them and complete assignments that they wouldnt have been able to do, so I stayed away. I of course was more and more exposed to it due its prevalence in today's world, and I eventually found out how useful it can actually be as a tool. For me, I like to use AI in two ways; one, AI can be very useful for things like formatting text, processing data, or organizing content that would otherwise be a very long and tedious task. For example, maybe I find a list of items which are separated by a comma, I can then tell chat gpt to format it as a list which I can then use to paste into software like excel or a study guide. The second way I use this technology is for asking quick questions while doing homework that I would normally need to ask a professor. Instead of having to wait for an emailed response or find time where I can go to office hours, I can get a lead on a general idea which I can then read up on in more depth from a credible source.

I personally use AI not to practice bad habits like plagiarism and basically asking it to do everything for me. But instead a tool in which I have at my disposal when Im stuck on a question or I dont really understand the topic. I believe that this is the best way to use AI especially in the STEM path. It is often times difficult to take in lessons and lectures in such a small period of time. But with the correct help of AI it becomes much more easier.

AI affects STEM in many different ways. STEM uses it as a means to check data, come up with different ideas, and even give step by step help for numerous things. As a student, I can use AI for homework help when I am stuck or for a second opinion when completing work. Its not ethical to use AI for answers without trying as it will not help me improve my skills in any way.

STEM Students can ethically use AI if they already know how to start a problem and have a sense for what the answer should be. AI tools that know how to do math can be a useful if the student already knows the steps but is confused about one or two.

AI can have a role in STEM by helping with research and problem solving. It can also be used to automate tasks that can take a human a longer time to complete. It can also be used to compute complex equations and other complex problems in a timely manner. As a student, I can use AI as a tool to help me succeed as a student. I should not rely on it but I can use it to ask questions that can help point me in the right direction of what Im looking for. It can also be used to explain a problem I dont understand thoroughly when I do not have a professor nearby to ask. However, I must take all the information with a grain of salt and do my due diligence to check that all the information it gives me is correct.

AI is becoming an increasingly important aspect of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, assisting with things like data analysis, simulations, and even automating boring repetitive labor. It's an effective tool that can increase efficiency and open up new possibilities for research and problem solving. I believe AI is friend not foe but we should not abuse it or rely on it. As a student, AI can be extremely useful for brainstorming, summarizing information, and debugging codes in my MATLAB, but we shouldnt simply accept its responses as a real true answer/value. We should use it to learn, not to substitute our own unique ideas. We should use to double-check facts, avoid plagiarism, and help us with tedious tasks. Basically, AI is a terrific tool, but it shouldn't handle all of our work, balance is key!

I think my contribution to STEM will primarily be around the engineering aspect of the field. Since my major is mechanical engineering, I would like to move into the automotive industry to apply my education and skills to this area. Although my interest in STEM is automotive engineering i would not mind possibly getting another degree or more education in other fields in the future. I think astronomy is another subject i find interest in and think it would be fulfilling to expand my knowledge later in the future. My contributions to stem will be to innovate and advanced automotive with my own creativity to bring a positive change to the world as well. I would also like to open doors for minority groups in stem fields like engineering to possibly guide and advocate for others to follow if they desire.

I think I could contribute to the STEM community by becoming another driven hard worker in relation to exploring new ideas in the community. I don't mind being challenged by things and so tackling challenges that most would find daunting I know I could take on without being frustrated or driven away by failing. Another why I know that I could contribute, although more broad, is that nobody has lived through my life through my eyes and so automatically I already have a different perspective on things then the peers around me. Like my peers they have a different perspective on things as well and I think that in itself is a contribution as well. I feel as though the more people we have that join this community the stronger it could get and the more that could be contributed to it. I would say that I've also always been somewhat a leader and so I know wherever I end up I could take charge and lead by example. Although I may not be the best at it I do know that I could put my best food forward and never give up.

I can contribute tot stem/the community by joining a club or attending seminars. I get emails all the time from the physics department that I completely ignore, but if I did read them and attend those events I would be contributing to the stem community.

I can contribute to stem/stem community by working an engineering job that helps structure buildings so they last long and or help by redoing standing buildings to withstand the weather in current times

I can contribute to the STEM community by applying my hands-on experience in engineering and mechanics to real-world problem-solving. Whether through designing custom parts, repurposing electronics, or helping others understand complex concepts, I want to make STEM more accessible and practical. Sharing my knowledge with classmates, mentoring those new to engineering, and continuously learning will help me grow while also supporting others. In the future, I hope to work on innovative projects in automotive design or renewable energy, pushing the boundaries of whats possible and making a meaningful impact.

I can contribute to STEM by doing what I do best and use my knowledge to work on my projects that will help me get a job. Because at the end of the day I am here to essentially check the box and make some money. Working on my projects will allow me to open my mind and hopefully later on solve other problems such as desalinating water efficiently. Something as simple as water we take for granted as some areas don't have access to clean water. Being able to desalinate water in an efficient manner will allow us to not worry about water and provide clean drinking water to areas in need.

I can contribute to STEM by networking as I think networking in STEM is a pretty big deal as it can lead to big opportunities within the industry or just making friends in STEM alone is a really good idea as learning certain subjects/concepts can be difficult tackling alone. Bringing it back to the question, by making friends within STEM you can contribute help within the community to help yourself learn a topic as well as offer your advice or ask questions with other folks. Publishing your research also whatever it may be in STEM is also contributing to STEM or even getting it peer reviewed is also contributing to the STEM community because you're keeping the integrity of the accuracy of your research when you're getting your research peer reviewed. But generally publishing your research or from a project helps the science field learn something new which ultimately contributes to the STEM community.

I think that by simply joining any STEM department in school, we are brought on with the inspiration to start contributing to the science community as much as we can. Here at this school, there is a great connection between my peers in the engineering department and I an hopeful that in the future I can make the same kind of connection with people to better my development. As a student the most I can do is limited by what I think I know and my confidence in sharing it with other people. To me, as someone who has not a lot of experience, I feel that my contributions are more directed towards classroom and discussion related advances as opposed to others who may already be gaining traction in the industry. I plan in working on that before I graduate in the future.

The STEM community is made up of many different people and experiences. A way I can contribute to the STEM community would be: my thought process that has been shaped by my surroundings and experiences. Communicating my ideas or thoughts in any way possible while also working with other people in the STEM community or beyond.

I can contribute to the STEM community by joining groups, doing projects which all members could learn and also guiding the freshmen into joining the groups to find their family, network and learn from their leaders.

I can contribute to the STEM society by putting forth my own ideas and research behind them. I understand that with that being said, it is a very broad way in which I could contribute to the STEM society. So, in order to be more specific, I can contribute by sharing my ideas with my peers in class and explain my reasoning behind those ideas by showing textual evidence or explaining my prior knowledge which led me to certain conclusions.

By providing my knowledge and experiences within engineering at sfsu I can further contribute to the communities that resonate in the middle of STEM classes. For the most part, many of the classes I take are math or physics-based so in the end more physics-based reasoning can be further exemplified within the community when I continue to study. Not only this but as I learn programs such as Solid Works I can use that knowledge to design or model varying future-proof parts that can upgrade the current designs in society. Also considering that there's a good chance the world will continue to decline in the coming years due to amazing leadership maybe having a major that is favored or skills that are favored will continue to contribute to society as a whole!

I could contribute STEM with having my own concepts and ideas that can be involve with anything that STEM does. Just another person adds another perspective towards the STEM community and I think that is a contribution anyone can do. A community with more people with more ideas can spread out from there and with that community it slowly grows together to help each other. A single person can build a house, but it won't be as effective with a community of people helping to build that house including everyone different ideas/concepts that can improve the house more.

I can contribute by innovating current designs. It is always important to find ways to improve everything, even if it already works well. Another way I can contribute to the STEM field is by helping others. One of the most important things someone can do is learn. Sometimes, we do not always remember how to do something, and this is where I can help fill in the blanks for others. I have always enjoyed helping others and teaching people about engineering. Someday in the future, I could see myself becoming a professor, but time will tell! Overall, I really want to make a big impact on the STEM community by creating something, improving a current product, or teaching.

I can contribute to the STEM community by helping encourage kids to learn about and become stronger in STEM subjects. This is especially important with minority children, who are often discouraged from pursuing STEM or arent helped when hey have trouble. I think helping uplift young people to be more enthusiastic about STEM is important to upholding and building the future of STEM.

One way I think you can contribute to the STEM community is you can do your job do projects and junk and that be a way to contribute, which is totally fine and reasonable, or you could go above and beyond and be some sort of researcher or inventor, and make new things to contribute in that way. There is two ways you could go about this, and I think it's important to consider that decision, and I think a big part of it is deciding what your job will be, and what company you work for. For example, if you were to work for a company like the BLM, and used your engineering degree to design clean energy dam turbines, or wind farms, or a way to stop groundwater contamination via landfills or something, or you could work for Boeing and design things like machines and in some extreme cases, missiles or objects of war.

I can contribute to the STEM community by donating money. Just kidding, well just kidding a little because donating is an actual way I can contribute. I can also contribute a bit more by getting my degree in Mech E and actually coming up with things that can further research for important fields such as medicine or construction or literally anything. Its hard to say what I can help with specifically right now as I am still early in my major. I can also contribute to STEM by opening my mind to learning, not just at school but in other areas as well. For example, I always read the information on each exhibit at the Cal Academy which I frequent due to being a member there. At least until November this year.

I'm a student assistant, so I help students everyday in the engineering stockroom and engineering office, with all types of their problems. I'm also part of the MESA, ASME, ASCE student organizations, so I help out with events.
Something I can contribute to stem is teamwork and problem solving. When people work as a team work can get done much faster.

I believe I can contribute to the STEM field greatly within social aspects. First, I believe I can bring inclusivity and diversity to the STEM field as a person of color. Besides this, I am apart of CoSEs Antiracism Committee where our goal isnt to end racism in education, its actually about making education for underrepresented groups more equitable. For example, our current mission is to survey students from represented and underrepresented groups to share their experiences in their STEM classes we want to see if their bad experiences can be minimized.

In a broad sense I think I can contribute to the STEM community by being a good student of the field. By being humble, curious, and thoughtful, I serve the community by helping in making it a pleasant environment for other people to be in, as well as an appropriate one in which others can learn. By also being collaborative and motivated, I can also aid more directly in the efforts of others. Using what knowledge and skills I have to contribute to a common effort can lessen the work load or improve the results of the final product. In combination with the efforts of others, not only can I do my best to help out, I also receive the benefits of learning from others' methods and perspectives. In a more specific way, I hope that Ill be able to contribute to the stem field by also being a good engineer. I hope that after graduating, Ill find work in my field and rise to a level at which I can be a good example of ethics and contribute original ideas and designs which can make a real difference within the community.

By studying Mathematics and Physics, I contribute to the STEM community by preserving knowledge for future generations to come. Although I may just be a single person, having these knowledge is crucial. Obviously the best thing to bring to the future are textbooks and examples and data. But I would also like to point out that each and every student studying in schools right now contribute to STEM.

I can contribute to STEM by ensuring that I am putting lots of effort into everything I do. This will help me be better prepared and more knowledgeable in everything I do. Ultimately, this will make it so there is minimal failure or error in all projects I do.

I believe one of the simplest ways I can contribute to STEM is by passing my classes, graduating, and eventually work in a STEM related field. Just by working in a STEM related field I feel like I will be contributing to STEM. I dont think I have to have some crazy breakthrough or work on a specific project in order to contribute to STEM because not every person would get the opportunity to do such a thing. As long as I work in a STEM related field, even at the lowest possible level, I will be helping those above me and they might be working towards some great goal, so I will be a small part of getting that goal accomplished even if I get zero credit. Overall, I dont think a person has to do a crazy thing to contribute to STEM.

I want to contribute to STEM by connecting and inspiring others with my outgoing attitude. I enjoy getting to know individuals for who they genuinely are, so mentoring and outreach come naturally to me. I'd love to teach young girls, volunteer in schools, and speak at events to demonstrate that you can be feminine, social, and successful in STEM. Networking is also vital for me. I want to join STEM organizations, work on projects, and share my experiences to inspire others. I aim to challenge stereotypes by combining my love of engineering with my passion for makeup, beauty technology, innovation and pink, duh! I really enjoy having open discussions about the issues that women experience in STEM and finding methods to support one another. I want to create a strong, uplifting environment in which women in STEM feel heard and respected, whether through club meet-ups, social media, or informal meetings.

I believe that my personal values align with those of the scientific community is multiple ways. I really enjoy how there are public scientific databases and information available from studies or research that is published to inform and allow for the opportunity to learn from these investigations. I agree with the idea that science should be performed to better society as a whole and work for the greater purpose of everyone. I also really enjoy the idea of innovation through science which parallels with what I would like to cultivate in my future career with the automotive industry. I also appreciate how science is based on evidence and observation and may continuously be revised and improved to help our country verbally understanding of the world around us.

I would say that my personal values intersect with that of the scientific community because my personal values include, respect, curiosity, and determination. I feel as if these are a lot of the things that exist already in the scientific community but you can't have enough off. For example starting off with respect when going into any community you have to respect those around you. New people joining the community as well as people that have been a part of the community for a while all have something to bring to the table and although you may not agree sometimes, you have to respect there perspective on things and there is always a way to respectfully go about it. Curiosity is a huge thing because there is always something that is new and if everyone stays curious than you will always be coming up with new ways to look at things. Lastly determination is huge because no matter how big the problem, you will always be determined to attack it head on.

I dont think my personal values really diverge much from the values of the scientific community. I would say that the scientific community values curiosity, hard work, and a willingness to learn/change your point of view. I definitely agree more strongly with some of those than others but I dont disagree with any of them.
I believe in equality and I feel like Im the stem community there should be equality and people shouldnt be judged.

Science, to me, is about curiosity, problem-solving, and constantly improving our understanding of the world. My personal values align with this because Ive always been driven by a desire to figure things outwhether its rebuilding a car, designing a custom part, or tackling an engineering problem in class. I dont like accepting things at face value; I want to know how and why they work. This mindset is a core part of the scientific community as well. Another value I connect with is perseverance. In science, experiments fail, equations dont always balance out on the first try, and designs need revisions. Ive experienced that firsthand in both engineering and hands-on work. Whether its troubleshooting a bad circuit or trying to perfect a CAD model, Ive learned that persistence is key. Collaboration is also a big one. Science isnt done in isolation, and neither is engineering. Whether in the classroom, at work, or in my projects, Ive found that the best solutions come from bouncing ideas off others. The scientific community thrives on shared knowledge, and I respect that deeply. Ultimately, I see science as a way to push boundaries and make life better, and that aligns with how I want to approach my own work and career.

In the science department now, there are a lot of differing opinions namely around AI and the moral advancement of biomedical research which is, to me, very concerning. To me, the principals of science are to advance humanity in the best way it can. For the people. By the people. Its really weird to think about how hundreds and thousands of years of collective research done by various people across countries and literally generations of research are on the cusp of being thrown out the window by the government. This is a bit of a tangent from what my views are but this is current and impending. I grew up believing in a community of science that was built of collective interest for the good of humanity. That had the moral obligation to act in line with what was good for the people around them. It felt like common sense. To want to be in the sciences to help other people in the way that only scientists can. Its odd now.

I believe that anything that can help to better or make our life easier is what every scientist is seeking for. My argument justify that discovery doesnt necessarily means that it has to help only the humankind but it could also be something to nourish the environment and everyone living in it.

As I perceive them, the values of the scientific community is to invent and create with the improvement of life in mind. My personal values intersect with the scientific community values in that I also want to produce tools that improve everyone's stay on this planet.

My personal values intersect with the values of the scientific community by helping the world make use of waste that they use. This is by making a waste company that will use waste compost for biogas and use that to produce electricity and fuel for cars.

My personal values intersect with those in the scientific community such that I believe that everything should be questioned and researched multiple times. It is important not to believe everything we hear the moment we hear them for the first time. We should look into that information to verify whether or not its true or should be widely believed. In science, it is important to recheck our peers and their measurements or their work as a means to deliver the best and most correct work possible. Doing scientific work requires brains to make sure everything is factual. Pride and ego should be put aside because whats important should not be if someone has a method in which is better than everyone elses but if the method is even correct at all.

My values are driven by dedication and hard work that benefit the scientific community. I'm extremely ambitious to achieve my current goal of getting a degree that aligns directly with the scientific community's desire to utilize those skills to build up varying technologies or other prominent discoveries. I also value talking and discussing with other members to coordinate efforts to build up a stronger report or analysis. The scientific community thoroughly indulges in group work to facilitate varying discoveries since coordinated efforts make better conclusions than just individual studies. Not only that but they can take a smaller amount of time if you work with others since you can split up efforts. I know for the most part I do most of the time tend to do work alone because I believe I'm capable of doing it but with extra help if can make things overall easier than before.

My personal values mostly relating to my major being STEM does intersect with the scientific community because its about something that correlates with the community. If I need help related to my major such as physics 3 than the scientific community probably can help me with it. I think the scientific community mostly values in helping others, but this is an assumption because I think most communities do help with each other to improve. However, not all communities are the same, but if the scientific community focus on helping others than it does intersect with my value of my major. When it comes to general a community of people is always nice to talk with and I like the topic of science a good amount.

My values align closely with the scientific community in many ways. Integrity, curiosity, creativity, precision, accountability, and equity are very important to me. I want someone to have integrity so I do not read or receive false research or information. Its important that someone has curiosity and drive to discover unsolved problems. Without curiosity this can lead to poor results because they may have alternative reasons to complete their work. I highly value precision in any facet of life. On the other side of the coin we need accountability when things are done without precision or accuracy. Accountability is essential in life. If we do not have accountability then we do not have order, which eventually causes complete chaos. Lastly, we need equity. Everyone deserves an equal chance at anything in life, but this should not be confused with giving opportunity to people who have not worked for it. I believe someone must build their resume, cv, or portfolio to show their merit. No one should be chosen or not chosen off of physical appearance.

I connect with the value of the scientific community of cross checking and verifing the results and ideas of those in the community. In the scientific community, this is done to make sure that one person or groups results are accurate, which included knowing how the group came to their conclusion, including experiments done and equations and theories used. For me, its also important to know how people come to conclusions for even mundane things, like when giving advice or coming to a decision, to understand why what theyve said is the best course of action.

Its hard to talk about values and morals in the scientific community. For me, being a mechanical engineer, in multiple of my classes we have had large discussions about the ethics of engineering, which is essentially, how we use our knowledge in the real world, an example being getting a job to create green energy sources versus getting a job at a defense company like Boeing or Lockheed Martin, both having an exceptionally high salary.

Im not totally clear on the official values of the scientific community but how I imagine it, its pretty similar to mine. I want to help improve this planet were stuck on in any way possible, whether it be through finding a more efficient and eco-friendly energy source and putting it into practice or designing a way to get rid of plastics. It could even be a way to get off Earth and go to another habitable planet. I just want to help humanity thrive. I will try my best to use ethically approved materials, nothing that were running low on or thats going to destroy the environment. Id assume all this aligns with the scientific communitys morals.

I believe that my personal values intersect with those of the scientific community because we are interested in the change that goes on around us in the world and in ways that we can change it to the better as well as being able to understand what is going on and how it is happening. My personal values consist of learning more about science and how it can help or how it is related to my everyday lifestyle and how it is being used, as well as a civil engineering major I look towards anything that relates to my major and how it can be used towards it and how i can help the scientific community by using material that wont damage the environment.

I don't think my personal values really intersect with the scientific community much. I really haven't had a problem with anything in any of my classes. The only real thing I can think of are maybe the way some professors teach, I think some professors are very old school, and it can be a little hard working with them.
Both the scientific and I value knowledge and understanding of the universe and using this knowledge to create a more prosperous future for humanity.

My personal value I believe strongly in is equity. I believe educational equity and fairness all around is important because it gives balance in society. I strongly believe everyone should be able to start off with the same opportunities whether you come from an underrepresented or overrepresented space. I think this greatly intersects with the scientific community because I think everyone deserves a chance to be innovative, have the same resources, and break systemic barriers in the scientific community.

I feel like I share a lot of common values with the scientific community. I value things like curiosity, facts, evidence, and overall knowledge, all things that are often pursued within scientific fields. I also value things like creativity and problem solving which are more indirectly related to science, yet still entirely common and useful in pursuing it. I think where I maybe stray slightly from the typical values of the scientific community is in my appreciation for other more subjective things like art or even philosophy. This is not to say that people within the community dont also value these things, rather that they are often not goals or products of the events which occur within it. One thing that I find exciting is when the two mix. Sometimes science can produce things that have more subjective beauty like cells under a microscope or infinite helical mathematical equations which is cool to see as something with a factual foundation can create something that is more perspective-based in its appeal.

My interest value in life especially in studying is I believe science and math are everywhere. Without it there will be no advancement. Although some people dont realize it, but science truly is everywhere. For example, weather, cars anything. Therefore I value the preservation of knowledge that we have attained as a community and for future improvements too.

I believe the science community values curiosity, problem solving, and collaboration which all intersect with my personal values. As humans, we have to be very knowledgeable and curious about the world around us to help create solutions for problems we may find ourselves with. Sometimes, we are unable to figure out there problems alone, which is why collaboration is so important. Working with others can make us acknowledge other perspectives and new ideas.

My personal values align with scientific values. I value honesty most, and science needs to be honest about what is and is not known. There also needs to be honesty when communicating science not non-scientists who may not have the knowledge necessary to fact check research papers.

One of my personal values that I believe aligns with that of the scientific community is determination. In the scientific community, I believe determination is what allows people to continue their research and continue making discoveries, even through multiple failures. I would like to say Im determined, especially in earning my degree. If I were to fail a class I wouldnt allow it to stop me from trying again because Im determined to complete my academic journey.

My beliefs in fairness and kindness align with the core principles of the scientific community. Science thrives on curiosity, truth, and collaboration, and I believe that giving everyone a voice leads to better ideas and discoveries. Fairness means staying honest and giving credit where its due, while kindness strengthens teams and makes STEM a more welcoming space. I want to support others, especially those who are often unheard, and help create an inclusive environment where everyone feels valued. Whether through internships, outreach, or simply feeling a sense of belonging, I know my values will shape the way I contribute to STEM. By uplifting others and promoting a culture of respect, I hope to make a lasting impact on both individuals and the broader scientific/engineering community.
